description:
Solid Italian choice for dinner with an intimate contemporary vibe.

We started off with the Crostini of chicken liver alla toscana, paired with a nice chianti... for obvious reasons. Generous rich amounts smeared on slices of bread - a great starter!

Next the pastas. I'll go out on a limb to extrapolate and say you can't really go wrong with any choices here. Both of our dishes were medium-portioned and tasted fresh and delicious. The level of ingredients and care of preparation evident made me confident that it extended to other dishes as well.

But the real winner of the night was the smoked burrata. It was absolutely out of this world! This special cheese is imported straight from Italy and as such is limited to a certain number of orders during the week (according to their menu). As of the time of writing this review, that number is 16 per week. We were a bit worried that since we came in on a Saturday we would be late to the game, but to our delight there was still some in stock. It's a bit pricey, but believe me it's well worth it. You have never had a cheese with such complex rich smokey flavors as this. I highly recommend adding this to your order if it's available.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Food: The food is ok. It's certainly no Cotogna, but it's ok. The pizza is probably the best thing on the menu. The flavors of the pizza are really good. Texture was ok. The crust is crispy until about half way through the pizza and then the large majority of the center is soft. But again, great flavors.

Service: I had to give this place 2 stars because of the service. People were just straight up rude. I've honestly never been treated this way at a restaurant and it was incredibly surprising. From the moment we arrived the hostess was rude and dismissive. Had it just been my partner and I we probably would have left because of her, but we were hosting friends so we stayed, assuming it would get better. Unfortunately, the waiter was also rude. At one point my partner joked to me under his breath, "why does it feel like everyone here hates us??" It was such an uncomfortable night.

There's just no reason to go here. You can find way better food at 100 different places in SF and you can find better service at your local gas station.
author: Meagan M.

description:
I don't write reviews very often but when i do, its probably an appalling experience! 

Very pretentious place.....
Im giving this place one star. Ok, i changed my mind and changed it to 2 stars. 

2 out our 3 visits made us felt like we were seated and treated based on how we were dressed and not because of table availability. My boyfriend live three blocks away from this place. I went here with him once and was really impressed with their food (amazing! ordered the rigatoni) and minimalist interior. We were dressed for a date night. 

The second time we went, was told that there was a wait time, 40 minutes. We saw open tables, hostess indifferent, snobbish but ok, no biggy! Didn't overthink it. I was wearing black leggings and a simple black sweater. We end up going to the sushi restaurant one block away, we were starving. 

My boyfriend went there tonight wearing t-shirt, jeans and sandals, was told that there was a long wait time. Open tables again and hostess indifferent. He came back after dressing up for a wedding and voila! Smile, warmth, open table and zero wait time. He was disappointed how different he was treated by the same person before and after he dressed up. 

It really saddens me that being in San Francisco, where were pioneering in addressing social injustices and inequality, this restaurant would treat customers based on how one is dressed. We understand dress codes but this place is trying too hard.  Ok, mediocre setting (like an upscale version of subway). Its confusing to expect so much for dress codes. I mean, this place screams minimalist, home kitchen with a bar. Which is homey.

 Anyhow, despite loving the food i wouldn't come to this place again. They promote an atmosphere of exclusivity and so much pretentiousness. 

Im actually disappointed writing this review coz i really like your food. Its just that how you pick and choose to treat your costumers that sucks!
author: Roux S.

description:
We had high hopes for our dinner here and Uva delivered. It had everything you would want out of an upscale Italian spot: quality but not too stuffy service, a casual family vibe, and hearty delicious food. Great date spot.

We ordered Spritz, margherita pie, and the pasta pomodoro. All were excellent. We'll try some more adventurous choices next time to see if they still deliver. We went on a Friday so there weren't happy hour specials, but definitely look into that
author: Rich S.

description:
Cute Italian place with good happy hour prices. 

Came here for dinner on a Friday, Id recommend making reservations in advance. 

The restaurant is intimate and cozy but there is lots of natural light at the front. The bar seating looks comfortable but the tables in the back don't look great unless you have a larger group and are forced to sit back there. 

I don't think they offer house bread, we ordered it specifically. That was weird. 

Get the meatballs, they were solid. But ask for bread with it because the sauce might overwhelm you. 

We also got the pomodoro pasta because everyone else said to. While delicious, the steep price tag doesn't seem justified for a dish that has no meat and not a particularly large serving. But the texture and sauce were 10/10! 

Maybe I'll come back for hh, mon-thurs until 6:30.
author: RachEl L.

description: There bottomless bellinis were $18. I went there asking the Bellini be replaced with anything other juice than peaches since I have a severe peach allergy and the waitress refused. Saying that they didn't have orange juice. They did. Overall food was good, but service needed to be friendlier.
author: Shamber E.

description:
Was craving thin crust pizza and decided to try this place out. My boyfriend and I arrived at 6:20 on a Monday but we didn't realize we needed reservations. Thankfully, the hostess said it was fine as long as we finished our meal by the time people who had reservations have arrived. Happy hour was still going on so we decided to get a Margherita pizza ($10) and added burrata cheese with arugula on top. Pizza was gooey, cheesy and crunchy all in one. 

 I forgot what pasta dish i got but it was light and creamy with fennel sausage and broccoli. My boyfriend got the lasagna. I liked both dishes but preferred the lasagna over my creamy pasta dish. 

As a palate opener, I highly suggest getting the Venetian iced tea (alcoholic). Light and refreshing. 

To top it all off, our server Kufi was super sweet and accommodating. He kept checking back on us to make sure everything was perfect.
author: Ada H.

description: Went here on a hunch and was surprised how good the food was and how courteously our waiter treated us. The pizza was delicious so was the lasagna.
author: Kwame N.

description: This place is awesome. A great vibe for happy hour, a date, or a business dinner. There are a lot of sharing or individual options and the food tastes great and is fresh. I've recommended this place to quite a few friends.
author: Drew F.

description: Good food and services   The place is small but very conform and cutie. The staff are friendly and will to provide a excellent service to you.  I went to this place to met my cousin who love this place. I have the lasagna and it was delicious and the wine was extraordinary good.
author: David R.

description: I came here for brunch on a Saturday, and it was actually surprisingly quiet. So if you are trying to find a place without a wait, this might be a good option for you. On the other hand, I wasn't overly impressed with the food, it was alright, but didn't knock my socks off. I ordered the biscuits and gravy, and was satisfied, but wouldn't come out of my way to come back. They also have bottomless mimosas for $18 bucks, which might be the real steal of the meal here.
author: Ross S.

description:
I adore Uva. I've been here around 5 times and each time they're just great. Came here on a Friday night (make a reservation as they get busy) and we got seated quite quickly. 

Service - good! I've had odd service here before when the server was super awkward but this time the guy was awesome. He knew his wine and was super chill, he left us alone and popped by when we needed him.

Food - amazing as usual! We got their marinated squid (I didn't eat it but my date said it was the bomb), pizza with smoked mozzarella (my fav) and their pomodoro pasta (super good). We also tried their chocolate dessert which I loved.

I'll be back in a few months. It's probably my favorite Italian place in SF. :)
author: Mira B.

description:
I love this spot. Great for an intimate meal - fun ambiance, small tables (not in a claustrophobic way).

Food is delicious. The eggplant parm reawakened my dormant love of eggplant parm such that I went on a bender trying to recreate it for a few months afterwards. The pizzas are quality, the pastas are delicious, and (as I mentioned) the eggplant parm is fabulous.

Fairly good wine list as well. We tried spritzers, which were also tasty. One of the nicer places in this general neighborhood (got yelled at by a homeless guy outside while waiting for my Uber).
author: Katherine N.

description:
Restaurant with amazing ambiance, good food, and great happy hour prices.

Uva Enoteca has a sophisticated but comfortable vibe to it's decor and layout. There's a small front room and a larger back area with more seating. It's a good choice for a date.

Happy hour is till 6:30 pm and there are some really good deals on there! Off the happy hour we got the $6 wine and the $10 Pasta Pomodoro. Really stoked they had the pasta on the happy hour menu and not just deals on appetizers. For around $56 we got 4 glasses of wine, Pasta Pomodoro, and the Sausage pizza. Great deal! 

Will be back for the happy hour and maybe to try their bottomless brunch as well!
author: Courtney N.

description:
Came here for my birthday. But I wasn't prepared to have some of the best pasta and pasta sauce I've ever had. The pasta it's self was very thick and was the definition of Al dente. There is no way to describe the pasta sauce other than it was seasoned extremely well, salted perfectly, and was not overwhelming other flavors in the dish. 
I would recommend paring  with a glass of wine. The restaurant was beautiful and the service was amazing.
author: Jake H.

description: We love this place!  Seriously, it's awesome.  We usually get the pasta pomodoro and the eggplant; both are terrific.  The service is pretty fast but be aware that you should make a reservation as they can get very crowded, particularly on Fri/weekends.
author: Kirsten P.

description: Super cute little restaurant near Fillmore! Made a reservation for two via open table. They have happy hour from 5-6:30pm with $3.5 beer and $6 wine as well as 4 four items, all between $4-10. We ordered a 3 cheese board, a glass of wine, pasta pomodoro off the happy hour menu, and chicken pate, all for $38 before tax and tip. For the cheeseboards we tried the formaggio, piave, and pecorino with truffle. All of the cheese were so good! Can't even pinpoint a favorite. The board comes with bread, nuts, honey, and jam. Chicken pate was strong in taste and served on toasted crostini. Pasta was tasty and they don't skimp on the sauce. Our server was friendly and answered all our questions.
author: Lexi R.

description:
My Order: Braised chicken thighs with San Marzano tomatoes, olives, basil, grana padano with a side of polenta.

From the first bite, I was titilated. Chicken slipped off the bone the way I slip into a pair of pajamas after a long day at work. With a fork and bread knife, I was able to transport the juicy decadence directly to my heart where it soothed me and brought a tear to my eye. The olives, tomatoes, and basil worked in tandem creating an ode to joy. I looked around as I inhaled my meal to the open kitchen, brick wall, and shelves of wine, instantly teleporting me to rustic Italy. The service was that which was fit for royalty, and even though the busy crowd summoned white noise, my focus was concentrated solely on the beautiful work of art before me. As with a musical symphony that touches your soul, I was sad, yet satisfied, when this experience came to an end. 

Btw the polenta was bland but I ain't even trippin tho cause the rest of the plate was lit af and you could dip that shit into the chicken sauce and whatnot and make that shit hella good.
author: Rav G.

description:
I thought Uva Enoteca was a solid spot for a casual Italian dinner, and it was easy to get a reservation which is always a plus. 

The pasta pomodoro was excellent. The tomato sauce was perfect, pasta was al dente, and topped with lots of fresh basil. I'd definitely come back for this. 

The appetizers fell a little flat. We had the burrata persimmon crustini and I felt it was lacking flavor. It wasn't seasoned and the fruit flavor wasn't strong enough with the cheese. We also had the kale salad which was just kind of boring. The kale wasn't massaged so it was hard to get through, and overall I just got kind of bored eating it. 

Service started out good--we got our orders in quickly and food came out at a good pace. But the wait staff seemed to congregate towards the back of the restaurant so when we needed things like a fork which wasn't at our table, it took way too long to flag someone down, and when we finished our food, our plates were cleared quickly but then we didn't see anyone again for ten minutes to get the bill. 

So overall, I would come back--I liked the vibe and the pasta was good. But I'd order every thing else differently and try and get a table towards the middle of the restaurant to get faster service.
author: Sophie S.

description: We spent a birthday dinner and service, food and dessert was wonderful! Service was amazing. Small and cozy with a good vibe!
author: Kelly F.

description:
Dropped in on a Sunday afternoon because they had a happy hour going on - I had a $6 glass of wine and split a $10 margherita (which was great). The place is bigger on the inside than I was expecting. They have a small dinning area right when you walk in, a relatively large bar, and then even more dinning in the back. 
The place wasn't at all crowded when we stopped by so we had no problem grabbing a seat at the bar and service was quick. After my glass of wine and pizza I left because I wanted to watch some of the Sunday evening football games, but I was very happy that I stopped by. As mentioned earlier the pizza was really good and tasted fresh. If your looking for a cheap Sunday dinner and drinks (wine primarily) they have fair happy hour prices.
author: Lyndon G.

description: Are you kidding me? Have the chefs actually tried to consume a whole spicy sausage pizza? Everything about this pizza was fantastic except the sodium level. Please use 1/10th the amount of this spicy sausage. It has a decent flavor, but this is by far the saltiest pizza I've ever consumed in 44 years by orders of magnitude. And I love me some salt (in the right amount). It was inedible without taking off most of the sausage, and even then it was still too salty. Nice crust and everything else was great. But the amount of sodium was mind blowingly high.
author: Ian B.

description: Delicious! The arugula salad with gala apples, pasta pomodoro, and stuffed shells were so good.
author: Diane C.

description: We thoroughly enjoyed the wine and cheeses. Eggplant dish was also delicious; lasagna had a great sauce but texture was more on the mushy side - probably wouldn't order again. Great ambiance; we had a lovely date night here!
author: Kristina B.

description: We had a pizza Margherita and an eggplant plate, it was really good. The wine and the service was great too. The only problem was the tiramisu, it was surprisingly dry, tasteless (not tasting coffee at all). I have even wondered if it was a tiramisu, and not a chocolate cake..
author: Leo A.

description:
Quite a cozy and casual, Italian with wine restaurant. 

I like the Rose that was the only Rose on the menu! Suitable and nicely chilled for the evening.

Their Italian dishes are meant to be shared with the warm and dimly lit setting.  The entrees were homely and went well with the bottles of wine! 

Charcuterie is a must get with wine and as a starter.  Broccoli pizza was ordered on attempting to be healthy.  Their wild boar lasagna was atypical. Eggplant platter was like a comfort dish. Pork and beef meatballs were a classic!  Hit me in the heart later, but the chicken pate was worthy to crunch and savor away at on crostini!

The surrounding brick and wood atmosphere was lovely and brought about a carefree spirit.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I want to give this place 100 stars! If you love Italian food or pizza, this place is a must try for you. The pizza is perfect with thin crunchy crust. The pasta is absolutely aldente. I recommend any of the pizzas but especially the meatball one. 

If you don't want to drink, try the spicy ginger ale. Amazing. 

Tip: I'd call ahead and make a reservation. The place gets packed and it's pretty small inside.
author: Ming Y.

description:
Small and cozy place in Hayes neighbourhood. We had an 8pm reservation for 4 people. We arrived 10min late and the table needed few more minutes to be ready but it was not a problem for us.

Atmosphere inside is really romantic with small tables, art on the walls and dim lights which I love. Our waiter was nice and patient with our several requests to take pics of us. Bathrooms were very clean and they were called "Water Rooms" hahaha! I thought it was a joke!

Dinner Menu was 1 page - nice and simple with few choices of salads and appetisers, 4 choices of pasta and secondi plates and few more options of pizzas. We opted to share a burrata pizza which was fresh and lovely. For main courses we had the boar lasagna (very tasty but also very heavy), stuffed sea shell pasta with spinach and ricotta (nice and light for someone who isn't super hungry), pumpkin pasta (which my cousin found very dry and couldn't finish) and the chicken which wasn't too great. We shared a Montepulciano D'Abbruzzo red wine (bottle for 40$) but not my kind of wine as it had a dry finish. 

Overeall good experience and would return if in the area.
author: Heliana M.

description: Came here on Friday to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday. The atmosphere was chic and comfy and the service was friendly and attentive. We ordered a great bottle of wine and especially enjoyed the lasagna. Also had some delish affogato for dessert (and they even put a bday candle in it, which many SF restaurants are unwilling to do)!
author: Laura F.

description: I've since visited at least two other times. (Since we lived around the corner it was a practical option.) They have a decent, affordable happy hour with some small bites that is quite convenient for a mama and young child at 5pm.
author: Camille L.

description:
I went here for a weekend brunch with my boyfriend . I have been wanting to try their meatball dish but the staff told us they only serve that during dinner time. Kinda sad.

I ordered a truffle egg sandwich and my boyfriend ordered a pepperoni pizza. The pizza was okay, wish the crust could be thinner and crispier. I didn't like the truffle egg sandwich at all. The bread was really thick and the sandwich was way too oily. Should have ordered their meatball sandwich :/

For the drink, I tried their tropical mimosa. I really liked it. I can't really taste that much alcohol and it was really refreshing.

The service was really nice. I think I just ordered the wrong thing. I have to revisit during their dinner time and their famous meatball dish.
author: Clare L.

description:
This is a solid restaurant with reliably great food, and it is fairly easy to get a reservation. The paccheri w/ butternut squash is excellent and one of my favorite pasta dishes in town, but I don't believe they offer it year-round, which is a big bummer. If you're in for lunch, the meatball sandwich is also another winner.

The service can be a bit hit-or-miss sometimes. I've never experienced anything that would keep me from coming back, just occasionally slow service with awkward silences and blank stares. If that doesn't bother you too much, then I definitely recommend giving this place a try because the food is SO good!
author: Cat N.

description: Cool name and luv the piggy logo/drawings.  It looks small from the outside but very spacious on the inside. Enough room in between tables walking with a cane. The two restrooms are wide enough too. We were sat in the very back by the kitchen, comfy seatings. Big menu!! Everyone were smiley and fast with serving our endless plates of food. Brought generous hot sauce and chillies. Gfs ordered 7 style of cured meat platter, grilled octopus, meatballs, lasagna, basil pizza. We will try out their dessert on our next trip.
author: Vee V.

description:
Great restaurant and great food. Have come here for a few nice yet informal occasions and always had a fantastic experience. The ambiance is classy and inviting - it's a darker lit restaurant with an upscale feel but not stuffy at all.

Food is high quality. The burrata is especially interesting and featured throughout the menu. To top it off prices are really affordable. Entre's are $20-$25. And the service has always been great. Perfect for couples or smaller groups (had 7 and that was probably the max)
author: Milan T.

description: Their group dining menu is a STEAL at about $30/person. They gave us plenty of food and all of it was delicious. You can mix and match the items on the group dining menu, which consists really of the best items on the regular menu anyway. The things I didn't love so much were the small dishes like corn salad at the beginning of the meal. The charcuterie and cheese (holla, truffle gouda!), stuffed shells, board lasagna, pizza (so thin and delicious) with not salty burrata and flavorful sweet tomato sauce, and the chocolate budino with almonds for dessert were my favorites. The staff was really nice and made a salad without almonds for my sister in law, who is allergic. I would definitely come here again, especially for group dining!
author: Christina G.

description:
This place has been bookmarked on my list for a while so we decided to try it and see how it is. Honestly, I didn't have a great time, mostly due to the service and a little bit because of the food. 

We walked in without a reservation, but there was plenty of space at the bar so we decided to sit at the bar. First, it took the bartender forever to even acknowledge us and give us a menu. I get being busy, but drop off some menus so we can decide. 

We ordered a few things: chopped salad, boar lasagna and the kale and sausage pizza. The chopped salad? That's a skip. First off, it wasn't chopped enough. A chopped salad should have all the pieces should be small. Secondly, the flavors weren't super complementary. The pizza was good, but the middle of it wasn't fully cooked or something. You really couldn't pick it up and eat it. The middle was a bit...wet and therefore you had to use a fork and knife to eat it. The boar lasagna, though, was the best part of the night. Definitely an order if you're headed here. 

Overall, okay place with a great lasagna. 

Protip: boar lasagna.
author: Nina Y.

description: Great restaurant with amazing service. The house red it to die for! Also I must highly recommend the smoked burrata as an appetizer. The main portions are tasty and generous in terms of serving size. I would recommend to anyone!
author: Bhavin S.

description: This place has an amazing plan for groups when I went there and high quality food. We got a lot of food which took a little while although it was worth the wait. The atmosphere and the waiters are terrific. The one put down I have for it was that it took nearly half an hour for them to serve us and by hat time we were a little full on the appetizers.
author: Oona O.

description: Great happy hour ($6 glasses of wine!). Not very vegan friendly, but their regular pomodoro pasta is delicious. The veggie appetizer plate is absolutely amazing- my mouth drools thinking about the cauliflower and corn salad!! Service is great, too. Space is small, so either make a reservation or get their early. My partner had the ricotta stuffed shells & really enjoyed it.
author: Rob M.

description: Been meaning to try this place for years. Finally dragged hubby over since he is always at the beer place across the street. Love the cozy unpretentious atmosphere. We ordered a lot, octopus salad, green salad, pizza and a pasta dish. We loved it all! I had a lovely flight red wines to go with it.
author: Mirba E.

description: We actually celebrated my husband's birthday there. Their wine list is excellent, they also have fantastic service. I liked the food clubbed with the ambience it was overall a great experience.
author: Sujoyee C.

description: The food here is amazing. Everything top to bottom is fantastic. We enjoy this place for what it is: delicious food in a romantic setting.  The main waiter (there all the time guy) was pretentious and dismissive.  Because of this, Uva is a take-out only spot moving forward.  Maybe we caught him on a few bad nights?
author: M C.

description: Cute.  Food was overall good and service friendly.  Not quite as spectacular as Montesacro Pinseria.
author: Kathryn C.

description: Really beautiful ambiance that you wouldn't expect judging from its exterior. However, once you walk in, there were candles, wine cellars, and attentive waiters that really make you feel nice and pampered. My mother and I cam here for New Year's Eve and had a wonderful time together.
author: Jin Y.

description: Given fellow Yelp reviews at an overall average of four, we were looking forward to an exceptional Italian dining experience, but with two exceptions, it was mediocre at best.  The initial impression was nice enough as the ambiance was modern and slightly hip.  Impressive Italian wine list to choose from, but was taken aback by the $25/bottle corkage fee for a casual atmosphere and modest menu.  To start, we recommend the burrata with figs and crostini which was very nice.  Also liked the cauliflower with capers; refreshing on a hot day in the city, and the olives were nice too.   The chopped salad, however, was disappointing.  Very little meat and cheese, but overloaded with red onion and red arugula rendering it unappetizing.  Presentation was also a mess.  For entrees, I enjoyed the fusilli pasta with pesto. While the mint is a very interesting and welcome compliment, some of my guests found it overpowering.   Additionally, the highly rated salami pizza was an unfortunate combination of being bland and very spicy at the same time.  Interesting hint of honey made it edible, but would not order again.    The best part of the meal was the amazing Italian dessert.  Affogato which is espresso over a vanilla scoop of gelato and chocolate budino were amazing.
author: Roy A.

description: Cozy, intimate ambiance. I came here for restaurant week and although they were super busy, the service was outstanding and everyone was so friendly. The roasted beets were refreshing, the mozzarella pizza was "smokey," and the bundino was decadent and to die for.
author: S W.

description: One of my favorite Italian places in the city. They have a great wine collection and their pizzas are amazing. My vegetarian friends also loved the place. Beautiful, rustic ambiance.
author: Khushboo B.

description: Solid Italian food in Lower Haight! The pasta dishes were the main attraction and the plethora of Italian wines on the menu made us feel like we were smack down in the middle of Rome. Pair that with great service in a comfortable dining room, we are already looking forward to our next visit.
author: Rich S.

description:
Lived near here, and for some reason only went once. Highly recommend, definitely one of my best dining experiences in SF. Come with a small group and go for the very reasonable family style prix-fixe. Generous portions with a charcuterie board, fun salads, cold appetizers, and your pick of main entrees among pizzas and pastas. Dessert was also a great final touch to an already fun and communal dining experience. 

I also loved the ambiance, lighting, and music - definitely didn't feel like the lower haight!
author: Spencer Y.

description: I always have a good experience at this place. The staff is attentive, and very helpful with the wine list. They often have items like truffle cheese and truffle honey available, and I highly recommend both. Menu changes seasonally, but when the beets with whipped ricotta are available, you should absolutely get them. One of my favorite spots for having a long, cozy dinner with friends to catch up. Have never felt rushed.
author: Carol A.

description:
Delightful! Uva has a warm, cozy atmosphere and a top notch happy hour that makes it an excellent choice any night of the week. I visited for the first time on a Monday evening (around 5pm) and was sat immediately. My boyfriend and I ordered pretty much the entire happy hour menu: olives, kale salad, a pasta dish, and a Margherita pizza. Everything was delicious! Service was quick, attentive, and friendly. Happy hour prices are great. 

I highly recommend with a small group of friends or for date night!
author: Fiona F.

description:
I went here for brunch with a group of 8 on a Sunday a few weeks back. The food is delicious, but there were a few things that subtracted from the overall experience. 
Because it was a busy weekend and we had a large group, they couldn't fit us in until 2:00. This wasn't a problem, because they said we could still get bottomless bellinis until 3:30, and we'd still get the brunch experience. That being said, though, it ended up feeling like they were annoyed we were there and it made us feel a bit rushed and uncomfortable. 
We ordered off of the group dining menu, where we got to pick two appetizers & two entrees and you split those along with a salad with the whole table. We had to go over it a few times with our waitress to make sure that the portions were going to be enough for eight people, and we were assured that the portions were large and that it'd definitely be enough food. However, the portions were so small that each person could only take one bite (literally) from each dish in order for everybody to be able to share. 
We ended up feeling unsatisfied with the amount and had to order another entree, which our waitress seemed reluctant to add because the kitchen was closing at 3:00. I guess they close the kitchen between brunch and dinner hours, which is perfectly fine, unless you're already having a late brunch and then when it arrives you get about 8 bites of food. 
I think for the group brunch, they need to make clear how many people it will actually serve. It doesn't list group sizes or portion sizes anywhere on the menu, and it really should be adjusted to have more when there is a larger group. We were under the impression that it would be a family style dining experience, rather than being a few regular sized entrees that we would all be expected to split. 
That being said, I would like to go again with 2-4 people to see if that makes for a better experience. I know large groups can sometimes be tricky at restaurants, and the food was actually really good. (And I'll definitely get my own that I won't have to share next time!!)
author: Traci A.

description: Love the ambiance here. So cute for Lower Haight! The pesto pasta is delicious. Highly recommend the prosciutto pizza and great Italian wines. The brunch is also awesome with bottomless Bellinis and the soft scramble.
author: Sonya S.

description:
The roommate wanted pizza for dinner. I wanted to try a new place, but I didn't want to pay Postmates' surge pricing, so I decided to try Uva Enoteca since they were on Caviar. We placed our delivery order on Monday, October 12th around 8:20pm. It arrived around 9:40pm. Prices below are what I paid ordering through Caviar. Looking at their online menu, Caviar is priced a little more than 7% higher.

*Little gem salad (dinner): little gem lettuces with anchovy lemon dressing, radishes and grana padano ($13.95)
*Pork and beef meatballs: served with ricotta salata, san marzano tomatoes and salsa verde ($16.05)
*Salame pizza: spicy salami, mozzarella, pecorino, calabrian chili, san marzano tomatoes, red onions, no clover honey ($18.75)
*Meatball pizza: mozzarella, san marzano tomatoes ($18.20), add Arugula (+$2.15), Calabrian chilis (+$2.15)

I enjoyed the salad. The lettuce was crisp and the dressing had a nice lemony anchovy flavor. It was overdressed for me, but I love my greens, so it still complemented the pizzas well. The meatballs were a little one note in taste and kind of dry. And the sauce was really acidic. It was a little too sharp and sour for my taste. The pizzas were pretty good overall. The crust was thin, but soft with a nice chew. I liked the meatball pizza more, especially with the arugula. But they forgot to add the chilis which was a bummer (and a waste of about $3). The roommate liked the salami pizza more, but I could see why they normally have honey on that pizza. The salami was rather salty.

Not the best pizza I've had, but for me, it was a better option than a place the roommate would have picked. At least the crust is on the thinner side. Everyone seems to rave about the charcuterie board. If I'm ever in the neighborhood, I may give them another shot just for that.
author: Elena N.

description:
I've only eaten here for brunch (x3) so this review does not reflect the dinner menu or service.

That being said, it's an awesome spot--honestly not sure why Italian brunch isn't more popular! The eggs with potatoes and tomato sauce are my favorite (ask for a side of bread to soak up the sauce). $15 for 2.5 hours of bottomless is a steal in SF and I've never experienced a wait here, which is unavoidable at trendier brunch places nearby.
author: Lauren T.

description: Ok ... I've come here twice for dinner now and had two slightly different service experiences but food is always amazing. First time, I dined with a girl friend on Friday night, immediately seated at the bar area, great attentive service from the wine selection to the food pairing. We ordered the eggplant crostini, meatballs, argula salad and mozzarella pizza and delicious bottle from Montepulciano. Entirely too much food for two ladies (even 3 maybe), but so glad we got everything as it was sooo tasty. Fast forward to last weekend, dined here on a Saturday night 4 girls without reservation. I figured we'd have to wait an hour but we kept getting called back and told a table was ready when it actually wasn't which was annoying. Then once we sat at the bar, the guy working that night wasn't very knowledgeable on the wines and kind of had a "whatever" approach to recommendations. It also took forever for our wine to come out and then we felt really rushed to order. Again, with that said, the 4 of us ordered the a 3 meat and 3 cheese plate, the arugula salad and eggplant crostinis. As we were ordering meals as well, we should have only gone 2 meat and 2 cheese probably but everything is just soooo good! My friend and I split the squash pasta and the lasagna bolognese. Both were very tasty, noodles on the squash pasta were cooked perfectly; the lasagna was not my favorite as the meat sauce was really more of a bolognese so it was creamier rather than hearty meat. Just a personal preference I think. My other friend ordered the lasagna bolognese as well and loved it and another friend ordered the chopped salad which was huge and looked so tasty. I really do still love this place and think the prices are so great, will come back again, just make a reservation for more than 3, fit in a pizza and try to keep from over ordering!
author: Aryn C.

description: A perfect little restaurant in the city. Great service, very decent wine list (but not cheap), and good quality food. The only problem is parking, but that comes with the area. We had squid and burrata for appetizers,  and octopus and pasta for main. Everything very tasty. Hope to be back.
author: Vadim R.

description:
This was our 2nd option for dinner after the first place couldn't get us in for 90 plus minutes.  I must admit, we were 8 people from out of town looking to feast on some good Italian food.  We were staying at Chateau Tivoli Bed and Breakfast nearby and I used Yelp to find a nearby Italian restaurant and I started walking to the first place because they didn't take reservations.  They told me that it would take over 90 minutes to get 8 of us in after 7:30pm.  I put our name on the list and searched Yelp again and I found this place and I started walking toward it. When I got to Uva Enoteca, it looked a bit small and I thought they wouldn't be able to get us in.  I decided to ask anyway and he said Yes. . I followed it up with how long would it be?  He said 15 minutes.  I looked around, the tables seemed full but I started contacting the others to let them know that I found a place to get us in. After 15 minutes, my party was there, we went in and they brought us into the back behind the bar where they had 2 tables set for 8. I was quite surprised.  

The staff here was very polite and took the time to explain the drink and food selection.  They only serve beer and wine.  I can make due without a margarita.  He told us that for parties of 6 or more, they offer a family style Italian dining experience for $30/person. That includes appetizers like fresh bread, cheese trays,  meat trays and olive trays to begin. They said we could order 2 pizzas and 2 pasta dishes along with dessert.  We decided to go for it. He also mentioned $25 each for all-you-can-drink beer, wine, soda (mix and match) which they wanted all or none to participate.  I was just drinking water with a couple others, so they decided to let some do the deal even though 100% of us weren't doing that. It was nice of them to flex for us. 

We got the appetizers which we all enjoyed then it was time for the pizzas. We ordered the meatball pizza and the salami pizza. Since we had 8, they offered up another pizza, I chose a margarita pizza. All of the pizzas were delicious, the crust was perfect.  After that, we had the stuffed shells and the boar bolognaise lasagna.  We liked the shells a lot,  some of us thought the lasagna was just okay. The dessert was shared but we also had a birthday boy that got his own dessert. We all left the restaurant satisfied and full of good food.  Please see my photos to see some of the goodness that we enjoyed.  Enjoy!
author: Jim L.

description: I recently had a party for 12 people here and Uva Enoteca really came through for us!  We had a birthday party with a birthday boy who was gluten free and we weren't sure of the party size until the day before - no problem for them.  They worked with me up until the start of the event, provided gluten free options and helped me feel at ease through the whole process.  They are reasonably priced, can handle large parties well and provided an over abundance of food (which was truly delicious).  Each guest had the same type of feedback, "this place is amazing".  I highly recommend them for anything from a casual date to a large party or just friends out for the evening.  This place knows what they're doing and they deserve a great deal of credit for what they provide.
author: Mitch M.

description:
I hosted a group of friends here for an engagement party and could not have been more pleased with both the service and the food. Rachel, the restaurant's group coordinator, was great with communication and when I showed up with my fiancee everything was taken care of.  The spread was fantastic for the per person price, and everyone in my group seemed to really enjoy themselves.  I would come back here both on a date night and for a large group again without any hesitation.  

Thank you so much for making my day so memorable!
author: Andrew C.

description: Came with a large party of six on a late Friday night. We were seated right away. The hostess, and other employees were very kind and accommodating. Highly recommend this place for a nice proportioned meal. Not too big, not too small. Just right . I ordered the lasagna and my goodness was it delicious. Such a rich buttery/creamy goodness to it. Rich with flavor in every bite. There were lots of groups of friends, so they don't mind lots of noice and chatter. Everyone was sipping on wine and having a good time. Definitely a cool spot to just indulge in good company and good food.
author: Bobbi D.

description: One word.. Bad service and bad food, cold pizza and they have to refill your mimosa not putting g a jar on the table.. It was awkward keep asking for drinks
author: Semo C.

description:
Okay charming waitress Lisa caught my eye. She's a pro & so nice. Chicken liver Crostini (aka pate) is crazy good. It's neighborhood alright. Every yelper's right about the Happy Hour. Delicious chianti $6 a glass. The crostini is 5 bucks, too. great deal!
We ordetrd pasta pomodoro. Lisa said yes we coyld ordet a meatball-+ extra sauce w the pasta pomodoro, so complainers rest easy. One thing-- the decor I'd like to change.
I'd like to decorate this place in old Italian restaurant old-school,  It's a little too sparse like techie-newbie for me. These kids should embrace tradition. You don't know you've got till it's gone San Francisco. And hey a**holes--it's San Francisco NOT "SAN FRAN" --ok? 

"SANFRAN" = FRISCO lame tech morons please note. 
 
The food & service is great. Pay attention to history please. Btw you don't have to buy bread, just ask. This place is great.And be sure to tip your server well--esp if it's Lisa ;)
author: Scott F.

description:
I, and two friends, came here for brunch. The food was good (when it finally came out) but other than that it was kind of a struggle.
The servers seemed like they weren't really expecting guests today or something. After ordering it took over 30 minutes to actually get our meals. Another couple came in at least 20 minutes after we ordered and received their meals at the same time as us. And keep in mind there were only 5 customers in the place and one table already had food when we entered . 
Food was good and the decor was nice but service was lacking. We want them to be great! We really do.
author: Brittnee G.

description:
Had brunch and bottomless bellinis ($15) on a Sunday afternoon. I liked that we were able to make reservations even for a Sunday brunch, and that it wasn't too crowded in general. Wait staff was pleasant and he restaurant is close to many bars, etc (lower haight). Bellinis were okay, much too sweet for me though; I'll go back to the mimosas but it was good to mix it up a bit.

Ordered the truffle toast that came on fontina, with a sunny side up egg, cheese, and truffle shavings inside the bread. It was pretty delicious. Included grilled zucchini on the side which was also good. My only complaint is that the entrees tend to be on the smaller side regarding quantity. Luckily, I was able to steal a piece of a friends Neumann bacon ;-)
author: Will H.

description:
A great, cozy place over the hill in Hayes/Haight. We went on a Wednesday and there were a ton of tables. The service staff was great and there was some delicious bread. 

The pizzas were great. There are awesome vegetarian options! The sauce was good and the crust was super thing and crispy. We also got some wines which were delicious and the waiter paired it for us well, we asked for tasty and in our budget. I would love to go here again for a casual pizza dinner.
author: Akshaya V.

description:
Not my first time here and never my last. Met a friend for Happy Hour on a Saturday. Couple things subtracted from the experience and I will mention these up front, ahead of my remaining glowing review.  Otherwise I would have given them "5" Stars.

1) Happy Hour not posted on the web site.
2) Happy Hour munchies are pretty darn limited. We had hoped to make a bit of a meal of HH food and drinks. Thankfully we stayed long enough to peruse the 5:00 Dinner menu.

Brian, back up Bartender (Holly was on break when we arrived) was really sweet and very well informed of the HH wine's and let us try "several" before we made our final choices. Sadly I can't remember the wines we chose, I presume HH wines change, so I have an "out" to my fading memory.

We did try duck liver pate on toast points, which was absolutely lovely and very, very plentiful. So much so, we asked for "extra toast points" to spread the pate around.

Next up a HH featured pasta dish with a slight tomato cream sauce.  Quite nice, but nothing out of the ordinary.

More wine please and Holly is back.  What a gem she is and Holly also knows her wines and again, let us try mini samples before we dove in.  I can say I had some lovely dry Whites and my friend had some yummy reds.  Again, names escape me. But don't think you can go wrong with anything you choose.

For our "main meal", like we needed more :-)....  We had one of the Pizzas, Kale, house-made fennel sausage, garlic, basil, pecorino, mozzarella.  It was De-lish and we finished every last little bite. I will say, the crust is quite thin and get's a tad "soggy" on the bottom, but the flavors were so good, you could look past the fact you needed a fork to eat the pizza.  Maybe it needs to be cooked just a tad more, not sure.

A couple sitting next to us let us try their salad of Mixed kale, almonds, ricotta salata.  It was absolutely the bomb and so refreshing and light. The Kale was chopped perfectly so one did not struggle with the cutting / chewing part, which can often be the case with Kale.  I wish we had ordered that, but as you can see, we had "plenty to keep us full and happy".

Yummy and interesting food choices, pretty reasonably priced, neighborhood gem, wonderful service, a great place to just "hang out at the bar".
author: Marla B.

description:
Cozy cute restaurant great for a night out for drinks and dessert or for dinner! 

Just came back from Italy and the pizza was very authentic. Loved the food here. Carafes of wine are also a plus!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Wandered in here looking for pizza with a friend a little past noon on the weekend. We sat at the bar and ordered our individual noms off the brunch menu. Because pizza is pizza, you can't go wrong with it any time of the day. 

Also I couldn't be convinced to order anything else, I decided on the Margherita pizza. The best part about the pizza was the crust which is thin but not too crisp. Along with the crust, the rest of it was quite mediocre. I was quite sad it was so unsatisfying!

The pizza wasn't memorable, probably why I forgot my leftovers in an Uber.
author: Shereen A.

description:
Warning: when you order the meatball "entrée" on a delivery website from here, BEWARE. You literally just get four balls of meat and sauce. No sides. NO BREAD. No UTENSILS. No NAPKINS. No consideration for presentation or care for at-home customer satisfaction. Really? Yes really. I can affirmatively say at this point it's happened several times here...whether ordering from Caviar, DoorDash, whatever and what have you.

$16 for this? Or rather $26 with the delivery/service fees attached. You would employ a service to deliver your food at a premium price and yet could care less about delivering a meal that is worthy of the expenditure? Shame.

In all fairness, The meatballs are good (boar lasagna yum) - why I've kept coming back hoping they've gotten it together. Sadly, no.

DONE.
author: Courtney T.

description:
Service: 3 stars
Wine: still 4 stars

After my first stellar visit, I brought friends back twice within two weeks. But to my surprise, the service was disappointingly unfriendly when it gets busy. They're quite efficient, but won't stop to talk anything about wines/beers. Still, a good pour for happy hour and good deal on $10 margherita pizza, but the rest of the food was meh and expensive (the beets dish was tiny, $10 and bland. the cauliflower dish was also small, $10, and heavy on capers). I probably won't be back unless it's purely for happy hour or cheese :-\
author: Maggie G.

description:
We came here on a Sunday for the happy hour and were all pleasantly surprised. 

FOOD: We mostly ordered from the happy hour menu and shared some olives, salad, pasta, pizza, and wine and beer, plus an eggplant dish from the regular menu. All the food was delicious! There's something so delightful about having simple but really well made pasta with fresh quality ingredients. 

SERVICE: Pretty attentive. We sat at the bar so had no problem getting drinks refilled. We did have to ask for menus a few times as more of our party arrived, but not a problem. Food did take a while to arrive, but it was worth it,

AMBIENCE: Dark, sexy, romantic. This place is PERFECT for a date. It seems pretty unassuming and nothing special if you walk by it, but inside... is where the magic happens.
author: J L.

description: I wasn't crazy about this place like I thought I would be. It's a cute little restaurant nestled in the haight. We ordered the chicken liver, which tasted like it just got pulled out from the fridge. Next up was the roasted cauliflower which was stone cold. Maybe it's supposed to be that way but it was unexpected and I didn't care for it. We also had the crimini mushroom pizza and stuffed pasta shells which were okay.  The stuffed pasta shells had too much sauce. The pizza was fine, but nothing special. Maybe we just ordered the wrong items but overall just mediocre food. Our waiter was cool so added a star for that.
author: shatier x.

description:
The cheese & meat board was the bee's knees. So was the spicy salami & honey pizza (although it was much spicier than I anticipated). The flavor profile of that pizza was pretty awesome if you like some heat. The cheese and meat board comes with an array of sides, including honey, jam, and mustard.

Our server's attitude was kind of a downer, though. It took a long ass time for her to take our order, and she was pretty impatient and rude. We all agreed that she suffered from RBF.

Another downer: the beef lasagna. It was small and unremarkable -- just mushy and not that exciting. I would stick with the pizzas and meat/cheese boards. 

Ambiance-wise, Uva Enoteca is really cute and cozy. There's a back room so the restaurant is bigger than it looks, and you can easily make reservations on OpenTable.
author: Valerie L.

description:
The last night of my stay back home in San Francisco for the holidays, my dad and I found this local Italian gem. From the outside it looks like a tiny restaurant, but as you step inside you can see how far back it goes! There's a small initial seating area, followed by a full bar, and a second seating area behind that. 

This venue has amazing food - healthy, incredible taste, and good ambiance to boot. They even have great gluten-free pasta options which are scrumptious (though I wish it wasn't $3 extra)! The only drawback we experienced was the service: Our waiter was very attentive in the beginning, but he definitely went MIA as the meal went on! We had to ask for water refills multiple times, and we even ending up flagging down the busboy for a dessert menu in the end. All-in-all, I would go back for the food and atmosphere, hopeful to get a slightly more attentive waiter this time!
author: Chelsea M.

description: Always a go-to dinner spot. There's never a wait, the pizza is delicious, the wine selection is great, and service is friendly. Happy hour lasts until 6:30, too!
author: Shannon A.

description:
We ordered the Salami pizza and Smoked Mozzarella pizza for delivery. Both arrived perfectly prepared and in exquisite presentation, almost too pretty to eat.  Almost.  

The Salami pizza (Spicy salame, mozzarella, pecorino, calabrian chilis, san marzano tomatoes, red onions, clover honey) had a cool bit of honey that complemented the chilis so well, I loved it.  Maybe a touch too much honey for me but great nonetheless.  

The Smoked Mozzarella (Smoked mozzarella, toybox tomatoes, garlic, basil, black pepper) was just a simple, well seasoned pizza that tasted sublime.  Yum.

Recommend trying out, we are looking forward to trying more from their menu.
author: Saminda W.

description: They were perfect! We had a party of seven, well six and a baby. There was only one in our group who didn't require a special diet. The menu was able to accommodate all of us. We went early for dinner. I had the Eggplant. Im not a vegetarian, however if all veggies were prepared this well i could be. The salads on the menu can be shared family style. We tried the corn and also the cauliflower. Both were great. Since we had six in our group, we should have tried a third. Two was not enough. The dinner portions were perfect. Filled you up and didn't need to take anything home. Great wine and beer selection too. I will return to try something else the next time i visit SF.
author: Jill M.

description: Good place and great food. Awesome! The burrata is very very good.
author: Charlotte L.

description: Best Italian I've had in my life. They're a little cheap when it comes to the wine pots, but food makes up for it.  The Lasagna - just do it.
author: Joy J.

description:
Glad I booked a table because the place filled fast.  

Mixed Kale, almonds, ricotta salata - crunchy & delicious.

Pork & beef meatballs w / san marzano tomatoes, grana padano, salsa verde - good.  solid.

Boar Bolognese lasagna w / bechamel, grana padano - was a disappointment, especially with the stellar reviews.  Not much flavor despite having boar meat & could use more cheese.
author: Kim S.

description:
Wavered between 4 and 5 stars here. Everything we had was fantastic, and absolutely no complaints at all, but it wasn't one of those places I had to tell all my friends about immediately. I think it was the service that finally made me give it the fifth star. Either way, I highly recommend it!

We walked in without a reservation, but the host made it clear he was doing everything to seat as sooner rather than later. Our waiter was extremely helpful, especially in helping us decide what wine to order. I mentioned I generally like Pinot Noir's and he brought three different wines for me to try (since the menu is almost exclusively Italian wines, and I don't know much about those). Also, their standard serving is an 8oz carafe so it's easy and plenty to share, not the usual 5oz glass, so that doesn't hurt either! 

For food, we got the stuffed shells and a broccoli pizza.  I was blown away by the stuffed shells. They were phenomenal, and I would recommend the dish. The pasta, filling, and sauce were all perfect in isolation and in concert with each other. The pizza was also very good, but the shells stole the show. 

All in all, eat here, drink here, be merry here!
author: Malika R.

description: Lovely presentation and yummy food. We went for a birthday and it was great! Happy and attentive wait staff.
author: Donna C.

description:
A meal made of HH specials.

Every day of the week has a happy hour period, and on a Sunday we happened to arrive on the tail end of those specials. $6 house wines and $5 veggie appetizers? Yes please!

We sipped our reds and chomped on some kale salad and roasted beets for starters. The kale was probably my favorite course of the meal. The kale was crunchy, the nuts on top added an extra layer of flavor, and it was perfectly dressed. The beets were tasty in combination with the ricotta, but I felt they could've been browned a little longer.

For entrees, we split an order of the pomedoro and the boat lasagna. The pomedoro was cooked al dente, and the sauce had a small bite to it, which was a welcome addition. I sprinkled a little more cheese on top which made the simple dish shine. The lasagna was presented beautifully, although I felt the actual flavors were a little flat. It was more meaty than starchy, so if you're looking for that entree that'll fill you up, this is the way to go.

Service was aight. Despite it being Super Bowl weekend and being the only table in the restaurant for the first 20 minutes, our server forgot our waters and table bread. When it came time to ordered, I tried to flag him down several times but he was out of sight usually. I can believe that the place is usually packed on the weekends, but more attentive service would've been nice.
author: Ben W.

description: Whoa. This place was great. Loved the happy hour pizza and salad. Incredible value for such deliciousness.
author: Adam B.

description: Very cozy and nice dining experience in this place! The waiter was friendly and helpful. We ordered two types of pasta. Both are very delicious. Will drop by next time!
author: Rachel J.

description:
Uva Enoteca.  What a cool name, even though the UVA is a little bit tainted if you've learned dermatology and this restaurant name kindles thoughts of broad-spectrum sunblock such as avobenzone.  Anyways, I'll begin my review because I'm sure few people reading this have questions about UV radiation on their mind right now, especially for anyone living in SF.

Uva Enoteca was a Yelp find, and there are a number of notable locations in the area.  It's N-Judah friendly, has non-impossible street parking, and is in an area of SF that's not too busy or sketchy.

The menu features a number of fancy-sounding Italian fare which seems quite authentic in cooking style, but adventurous in choice of ingredients.  (In Yelp categorization, I would call it Italian (New) and not fusion.)  

For 4 not-so-hungry girls on a grad school budget, we got:

Boar Bolognese lasagna w / bechamel, grana padano $17: Tasty, but we're not really sure what made it distinctively boar.  (I wish I could make a pun about boarishness, but it was too refined-looking and not boarish :/)  To us, it tasted essentially the same as ground pork.  

Baked Japanese eggplant w / san marzano tomatoes, mozzarella, ricotta salata, grana padano $17: This was our favorite!  Because Japanese eggplant is awesome and makes even authentic Italian dishes like eggplant parmesan way better.

A pizza, ~$16: Apologies for the poor description, but after looking back-and-forth at my picture and the menu multiple times, I still couldn't figure out what we ordered.  It was a good pizza though, with the fluffy but thin crust, a mostly tomato based sauce, and toppings that gave it character.

Service was a bit frustrating because we got attention when unwanted and no attention when neede.  One of us got there much earlier so waited for the rest us at a table, but noticed that the staff seemed to be giving passive-aggressive glares even though the restaurant wasn't even that busy.  On the other hand, during our actual meal we had some problem flagging down servers when we needed them.  Meh... bumped down my 3.5 stars food-ambiance to 3 stars overall: so 4 stars if you look at restaurants Michelin style, 3 stars if you are influenced by service.
author: Edna C.

description: Great neighborhood spot! Went for Saturday brunch and had a wonderful dining experience. Looking forward to revisiting.
author: Jason V.

description:
They have amazing boar lasagna. It's one of the best lasagna I've ever had in SF. It's served in a hot pan, very flavorful and the taste is well-balanced: tomato-ish, creamy, salty, meaty, without overpowering each other. I finished everything on my plate, I almost cleaned up the pan with some bread... "Delicious" is not enough to describe my feeling after having it, "happy and satisfied" would be more accurate:) 

I paired the food with a mid-body red wine recommended by my waiter, and I also sipped the wine from my friend, both are very good. 

I've seen my neighbors also ordered the same thing, and they devoured it very quickly! Will definitely come back for again to fulfill my craving for creamy meaty and tomatoey lasagna!
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
This lovely rustic Italian restaurant is an unexpected tenant on Lower Haight, but I love it nonetheless (or maybe that's why I love it).

I visited Uva a couple months ago when some college friends were in town, and admittedly, at the time its biggest draws were 1) that it's walking distance from my apartment, and 2) they take reservations. However, the food turned out to be compelling enough on its own, and I'd definitely recommend it even to locals outside of the immediate neighborhood.

The four of us shared the boar bolognese lasagna, butternut squash rigatoni, and the kale/fennel sausage/mozzarella/pecorino/basil/garlic pizza. Of these, for me the butternut squash rigatoni (having breadcrumbs in this dish is genius--so good!) was most memorable, but I still thought everything was delicious.

My one gripe is that the portions are kind of small, but I guess it's NBD because if you still have some stomach space, Bi-Rite's not too far away. :)
author: Kelly R.

description:
This place reminded me that I was once the worst waitress ever. Our waiter at Uva Enoteca, however, knew absolutely everything there was to know about their food and extensive wine selection! He took the shoddy information we could provided about our wine preferences and made some great suggestions without judgement.

The meat and cheese combo plates rule! It might not look like a lot of food, but I still left doing the post-dinner 'I may have overdone it/you've done it again' walk.

Great spot for a double date for folks like me who are practically crippled by the social awkwardness of double dates! Picking your meats and cheeses for the table was a natural icebreaker.
author: Alexis H.

description: Hostess was very rude and even though we had a reservation and were on time, she wouldn't let us sit/wait inside so we had to wait outside in the cold when there were several empty tables available. Also no pizza available which is the reason we chose this restaurant.
author: Molly S.

description: What a gem. One of the best Italian spots in the city for sure. The food was excellent. The raw corn, the ricotta crostini and the special burrata appetizers were all superb. Everyone loved their mains as well. The spicy salami pizza was so tasty! Can't wait to return.
author: C.K. O.

description: Everything about this small restaurant is great. The atmosphere is awesome. The staff is super friendly and kind. The food is AMAZING! The pizzas and the pastas are to die for! The wine and alcohol list is super extensive, something for everybody. Would recommend this to anyone!
author: Thea R.

description: Cozy ambiance, delicious wine, tasty octopus and pasta. It was just what I wanted for date night.
author: Hayley Y.

description: So happy to give Uva more chances. Now a neighborhood fave. Happy hour is great to share pasta and a margarita pizza. If you're feeling fancy, the smoked burrata is delicious.
author: Brook S.

description: Delicious pizza in the lower haight, and great service. Their entrees are equally impressive. Atmosphere has a bistro feel. Charming.
author: Jimmy J.

description:
We showed up for Happy Hour ( they offer a very inexpensive simple but good menu).
Ordered the HH red and the HH white ( Gavi) both good wines for the price.
The HH menu is pretty basic, margarita pizza and rigatoni with tomato sauce but tasted really good.
The service form the Bartender was good. We had everything we needed. 
Have been there for dinner before and the portions are very generous and tasty. 
The meatballs appetizer is basically a full meal and very delicious.
Wine selection is great and generally good service.
I'll go back.
author: Junior V.

description: Cute little place to get brunch, although the menu is pretty limited. I opted for the breakfast sandwich, and added bacon for $2 more. The bread was toasted perfectly, and the portion size was perfect. It also came with a side of arugula and corn salad, lightly dressed. My roommate got the biscuits and gravy which she enjoyed as well. The biscuits were soft and warm, and went great with the soft scrambled eggs. We both also went for the bottomless bellinis. Yum!
author: Gina P.

description:
The restaurant is very small, just like its portions. The food took forever to make, but the quality was really good. I can't actually remember the names of the dishes I order, but one was some sampler/ appetizer with beets, olives, potatoes, and some green thing. The Margherita pizza was really good.The best item on the menu is the BOAR BOLOGNESE LASAGNA. Please eat. 

also love that you can make reservations online!
author: Juliana P.

description: Octopus is a must have here! Moved from a table near the door to the bar and felt being punished by the grumpy employee at the bar. Actually none of the employee smile here for some reason ...
author: Coco H.

description: What an amazing way to start a Sunday.  This is a hidden gem with friendly happy service, awesome good, $12 bottomless Bellini, great decor, fun location.  Really loved the lasagna, the decadent breakfast sandwich, and the truffle egg toast.  Beautiful place to enjoy a nice weekend brunch.  Highly recommended.
author: Scott H.

description:
Italian food that hit the spot. The menu offers many vegetarian options in salad, pasta and pizza. 

Little gems salad was light, refreshing although a bit bitter. 

The stuffed shells came with four large pasta shells, filled with ricotta and spinach. It was very soft and easy to eat. We had a pizza to share as well, but I question whether four shells as a standalone entree is sufficient for the average person. 

The roasted mushrooms pizza has a nice flavor - although it tasted almost exactly like the shells with all the cheese and tomato. Also, it was soggy in the center and when you hold a slice up, the tip drooped.. 

The strawberry and mascarpone tart was not very sweet, which is good, since the mascarpone is heavier. They do make the tart in-house. As for the vanilla gelato - we only ordered it to go with the tart; it is not worth $8 as it is purchase from elsewhere and was not very special.. they added too much sea salt to it as well. 

Overall, a nice local spot for comfort Italian food, attentive service.
author: K. N.

description:
Oof. This menu is a minefield. Came here for happy hour and was continually surprised by how disappointing the dishes were.

No go on the cold cauliflower, meatballs were ok to eat but a little weird, chickpea crostini has Rosemary dumped all over it -- took one bite and couldn't continue. For reference, I am not a picky eater. 

Two stars because the happy hour white wine was good and cheap, and the rigatoni with tomato sauce was okay. But honestly, that's a dish that's pretty hard to screw up, and they screwed up almost every other seemingly simple menu item. 

*To be fair, coulda been an off day but I won't be back to find out.*
author: Anthony D.

description: When eating here I can tell that this restaurant definitely uses fresh ingredients. I ordered a margarita pizza and shelled pasta and both were so delicious. The service is awesome, the staff are so friendly and ready to help. The inside is very clean the lights are dim, and it's not too loud. I highly recommend doing a reservation ahead of time as they are a busy restaurant. One thing they should improve on is maybe increasing their portion sizes especially for the prices they are charging. The personal pizza is small and costs around $19 and for the pasta you only get four shells for about 18 bucks. Overall I do recommend for fresh Italian food what do suggest to come early because parking in the area is difficult.
author: Fatima A.

description: Came here with a friend the other night for the first time. We were excited to come after hearing such good things and reading great reviews. Upon arriving the service was slow and everyone seemed stressed and flustered. I had a reservation but was awhile till anyone even acknowledged me at the front to be seated. Once sitting it took quite awhile for any service and finally had to ask to order. We got the spicy salame pizza and added an egg, the meatballs, and the pate crustini. Food was pretty good, slightly on the heavy side. We got the chocolate budino to share for dessert but wasn't too impressed. I would maybe come back again but overall the service was really lacking and food so pretty decent.
author: Emily F.

description: fancy Italian meats, cheese and prices. we went on a saturday so it was busy and loud but the service was great and the 2 of us didn't have to wait too long. our server was helpful with getting something good that accommodated our strict diets and allergies and the serving sizes weren't huge. it's perfect for a date or getting a drink with friends. i don't think i'll come back since they don't have many vegetarian options an it's pricy.
author: Kat S.

description:
Having gone months without talking/seeing each other, friend/fellow Yelper Jenny K. and I came out to Uva Enoteca for a reunion of sorts.  When we had decided on coming here though, I actually laughed to myself (I'm not crazy...just a funny guy) - I had JUST bookmarked them to try! 

While it's unclear to me if Uva Enoteca is a wine bar that serves food, or a restaurant with a great wine program, either could be right since they blend the food and wine together so well.  Although I can't recall his name, our server gave us some great recommendations on the food and on an awesome bottle of wine (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uva-enoteca-san-francisco?select=jEUJtJOCns9y76i3oKWhuQ#jEUJtJOCns9y76i3oKWhuQ).

- MEAT BOARD (Six Choices) - Hot Coppa, Speck, Bresaola...Three for $15
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uva-enoteca-san-francisco?select=jEUJtJOCns9y76i3oKWhuQ#qPlVNB8CiOjOcsoPuZVelw)
Mmm...meaty goodness.  My favorite was the Bresaola - very flavorful with legit heat to it.  The Hot Coppa had a nice smoky, spiciness (though not as spicy as the Bresaola), but the Speck was just okay (reminded me of smoked honey baked ham).

- CHEESE BOARD (Seven Choices) - Brinata (sheep), Bermuda Triangle (goat), Grana Padano (cow)...Three for $14
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uva-enoteca-san-francisco?select=jEUJtJOCns9y76i3oKWhuQ#HarY79jBAdzyQvVMAEnhsw)
Mmm...cheesey goodness.  While Jenny K. loved the Bermuda Triangle (kinda gamey/bleu cheese-ish), I liked the Brinata better - super creamy texture and a taste that fell between goat cheese and cow cheese.  However, we both agreed that the Grana Padano wasn't worth it.  Not bad, but I'd try something else.

- PORK AND BEEF MEATBALLS with Ricotta Salata, Tomato, and Salsa Verde...$15
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uva-enoteca-san-francisco?select=jEUJtJOCns9y76i3oKWhuQ#wlH3JR8IGHfhSsyvao9FXQ)
Quite simply, it didn't stand out.  It looked great on the dish, but the flavor left me wanting more, whether it be more of a savory flavor or herbs/seasoning.  Good enough to satisfy, but didn't make an impression either.

- SPICY SALAME, MOZZARELLA, CHILIS, AND SAN MARZANO TOMATOES PIZZA...$15
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uva-enoteca-san-francisco?select=jEUJtJOCns9y76i3oKWhuQ#gT3sYxPMMvW2GvZ2zK-zPg)
Where the Meatballs fell short, the Pizza excelled.  The crust doesn't quite approach my favorites, but everything on top of it packed a punch.  The salame and sauce (surprising for me) were great, but I wish it had more cheese!

- LAVENDER & THYME PANNA COTTA with Blood Orange Compote...$8
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uva-enoteca-san-francisco?select=jEUJtJOCns9y76i3oKWhuQ#rLiPD_bcx2W0blB4zOqsvg)
My least favorite dish.  The panna cotta had a great consistency/texture, and I liked how subtle the lavender was, but the thyme was too strong.  The blood orange helped to freshened up the dish, but it was too bitter to strike a good sweet/sour balance.

Since the place is somewhat modest in size, reservations would be best (especially on Fri/Sat nights), or at least to come early/late the heavy dinner crowds.  In either case, make sure you allot enough time for parking as well since parking in the area can be scarce.  Maybe we'll even see each other!  I definitely plan on coming back for the charcuterie and cheese boards.  Plus, it makes for a great date spot as well!  ;)
author: Mike L.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday dinner. We managed to squeeze a large party in here. This place isn't very big. 

We ordered family style from one of their prix fixe menu things for groups, and ended up paying per person.

Cheese and Meats - The cheese plate was definitely very delicious, and this is where most of the stars come from. Delicious cheeses, and the cured meats were pretty good too. The assortment was not really enough for everybody, but I guess it's only an app, so they want us to save room for the rest of the food coming out. This was the best part of the whole meal though.

Salad - Par.

Pizzas - The pizzas were not spectacular. One came out slightly burnt actually. They were not memorable, nor that flavourful. Meh, wouldn't recommend this at all.

Pastas - Two pasta dishes came out, I honestly don't remember which ones they were. I enjoyed them though. They were very mediocre though. They weren't good nor great, but they weren't bad. Came out perfectly al dente. Some people thought it was undercooked, but I promise you it wasn't. 

Dessert - Everybody loved the desserts. Lemon & olive oil cake, apple chutney, vanilla gelato and Chocolate budino w/ caramel sauce, whipped cream & marcona almonds. The budino is very very rich, so keep that in mind when ordering. Despite not enjoying desserts that much, these desserts were pleasant. 

Wines - Severely over priced. I wouldn't recommend it. We ordered a few bottles of different wines. There was maybe one wine that was worth the 50 dollar price tag, but the other bottles, honestly lacked depth and complexity. That "2009" on it doesn't necessarily mean much, nor does the $45 price tag on it. Beer pricing seems better, but we didn't order beer.

Service... there wasn't really any service. Very lackluster. 

I think it was okay to try once. The cheese and cured meats are worth a potential return, but honestly the rest of it killed the experience. I'm sure you can find other places with decent to good cheeses and cured meats with more affordable wine and better service. Not recommended and probably won't return.
author: Kaje Y.

description:
Came here because I wanted to eat pasta after a long day out. I'm not from the area was visiting for a trip and yelped this place. 

Environment
It's a cozy restaurant with a stylish design. It's not too fancy, not too casual.

Food
We started off with the Carne with 3 types of meat.  We didn't know what was good so we asked for recommendations from our waiter. He suggested the Salame Caccintorino, Speck, Prosciutto Giovane (I think) so that's what we got. The salame was a little tasteless but both the speck and prosciutto were really good!:)
It comes with some really good bread as well as some mustard to spread. 
We also got the an appetizer with roasted squid with green olives, celery, calabrian chilies, oregano, garlic (the menu online has  no name:(() and we thoroughly enjoyed that as well. 

For the entree, I got the pomodoro (w/mezze rigatoni, garlic, chilis, pecorino) which I really liked! It wasn't too goopey and had a nice cheesy tomato taste:)

Service
Although they seemed understaffed, we didn't feel like we had slow service and they were pretty attentive to us throughout the whole dinner:)
author: Nicole S.

description:
The best service I have ever gotten at a restaurant!

I was feeling somewhat ill and lightheaded and the waitstaff could tell and sat us immediately, after giving us waters to drink while we waited. Ordered the cheese plate with a side of meat. The meat came out maybe five minutes late and the waiter took it off my bill.
The cheese was all amazing and I even got my picky boyfriend to try the truffle sheep cheese. The cheese portion size was easily double what I am normally served in NYC.
 If I lived in San Fran this is a place I would go to often for fun date nights and delicious cheese plates 

Thank you!
author: Alli D.

description:
We had dinner and drinks here last night and it was awesome.

Wine is served in small beakers that seemed like 2-3 servings and the wine that was recommended was very good.

The food (lasagna and pizza) were very well prepared and really tasty. We were even offered bread to soak up the lasagna!

The service was very prompt and polite and the atmosphere inside was great - buzzing with people but no loud music or overly loud guests.
author: Tom N.

description:
After speaking to the manager about our unfortunate service, we went back and had a completely different experience.  Our service was perfect, attentive, and well-timed.  Our server was very helpful with the wine and cheese lists.  

We had an amazing cheese plate and great bottle of wine.  Our entrees were also delicious.  We had a pasta with squash that was like a sweet and complex macaroni and cheese.  We also ordered the spicy salami pizza, which had the perfect balance of sweet and spice -- the combination of the honey and Calabrian chilies is well thought out.

I am really happy that the manager highly encouraged us to go back.  UVA will remain on the short list of local haunts.
author: Kiki I.

description:
Service was really slow and very disorganized.

We had to wait for long for almost everything.

Food is strictly okay, did not feel like an Italian restaurant at all :(

Try to find a better option.
author: Sam M.

description:
This was a great little find in the lower Haight. The service was great, the atmosphere was a little classy, but the servers were super casual, and the food was delicious. 

We got stuffed shells with a Barbera pairing. Both were amazing, and the Chopped Salad appetizer was great. It's not the cheapest place, but it's not crazy expensive. Highly recommend!
author: Charlie Y.

description: This place was adorable, very small and kind of local looking. We were looking for somewhere to eat on a Friday night and walked up to this place with no reservation and were able to eat at the bar (which we were perfectly fine with). The bartender was extremely nice & the food was good! I got the stuffed shells which I honestly expected to come with more based on the price but regardless it was super good (the tomato sauce was amazing). My fiend got the pesto pasta and it was incredible!!! She said it was a little too salty for her but I thought it was perfect. All in all great place!! Dark lighting so if you're trying to Instagram think again ;)
author: Cara N.

description:
BLUF: Go for the group dining!! 

I went on a Saturday night for dinner for the first time to Uva Enoteca. We made a reservation for a group of 6, and ended up having an extra person join and the waitstaff was super accommodating, even though the restaurant was already pretty crowded.

We were pleasantly surprised to find that Uva Enoteca offered a great deal for group dining, which included several courses, including: a variety of salads, cheeses and charcuterie, several pastas and pizzas and a couple different desserts.
