The lasagna bolognese was a highlight, and all the pizzas were delicious.  It was a fantastic sampling of foods, and very much worth the price of $30 per person. We were STUFFED at the end. Our server was very attentive and gracious too.

I'm so happy I live in the neighborhood -- I'll definitely be back!
author: Olivia S.

description:
Wow, this was a great experience.

I was here brunch and really enjoyed everything we had:

-Biscuits with Gravy and Scrambled Eggs - these were some of the best I've ever had.  A gourmet twist on a Southern classic, the gravy had a very slight sweetness to it that helped to make it much more interesting.

-Egg Sandwich - the was such a simple dish: eggs on toast with a salsa spread - the use of quality ingredients really made this stand-out since it all tasted so fresh.

I would definitely come back here!
author: Ken G.

description:
Such a great find and cozy atmosphere. Wonderful pizzas but the real star was the smoked burrata with maldon sea salt, olive oil & toasted crostini. If they have it, make sure you order it. They only make a certain number a day and it is incredible. 

Definitely a more casual, cozy spot for a couple or place to grab a bite and a bottle (or two) with friends. Highly recommend!
author: Alison C.

description:
Is this a pop-up restaurant? It was so understaffed for brunch, even I wanted to help. 

So we were basically invisible to the server. I know there's a drought but asking for water five times is a bit too much. Meanwhile the white groups around us had carafes of water (just a warning to the brown ones reading Yelp). 

Thank god for Jesus! Oh not actual Jesus! Jesus is the nice guy working who actually gave us service. He needs a promotion from a bar back. He was the only redeeming part of the service here.   

The food is good. I'm not a hater and I'll give credit when it's due. I got the boar lasagna and it was it lived to what was expected. 

In summary, the operations of this place needs a redo. So much potential, but for me to have to flag a waiter down like a Virgin America plane, I can't.
author: Guillermo M.

description: I went during the bottomless bilini brunch. The drinks were great and strong! The food was awesome, my friend got the egg toast and I got the stuffed shells. Both of us were really happy with the service and how attentive the staff was. Will definitely be coming back!
author: Delaney B.

description:
Absolutely love UVA. Perfect for a large group or a small date. I can't speak to the experience of groups ~4 or happy hours.

I went back for the third time for a group dinner. Their $27 family style just can't be beat. The antipasti was so good that we were full from that and the salami and cheese (the corn, chickpea crostini, prosciutto, humboldt's fog were faves). The pizza was as good as I remembered but the boar bolognese tasted like it changed from last year. And unfortunately, my favorite dish, the caccio e pepe is no longer on the menu.

The dessert was heavenly - ice cream with some sort of chocolate caramel cream concoction. I don't even like chocolate and I was fighting with people over it.

For the price, I would come back to Uva any time!
author: Alice Z.

description:
Hmmm not convinced ... The octopus plate was good but the pasta ones were just "meh": 1 star down. The bill came quite expensive for what we ate: another star down. 

Might come back for the brunch on a weekend but wont eat here for diner anymore. Just take a lyft and go to north beach.
author: Margaux M.

description: A cozy spot to get some delicious Italian food. I'm definitely a fan. The meatballs were fantastic. My only complaint is that it was a bit louder than I expected.
author: Derry N.

description:
We came here for a nice meal before a show at the The Independent.  I had seen this place before while walking around the Haight and was curious.  They had a really good happy hour with wine, beer and appetizer bites - good deal! So we ordered one of everything of the bites (corn, pizza, pasta), plus we ordered meatballs for extra protein.  We had several glasses of wine, caught up on girly chat and enjoyed our food - all tasty good and satisfying!  Service was real nice and friendly too.  

There was a birthday party in the front area with a long table enough for probably about 16-18 people.  They brought their own decorations and it was private enough that they had their own area without being too enclosed, and it was nice and bright - a cool place for a group get-together.  

I would come back here again for the happy hour, food, drink and service!  We were very happy and full, plus our meal was reasonably priced.  Also, The Independent was a quick 10-minute walk away so this was perfect!
author: Maile N.

description:
Dinner = yummy, especially the pizzas, but you can't go wrong with the pasta, either. 
Brunch = awesome (biscuits and gravy!!)
Bottomless bellinis at brunch = delicious (and generous...)
Wine list = extensive

You should definitely try this place on your next date night or girl's brunch.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of this hood, but this is one of those places that is changing my mind.  It's the type of restaurant you could expect to find in the heart of Italy, on some side street where the locals go.  It's modern, casual and very warm and friendly from the staff to the food, we had a great time. 

We arrived and I was promptly seated, while my hubby tried to find parking.  I was offered wine, food, the staff was super friendly and not irritated at all that we were running late.  

We ordered, some wine, beets and goat cheese, the lamb sausage and pizza.  Everything was great, simple, clean ingredients that taste great, you know exactly what's in the dish, no surprises or sophistication but just great Italian food.

The portions were nice, great for sharing, the beets were sweet, the lamb sausage spicy, the pizza just out of the oven.  Yummy!

My husband ordered the chocolate mouse, even though we were full, he was craving something sweet.  It was perfect, not too sweet, great flavor, and yes I'm a chocolate lover, specifically bitter sweet. 

A few things to maybe smooth out, the food came out really fast, it could have been spaced out better, especially since the table was small and it was hard to maneuver. 

The place was also a bit stuffy, and it was a cold night out.  That I didn't like at all, I luckily wore layers, but sitting in tank top and being warm is not a great atmosphere, they need ventilation.  

I definitely recommend to give this place a try, whether you're on a date or out with friends, or just want to sit at the bar.  The prices are also very reasonable, nothing was above $20.
author: Inga W.

description: Love the pastas and the appetizers. The Kale salad and the seasonal pastas (we had butternut squash) are great.
author: Matt R.

description:
I found this place on Open Table and decided to go with it because it was reasonably priced, had a great menu, and was a 1K point place on OT. I was not disappointed. 

The pizza here is amazing! I highly recommend it and service was decent as well. I would come back.
author: Charles L.

description:
I really enjoyed my dinner here. They had some interesting selection of cheeses and I love the fixin's they give you with it (honey, jam, almonds, and some bread). Pizza was solid, and their boar lasagna was VERY tasty.

It sounds like their happy hour menu is one of the best in town, so I'll definitely be returning to try that!
author: Kazu O.

description: Love the ambiance here. Great wine menu, great service, delicious menu. I like sitting at the bar.
author: Gina R.

description: Turns out everyone who works there is incredibly awkward. I stopped getting pizza "to-go" from here because Pauline's is better. I've been to Uva twice for brunch, the food is good, but the service is horrendous.
author: Sara H.

description:
A sweet little place (mostly 2 and 4 tops) tucked away on Haight street (you could walk right by it)

We spilt 3 things.  The meatballs (our favorite and a generous portion) the bolognese pasta and a pizza with salami, pepperoni, onions and other items. I had requested it be well done, and the edges were charred, but it was still too sloppy to pick up. Good yes, but not the best, I like to eat my pizza with my hands not a fork and knife.

The pasta was very good, I would have liked more sauce but it was subtle and I like the rosemary (I'm adding that to my sauce next time!)

Our waiter Boris  was efficient and nice.
author: Amy W.

description:
My wife and I had the most interesting Lyft ride to this restaurant.  I won't get into it now but the awkwardness of the moments we spent in the car as the driver attempted to launch Pandora and keep the GPS going, created tons of dinner conversation.

We decided on Uva because we were both craving a cheese plate of superior quality.  And Uva did not disappoint.  They also serve great wines at reasonable prices.  I was impressed by the ability of our bartender to assist with the cheese selection process.  We also tasted their pasta happy hour special.  We both appreciate perfectly cooked, al dente pasta.  As my wife noted, the dish had two or three tablespoonfuls of sauce but that was more than plenty.  Perfection accomplished.  The bar is comfortable and the space is inviting and warm

Chocolate boudino rounded off a perfectly simple, fun early dinner while in San Francisco.
author: John L.

description:
Have been here many times with large and small groups. Food is always yummy as well and reliably good. The bottomless bellinis on the weekend are great for large brunch groups.

I like that this place isn't overly crowded or difficult to get reservations at, but at the same time always has good food, nice staff and a nice ambiance inside.
author: Ray Q.

description: Came in for drinks and had to experience rude host!! How much does delicious food or reviews matter, if they can't treat customers with decency and courtesy? Zero.
author: Alex P.

description:
Came here for brunch with a large group, so we were forced to order off their group dining menu. Order 2 types of breakfast items, 2 types of lunch foods and they'll bring out 10 total plates for the table to share.

We got 2 challah french toast, 3 truffled egg toast, 2 stuffed shells, 3 margherita pizzas.

Oh, and a table full of bottomless bellinis (sparkling wine and peach Kerns nectar juice)

Holy moly.

The antipasto and salads were good - charcuterie and cheeses with olives and toppings. The salad was romaine hearts with caesar dressing and parmesan and radish. Both very good but I wouldn't have ordered them if they didn't automatically come with.

The truffled egg toast is not at all what I expected - it's a single piece of super thick, crusty toast with truffled cheese on top and a truffled runny egg yolk in the middle. Served with zucchini. 5/5 for sure - highly recommend.

Challah french toast - I'm not a big sweets for breakfast kinda gal, and I admit that it was pretty good. It was definitely way too sweet for my taste though, but others thought it was perfect.

Margherita pizza & stuffed shells were good, but not any better than anything you can make yourself at home. 3.5/5

One nice thing is that they actually were very conscious of keeping our bottomless bellinis full, which is tough to do during a busy brunch hour with so many people to accommodate.
author: Amy Y.

description: I've been here twice outta convince... both a mistake!  I got the specials...  house red wine- meh!?!; olives tasted old- meh?!; bread is definitely old and note to UVA it's better serve butter & salt when the bread is tough; the pasta was UNDERCOOKED and your prepare meatballs were cool in the center... at least ilthey were properly stored so I won't get sick... shame on you but for whatever reason NOTHING is worth the $$ other than s sausage (rosamundes) & of course good beee at s good price (Toronado)
author: colleen ..

description:
Came with a good friend and shared 2 entrees and wine. Made a reservation because the place is popping. Loved the atmosphere. Quaint little place.

The Boar Lasagna was the best!!! So delicious, creamy, meaty, and good! It makes me drool thinking about it. The pizza was also delicious we got the one with the spicy salame and mozzarella. You can't go wrong with any of the pizzas.
author: Jenny C.

description: We arrived at 4 30pm on Sunday afternoon.  Seating was immediate and service excellent. Great house chianti and delicious food. I loved the cauliflower salad. We also ordered the meatballs, cold cuts,  pasta, and pizza. Delcious!
author: Dan A.

description:
Had a nice dinner at a nice price tag thanks to LivingSocial. Would never have noticed this tiny little wine bar that serves pretty good Italian food in a strip of more dive bar type spots.

My friend and I tried:

~~PASTA $15~~
* RAGU - 3.5 stars
(Orecchiette, wild boar, tomato, sweet onions, parmigiano)
The wild boar was tender and delicious. The pasta was soft and tasty.

* AUTUNNO - 2.5 stars
(Orecchiette, upland cress, tarragon, pumpkin seeds, butternut squash sauce)
All the ingredients sound good but together it just made for a very bland and plain dish.

~~DRINKS $8~~
* ULTRAS - 3 stars
(Birra bionda, ginger beer, lime, lemongrass & tarragon)
Got this because I LOVE ginger. Its flavor was pretty good, but I couldn't taste any alcohol! And I usually don't complain about this because I don't like the flavor of alcohol, but I'm not going to spend $8 on a fancy Ginger Ale...

~~DESSERTS~~
* Pot de creme - 3 stars
Yummy dark flavor. More light & fluffy then a really heavy dense chocolate - I prefer the latter. Came with a chocolate shortcake on the side, which we didn't realize would be basically be a repeat of the shortcake dessert we also ordered.

* Shortcake - 2.5 stars
The shortcake was very similar to the one on the side of the pot de creme. It is very dense, a little on the hard side. This one had a berry filling. The creme fraiche (or whatever) on top was really nice, but the berry sauce surrounding the shortcake tasted artificial and too sweet.
author: Ziyan C.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF! Such a cozy, romantic vibe in here. I've always loved everything I've ordered and I never skip out on dessert. Definitely a perfect spot to go on a date or catch up with old friends. 5 stars for ambiance and tasty food.
author: Shannon L.

description: While we had a walk with my friend, we got very hungry. We stopped by and it turned to be a really nice place. I hope its not only because we were starving. Everything seemed fresh and very traditional.
author: Liz P.

description:
First, the staff doesn't look like they work there, no identifiable marks of any kind! 
Second, as good and weird as the food is, this place can not serve the amount of people they're trying to attract...
author: DVolt B.

description: Mmh. Not so convinced unfortunately. Sad, I thought it would be a good pizza, but in the end it was not tasty. The service is good though, and the local very nice!
author: Alex G.

description:
We had an amazing dinner,
Everything on the menu extremely delicious!
Had a really great time there with my friends,
Highly recommended!
author: Michael J.

description: Went here for a quick glass of wine. Great service, reasonable prices. (I paid $11 for 8 oz of Lambrusco and the most expensive carafe would be around $15) It's a bit on the loud side (I figure that this is cause of the bottomless Bellinis on the weekends ($15 for 2.5 hours)
author: Jellie S.

description:
Fine Italian dining in an unlikely location (Lower Haight).

Really killer cheese plates, the chickpea crostini, cauliflower app and mushroom pizza are all favorites. Also, a great place for brunch with no waiting. Reasonable prices as well. As someone who's dined here 20+ times, I will say that the service used to be a bit hit or miss but I haven't had an issue in the past 10 visits.
author: Robby W.

description: Loved the ambience of the restaurant. The food was easy and great. Would recommend to a friend.
author: Amy L.

description: I found Uva Enoteca when I searched "Best Italian Restaurants in SF" and it did not disappoint! The Carne charcuterie platter in particular was fantastic and the pizza was incredible as well. I would absolutely come back again!
author: Rachael B.

description: Tasty food, delicious wine, great atmosphere and friendly staff. As a solo traveler it was nice to sit at the bar without being too conspicuous sitting alone at a table. The wine list was long and from my vantage point I saw the bar tender was very knowledgable and all the wine recommendations were spot on, including mine.
author: Suzy D.

description: First time here! My husband and I love it. Great food, great service and great wine. We order the antipasti, good surprise! And of course we will come back. Ps: finally good coffee in San Francisco.
author: Daniela C.

description:
Came here for my birthday dinner with a pretty big crowd of 12. I was able to book the table with only a week of notice, and add on people with no issues. SCORE!

With that many people, we had to go with the prix-fixe, but they do family style with more than enough food for the number of people. The highlight was the cheese board.. which admittedly they do not make in-house... but it is VERY good. The pastas were okay, and the pizzas were very bland. Dessert was good but I was quite drunk by then.

Our server was pretty cold.. and we weren't even rowdy!
author: Vivian H.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night for a date :)
Make sure to make reservations even if it's a weekday!

Server we had was so friendly and personable. She really added a nice touch to my dining experience.  Answered questions, gave personal opinion and was quick.

We ordered:
-cauliflower : a cold salad. very very yummy. appetizing for sure - lemony, capers, the perfect bite. not overly cooked/mushy. huge portion!

-mushroom pizza : my favorite for the night!! a great amount of mushrooms on pizza. chili flakes / chili oil complimented this pizza wonderfully. yum yum

-stuffed pasta shell with ricotta : ricotta was divine. pasta shell was cooked perfectly. tomato sauce was very flavorful. 4 huge shells. don't be fooled - it's filling!!!

wine: Riesling - they had a great one here and the pour is GENEROUS at Uva Enoteca. I definitely walked out smiley and rosey cheeked ;)  

Will come back! Can't wait to try other things on this menu. A nice spot in this neighborhood/Lower Haight!!
author: Selina W.

description:
What a gem! I was meeting up with a friend for dinner and he suggested this place. It's a super cute restaurant in the Haight and the best part is - they have an AWESOME happy hour! For such a cute place, I didn't expect to be able to get $2 beer which wasn't Bud Light. They also have wine for $4 - there's only one option for the beer and wine but who cares? It's $2! And delicious!

They also had happy hour options for their regular menu items. You save about $4-$5 per dish during happy hour. We ended up getting a Margherita pizza and pasta to share - both were $10 (usually $15 & $14 respectively). The pizza was thin crust and had just the right amount of basil and mozzarella. The pasta pomodoro had a surprise kick to it but it was also yummy. I did think the pasta was a little undercooked for my taste but I tend to overcook my pastas. I took some leftover pasta to my boyfriend though and he really enjoyed it. 

They have a small menu but the items I had were tasty and I just can't get over the $2 yummy beer. Come for their happy hour!!
author: Jennifer T.

description: I had dinner here yesterday with a friend and I was astonished by the poor service. The waiter came to us only to take our order, deliver our food, and did not even offer us water in the meantime or check how our meal was going. We would constantly be approached by staff trying to clear our plates when we were clearly still eating. To end the experience, a member of the staff came to ask us to leave because they had another reservation waiting. I find this very rude. It was my first visit and last, which is a shame because I live quite close to there. As for the food, the Spicy Salami Pizza was quite tasty but comparable to that of Little Star, which I think has a much more laid back ambiance.
author: Karina L.

description:
Advice: Don't get their margherita pizza: we had to send ours back because it was badly charred...then we received one that was still pretty charred...tasted like charcoal,,,it may be because the amount of toppings are making it bake quicker. If you order one, get their mushroom pizza. The garlic is perfect, and it wasn't charred on the bottom at all. It was amazing.

The server was very knowledgeable about pairing cheeses with wines, and helped us choose a few for our cheese board. Attentive service, and they were good enough to take our burnt pizza back, and we got a replacement, which seemed a bit doughy, but was much better than burnt. It's a bit overpriced for our tastes; we had ordered a good deal of appetizers and entrees for our party of 5, along with wine, so it added up. It may be a good place to take a date to impress them, however. Just don't order the margherita pizza, to be safe.
author: Eli B.

description: Love this place. For some reason when other places around have a 45 minute wait, they are able to find a seat for you in no time. We've been here a couple of times and all the food that we've tried has been amazing. By far our favorite Italian and go to pizza place in the neighborhood.
author: Priya B.

description:
Uva Enoteca is nothing short of spectacular. We started with the Prosciutto Cotto(which practically melted in your mouth) and a couple of cheeses for an appetizer. Out of all the tasty cheeses, the Pecorino Moliterno w/ truffles has got to be one of the most delicious cheeses I've had in my life. For pasta, I highly recommend the Boar Bolognese w/ fusili con buco and parmigiano reggiano if you're looking for a pasta dish that's tasty, confident but subtle and definitely not overpowering. If you're a chocolate lover, for dessert the chocolate Budino w/ caramel sauce, whipped cream & marcona almonds is a must order. The oatmeal cookie with vanilla gelato & caramel sauce is the Ritz Carlton of ice cream cookie sandwiches. 

This is my ideal date spot. The food from start to finish is pure delight. There was fantastic service and it's a intimate cozy place perfect for my love and I.
author: Caroline N.

description:
I thought I was starting to like this place and kind of thought of it as my 'go-to' cozy Italian restaurant. I think it's still nice, but I'll stick to dinner service only.

I came here for brunch once, and had a pretty bad experience. Fortunately, I had thought to make reservations before arriving, so we didn't have to wait in line. However, we waited at the door for someone to seat us for about 15 minutes. I think they were short-staffed that day, but it was still pretty ridiculous.

Secondly, after we were seated, we had to wait another 20 minutes to place an order. The server forgot milk for my coffee and was not very attentive (water glasses were empty for long stretches of time). Again, I figured they were short-staffed, so I understand that things get busy, but we still didn't have that great of an experience.

Lastly, when the food came out, it was very poorly cooked. I got the frittata, which was small, dry and flavorless. My friend got the baked eggs with tomatoes, and the eggs were WAY overcooked. The yolks were completely hard on the inside and there was a plasticky film on the bottom of the eggs where they had been fried for too long. I looked over at another table and it looked like their eggs were a little better cooked, so I guess it's hit-or-miss, but I was just surprised that they would be okay serving such inconsistent dishes. The sauce tasted can-like as well. We were not very happy with the food, and felt like it was a waste of money.

Their dinner service (at least on weeknights) is a lot better, and I really enjoy the charcuterie and polpette. I'd come her for dinner, but skip the brunch.
author: Rhea K.

description:
Lasagna was good! Pizza wasn't great. Good wine. 

We had reservations, but we still were asked to wait 15 minutes. Then we were sat at a awkward table away from all the other seating areas. It was in a walkway beside the bar and the recycling bin. It was  annoying to listen to glass breaking and have waiters talking loudly to the bar tender. 

We didn't have a waiter. The bar tender and host waited on us. It as awkward. We had to ask for things over and over. 

Overall it seemed like a nice place, but the service was bad cause they seemed understaffed. Also, that table sucked. They should get rid of it. Considering we had reservations, it was pretty lame to have to wait for a seat and then get sat there and have spotty service.
author: Alyssa P.

description:
Cute little place with great food and pizza! but I can see it falling off my radar as there was a mix of good food and good staff interaction but unfortunately just not enough to get it a spot in my regular rotation. 
But I will keep them on my bench! 
Stay dry everyone!
author: Leonard H.

description:
I love the food at Uva! The lasagna is extremely delicious. 

Unfortunately, the waiter knew little about the wines on the menus. All of the wines are Italian varietals with names you will not recognize. I asked for a wine that would be similar to a cabernet, and the waiter recommended a merlot. Um, no, those are not similar. I assume it was because the merlot was the most expensive wine by the glass at $19. I really don't like being up-sold, especially at a restaurant. And obviously an Italian restaurant would have wines that are more like a cabernet than a merlot.
author: Jamon B.

description:
I liked Uva. Great cheeses, perfectly al dente buccatini with a nice wine selection in lively Lower Haight location. I will mention though the Cacio e Pepe was a tad on the too spicy side (husband is used to my Korean mother's spicy cooking but this dish had him sweating!) and the pizza got slightly too salty in certain bites. 

Our server was efficient (despite doubling up on duties and acting also as host that evening) and he even remembered the name of one of the cheeses we had selected when I asked him the name of it much later (so I can remember to order it next time) when I expected him to respond that he didn't remember it. 

Another plus - the prices are decent for an SF establishment.
author: Esther A.

description:
I had dinner here last night and loved the cozy, warm, intimate atmosphere for a Sunday night. 
We had two salads, the Mixed Kale and the Bresaola Arugula salad. The Kale salad had great flavors but a little too salty for my taste. The Bresaola Arugula salad was great! My kind of salad (aka light on the "salad" and heavy on the meats and cheeses).

Followed the salads with the Margherita pizza as my philosophy is that you have to judge all pizza joints by the quality of their Margherita pizza. Uva nails it! Delicious sauce and crust but the fior di latte mozzarella is the real stand out on this pizza. 

The service was fine. 

Overall a great neighborhood date night spot that won't break the bank. Will be back to try pastas and desserts for sure.
author: Allie D.

description:
Uva Enoteca's pizza is what pizza-dreams are made of!

I came across this restaurant on a Saturday night when searching for Italian near by. We got there around 7 and managed to get a table, but it got really crowded shortly after. They had a variety of interesting appetizers, but we decided on the burrata and persimmon which far exceeded expectations.

For entrees we ordered the baked butternut squash rigatoni and the meatball pizza. The butternut squash dish was very tasty, but the pizza really stole the show! The crust was thin, doughy and cooked perfectly. There was the perfect amount of sauce, cheese and meatball, and the combination of everything really blew me away. I did not expect this little restaurant to have what I consider the best pizza I've ever had, and am already planning my return!
author: Staci L.

description: Great wine bar with friendly staff and good happy hour. $5 wine (they only have 1 kind that varies) and $2 beer. I've been here many years ago and also enjoyed the food. seating at tables in front, in back or at the bar.
author: Christine L.

description:
This is a great date spot. We go often and always get great service. The staff has good wine pairing recommendations.
The cheese plate is delicious! Especially the honey goat cheese. 
The meatballs are some of the best I've ever had.
Also my first time trying a fried egg on top of pizza-- definitely try it.
author: Haley K.

description: I brought my girlfriend here for her birthday and now it's our favorite place to eat in the city. There happy hour is great. There pizza is great. The waiters are incredibly knowledgable about which wines match well with which meals. It's small and it feels like a special environment that not many people know about.
author: Kareem A.

description: Pizza was decent.  Under normal circumstances, somewhere between 3 and 4 stars.  Meat was quality, but the bread was a bit on the cardboard side.  The real downsides are the prices and arrogance of this place. Everything is about $20.  Mini pizza, $20.  4 tiny meatballs, $20.  So overpriced.  So overrated.  Arrogant staff too cool to care about you.  Oh, and the happy hour ends around 5pm.  I suppose that's helpful to those who live next door and work from home.  Don't waste your time.
author: mario k.

description:
Cute San Francisco eatery - my fiance and I went here for dinner last Friday night.

For our first course we did a combination of appetizers - they were all just okay - if i went back I would skip them.

we then shared a pizza - it was AMAZING; asparagus, two types of cheese, and potato, with a sourdough crust!!!

We finished off with a Guinea Hen. To me a lot of poultry is very similar. It wasn't as gamy as I remembered it and quiet delicious.

The service was quick but a bit stand off-ish we never said more then hi and our order.

Wine list was good.
author: Drew P.

description: One of my all time favorite restaurants. Excellent wine list, mostly great service, awesome Italian charcuterie and reasonable prices. Great classic Italian bistro decor. Will always recommend.
author: Kate E.

description:
What a fantastic dinner spot in Lower Haight!

The maître d started a great evening by seating us immediately despite the fact that the other half of our party was late and the restaurant was packed (note that we had a reservation). Walking to our table, I immediately appreciated how Uva Enoteca makes great use of its space. The restaurant is small and charming, but we didn't feel like we were sitting on top of anyone.

The wine selection was a bit limited, and the price floor for bottles was on the higher side (~$50). That said, the two bottles we ordered were fantastic. We ordered a few appetizers for the table (bresaola, persimmons with burrata, chickpea crostina: all delicious), and each couple split a pasta and a secondi. In my and my girlfriend's case, we shared the puttanesca, which I'd give a solid B, and the meatballs, which I'd give an A-. We couldn't resist dessert, which ended up being a budino and an affogato. Both desserts were nothing short of excellent. All of the food, maybe minus the puttanesca, I would absolutely recommend. 

The meal was perfect, made even better by great company, great service, and a great atmosphere. Grazie mille, Uva Enoteca!
author: Matt T.

description:
I love this place! I love this place! I love this place! I've now eaten here twice for dinner- once on a date and once on a frate (see my Hops and Hominy review, it will make more sense then). I live in Pac Heights- but if you wanna meet at Uva? I'm there.

It's small, it's loud. It's like a little bit of Italy decided to move to the Haight. Don't ask me why, but they made that decision- and I fully support it.

Both times I've gone I've ordered the Pomodoro. Yes, I know- quite simple. But hey- Uva Enoteca gets it. You don't mess with perfection. And this my friends? Perfection in pasta form!

While I can't remember what my date ordered (something seafood/pasta based) I know my frate ordered the lasagna. He honestly wouldn't stop talking about it for weeks! For the record, this is a man that rarely leaves SOMA...and yet he went back THE NEXT WEEK to have it again! 

Can't wait to take friends and family here!
author: Annalise F.

description: This is an adorable little Italian place in the Lower Haight. I was happily surprised with the romantic ambience and the attentive service. The smoked burrata appetizer is not to be missed! Wouldn't recommend sitting next to the cheeses though- it's a bit smelly. All in all, a delicious Italian meal with reasonable portion sizes and great ambience. Keep in mind this is not cheap- we spent about $80 on one appetizer, two glasses of wine and two entrees. Definitely would recommend trying this place if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Kerry R.

description:
Worst service I ever had
The waiters are so rude and I will never come back here again
They are confuse and also made me and my fiends feel so bad
author: Fernanda A.

description: Great place! 4.5 stars.  We live in the neighborhood and come here frequently for really great pizza. I love the margherita pizza + calabrian chiles and arugula. I also like the kale salad and pasta pomodoro. They also have an impressive wine list and very knowledgeable bartenders. Cozy and great for date night or small groups.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I have got to say right off the bat that I have not had this yummy of food or this good of service together in one delightful package in San Francisco for a while. 

A friend I was having drinks with across the street at Toronado had suggested that I might want to try this place out for dinner before I caught a flight out of SFO and that they had a great happy hour. Due to the fact that is was literally across the street from where I was I thought to myself, "Why not." 

Service was spot on and the bartender Beth was so beautiful and sweet. 

I had the happy hour riesling which for five bucks for a very generous pour was great. The brushette they had on the happy hour menu for a mere four bucks and honest to God it was one of the best brushette I have had for a while and was also a generous size. Just because I was feeling like a fatty and had skipped lunch I went for the Coppa Pizza as well but was only able to take down half of it. The pizza had Coppa, montasio cheese, and a bechamel sauce with green apple slices on top. The crust was light and crisp. I loved the interior, beautiful without being pretentious. 

I will definitely go out of my way in the future to dine at this establishment again.
author: Rebecca T.

description: I contacted Uva Enoteca about making a large reservation for brunch (30 people), and Boris got right back to me with information about prices and options. We ended up reserving the back of the restaurant and they served us a selection of dishes family style. Everything was awesome: meat and cheese platters, salad, eggs over potato with a tasty marinara, French toast with berries and whipped ricotta, and margarita pizzas. We also got carafes of bottomless bellini's and some fabulous coffee drinks. Although it was a tight fit with the seating, we are all family so we didn't mind getting cozy. The general manager, staff, and cooks were so kind and accommodating, and all and all it was a reasonably affordable event considering the abundance and variety of food and drinks. I look forward to eating there again when I have a chance, and I really appreciate the great job they did to make it such a special (and delicious) day for my family!
author: Madeline E.

description: The meatballs were good. The stuffed shells were okay. Service was kinda slow. Overall, not worth the price for the somewhat small portion size / taste.
author: Christopher B.

description:
This is just an initial impression review, might revise after I have been back. I only had a beer (the amber) and the Meatball, sweet peppers,fresh mozzerella, tomato pizza. 

The pizza was really good, I want to try other things on their menu (like the wild boar ragu everyone is talking about) but there's a good chance I will order the meatball pizza again too because it was great. The ambiance was also nice, probably a good date place.
author: Ely L.

description: Consistent deliciousness! I frequent this place for brunch, lunch and dinner. I ate an entire pizza to myself, once. Just once. The spicy salami and I added a fried egg with arugula. I suggest you do the same :)
author: Parasto S.

description:
If there's one thing I dislike more than the copious amounts of poo on the sidewalks of SF, it's waiting in line to eat for more than 30 minutes. So when Kat & Mark suggested this little spot with no wait, I pounced. 

We walked in, were seated right away and the moment our butts hit the bench, we had a carafe of water. Besides the incident of the missing Coca Cola, everything was outstanding. The server recommended a mid range bottle of wine to go with our wild boar ragout. Thick bucatini noodles with lean boar and tangy tomato. Kat had the potato and brussel pizza and it had my favorite of all cheeses: burratta. Swoon. 

Delicious food, low key atmosphere, good wine and great friends made this the first of hopefully many successful and fabulous SF stops.
author: Kelly S.

description:
We were here a group of 12 people and we took the group dining $30 per person.
Worth any price with the variety of options to choose unlimited food and dessert.
I enjoy eating and dining.
Fast service and a nice area
author: Andrew B.

description:
A solid four stars for the service, boar lasagna and the semifreddo dessert!  These were all delicious and our server was really pleasant and attentive. 

The corn appetizer was a little bland, I quickly discovered I'm not one for raw corn.  The margherita pizza also was under seasoned but we enjoyed the hh price.

Cute/fun spot for some wine and pasta!
author: Brianna M.

description:
Great place to catch a bite. Just a few blocks away from the pink ladies, Almo Square. We had the the "Happy Hour" special of a margarita pizza and penne pasta with anti pasta salad. The house beer was $2.50 and house wine $6. Not a bad deal. Dinner for 2 was a little under $40.

Everything was delicious!
author: Gabby D.

description: I love that this place feels so neighborhoody.  This place is super friendly and everyone is very welcoming.  We got the beets and cheese plate to start, but great dishes.  Love that the cheese plate also comes with nuts, jam, and honey.  We also go the lasagna, and a pizza.  I completely admit that I'm super particular with pizzas after discovering del popolo.  However I really like the pizza here.  Definitely want to come back for happy hour.  (Love that they have happy hour every day!)
author: Tiffany C.

description: Uva is my second home.  I love, love, love it!  Amazing food, warm, attentive customer service (I mean, half of the staff know me by name when I come in), and just a general comfortable, welcoming, homey vibe.  If I could move it to my living room and make it free, I'd probably quit my job and never leave.
author: Emily S.

description:
Came here on a Friday night to celebrate my best friend's birthday. We (3 of us) was looking for a place that was intimate and classy, but not too quiet that it'd be shunned upon if we raised our voices. After all, we DID plan to spend a lot of time here since we were looking forward to ordering a whole bottle of wine. 

Made reservations and had no problems getting seated within a couple minutes. Our server/hostess was super friendly and she definitely made our experience here much less intimidating (must I remind you that I'm NOOOO wine connoisseur!). She was very attentive when asking what sorts of wine we usually enjoy - whether we prefer light/heavy, acidic/mellow, etc + even gave us samples of the anglionico and cannonau to tend to our EXTREME indecisiveness (so sorry!). Totally give her props for being so patient and accommodating! 

We were all a bit full from dinner, so we decided to just pair our wine with some cured meats. Tried 3 per recommendations -- Speck (my favorite), Salame Rosetta, and Coppa Dolce - umbria. All were fantastic; the meats were moist, well-spiced, and delicate enough to practically melt in your mouth!

You might run into trouble when finding parking on Fri/Sat butttttt I'd still come back for ya, UVA. Cute and cozy date night for two or with a small group of friends --will come back for their their cheeses, pizza, and pastas next time!
author: Regina C.

description:
Cozy small place for a casual meal. I came here for the first time with my friends for lunch and even though it's a really small spot, they took our reservation for eight. We ran into horrid traffic and didn't make it until at least half an hour past our reservation time, but we called them right when it was our reservation time and told them we would be late and they happily said they would hold our table. It was probably because they weren't very busy but still nice of them to do so. 

We ordered family style and got to try several different plates. The biscuit and gravy was good, it was one of my friend's faves. Other plates included meatball sandwich, ham pizza, bacon, French toast, some potato in red tomato sauce and some others. I really liked how some plates came with a side of arugula salad. The French toast was pretty big and looked more like a big plate of dessert to us so we saved that for last. 

All in all everything was pretty good but I wouldn't say anything really was a favorite. One of their big attractions is probably the endless Bellini's for 2.5 hours. They're really awesome at keeping you topped off too. 

Parking can be a doozie here. Look for parking two blocks down by the homes and just walk over. No parking meters there either. 

If I'm in the area I would come back for a quick bite again.
author: Annissa H.

description:
In keeping the tradition of going to The Independent after xmas to see CRACKER / CAMPER VAN BEETHOVEN, we needed a yummy pre-Cracker dinner & Uva Enoteca was calling our names

Drinkys included some chili / basil / prosecco thingy & boy was it SPICY.....and gewd!  Totally loved it!

Started out w/ the Cheese Course & had:
Truffled Pecorino - OMG this was delish!
Some CA goat cheese that was creamy, soft, spreadable & very mild - it was outstanding
Tallegio - soft & mild - another winner

We each couldn't decide on one entree, so we decided to share the following:
Wild Mushrooms w/ Goat Cheese & thick spaghetti noodles - too much basil for my taste but the bf absolutely loved it

Pasta w/ Pumpkin Seeds & Butternut Squash Sauce - this was my absolute fav!  Super light & pumpkinny but not overpowering the pasta

Dessert was the Pear / Pecan Pie - they lost me on the Orange-infused ice cream but bf liked it a lot

Music in there was absolutely incredible w/ lots of Cure, Smiths, Depeche Mode.....etc.....& I'm a 80s girl all the way, they completely won my heart that night.  This could be a pre-Independent trend starting...
author: Adrienne G.

description:
I went to Uva Enoteca last night and had a pretty good experience. We made a reservation for 6:30pm so it was still empty, but by the time we left at 8:15, it was crowded and there was a wait at the door.

We started with the figs and burrata and I got a ginger soda. A++ on the appetizer! The sweet figs with balsamic and herbs were so amazing alone, and the burrata it just set it completely over. I would highly recommend this. The ginger soda tasted pretty watered down. Maybe they're going for a subtle ginger taste but I would have preferred it to be stronger. 

My friend ordered the boar lasagna and I got the pizza with proscuitto, mozzarella and ricotta. I had a bit of the lasagna - tasted delicious! She ate the whole thing too which is impressive because she's little :)

Pizza was a different story. It was okay but as I ate the middle started to get soggy so the point of each piece was droopy with toppings falling off. I don't think anyone enjoys a flaccid piece of pizza. And also the proscuitto - it tasted like store-bought deli ham. I'm not uppity about food but I was expecting something a bit more impressive from this place.

Lastly we go the chocolate bundino for dessert. OMG. This was so good. I had no idea what we were ordering, but it's like a super thick custard/pudding with whipped cream, caramel and crunchy goodness. We couldn't finish it all but it was amazing.

I wish I'd liked my pizza because it will probably keep me from coming back, even though the place had a nice ambiance and played good old school hip hop (an unexpected surprise).
author: Courtney N.

description:
Good food, pretty close to the authentic Italian. Good wine list, although the dessert wines can be improved. Cozy ambiance, though a little noisy.

Pretty good overall
author: Giorgio R.

description:
If you want good food, wine, service, and atmosphere, then you should dine at Uva Enoteca.  It is an adorable restaurant/wine bar that is perfect for a casual, yet romantic date night!  It is also pretty easy make reservations via OpenTable.  The service was out of this world and their wine knowledge is outstanding.

As far as wine, we told the server to give us a flight of his favorites, which turned out to be great! For dinner, we shared some olives, a mixed cheese plate, mortadella, mixed vegetable antipasti, and the baked eggplant - all of which were very good.  Even though we were stuffed, we ordered the persimmon tart for dessert which was amazing, so definitely save room for dessert!

Between the cozy atmosphere and the ease of getting a reservation, even on Friday nights, I will definitely come back to explore more of the menu at Uva Enoteca.
author: Juliana K.

description:
3.5 stars 

I would SO come back for that meat board. 

You'll find so much meat on that wooden plank than in the Castro on a sunny day!

Clearly, the person who put together their charcuterie plate is not only thoughtful, but awesome as well. They give you 4 different price points so you can try one, three, five or all seven of the cured meats. We ordered the $29 board for 7 choices: Prosciutto di Parma, speck (spicy prosciutto), two different kinds of salumi, mortadella, hot coppa and Bresaola. I may not know Italian very well, but when it comes to salted meats, I am fluent in it.  My favorite of the bunch was the hot coppa -- rich on the palette with hint of spiciness. The Bresaola had a gorgeous deep purple color and loved the cinnamon-y spice it had. They provided us with lots of sliced bread (wish it was a plain baguette instead of the weird bread with dried cherries baked in them which did not go well with the charcuterie) Also, more condiments should be offered such as pickled onions or even cornichons, instead of just the whole grain mustard.  Nevertheless, generous servings filled up all six of us even before our entrees came.

Now, I like all things pasta, but their pasta here --- not the best I've had. I ordered the wild boar ragu with orecchiette pasta but the burnt top made the dainty pasta shells unappetizing. I think they meant to just toast the cheese until it's bubbly, but my friend got the exact same dish and his was too burnt as well. I still dug in and maybe took 4 bites and took the rest of it home. (no, it didn't taste better the next day either) My friends had better luck with their pizzas and other pasta dishes.

Desserts were a vanilla gelato topped with olive oil-sea salt and a pear and anise sorbet. The sorbet wasn't icy enough to be a sorbet, but it had a good anise flavor topped with candied nuts. Also, one dessert should be enough for two people, since they actually give you 3 huge scoops of gelato, the most generous I've seen thus far at an Italian resto.

Our server was good, she made helpful recommendations on navigating their wine list which is filled with Italian varietals. The winery name escapes me but we had a bottle of Sangiovese for only $33 so the mark-up wasn't that bad. She was funny as well and kept on with the corny jokes: "what do gay horses eat?!"  Haaayyyy!!  See? told you she was hilarious.

Uva Enoteca makes for a nice, affordable, "upscale" neighborhood restaurant especially in this part of gritty Lower Haight. I may not order their pasta next time, but that charcuterie board has my name written all over it.
author: Janice C.

description: This place is really good for brunch, and relatively easy to get a table.  Egg sandwich and biscuits in gravy are tasty.  The bellini is also very good, and the staff is always really nice.
author: Christina S.

description:
After my boyfriend and I discovered this place we went 6 times in two months. And it ain't cheap. What makes Uva sooooo amazing are the cheese and meat platters. You have the option to mix a variety of delicious, fresh, delectable meats and cheeses which are accompanied by bread, mustard, honey, jam, and almonds. It's like a little booshie picnic with all your friends! While the pizza wasn't anything to flaunt over, the boar pasta was incredible! Super flavorful- the perfect comfort food. Just grab some red wine and dig in and you're guaranteed to be satisfied. Finally, if you're not so sick of cheese you're going to explode into a pile of cheese goo, I'd say get the 
Burrata, Heirloom Tomatoes, Basil, Croutons, Aged Balsamic Vinega appetizer to split. They mold this dish to perfection. Mmmm just thinking about it now is making my mouth water!

Overall, LOVE Uva and would recommend it to anyone willing to travel to Lower Haight!!
author: Nicole G.

description:
This is my second time being here and I absolutely love the food so I've decided to make sure to write a review this time. 

Great Italian food and great atmosphere.  There is nothing specifically that blows my socks off to write a five star review but I do love the food and will definitely come back. 

The service isn't amazing but it's definitely not terrible.  They don't come by the table very often and you won't leave feeling like service was part of your experience but that doesn't bother me as this doesn't feel like one of those kinds of restaurants.

Thumbs up!
author: Lauren P.

description: This place definitely requires a reservation but we got lucky and found seats at the bar. The service was friendly and the wine was excellent. I ordered the pomodoro, which was basic but very yummy. It had a little bit of spice that was very good. One friend had the shells, which were very plain- nothing special there. My other friend had the lasagna, which was so, so good. We started with a beet salad that was good but not amazing. Overall, the ambiance is great and there is good food and large wine selection. Good for sure, but it's nothing life changing.
author: Jenny W.

description: New place for lunch! Although I've been to Uva many times for dinner, I went today for lunch for the first time. It was delicious! I can't recommend this place enough. The chopped salad was soooo good. Only problem is that I may be craving it again tomorrow!
author: Tasha R.

description:
Overall, a fantastic meal. 

The assorted veggies were fantastic (asparagus, eggplant stew, cauliflower). The boar pasta was perfectly rich and the pork loin with corn, figs, carrots was a huge surprise (far sweeter than I'm usually comfortable with, but surprisingly tasty - really an inspired pairing).

Wines by the glass were also excellent and the waitstaff were great with suggestions.

Unfortunately the whole meal was a bit let down at the end by an awful spiced almond gelato which was so overwhelmingly salty that it was almost inedible. To their credit they acknowledged it as a mistake. Wish we had sent it back though.

Will definitely return!
author: Amy D.

description:
Cute little Italian/wine bar spot in the Lower Haight! There actually aren't too many restaurants in the Lower Haight neighborhood I'd suggest, but I just tried this place out on Saturday and I'd definitely recommend! So if you're looking for a cozy dinner with friends or a good date night, head on over to Uva Enoteca.

A friend and I decided to go here Saturday afternoon, and I was able to go online and make an OpenTable reservation for just a few hours later - impressed! When we arrived at 6:30, the place was nearly empty, but as the night wore on it filled right up. We sat at a 2 person table in the back of the restaurant, and the atmosphere was perfect. It felt lively, but wasn't so loud we couldn't hold a decent conversation across the table. The service was also excellent - our waitress checked in regularly, didn't judge us for bringing a cheapish bottle of wine to a wine bar (or at least, I don't think she did), and also made some great cheese plate recommendations. By the way, if you bring your own wine, corkage fee is $18.

Between the two of us we ordered one pasta dish and the 3-cheese selection cheese plate - Humboldt Fog, La Tur, and a Provolone. Our server actually suggested the provolone and I asked her if it was too mild (I was imagining the kind of provolone you get on a deli sandwich - flavorless). Although I preferred the other two cheeses, it was still delicious and nice to have a variety of flavors. The cheese plate also comes with fig jam, honey, and roasted almonds. Overall really nice! For the pasta, we ordered the puttanesca bianca, and it was okay - I didn't love it. It was nicely spicy, but other than that there just wasn't enough going on. I would have proffered more vegetables in there or something! The pizzas also looked good, so if I come back, I might go for that instead. 

I imagine this spot is also nice for a wine and cheese happy hour, which I'd love to come back to try someday.
author: Lindsey B.

description: Poor service and overpriced food. I had the pasta with tomato sauce which was nothing special, and our waiter did not even offer us water, much less check on our meal. My suggestion would be to hire friendly staff and train them better.
author: Maria V.

description:
I got two of the Living Social deals. One for Brunch and one for Dinner, so I can review both services. :)

First, the brunch mimosa deal was good! I forgot what we paid, but it was botomless. I think it was $12 pp but don't quote me. My boyfriend's meal was great, but I ordered the Margarita pizza and it was not so good. It came out completely doughy. The sauce and cheese looked good, but they also cooked the fresh basil on the pizza. The basil is supposed to go on either after it comes out or only for the last couple minutes. That I could have lived with if the pizza dough wasn't mushy.

The server asked how our meal was and I told her. She very kindly said she would have another one made. Unfortunately, the second pizza was burnt on the bottom and still doughy. At this point I was starving and ate it anyway. I felt like I had to considering i was there on a LS deal anyway. She asked again, and I politely told her that I think they may need to cook the pizza longer at a lower temp (just a suggestion, I knew something needed to be changed). She handled it so well and without any frustration. She also took the pizza off the bill without any request from me. We tipped her over 20% on the original amount. 

Now, for dinner service I went with a friend. We got the happy hour wine and a few of the happy hour specials (food and drinks about $2-$3 cheaper than normal). The food was good, the pizza was cooked better (friend insisted despite my guidance against), and the server was friendly. He said we couldn't combine the LS deal with HH prices. I was a little let down, but didn't make any fuss. We asked if he could just charge us the regular price and use the LS. he did that. The deal only actually ended up take $10 off of $80 that way.

Would I go back again? Maybe for HH drinks and snacks on a weekday, but I wouldn't seek it out.
author: Kristen M.

description:
I live just down the street and walk by all the time. Had dinner here last night for the first time with a friend and was quite impressed. I had the Boar lasagna and split the spicy salami pizza. Both items were pretty damn delicious. I also got a Pilsner with my meal - slightly bummed it wasn't from the tap. 

Service was attentive but not overbearing. No complaints, will be back.
author: Anthony C.

description: Great food and awesome service. We came in and even though we did not have a reservation on a saturday, they found us a spot. Good prices also!
author: Sophie S.

description:
One of my favorite places to eat.
I always have to eat here once every time i visit.  I never get to try the cheese and meat apps, but i do love the Olives.  I think their menu is always changing also.  This time i had the pasta pomodoro, it was pretty plain.  But i do remember have a very delicious pasta the last time i was here.  I think this place is a really hit or miss with their menu.  

I really want to try their meat and cheese appetizers, definitely a place for a foodie or someone that loves Italian wines.  I love having the lambrusco here, its a red chilled sparkling wine, it is to die for.  Unfortunately this time they were out of their Lambrusco, so i settled with a lovely glass of prosecco. 

Their tarts are also delicious, my favorite tart that they had so far is the strawberry tart.  
Definitely worth a try, maybe more in the summer.  

They're also very quick and efficient.  We got in at 8:00 and we left by 9:15.
author: Kristin I.

description:
Cute, cozy, casual restaurant. We tried an appetizer and two pizzas. 

For the appetizer, we chose the Panzanella salad.  It was....meh.  About 70% of the salad was croutons, and it seriously lacked flavor although the small chunks of fresh mozzarella made it tolerable. 

Our first pizza was the Margherita which was delicious!  Thin, fresh, excellent crust, and piping hot.  

The second pizza, The mushroom pizza however, was close to inedible.  Salty, oh so incredibly salty.  We left most of the mushroom pizza untouched.  I would have gladly sent it back IF our server would have checked in on us.

Now for the good part - the wine.  The wines are decent and if you order a glass,  you get the most generous pour on all of Haight.
author: Nikki G.

description:
LOUD. Which is fine if you're a busy restaurant, but this place just has bad acoustics and they haven't done anything about it, it seems. My date and I basically had to sit in silence or yell at each other to be heard over a raucous table of 4 across the other side of the restaurant.

The boar lasagne was DELICIOUS, pizza was decent, the recommended wine pairing (most expensive by-the-glass red on the menu) was meh. The dessert, chocolate boudin, was disappointing (and I'm very, very rarely disappointed by dessert generally, let alone chocolate specifically). It had a gritty texture to it that just didn't work.

Overall food was decent but the place didn't have enough atmosphere or personality to get me to come back unless I happened to be wandering by at dinnertime in need of feeding.
author: Laura N.

description:
What a fabulous experience.  Quaint, great service, and the food was amazing.  

I had the lasagna, the dish was amazing.  The sauce was so good.  My wife had eggplant, our friends meatballs and pizza.  Everyone celebrated the taste and experience.

Parking can be a challenge, so plan accordingly.  The place is small and somewhat noisy.  Service was great.  

The Lower Haight is one of our favorite neighborhoods and Uva just topped our list of favorites.
author: Ken M.

description:
Came here last night with the hubz and a friend that was visiting SF. What a great find! The food and wine were delicious. The wine was a bit pricey, but not too bad overall. The food was DELICIOUS! I'm a big meat and cheese plate girl, so their 3 meats and 3 cheeses were a huge hit with us. We also ordered the lasagna and the spicy salami pizza. Lasagna was great- not a ton of tomato sauce, but the meat in it was divine. The pizza.... Oh the pizza. So good, spicy, and slightly sweet because of the addition of honey on it! It reminded me of the spicy salami pizza at Paulie Gee's in Williamsburg, BK (my former hood). 

I already made my next reservation for when the parents come into town! 

4 stars because the meat took a while to come out, and the wine list is pricier than I would have thought (maybe a total of 3 wines under $40)
author: Carolyn C.

description:
Part of me doesn't want to share and the other WI part is friends help each other out. I'm reviewing on my two brunch visits.
Bottomless Bellini's. And delicious food, perfect portion ladies. No one wants bottomless food. Come here for AMAZiNG service, correct food portions and Bellini's in the sun!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Great little Italian restaurant. We sampled quite a few dishes from the menu and were generally pretty impressed. In particular the pizzas were quite tasty. And the wine list is exceptional.
author: Ruben K.

description:
Came here on a Sunday evening. The place is much larger than it looks initially, so that was a nice surprise. I got a glass of Prosecco and the pour was very generous so I loved that!
Got the pizza salame. I was disappointed since the reviews were so great, the sauce was too sweet.
author: Monica A.

description:
Pricey but the service and food make this a great find for special nights out. 

I didn't have reservations and got lucky a spot was open at the bar. Simon was brilliant at giving wine recommendations and suggestions from the menu to go with the wine pairing.

The antipasto selection of meats is interesting especially the speck. Their pizza is plenty to split between 2 if you get an antipasto and still leave room for dessert. The strawberry cheesecake is yummy even if you dislike it (which I normally do) and the chocolate budino is heavy but sinfully delicious.

The interior is softly lit and the ambiance is incredibly warm, minimalist and delightful. Will totally be coming back for the next special occasion that merits eating out.
author: Steph S.

description:
I chose this place for Dine About Town because of their menu selection.  And it wasn't a disappointment.  Shout out to open table for easy reservations.

The place is intimate buzzing with conversations.  

Their antipasti plate was very meaty.  It was more meat than I can pack with cheese in my mouth.  

The first bite I took of the spicy salami pizza, made me speechless.  There was a spicy kick followed by a sweet after taste.  "You have got to try this.  It's so good", is all I managed to tell my friend.  It was a single person serving but can easily have been shared by 2 people.

I was able to test out both pumpkin panna cotta and chocolate budino for dessert.  What can I say?  I wasn't even guilty I ordered dessert.

I don't frequent this area but Uva made it to my list of restos.
author: Pam S.

description:
Situation
- Dinner on a Friday night

Pros
- Great service
- The Boar Pasta was pretty good
- The interior was nice

Cons
- The waiting area was very small
author: Dipesh G.

description:
-----FOR DINNER ONLY----
YUM! Cute little wine bar with good food to accompany it. Came here with my boyfriend and childhood friend (both big red wine fans) and judging from what they got, they were fans.

Ordered the cheese and meat plate along with a pasta dish (wow I don't remember the name to anything). Everything was delicious and light. There were accompanying side dishes such as honey, granola, etc. for you to eat with the cheeses and meats. 

Service was friendly, price was decent, would def. come here again
author: Diana Y.

description:
Date & Time:  Friday May 22, 2009 @ 5pm
Stars:  3.5
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  30-Somethings in Seven Jeans Paired w/ Cashmere Wrap Sweaters for the Ladies & Blazers w/ Paul Smith Shirts for the Men Accompanied by Their Visiting Parents
Atmosphere:  Understated Elegance
Decor:  Cozy & Slightly Rustic.  Wine Bar.  ChalkBoard Announcing Events such as A Guest Sommelier.  Tightly-Packed Benches w/ Tables for Deux & Quatre & A Couple of Tables for Quatre & One for Deux
Service:  Attractive, Friendly, Efficient Female Server
Imbibe:  Vino
Devour:  For Starters:  Assortito Carne(Proscuitto di Parma Sopressata, Mortadello), Verdure, Formaggi.  Entrees:  Wild Boar Ragu & Oyster Mushroom Lamb Sausage Pizze
Total:  $75.01
author: Genevieve Y.

description: Enjoyed a couple different 2oz pours and the cheese plate (we tried all 8). Laid back environment...servers all sweet and attentive. It was a good choice for an intimate venue.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Well executed and honest to its roots.  This is not your standard spaghetti and meatballs type of place and neither is it innovative for difference's sake.  They make highly focused dishes with quality ingredients and simple, unpretentious presentation.  For me Uva stands out as one of the best italian restaurants in the city not because of creativity or originality (like Cotogna in North Beach), but rather because of fantastic execution and attention to detail.  Perfect sauces, pizzas that give nearby Ragazza a run for its money, refreshingly delicious vegetable dishes and perfectly sized portions.  A gem.

The only downside I can muster up has to do with the way the menu is structured.  Be wary of going here with a group if some members of your party are super picky or don't like sharing.  The menu really works best if you're sharing and otherwise can be a bit confusing and intimidating.  Not a good place to take out-of-towners who would just as soon go to Olive Garden.
author: Hank H.

description: I've been here for dinner a few times and always have loved it but tonight was a 5+ star experience worth writing about! I took some out of town friends (a party of 8) out for dinner tonight and wanted to make sure I picked a great restaurant with decent vegetarian options since half our party was vegetarian. They seated us on time and I loved that they gave us an option of a set menu or ordering off the regular menu. The group menu was fantastic and surprisingly had a ton of veggie options. This is probably the best group dinner I've had in my 5 years of living in SF. The food was amazing, and the price of $30 per person is incredible for the amount of food we received. The stand out dishes for me was one of the cheeses they served during the appetizer (I believe it was a Gouda cheese with truffle) seriously the best cheese I've ever had, the spicy salami pizza and the pesto pasta that was served. The service was excellent, the food and wine way better than expected and all at a really reasonable price. I can't wait for the next group of friends to come visit so I can relive this experience all over again!
author: Kristal G.

description:
WOW! Absolutely loved this place! I find it surprisingly hard in the city to find great Italian food with a great ambiance. Uva Enoteca has both, along with fabulous food and service. Our waiter went out of his way to let us taste 3 different wines before deciding on one, and was beyond attentive and friendly throughout the entire meal. The 8 ounces of wine is GREAT and very reasonably priced. They also take reservations and have a bottomless Bellini brunch on the weekends which I plan to try next time I go to the fabulous place. 

Recommendations: 
CHEESE PLATE - ALL OF IT! 
Stuffed shells were amazing.
author: Alexis T.

description:
Came for date night on the last day of DAT Jan 2013.

He had the boar bolognese and I had the DAT menu: cheese board, margarita pizza, chocolate bundino, and prosecco. I'd say the most memorable thing, sadly (see below reasoning), was the cheeseboard...except the pickles, which were a tad too vinegary. 

I feel guilty about this: Is it bad that while eating the pizza I kept thinking of Delfina crust? And that when we were eating the boar bolognese we kept thinking about SPQR's version? Slightly unfair, I know, since they're on different levels, but couldn't help but shake it out of our minds. 

All in all--it's fine food, but for a special occasion (and have the time to wait..), I'd make the case to head towards lower pac heights for a better version..
author: Vivian C.

description:
Great selection of cured meats! We ordered the plate of 7 and each was tasty. The focaccia bread was light and fluffy with great texture and the olive oil served with it was flavorful. Their happy hour menu is pretty good too. 

We ordered the kale, pistachio, ricotta salad. It was crunchy and fresh. I love kale. 

We ordered the margarita, spicy salame, and meat ball pizzas. All were nicely done. I really liked the crust. It had a nice flavor, was thin and slightly crispy, slightly chewy. 

We also tried the boar bolognese. I was only so-so about this. It was tasty, and the balance of noodle, sauce, and meat was nice. But it wasn't my favorite. 

The atmosphere of the restaurant was light and airy. We had a group of 9 (8 adults and one baby... a very quite and considerate baby :) ) and they were able to seat us comfortably.
author: Casey C.

description:
Cute little space in lower haight, where I have been trying to go for so long, well finally, I did!

Happy hour specials were great. Cheese selections were terrific and the staff was well-informed about the menu. The pasta was delich, perfectly al dente, simple and perfect. I would say the staff might had been only slightly under-attentive, but the food is definitely worth a tasting.
author: Jenn D.

description: This review is for brunch and I was hesitant to write it because it's one of the best kept secrets in the Lower Haight. $12 bottomless bellinis and an excellent brunch menu. Lunch looked pretty amazing as well. I've had the truffle toast, French toast, biscuits and gravy and the breakfast sandwich and each time I am blown away. The staff is friendly and keeps the bellinis filled which is the best part. I'll be back next weekend!
author: Courtney K.

description:
are you and your taste buds in for a surprise! I'm very impressed with everything about this place, from the food and service, down to the details. Thinking about the meat and cheese plate (and accompanying condiment pairings) here makes ones knees go weak. Who would've thought that pairing honey with bread, cheese, and lightly salted sunflower seeds would rank as one of the top culinary combinations ever??!

This is the kind of place that makes people fall in love (with each other, and also with the human capacity to produce such scrumptious food combinations!)
Definitely an "I don't eat to live, I live to eat" kind of place. 

Wild Boar ragu: unbeatable. I cannot think of a better pasta dish I have ever tasted in my entire length of being on this planet. The pasta was just the perfect amount of softness, the flavors were robust, it was just unreal.

pizzas: wow, they were perfectly proportioned, not too much overwhelming cheese, soft yet sturdy crust, everything you'd want your pizza to be.

RESERVATION RECOMMENDED! MIGHT AS WELL PUT IT ON SPEED DIAL.
author: Tuwie N.

description:
What a perfect date spot -- intimate, cozy and delicious. Fantastic service -
Beth was a dream - and the selection was well appointed and not overwhelming. The small plates are all great and the meat / cheese selection is a delight. 

We had the boar bolognese which is just fun to say and even better to eat. The terladego wine was a perfect compliment to the smokey flavours. We ended the meal with the chocolate mousse cup and it was decadent. 

I'll certainly be back - and I hear their happy hour is a steal.
author: Anthony V.

description:
We came here for the brunch and it was....meh.  We had a reservation at noon, and when we arrived, the place was almost empty.  We ordered the two slow-cooked egg dishes and they were just okay...nothing great or exciting.  The potatoes were actually a little under-cooked. The service was pretty slow too, although the waiter was nice. 

I will say that the orange juice was pretty good.  I wouldn't come back for the brunch.  Maybe we'll try the happy hour.
author: Ashley B.

description:
I feel really bad giving this cute little place only one star. The service was pretty friendly, and the complimentary bread was great! 

Wine: I've had better. Alot better. Maybe I'm just not a fan of Italian wines? The bartender was nice enough to let me try his small variety of Reds by the glass, but I was pretty unsatisfied. If I had to describe Italian wines, they tend to be pretty bitter, somewhat acidic, and with no finish. They are also not very full bodied. Or maybe it was just the ones they served at Uva.

Food: Not so good. Wild Boar Pasta tasted ok, but kinda like I reheated it from Trader Joe's. Burrata Cheese was not the best, and was served over grains. I disliked the grains so much that I couldn't even get myself to finish the last piece of cheese (that stuff is expensive!). Keep in mind though that I'm the kind of person that hates multigrain bread; I just hated the texture and the flavors here.

Note: With just a party of 2, we were able to walk in and sit down within 10 minutes on a Friday night!
author: Jess C.

description:
Only been her for happy hour, but my friend and I both enjoyed our wine and snacks and left feeling very happy!  
Will definitely be back.
author: Liz A.

description:
I don't often write reviews, but this time I really have to take exception and it's only for the MEATBALLS. 

Having just received my meal after paying a hefty tip and delivery fee to Caviar, I was extremely disappointed with the meatballs.

I am very sensitive to goat cheese and any kind of game meat...particularly lamb, and I would swear these meatballs have one if not both ingredients in them. I was so caught off guard by this I called to ask and was told neither ingredient is used in the meatballs.

Needless to say, I'm not sure I believe them. I am one of those unfortunate super tasters AND THERE IS SOMETHING OTHER THAN BEEF, PORK, AND SEASONING IN THERE. It's really unfortunate that I now have to chuck $20 worth of meatballs because someone decided to add a little something to them.
author: Nora L.

description: This is a great Italian place I was a fan of the location and cute layout. The bar next door was so grungy such a difference. Both the dishes I had were proteins as I'm a fan of it and less carbs. The meatballs were delicious so savory and the sauce was perfect. Everyone's pasta dishes looked great. The restaurant was a little dark!
author: Priya S.

description:
Great for Carbs (Pizza and Pasta),  I  would give them 5 stars.

Not so great for Veggies and Meat, I would give them 3 stars. (That's were I got my 4)

Price per Value Ok. They are not expensive, but, of course, better food costs more (like those heirloom tomato appetizer was at $16 while everything else was $5 to $10.)

 Also,  I gave them a 4 instead of 3 for meaning well, for the friendly and fast service and modern facility.

Rigatone Pomodoro and Roasted Mushroom Pizza were absolutely excellent with truly Italian flavor.

Their entrée meat choice was  scarce.  Choose between pork and beef meatballs and lamb sausage.  And if you don't eat pork, it leaves you no choice.  The lamb sausage with beans was good though.  Not too much of a sausage and priced at $16.

If you like veggies, it's not a great place either.  For Roasted Veggie appetizer it was corn (disappointment).  The taste wasn't too bad... however, with added cheese, olive oil and basil anything could be good.

Sicilian cauliflower was horrible and over salted.  Very rarely I wouldn't finish my plate, if I paid for it, but this was the case.

Marinated Olives were great!

They don't give you free bread or focaccia, as other yelpers mentioned, but it was ok with us.

We liked the Happy Hour $2 beer and $5 Sangiovese wine.

It was a friendly place for a casual meal,  but having veggie and meat lovers in our family, we might explore some other places in the city next time.
author: Michelle R.

description:
A friend and I had a Bloomspot for brunch here, and it was totally worth it. We both got their slow-cooked egg dishes, which were very generously portioned and tasty. She also got totally hammered on the bottomless bellini ($10), which was actually refilled pretty regularly and smelled fantastic (I was the DD... life is hard). 

I also really liked their vanilla ice cream with olive oil and sea salt. At first, I was a little put off by olive oil on my ice cream, but after my friend described it as "buttery", I saw the light and dug in. Again, very generous portions so I would recommend sharing if you're on a budget or watching your diet.

I think this is an adorable spot, and my only hope is that they get more staff soon. Only one very sweet guy was running the place and even though they weren't full I could tell he was pretty swamped. After we got our check, we were still sitting and talking and it was difficult to catch his eye and get refills, so I wish he had some back-up. Anyways, I would definitely come back here for their $5 wine and $2 beer happy hour!
author: Rachel A.

description:
I used to be a resident of Lower Haight and that is mainly why I chose to try this place out.  In my opinion, the food was decent, nothing to write home about but not terrible either, simply ok.  

The reason for my one star review is mainly directed to my server on the night I decided to dine at Uva Enoteca.  I feel that maybe it would've been in my best interest to lower my standards before I went here because I have never been so disrespected by a waiter in my entire life.  Having been in the food service industry for years prior and being someone who loves to dine out religiously nationally and internationally, I understand there are good and bad days, however I was not expecting this.  

Our waiter was aggressive, disrespectful, and egotistical.  He challenged questions I and my friends had about the food and the wine menu.  The sequence in which the food and wine were brought to the table as well as when the to go boxes were presented was super sloppy and unprofessional.  Our water rarely every refilled our water, let alone our wine.  We asked the front desk person if they could bring out a slice of cake and candle for my friend because it was her birthday, offering to pay for it of course, and that never came.  All in all an utter disappointment! 

Honestly, if our server said "I'm sorry, I am new/totally slammed, forgive me if things come out as they are ready or for me being short with you" my friends and I would've totally understood and would've appreciated the honesty but instead we left disappointed, underwhelmed and quite frankly pissed. 

Who knows maybe it was this servers first day and felt overwhelmed and didn't know how to handle things.  I am not sure.  But what I am sure about is that I think this restaurant should be a lot more selective at who they decide to represent their establishment and maybe set the bar a lot higher when hiring.  In my opinion a bad day in the kitchen is nothing compared to a bad attitude because attitude is everything when you are a server and essentially working for gratuity.
author: J D.

description:
