Just an okay experience. We ordered two apps: roasted beets and eggplant burrata. The beets were meh. We thought they were pretty similar to the beets you can buy from Costco. The burrata was nice though; the cheese was creamy and the flavor combination was bright and flavorful. 

Our main entree was also just okay. We shared a mushroom pizza with salami dded on, which was good except for the weird pieces of cornmeal dusted into the dough. Maybe it's adhering to the rustic theme but it made for an unenjoyable chewing experience because the cornmeal was super  hard, like tiny rocks. I was concerned for my teeth.

The saving grace was the pumpkin panna cotta. It was really good and creamy and rich. However, it wasn't good enough to raise this up to a four. Overall a pretty average experience.
author: Becky L.

description:
Great find (thanks for the rec, Max :))!

We ordered:
C H E E S E (3 for $15)
- Humbolt Fog - goat (insanely delicious) (
- Grana Padano - cow (slightly less strong than the first, but fantastic with the fig jelly)
- Formaggio de Miele - goat (wonderfully fluffy and infused with honey)

M E A T (3 for $14)
- Speck (typical prosciutto - very tasty, but I wouldn't say extraordinary)
- Salame Rosetta (great with the mustard seeds)
- Bresaola (had strong smoky flavor - would order again!)

P A S T A ($16)
- The wild boar pasta (hearty, filling)

For wine, I had the verdicchio (white) ($12) which definitely held its own against the strong flavors in the cheese and meats. I also thought it complemented the humbolt fog perfectly!! My B had the sangiovese ($15) which he thought was the only slightly disappointing part of the meal.

Would definitely return next time we visit the city!!
author: Helen D.

description:
It is rare when I can dine in an Italian style eatery and feel like I am back in Italy.  The Haight has an abundance of dining hot spots but Uva Enoteca has a little something that makes it special.  While the dinner entrees are limited, what you really come here for are the endless variations of cured meats and cheese platters.  If you're not ordering that, then you've missed the point of the whole place.

We chose a platter of three cured meats (carne, prosciutto cotto, and soppressata) and three cheeses (formaggio miele, pecorino, and gorgonzola).  The meats are cut ever so thin.  It's almost sheer. It simply melts in your mouth.  It is sublime to say the least.  The soppressata was my personal favorite as it was so flavorful.  The cheeses were all spectacular.  You are offered condiments such as honey, jam, etc. to enjoy them with.  Ask your server for advice on which cheese suits which condiment best.  When they are paired perfectly, your mouth will burst with an explosion of perfect, harmonious flavors.  I would have to say that Uva's cheese platters outmatch the cheese course at one of my favorite San Francisco fine dining restaurants.  It is that good!

I could describe the entrees we had but honestly, the entrees pale in comparison to the cured meats and cheeses so I won't even bother.  One of the best parts of Uva Enoteca is that they also let you order wines in two ounce pours.  Now why didn't people think of that before?  You can try different wines with different meats or cheeses.  More importantly, you aren't stuck with having to drink something that didn't quite suit your palate.
author: Chrys S.

description:
I love this place. Their cheese and meat selections are amazing! This place actually has bottomless bellinis for Sunday brunch, as well as a great brunch menu. The bad thing about having brunch in SF is that most brunch restaurants have at least an hour wait. Uva Enoteca is more known for dinner but I'd say it's as great as a lot of other brunch places without having to wait in line! They also have a wine sampler for dinner which is really yummy and affordable too.

The only downside is that almost the entire menu is in Italian and I have no idea what anything means. I wish they had some english in the menu to at least explain what type of meat I was getting!
author: Corabel S.

description:
YUM! Asked for a wine recommendation since everything seemed really Italian and not to my understanding (also the wine list was extremely long) and he got us a really great glass of wine. We also ordered the burrata with eggplant starter which was DELICIOUS. It had green olives and some herbs on top and it was so good.

We got 2 entrees: the spicy salame pizza and the meatballs. I LOVED the pizza, no complaints about it at all. The crust was even delectable. The meatballs were sweeter than I imagined and weren't my favorite thing but I liked them and I liked how soft they were. My boyfriend LOVED them though.

It was really full on a Wednesday night so to avoid waiting we sat at the bar which we are okay with. The wait for the food was a bit long but the waiter/bartender was very apologetic which was nice because we werent even really that bothered - the wait wasn't that long. He said the wait was a bit long because they just started doing some waiter-to-go service that day so things were a bit hectic. But I thought it was cool that they were starting that service and will keep that in mind next time we dont feel like braving the cold weather but want some bomb ass Italian food.
author: Alexandra W.

description: The food is wonderful here! Our family of 5 shared a cheese platter, 2 chick pea appetizers, tomato and cucumber salad, a margherita pizza, baked chicken, and stuffed shells. Salad, chicken, and pizza were the favorites. The host was very pleasant, but our waiter was condescending when asked to explain some of the items on the menu. If he had been nicer, this would be 5 stars.
author: Kathy C.

description:
not too impress. wine bar need a little extra something but not bad good place to hang out
Order pizza was ok but the past was not acceptable under cooked and no sauce 
Sent it back 5 min later we got our plate the same thing undercooked and no sauce 
Service I say I was ok fair 
Food I do not  recommend eating there
author: A. M.

description:
Food: 
1) Seared polenta: Very interesting......Polenta always came runny but this place "seared" it so it came in three cubes. Paired with some mushrooms, cauliflower and cubes of meat, the taste wasn't bad, but it just wasn't to my liking I guess...
2) Mushroom, pink sauce pasta: The pasta was like swollen spaghetti noodles. Kinda weird because it's so thick...almost like it's an udon noodle. The sauce was good, but again, not my cup of tea. 
3) Cheese and Meat appetizer: The cube of cheese was SO SMALL, it was literally like the size of a quarter! The meat was pretty good though! Had really nice flavoring. Not sure what meat or cheese we ordered but the cheese was a rip off because you got so little of it! 

Ambiance: 
Cute place. The restaurant is longer than it is wide...so the front of the restaurant looks super small because of it's narrow width, but since it's really deep, it can actually sit a lot of customers. There's a bar with bar seating and just regular table seating. The place looks very new and edgy. Great for groups or dates. 

Service: 
The waiters don't have regular uniforms so they are seriously wearing normal, casual clothing so it was difficult to tell at times if the person was a waiter or just a normal customer/person walking towards your table. That kinda made things a little awkward. 

Price: 
A bit pricey and you don't get a lot of food...

Overall: 
Not too impressed with this place. Food was decent but I'm sure there are other WAY better Italian places that you could get a better meal at and pay way less.
author: Amiee H.

description:
I love this frigging place. It reminds me of something I'd find in the East Village. With better prices. 

Uva is a stop on my list every time I'm in SF and I am never disappointed. Where else can I get a carafe which equals a big ass glass for $9. NINE dollars, people. Any amateur wine fiend's dream.

Please don't ever take the boar ragu off the menu, I would cry. 

Olive oil vanilla gelato with sea salt , hayll jess papi.
author: vivian s.

description: Everything I ordered was delicious. You can not order wrong. I loved the kale, garlic with fennel sausage pizza. Highly recommend trying.
author: Sarah W.

description:
3.5 stars. 

Good wine selection, most if not all Italian. Server was knowledgeable and recommended a wine we liked (don't remember the name but it was red). Started out with cooked meat Porchetta - castelucchio.. basically a pork loin. Pretty tasty. Also ordered 3 cheese.. I picked a goat cheese and let server picked other 2. I'm always open to anything so it was good. 

Ordered the burrata salad.. meh, skip that one. Then the meatball pizza. It was OK, I did like the sauce.. very tomato-y. Could've ordered more food but we were just right. 

Now my nit picks. We were seated in the back by the kitchen and all that smoke.. we smelled like smoke by the end of the evening. Also I was a little surprised by the vibe of the people who worked there.. hipsters in flannel lumberjack mode. I guess we were just a little too dressed up. Nothing wrong with all that, just know it's a really casual place. Very minor complaints. But server was outstanding, kudos to him.
author: Vol T.

description:
Wow. This is a neighborhood gem. 

Pretty large, but intimate space. Great wine list with 2 oz, 8oz, or bottle options. Fresh ingredients cooked the italian way.

We had the corn salad (summer in your mouth), pesto pasta (personal favorite), and sweet tomato pizza (gooey crust). Would order them all again. 

Very friendly and fun servers. Can get noisy, but it was a Saturday night. We got in 30 min before on open table and would do it again and again.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
Came in for brunch this morning with a few of our friends who live too far away from their fathers to spend the day with them. Super cute place! You would have never known that little hole in the wall was a nice italian wine bar. 

Though it was really busy and they seemed understaffed, the waitress was really nice and very helpful, keeping our bottomless belinis full.  Everything we ordered was really great, and even when we thought it was a small portion it was filling and just right. As usual, my favorite part was the dessert! Had something called a "semifreddo", I was unfamiliar with it, and unsure when it showed up but it was SO GOOD. Pizzas and pastas and eggs- oh my!
author: Mercy T.

description:
Of all of the casual shared plate Italian places in the city (Delarosa, A16, Barbacco, Beretta, etc) Uva Enoteca is my wife and my absolute favorite!  Here are a few reasons why:

- Uva does not get the pretentious crowds that the other locations are always crawling with.
- The service at Uva is fantastic! 
- They may have the best and most affordable wine list ever.  Dozens of fantastic Italian reds for under $40 a bottle.  
- The cheese plates are out of control (try the truffle cheese)
- Pastas and Pizzas are always inventive, fresh and delicious.
author: Dan L.

description:
This place is great.  Easy to make last minute reservations, but still always pretty crowded with a great vibe.  

Surprisingly good food:
Kale salad - amazing (cause who really likes kale that much?)
Carrots - this carrot dish was out of this world good!
Strawberry mascarpone shortcake - The cake was like the most amazing scone like texture and taste with strawberry mascarpone topping - it was pretty amazing.
Eggplant pasta dish - wide noodle like short rigatoni with eggplant, tomato sauce and basil.  it was a really good pasta dish; simple with great flavor.
Margherita pizza - perfect crunchy and chewy crust at the same time with buratta cheese!

We also had the spaghetti amatriciana - no surprises here, I knew was I was getting.  It was good.  We also had the meatballs - note: it did not come with pasta, just tomato sauce on the bottom.  The cheeses were also great, along with the cured meats.

The other desserts were very good too: Tripple chocolate grenache cake and vanilla gelato with olive oil and sea salt.

The wine was also pretty good.  We were a group of 4, had 4 glasses of wine and some espresso at the end.  I think we got a lot of food and the bill was only $200.  

The lower haight is the best.  This place and Maven are my new go to spots!
author: Lyndsey H.

description:
Yum! I really liked this place. Made a reservation through Open Table. Friendly service recommended a good glass of wine. We had a pizza, which was wood-fired thin crust with a very tasty, salty tomato sauce. We also had the meatball appetizer, which was a substantial fresh-made portion, and a fresh corn salad that was surprisingly refreshing. 

All the food was good so we sadly had to pass up dessert, but plan to go back. I also really enjoyed the music they had playing - unusual enough that Shazam couldn't identify it.
author: Sam Z.

description: I can't speak to anything on their menu except the margarita pizza. I've been here three times now and that's all I get because it's so. freaking. good. I crave it all the time. It's like crack. And if you come during happy hour it's only $10. You're welcome.
author: Marian S.

description: The food is tasty, we had the boar lasagna and the meatball pizza. We really enjoyed ourselves. It was a bit frustrating that although we had a reservation we waited 20 minutes. I will admit that I was annoyed, particularly because I thought that the host was particularly inattentive. But, they made up for it by offering free wine and the rest of our time there was pleasant.
author: Emily K.

description:
This is a very San Francisco-esq restaurant, in actual layout and food style. If you don't know what I mean, it's: narrow-ish, dimly lit, bare tables, prompt but not too chatty servers, a good wine list, and a modern twist on traditional food. 

My party of two ordered a few appetizers, though none of them stand out. If I had to pick a favorite, it would be the squash. 

As for mains, we split the asparagus and potato pizza, and the guinea hen. The pizza was very good, and unusual tasting. The guinea hen was good, but my favorite part of the dish was the stuffing. It was moist, flavorful, and offset the hen perfectly. 

I cannot remember the wine that was ordered, but I do remember enjoying it!
author: Sonia M.

description:
You know, I really want to like this place. And sometimes I do, but it's just as often I don't (I live in the hood, I've been a handful of times). 

The ambience is great, but the staff can be quite surly. The pasta, the pizza... it tastes mostly good, but there's just something missing. I'm guessing that the menu was created by some awesome chef who's not there anymore, and it's being executed kinda wrong. The last time we ordered a meatball pizza, the top of the crust was burned but the bottom crust in the middle was raw/undercooked. 

Does the menu ever change? They don't seem to ever have any daily specials, either.
author: Angela K.

description:
They have a happy hour Sat/Sun from 3 to 6:30 pm! We arrived at 6pm for an early dinner before a show, and were very happy with the $5 pours of a smooth Sangiovese. 

The veggies were very good, crisp, tart asparagus and the broccoli had a really nice light sauce.

We had the spicy sausage pizza, which was just big enough to share. It had really fresh Mozzarella on it, and nice wood fired crust.

For dessert we topped it off with a nice Cafe Afogato which is always SO GOOD to end a meal with. Our second glasses of wine we stepped it up to a Primativo from Puglia which was fruit forward, very smooth, and a Barbera that was KILLER but pricey at $15 a glass.

Super clean inside, great service, easy to get reservations, this is a must do while hanging out on Haight St.
author: Mike H.

description: Uva Enoteca is a great restaurant.  Their timing was impeccable, which to me is the sign of a strong restaurant. We never waited more than 10 mins between courses. Our carafe never ran out of water and it wasn't one of those awkward services where they seem to interrupt constantly to do so, we didn't even notice.  The food was delicious, fresh and my leftover boar lasagna made the best breakfast, ever.
author: Kyle F.

description:
Horrible experience.  Waiter was not only not there but was also super rude every time a request was made (we asked for bread for example - every table
seemed to have it but somehow we did not. When we finally got it, it was brought with an attitude).  Also, my main course was brought to the table as I was eating my salad, so I asked that the food be sent back.  The food was then dropped off 20 minutes later fairly cold as if it had just sat in the kitchen (likely what happened).  My partner ended up eating her cold pasta cause she was starving but I just sent mine back and told the waiter I didn't want anything else.  Her pasta had very little flavor.  In summary, we were in and out in 45 mins and that was one of the worst dinning experiences I've had in SF.  Kudos to the busser who was super nice, friendly and attentive.
author: R X.

description:
First off..I reserve 5-star reviews for only the exceptional.  Uva Enoteca is exceptional in every way.

I recently held a bday dinner for 12 people at the restaurant and we all had a wonderful time.  I've eaten at the restaurant several times prior and settled on UE because of:  1) the service, 2)  the location, 3)  the wine list and 4)  the exceptional food!

I worked with Frank and he was very helpful.  He/they provided me and my party with a well-varied and very fairly priced prix fixe menu.  The portions were ample and everyone was happy and impressed with the food.  Their wine hails mostly from Italy, which makes it important for the staff to be well educated on their offerings (because us CA wine whores rarely stray from the homeland).  They not only know their shit, but are quite accommodating about providing tastes.  Everything was just easy and enjoyable, which can be a challenge for a party of our size.  And the service was just stellar...as always.

I can't say enough about how much I enjoy dining at Uva Enoteca.  Eat there and be merry.
author: Drew W.

description:
This place is pretty good, but nothing spectacular.  I've been for breakfast and for dinner. It's pretty close to my house, and they have a unique twist to their food, which I like.  However, I don't frequent much, because dishes like pasta and salad I usually do myself.  (I'm not the biggest pizza fan - for some reason I can eat cheesy pasta, but not cheese on pizza).  

For brunch, they have bottomless bellini's, which is pretty cool. French toast yummy. Fried eggs yummy (and cool that it comes with a salad for breakfast) and they used to have a pork fussilli pasta breakfast dish (I don't see it on the menu now) but that was different and tasty. All of them are different than your usual weekend brunch spot, and I like that.

For dinner, we've had salads which were yummy and pasta ragu and pasta cacio e pepe. We tried the ragu because everyone was talking about. It was okay, but nothing great. My bf and I both liked the cacio e pepe a lot more, and it was on their HH for like $8.  I think a lot of people come here for small dishes/cheeses, but I'm a little lactose, so I can't comment on that. They have a lot of small dishes, though.  What I did try (bc they had it on HH) was the lentils, and they were cold. I wish I would've known that. My bf and I didn't like them.

Desserts - I'd steer away from, unless your really having the urge. I think they save things for a pretty long time, and the dessert I got was pretty stale. I still ate it, it wasn't horrible, but I wouldn't do it again.

Servers/bartenders are super friendly, and from what I saw knowledgeable about the wines.  The one server did give us 'too much time' alone (which stinks when your trying to ask for something) but the boy bartender brings back some points.

I'm sure I'll be back, probably for breakfast than for dinner. (So breakfast a 4, dinner 3, but my rating just can't stretch for the 4 for some reason...maybe it's bc dinner (even w HH items) still is at least $60+tip for 2 ppl and not something you want to splurge on frequently.
author: Jessica S.

description: So rarely do I give 5 stars. And perhaps it would have been a 4 on any other day but the service was impeccable! Brian was our server and he went above and beyond. Which I really appreciate. The wine list extensive. The kale salad was remarkable. The pizza exquisite. Cheese fabulous. Ambiance romantic and casual. This is my go-to spot and I can't recommend it enough!
author: Reham A.

description:
Been here four times now, because I'm so confused about what the heck to make of this place.

First time, underwhelmed. Didn't come back for over 2 years, and can't remember what the boyfriend and I ate or drank.

Second time - boyfriend and I wandered in when everything was packed with drunk idiots for Bay to Breakers, and needed to take cover from the stumbling and bumbling masses. Coppa pizza for myself, and spicy salami pizza for the boyfriend. Mouth Orgasm. Body Orgasm. Why had we ignored this place for 2 years?

Third time, one week later - Wanted to recreate Mouth/Body Orgasm experience. Ordered the same pizzas as a week earlier because we are old and like routine. This time I got a fancy drink off the happy hour menu because I was feeling crazy. Pizzas seemed half-cooked, and cheese covered only the center third of the pizza. Where the heck was the meat this time? And why was I charged full price for a happy hour drink? And why is Open Table scolding me as a no-show? Confusion sets in.

Fourth time, last night - Utter despair. Ordered the same 2 pizzas again, goddamn, are we old and boring. Boyfriend openly weeps at table, draft beers seem to have been removed from menu. Coppa pizza is burnt on top, and completely uncooked throughout. Why the hell is it so spicy? Spicy salami pizza is completely uncooked, burnt on top. And why isn't it spicy? It wasn't until today that we realized f-ing Uva mixed up the toppings (boyfriend ate the leftovers). The coppa pizza came with apples (normal) and spicy salami (not normal). The spicy salami came with coppa (not normal).

This place is a nightmare. But I'm totally going back because it's like playing the lottery. A rush of adrenaline, thinking you might hit the jackpot, and mouth orgasms for everyone. But of course, the odds are against you.
author: Pickles The Cat ..

description: The worst restaurant in San Francisco. The service was terrible and rude managers and owners. They treat us like a shit and they didn't explain how the things working. It's the worst service that I had in USA.  I don't recommend for anyone!
author: Fernando B.

description:
My friend and I were just reviewing the wine menu when the waiter came over and offered his help.  After we both described what we wanted, he immediately disappeared.  It was odd that he didn't tell us what he was bringing.  We just assumed he was going to bring us a taste of something.  Anyway, he came back with two of the most expensive options on the menu.  He didn't even mention the name of the wine or price just started pouring.  It just all felt like he was selling us something rather than wanting us to have a great experience.

We then ordered our entries.  Nothing amazing but it does the job.  After we ordered our entries, he asks us why no appetizer?  It just felt like he was pushing us all night.  Won't go back after him tricking us into a $17 glass of wine that was only okay.
author: Lenni R.

description: Absolutely loved the burrata appetizer, the soft texture of burrata mixed with the crunchy side of wheat berry, salty and sweet. The cooked prosciutto was quite good as well. Excellent service. Chianti classico by the glass 2008 was a good complement for many dishes. Skip the wild boar gnochetti - didn't like the meat quality / taste. Perhaps the tomato sauce needed to infuse into the meat a bit more. Loud atmosphere -- it takes effort to catch up with friends that one hasn't seen for a while.
author: Rebecca C.

description: So happy to return to this neighborhood favorite and find that it's as good as ever.  Friendly, attentive service.  Good value wines.  Delicious aromas coming from the kitchen and simply the BEST heirloom tomato, burrata, basil salad ever.  It had real flavor, something that's been sorely lacking in all the would-be Capreses I've tasted lately. I will definitely be back... and will for sure try the pasta.  The plates that passed us by looked wonderful.
author: Lorraine F.

description:
I just want to preface this with the fact I don't hate the place. In fact, I wanted to love it because of the atmosphere and the incredible service. So let's start there. 

Cute place you walk into that takes you away from the lower Haight and changes the vibe immediately. Greeted by a nice hostess and then waited on by a server that seemed to be picking up a lot of slack from being under-staffed. She still made sure we had excellent service and spent plenty of time with us to answer questions.

I'm not going to critique the wine because I honestly am not the kind of person that should. I wanted their reasonably priced Chianti ($30-40 something or other), but they were out of it and the server made a few other suggestions. I'll just say that I wasn't a fan of whatever it was we got, but my girlfriend was pleased and as a guy that's all that matters at the end of the day.

Burrata on farro, honey, persimmons, and pomegranate was very good.  I think it was the best thing we had the entire night.

Lamb & Sausage on skewers - This was a fine dish that had a lot of flavor with the polenta and the glaze/suce they put on the meat. I would recommend this if you decide on going here.

Auttuno - Their Autumn pasta with butternut squash sauce is probably one of the most bland things we've ever tasted. It literally was devoid of any flavor beyond the shreds of speck they added in. We politely asked if we could order anything else as a replacement and without hesitation the server said "Of Course" and brought us back a menu.

Spicy salame pizza -  We ordered this as a replacement to my gfs Autunno pasta thinking this would be a safe bet as it had simple classic flavors on the menu. The pizza crust was like a cracker and the cheese tasted as if it came from a Little Caesars $5 pizza. We wanted to stop complaining so we ate a couple slices, told the waiter it was delicious, and boxed the rest to go so not to waste more food and gave it away after we left. 

We wanted to like this place, but the pasta and pizza were so bad we just can't see ourselves trying to spend another $110-120 just to give it another shot. Maybe it was just an off night and you will have better luck next time around. It truly does have a lot of potential, but I'm also not one of those people that believes in "You just ordered the wrong thing". Everything on the menu should be the right thing to order at a place like this.
author: Sean S.

description:
A perfect place for a date night! This is an intimate space that is still friendly and relaxed. The food was exceptional and the servers did a wonderful job of assisting in wine selection. We ordered the eggplant and gemilli pesto dishes which were both made with fresh ingredients, cooked correctly Italian.

I highly recommend the panna cotta with strawberry compote for dessert. A great way to cap off the meal! 

*Good idea to make a reservation on Open Table to secure a table. It can get pretty busy.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Went there to try the bottomless bellinis and it was definitely worth it.

Their food was good, not the best.
Cheese Plate was amazing!
Service was OK...could have been better since there was not a lot of people.

They need to do a better job at keeping the Bellinis coming!
author: Monica V.

description:
Very cute little place on Haight Street. The meat and cheese selection is impressive. That is probably my favorite part. They serve the platter with delicious mustard and bread.
We also ordered the boar bolognese and the Margherita pizza. Both were very good. The service was mediocre but the restaurant is kept very clean and our food came out in a timely manner. Their portions are slightly smaller than average and their prices are slightly higher than average, but the quality is exceptional.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Love the ambiance, the wine and the food, and the happy hour is great! 

My boyfriend and I started off with the roasted broccoli dish, which was delicious. I'm not sure what the grain was with it, but it was really good. 

I had the pasta pomodoro, which was amazing. The sauce was creamy and cheesy and basil-y. Loved it. 
My boyfriend had the boar bolognese, which he really enjoyed. I don't eat pork, but I'll take his word for it. 

For dessert we had the chocolate budino, and it was really great! 
I will be back!
author: Cami J.

description:
Amazing cheese plate. Also unlimited bellinis... what else do I need to say beyond that? 

Brown sugar + black pepper biscuits were quite tasty. It was fairly empty for brunch, but that was fine with me; it means more attention from the wait staff. 

Also cute waiter is always a plus. :-)
author: Chris W.

description:
I had a living social voucher. This place was nice. The food was good. The interior was nice and calm and inviting. Our server was very sweet and knew the menu and made nice suggestions. 

We had the meat platter, the meats were good. The bread was nice. It would have been nice for them to offer a meat and cheese platter (they only had meat or cheese). It could have used another condiment. 

We had a caramelized onion pizza with Gorgonzola cheese. This was good but be warned, the Gorgonzola was STRONG!

Overall it's a good place. Food was solid and well put together. $10 bottomless biinese were a hit with my girlfriend.

If you are in the area it's a winner for a casual stop.
author: Jill T.

description: This is a super delicious neighborhood wine bar with great Italian food, super-friendly service and an incredible selection of affordable wines. The servers are knowledgeable and will always hook you up with the best value wines instead of pushing the most expensive ones. It's usually fairly fully and rightfully so.
author: Brian K.

description: Meh...came here, the staff were not very attentive, probably because it was incredibly slow.  Food was decent, but wouldn't make a second visit.
author: Scott J.

description: Don't go to this place!!! The service was horrible, and the food wasn't good. I had a bad experience. We felt like we were trick, they supposed to serve bellini all the time for us in the brunch, but later they said that we had just 2 hours for drink it. The staff was really rude and they served less food than we should have received. The pizza was poor and the bread was raw. I don't recommend this place!!
author: Vivian L.

description:
We came here for a girls dinner on a sunday night and were able to get in quickly, which was great bc we were starving!

We started out by ordering a nice bottle of the barbera, which was quite nice and reasonably priced.  Appetizers: We started with the burrata with pomegranate seeds and and the brussel sprouts, which were surprisingly really good.  I mean, brussel sprouts can be done very badly and these were roasted perfectly.  Burrata--nice and gooey with the crunch of the seeds and toasted nuts.

For mains, this is where we got a little disapointed.  For some reason a majority of us were interested in the spicy salame pizza, which was OK but not great.  The sauce was a bit sweet for my taste and lacked the zest I enjoy.  My friend had the pasta with garlic, basil and tomato, which was done well. Overall, I'd say it was a decent experience (good service etc) so I would come here for wine and apps but dinner...not so much.
author: Namita A.

description:
Met my 2 good friends here for a little dinner 2/24/2012

I walked in and couldn't find them, so I walked back out.  Apparently the 'mirror' on the right side of the restaurant is not a mirror but another side of the restaurant. 

So i don't know shit about wine and I immediately began to bombard our server with random facts about myself, "I like flavor. but i dont want it to be too strong. I dont like Cabs. I dont know anything about wine. help. You pick." I'm sure I was just throwing out a bunch of contradictions and if i were him i would be annoyed.  Anyways, he ended up recommending a red wine that of course I don't even know what it was called, but I was happy with it. 

3 meats for $15, 3 cheeses for $15. The prosciutto was my favorite, we also got speck and this pepperoni looking thing. The speck (pork belly) kinda just tasted like ham, it wasn't really special in my opinion.  I'm sure the cured meat gods are frowning upon me now, but whatever. 

Service was great, i wish i remembered what his name was. Checked on us several times, i'm also allergic to dairy so he made sure the 'pepperonis' didn't have milk in it. 

I want to add that we were seated at a table that was ment for two, and it was quite cramped. Especially with all the fancy wine paraphernalia filling our table, i kinda felt like a bull in a china shop. I guess his spidey-senses noticed that somehow, and he gave me the wine on the house! I was honestly thinking of saying something about it not being on the bill, but quite frankly i'm hella broke and could use a break.  But anyways, much appreciated! If it wasn't for his nice gesture I probably wouldn't have gone out of my way to write this review on the place.
author: Randy N.

description:
Been a few times now, and I'm becoming a big fan... not that that's hard to do when there's wine involved ;)

The staff is knowledgeable and friendly--not wine snobby.  They recommend wines based on what you tell them you like, or what you're ordering.  They also make great cheese, and meat pairings recommendations.  We just ordered our wine and told them to suprise us.  You can't really go wrong with the quality on this menu.  Though, I definitely advise ordering the house made pate--it's always been different but has always been really, really yummy.  And they bring you other little treats too--bread, honey, corn nuts, jam--all on the house! 

I tried a sparkling red for the first time and loooved it.  I wish I could remember the name... oh, well, I guess this just means I **have** to go back!
author: Olivia D.

description: Amazing pizza, possibly my favorite in the city. Brunch is usually average but you cannot go wrong with $12 bottomless belinis. Also, it's never crowded for brunch which is a rarity in this city.
author: Amy S.

description:
Ambiance was great!
Food overall was ok, nothing crazy special
The cheese was unique and delicious!
Probably wouldn't go back, but glad I went once.
author: Anjarae W.

description: Its hard to find real good italian in SF, but Uva Enoteca helped my craving a long way! Had the spicy salame, the dough was five stars, had a lot of chili which is made it,, well,, spicy, but I like that so please continue! The place itself is really cozy, great for a date. They have a wide sortment of wine which makes you stay longer than you should!
author: Sindre P.

description: The kale salad is delicious!!! They have a really good selection of wine and the pizzas are really good. The service was perfect, the staff is very friendly and helpful.
author: Rachel M.

description:
clear delineation between great and the not so great

great: assorted meats, focaccia like bread, cheese, mustard, pizza, wine, veggies, staff 
not so great: all egg dishes at brunch, pasta
author: Wakako U.

description: This place was excellent! I came here last night to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday with his parents. The service was amazing and the food was delish! They also do these amazing 12 oz. pours of wine. Loved it. The server recommended a great wine and it was a hit with everyone. Definity a must try! We will be back for sure :)
author: Sheila S.

description:
My biggest gripe with this place is that the listed hours are really confusing. It says that happy hour is from 3:30 to 6PM on Sunday, but the restaurant doesn't open until 5PM? We showed up a little early and were turned away until after 5 which was annoying and confusing.

Otherwise, the ambience was good, it looked like a nice place without the pressure of "fancy" restaurant. We ordered everything off the happy hour menu and it was all good! Pizza was nice and light, same with the bruschette. Both delicious. And the wine was great, and really surprised us with how good it was and how much we got for $5!

The surrounding neighborhood is a little sketchy if you stray too far. But would definitely recommend.
author: Rodolphe C.

description: I wanted to like a new Italian place, read the reviews and so we braved the Lower Haight on a Friday night. Bottom line, the place is insanely and unnecessarily loud, the food is of really low quality (4 slivers of sardines right out of the can and sitting on a pile of red pepper is not a quality appetizer), and the pancetta was a hunk of fat intertwined with a bit of meat. One and done - thankfully Maven is right next door so we were able to end the evening with people that care about the quality of their product.
author: damon k.

description:
If you're here with a group I highly recommend going with the 3-course family style option, they keep the food coming until you can't eat any more, every course was also fantastic! My favorite course was the appetizers, so much charcuterie, cheese, salad etc.
The service was also very good.
author: June O.

description:
Awesome menu! You can get anything from small plates to a full meal with entree and dessert and everything we tried was really good. Didn't love the boar as much as everyone else did, but the farro salad was fantastic. Interesting cocktails and plenty of wine options.
Also, wonderfully not a scene in the midst of a kind of hectic block! We made reservations but might not have needed to, and sat as long as we liked without feeling pressure to clear the table.
Very comfortably-fancy feeling - if I lived closer this would totally be my go-to spot!
author: Alison M.

description:
It had been quite a while since I had been here last but came again last Saturday with a friend. Came here the first time with Lisa W. (see review here as well) and we had a great experience. I got their eggplant sandwich and potato rosemary pizza, such good stuff. Sadly, it wasn't the same for me this time.

We got a cheese board, which was great. I wish I could tell you which cheeses we got but sadly, I don't remember. Loved the honey and currants the give with the cheese. In addition to the 3 cheeses, we got a 3 vegetable order and got the cauliflower, eggplant stew, and the asparagus. The cauliflower was really good but the other two were sub-par at best. Also got the Caramalized onions, cress, gorgonzola, tomato pizza with burrata substituted for the gorgonzola which was good, again not great (which the rosemary pizza in the past was).

I appreciated the lower cost of the bottle of wine here vs other places which was still pretty quality but the food just didn't measure up to what I've enjoyed in the past. Loved the ambiance as well and the service is stellar.
author: Raina B.

description: Dined here for the time tonight and ordered the margarita pizza and I have to say it's probably one of the best pizzas I've had in the city. I mean at the level of Tonys or a Zero Zero to set a bar. Food was great, drinks were great, and the staff is very friendly. So glad my gf found this gem near home. Will be coming here more often.
author: Hammed K.

description:
Uva Enoteca is a solid choice for those who love cured and cooked meats. Plenty of options and the servers were very knowledgable on the different meats (part of the pig, saltiness, fatiness, etc). And if you ever get lost, there's always a diagram on the wall of a pig and the part of each meat.

Besides the cooked and cured meats, Uva also offers a variety of cheese and veggie dish options. None of which we had the stomach room to try as we opted for the pizza and pasta choices. All of the entrees were solid, but the meatball pizza stuck in my mind as I love pizzas that are piping hot, oozing with melty cheese. This was one of those pizzas and oh, it was good. May come back to try some of the other dishes :)
author: Angela S.

description:
Great happy hour, excellent wine selection, warm, inviting space, and a good location next to some nearby watering holes you can meet up for a drink before dinner or simply sit yourself down for a happy hour here.  You could stay for dinner, just for the happy hour, or have a romantic night out or a friends' night out here.  Miraculously, we found parking a block away - I was in the city anyway for a haircut and we decided to meet up for dinner.

Food was outstanding.  There are enough veggie options to keep the veggie entertained.  The first time I was here I believe I had the mushroom Boscaiola pasta, so this time around I opted for the Frico with pear, tomato, and brussels sprouts.  Arugula salad to start.  Both were excellent.  Service was a little slow on Tuesday night - I had a two hour parking window after parking my car, stopping at Mad Dog in the Fog before our reservation, and eating at Uva, and I barely made it.  The Frico plate was a little light, even with a salad to start, but I'm sure if I had the mushroom Boscaiola it would have been filling enough.  I would have except I just had mushrooms in cream sauce for lunch . . . 

I'll be back again - Uva is a solid choice here.  Gourmet Italian and fine wine - hard to pass up!
author: Joe B.

description: Pretty pricey for some pizza and wine but it was really good! The wine they recommended was delicious!
author: Tiff W.

description: What a great Italian spot in Haight, right across from one of my favorite bars in the city. I never would have thought this place would fit in well with all the grunge bars around it, but it is a quaint Italian restaurant that serves excellent food. I highly recommend the chilled Cauliflower appetizer and the Boar Lasagna! They also have a great Happy Hour: $2 beers or $5 glasses of wine.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Came here on a weekday with a friend and was promptly seated. The atmosphere is nice, very cozy feel and it's a good place to have a conversation since you can actually hear each other. We had the following: 

Venetian cauliflower - we got this based on recommendation from our waiter (it was this or the Brussels sprouts from the vegetable section). First bite was great and had a burst of flavor, the cauliflower is almost pickled in a vinaigrette with shallots, raisins, and capers. However, as I took additional bites it became increasingly sour and despite loving sour food, I had to stop because it was a bit too much. 

Spicy salame pizza - this was good, a bit like a pepperoni pizza. It wasn't the best thing in the world but definitely a safe and tasty choice.

Roasted pork loin - the brussels sprouts and bacon wrapped dates in this tasted great, but the pork loin itself was underwhelming. Wasn't particularly flavorful, and was just pink and "porky" tasting. 

I also wish the staff would have sold us a little more on the food. I feel like the food may be prepared in unique ways or using less common ingredients (I saw a bag of malted flour on my way to the restroom) and that is not conveyed through the menu so it would have been helpful if someone would have talked us a little bit through things, especially after we told our waiter it was our first time there. 

Overall, perhaps we just picked the wrong items, but it wasn't a compelling enough experience and we probably will not be back.
author: Linda L.

description:
The food was bland. 
Everything was just a little over priced
Everyone was too cool for school. 
The waiter took my friend and I's wine bottle and said it was empty...which it wasn't. 
Then he complained to the people next to us that he had been "pouring for us all night." We were there an hour and a half.....We came at happy hour, ordered drinks, and then we ordered food and a bottle. This doesn't seem unreasonable. You're a wine bar.
author: L P.

description:
Cheese platter won me over! Great presentation, came with almonds, delicious fresh honey, some type of jam and endless bread as if there wasn't enough gluttony already going on. I will be back to try the meat platter which looked equally fantastic. 

Had a bloomspot deal and it was WELL worth it. The place is already reasonably priced to begin with for the quality of food and the knowledge of the servers. I agree with other yelpers.. the italian food words were a little tough for me to decipher, but made it more of a valuable eating experience. 

Will be back for happy hour to get my drink on. Wine and cheese, thank you please.
author: Katie P.

description:
Courtesy of my friends LS deal my pals and I dined here last year...yup, this review is long over due! We made a reservation as its Sf and on a rainy Saturday night the last thing I wanna do is stand in an hour+ line. 

We shared a few appetizers (cheese, olives & cold meats), the boar pasta, pizzas and vino. We thought the food was pretty good and the service was equally as good. 

I don't find myself in this neighborhood often but would certainly dine here again!
author: Leanne S.

description:
A friend & I came here with our LS deal on Friday night and had a lovely time. Our waitress was knowledgeable in helping with meal and wine selections. We ordered a selection of three cheeses, our favorite being the Pecorino Moliterno w/ truffles, god I love truffles. W e also had the pickled vegetables (to mentally compensate for the pasta we would be gorging on) with mustard seed which was yummy, earthy and crunchy. I ordered the amatriciana pasta and she had the trufulo. I really enjoyed the the texture of the noodles, however, my dish did not have as much of a kick as I expected with the chili. I preferred the trufulo. As far as Italian pasta dishes go, these were good, but lacking the punch of flavor I look for in my favorite dishes (check out Ristorante Parma). However, the overall dining experience was enjoyable, I would come again to try more of the appetizer selections, and of course, wine.  

Ps. This place is ridiculously warm inside. Dress appropriately to avoid heat stroke.
author: Nicole Z.

description:
Love, Love, Love. 


This is one of my favorite places in San Francisco. It's cozy, yummy, have great happy hour and perfectly priced. 

I always schedule dates or friend catch up dinners here because I know my friends are always pleased with the food. 

Some of my favorite things:

Verdure:
Brussels sprouts, onions, pomegranate seeds
Roasted heirloom carrots, marcona almonds, golden raisins, agrodolce
Raw kale, pistachios, ricotta salata, meyer lemon vinagrette 

Insalate:
Burrata, farro, persimmons, chestnuts,honey
Chopped romaine, radishes, gorgonzola, pears

Pasta: 
BOAR
Spaghetti alla chitarra, boar, pepper & onion ragu, parmigiano, panko

Pizze:
Mascarapone, bechamel, chestnuts, apple, pancetta
Caramalized onions, radicchio, gorgonzola, tomato 
Spicy salame, herbs, pecorino, tomato
Potato, goat's cheese, rosemary, tomato

MMMM!!! Love it!
author: Arlene R.

description:
This review is long overdue. My friends and I came to Uva Enoteca on Friday evening, and we absolutely loved it - service, wine list, atmosphere and food. 

For wine, we chose a bottle of Barbera ($42) per our server's suggestion since we're looking for Pinot Noir resemblance. Next, we shared a charcuterie and cheese plate. You can mix and match the options from the menu. We went with 3 items each from meat and cheese. Most of the items were sourced from Italy, with a few from local purveyors. 

For entrees, we shared 3 dishes: pizza, pasta and pork loin. We all agreed pork loin is our #1 favorite. The pork must be slowly roasted, so the meat is so tender. It comes with Brussels sprouts, carrots and bacon wrapped dates. I think I can finish this dish by myself very easily. The pizza is not your typical Neapolitan style with burnt crust. The crust here is more white and has a slight sour taste (not sure if sourdough was used). However, heirloom tomatoes and goat cheese made our pizza very special.

We enjoyed our meal and conversation with great friends. Definitely recommend you try it out!
author: Saran R.

description:
I feel bad for the homeless person who picked up the leftovers we put on the trashcan outside (the bulk of the meal). After a few years since our last experience we thought that it would be worth another shot since it's in the hood and people seem to love it. 

Bad call. Every one of the 5 dishes that we got was bad, and some were strait inedible, right down to the cocktail and bread. The service was good and atmosphere would have been nice if they weren't playing loud heavy metal.

I'm not the type to give one star because the waitress looked at me wrong, it takes a lot. And the price to food quality ratio of this place is worst I've ever experienced in SF. I seriously have no idea where people are coming from with all of these raving reviews. More power to the people who like this place, but you couldn't pay me to go back.
author: M L.

description:
Ambiance was cute. Very "hipstery"... they call their restroom, the water closet. We got the salami pizza which was very good but on the salty side. We also got the chicken pasta which was very flavorful and the pasta was cooked perfectly al dente. 

If you're looking for a nice cute dinner with some girlfriends or a date on Haight street this definitely is the place to go! Try the happy hour!

Tip: Its sort of hard to see initially because of its black paint and only says UVA. It's right next to Laundry Locker, FYI. Also, the right door is locked. Go for the left one first!
author: Ann P.

description:
I'd definitely recommend it. Good ambiance. They have one of those limited-but-desirable menus.

The waiter was kind enough to steer us toward a pretty good Sangiovese. His advice was appreciated, as I'm woefully ignorant when it comes to Italian wines.

I had the burrata salad, which was light and delicious. I've yet to have lousy burrata, so perhaps I'm grading on an easy curve here, but Uva's has radish and mint, and unless you're allergic to good food, I think it's safe to say you'll enjoy it.

Main course: beef & pork meatballs. Lotsa meat here. Enough that I though I might have to call it quits between balls three and four. Flavor was excellent; sort of a dual-sauce thing going on, with a well-excuted marinara sauce as the primary, and a (mint-based, if I recall) salsa verde as the secondary. If you're a linebacker type, or you've just been rescued from a shipwreck, feel free to have a go at them yourself. Otherwise, enlist help.

Final verdict: I'll likely go back.
author: Brendan D.

description:
Wow, what a cool place Uva Enoteca is.  We had our latest dinner club here and everyone enjoyed themselves.  The meat and cheese appetizer to begin with were amazing and so tasty as were the salads which were different but very good.  For the main meal, the panninis (unlike traditional) pannins were very good and the pizza was excellent.

Our waitress was great and a lot of fun.  The art in the space was very cool and compelling as well but the biggest draw for me was that they were playing Motley Crue's Shout at the Devil album.  They are my favorite band but to hear them and especially that album in a restaurant was pretty damn cool.
author: Blake B.

description:
I've never had a problem making an OpenTable reservation here, which is surprisingly considering how flawless the food is here and the bustling location in Lower Haight. The atmosphere has the potential to be intimate but there are often large and gregarious groups dining here so I wouldn't reserve this spot for a first date. 

Plenty of vegetarian options stand out on the menu but if you're a meat eater, you obviously have to try the wild boar ragout. Take note of the nightly specials too, because they're usually quite tempting. Pizza with asparagus, fried egg and goat cheese is dynamite, and the pecorino, salt and fresh cracked pepper bucatini is out of this world. Most recently I thoroughly enjoyed a plate of pasta with wild mushrooms, goat cheese, heirloom tomatoes and parsley. Uva definitely tops my list of Italian restaurants in the city thanks to the great menu, ease of access and lack of pretension or fuss.
author: Kat F.

description:
I'm not in a generous mood today. 3.5* and I rounded down. 

I'm not from SF and I don't know the area all that well but the Uva Enoteca brunch ad on Yelp caught my eye. Did somebody say Bottomless Bellinis? I read reviews on dozens of other brunch places but no matter how great everyone else's menus looked, I couldn't get the thought of the Bottomless Bellinis out of my mind. 

Keep in mind that a regular bellini costs $7 and I was determined to get my money's worth so I had multiple refills. While they tasted good, they seemed too dense - perhaps not enough prosecco? It didn't matter though, I was feeling pretty happy after a couple of glasses. 

The food is delicious but on the petite side. At $8-$11 for most items, the menu is priced right but the portions are just too small. We all ate every thing on our plate and everyone was still hungry. That made me a little bit sad since I had also consumed several liquefied peaches by that point as well. We ended up going to get ice cream after brunch.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Uva Enoteca has a special place in my heart because of the fact that my boyfriend and I had our first date here. That was over four years ago. Since then I have returned at least four times to have a great experience on each visit. The wine list has a great selection of italian wines and the staff are very knowledgable and helpful with wine selection. I have not yet had a bad wine here. The food is also always great from the pizza to the extensive cheese selection to the salad. Last time my boyfriend and I were here we spit a very tasty pork dish in balsamic sauce with brussels and we loved it. 

I am thankful to have this great place nearby with the right relaxed yet romantic atmosphere where delicious wines and food can be expected. A good review for Uva is long overdue.
author: Christy D.

description: This review is only for the pizza take out, which I ordered through Caviar. Unfortunately Caviar does not have many pizza places to order from, but this one is definitely not to par with other options in town. I am Italian and I may be picky about my pizza, but the sauce and dough were more like an American pizza than an Italian pizza. For ~$20 with tax, it was not worth it. For that price, Il Casaro has better pizza.
author: Alberto T.

description: Great service. Awesome salads and desserts. Order the meatballs.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Uva Enoteca is a cool little spot located in lower haight or what I have nicknamed as hipster homebase. Haha. Anyways, this little wine bar has a classy little store front and has a bourgeois feel inside. I liked it, but not too much. I didn't really think there was anything that special.

My friend and I got a half bottle of moscato. It was really really sweet, well duh, it is a dessert wine. Tasted a lot like sparkling cider. Haha. My friend got a red wine, I didn't try it, but it sounded really good when our waiter was helping us noobiess pick what to eat & drink. I am happy we got such a patient waiter because we were asking him to help us pick EVERYTHING.

3 cheeses $15 - I chose all the cow made cheeses. Yummy.
3 meats $15 - specka, pancetta, prosciutto
Pizza - sausage and pepperoni, I liked the pizza best!

Nice experience, don't know if I'll be coming back in a jiffy.
author: Jackie M.

description: Nice vibe, good for a date night. Had the Japanese eggplant, stuffed shells, and chocolate boudino. All were great!
author: Neil J.

description: Liver crostini, corn salad, meatball pizza, kale pizza all just ok. Not bad not great just ok. Waiter was very nice. Prices were just right, otherwise I would've given two stars.
author: LT B.

description: went for valentines. ordered the 5 meat board. one of the best we have ever had. wife had wine and i had a fort point. we followed with some chick pea crustini. would have never imagined that garbanzo beans could be made in such a way as to taste so good. it was some kind of olive oil and rosemary puree. outstanding. finished with some chocolate mouse deal in a glass. again outstanding. definitely am going back and would definitely recommend.
author: scott c.

description: Despite having to look for parking for 20 minutes the food was worth the hassle. The AMATRICIANA was too good to be true and the carne selection was so tasty. The pancetta I had to eat slowly because I wanted to save it for last because it was too delicious! I will definitely be back again!
author: Crystal I.

description:
Uva Enoteca is a nice sit with a cozy atmosphere. Service was very attentive and helped me with my inability to translate Italian and understand what exactly was being offered on the wine list.

There was a great selection of bottles and a decent selection of wines by the glass. The server recommended some really good cheeses as well. 

The wild boar ragu I ordered was not anything special, it was pretty basic with no wow factor. We also had the asparagus potato pizza which was better than the ragu but not out of this world.

If you are in the area stop by for the cheese plate, wine, and the pizza.
author: Ryan J.

description:
Peek in.  If you see a red headed waiter, scram, because he is the rudest S.O.B. I have ever met.

My dear pal and I (both bottomless mimosa brunch experts) stepped in on a lovely Sunday afternoon at 1:15 pm.  We both ordered bottomless (obvi) and pizzas with prosciutto, tomato, arugula, topped with a fried egg.  The pizzas were absolutely divine--the perfect combination of salt, cheese and tangy tomato!

Around 1:45, the waiter came around and said, "We're closing early today because of the baseball game. It's last call now! I'll refill this carafe for you!"

However at 2:00 pm, I politely asked if we could get one final carafe before we were on our way.  This was when the appalling conversation with the impetuous ginger waiter ensued.

Waiter: I said it was last call.
Me: I understand, but we ordered bottomless.
Waiter: Well, we are closing early today because of the baseball game.  We don't want people coming in and ordering bottomless at the last moment.
Me: Yes, but your website said you have bottomless on Sundays until 2:30 pm and it's barely 2:00pm.
Waiter: Well, we say it's bottomless, but it's really bottomless to a point. You guys already had 2 carafes, which is a great deal.
Me: Fine, we are alcoholics, okay? Don't market "bottomless" when you mean "bottomless to a point."  If you were closing early, you should've told us when we walked in.  It doesn't matter anyway.  You're not the owner; there's no use complaining to you.
Waiter: Well, I'm the bar manager.
Me:  Good for you. We'll just stop in a bar on the way home.

In the end, the waiter/bar manager charged us for a single mimosa instead of bottomless.  He probably would've made more money by simply refilling our glasses.

Bottom line: Awesome food, but if you see a ginger waiter with specs, perhaps it's best to come back another time, because he will refuse to refill you with a hefty side of attitude. The food was spectacular, but I can't give it any more than 2 stars due to the ridiculous server.
author: Sherry C.

description:
Food=4.5 stars (for quality and consistency), 
Staff attentiveness = 3 stars (staff tend to be a bit snooty)
Ambiance = 3.5 stars (can be a bit noisy on a busy night)

Although, the service staff could be a bit warmer and more attentive, I'd still come back on a week night when it's not too crowded and noisy.  I did enjoy the food here!
author: thuy n.

description: The meat & cheese plate was amazing. The waitress was super helpful with giving cheese and wine recommendations. The pizza with meatballs was delicious. Great experience!
author: Desa F.

description: I eat and/or have wine at Uva three or four times a year.  I've always loved it!  House-made charcuterie, Italian wine, ever-changing menu...  Try the pasta (it changes) with wild boar - after a charcuterie and cheese course.  It's a delightful spot!
author: Jason C.

description: The food was amazing. I had the mushroom and arugula pizza! But the menu you was slightly hard to read and the server was so new she didn't understand it herself. So choosing a nice wine turned out to be difficult. Drink menu was also a little bit more on the pricey side. I think if I had had a server who was more experienced the evening would have been great. But definitely some wicked pizza!
author: Alyson L.

description: Very good value for the price. I had the boar lasagna and thought it was great, even though I burned my tongue when I first got it out of excitement. Our waitress was great and the place feels intimate given the layout. It's in a fun, casual part of town, so very easy to have a good meal and then head out to some other places in the area for nightlife.
author: Jay G.

description:
Stopped in for a date night one Friday night. I was able to get reservations on open table rather last minute. I always get suspicious when I see wine bars that serve full dinner menus... Is it a place with good wines that happens to serve food prepared in a toaster over like so many wine bars are? Within the first few minutes, I learned this is a wine bar but it's also a restaurant. 

First things first, the wine. They were awesome about letting us sample a few things till we found what we wanted, and the staff did a decent job of explaining the difference between the two contenders we selected. Having enjoyed a Kerner just the week before we went that way, and while it was a little sweeter than the previous bottle we had it was definitely enjoyed.

I loved the top of the menu rife with meat, cheese, and veggie options. We selected some cheeses, green beans and lentils. The veggies were fresh and lightly seasoned/dressed. For the salad course we devoured the Burrata with pears and for the entree we loved the wild boar ragu made with fresh pasta. 

We left pleasantly surprised at what a lovely meal it was. I would definitely go back.
author: Nikki M.

description: Incompetent management team; employees are treated like shit. Cooks, servers, and food are exceptional, but ethics are lacking big time.
author: Kayla C.

description:
My wife and I had our New Years Eve dinner here. The staff was extremely friendly. Our server was patient and gave us some great recommendations. She pointed us in the direction of a great wine that would go well with our food.
We had the zucchini and arugula salad and a 3 meat sampler. The Speck, Salame, and Cotto were magnificant while the salad was fresh and flavorful. 
We had the Boar bolognese which was cooked perfectly. The pasta was soft and the sauce was very tasty. We also has the spicy salame pizza. The pizza was a thin crust but still had a crunch. The sauce on the pizza was excellent as well.
We saw so many other items being brought out that we want to try. I guess thats the essence of a great restaraunt. We will be back
author: Cassandra C.

description:
Classy sort of joint. I really like that you can order 2 oz. glasses or 8 oz. glasses, which basically means you can build your own little tasting menu and it's no more expensive than just getting one full glass.

I was a bit annoyed that the wines listed have no descriptions whatsoever. Come on, now, that's a bit pretentious. Most people won't recognize most of the wine listed. So just have a bit of info. Is something full bodied or spicy or floral or dry or what?

The bartender was straightforward and polite, but not particularly warm or inviting. That's okay; it was getting late and he was probably tired. And he was nice to us. It's just a different experience when a bartender is interested. And we were the only two at the bar, and I said that my friend was totally new to wine, so... but oh well.

I'd go back for sure, even though I didn't love the wine selection (I tried 6 of the 8 reds, and I know my way around wine well enough). They just weren't to my taste. But I'd go back, give them another shot, and try others. A good place.
author: Neha B.

description:
It took about 35 minutes to get our food on a sleepy Sunday night. What the eff. 

The waiter was mostly absent and not terribly pleasant when he was around. 

As far as the food goes, the meatball pizza was good, but the crust could have been thinner, and the boar gnocci was just okay. I think boar is one of those sexy meats that chefs use just because it sounds interesting---I found the flavor was kind of like cheap beef/pork...chewy and fatty. 

The service and wait left a bad taste in my mouth, even though the food was decent. I won't be back.
author: Emily D.

description: The meat/cheese plate is a fabulous appetizer - we took our waitress' recommendations on meat/cheese selections and she did not let us down. All our meals were delicious, plus the place has a great wine menu to boot. I was pleasantly surprised at the low price tag at the end of the night, too! Between 4 of us, we had appetizers, wine, entres, and desserts, and it was only a little over $40 a piece. Not bad!
author: J.R. M.

description:
This place sticks out a bit for the neighborhood that it is in. When you walk in off of Haight it is like you enter a different world. It is small and decorated nicely.

I have been here for happy hour and for dinner. Both times it was a good experience. Happy hour has food and drink specials that are discounted a bit but not a huge saving. Dinner was good and reasonably priced but the portion sizes are a bit small.

If you order 3 or more of the cured meats it is a pretty good deal. There is a good selection available from Prosciutto to Hot Coppa to Mortadella. The Speck was definitely my favorite though. They serve cheese and vegetables in the same fashion as the meats where you can order 1,3,5 or 7.

The pizza selection is good and is very tasty. The pasta selection is small, as well as the portion size, but it is pretty good. Not the best Italian dinner I have had recently but definitely not bad. I had the AmatrIciana and I tried the Ragu as well. They said the Ragu was their most ordered item and it's for a good reason, baked with crispy cheese on top.

I would recommend coming here for a drink and a small bite rather than a full dinner.
author: Frank J.

description:
This was one of the best meals and dining experiences I've had in a long time.  The restaurant itself is beautiful and has a good vibe, but their staff is what really made this a great experience. They're all very knowledgeable and welcoming, not to mention were fantastic about answering our questions.

It had been a few years since I've been to Unva Enoteca, and it will only be a few weeks (if that!) until I'm back this time.
author: Colleen M.

description:
Spicy salami Pizza + arugula was delicious...and the Wine!!!  

the kale salad was not as good as last time we had it; it was too lemony and too much raw shallot...I thought there were supposed to be nuts in it too, but i may try again.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I do not understand why some people are obsessed with this place - I suppose when you compare it to some of the other restaurants around lower height, it is one of the only "upscale" options.

I use quotes because it really isn't, they are trying way too hard. Our server could not have been more flustered. We asked for a coster at the beginning of the dinner so that our table wasn't wobbly. She brought it to us as she handed us the check. 

The food was way overpriced for what it was. I got this pasta dish that had way too much pepper on it. It was basically someone who can't cook making shells out of a box and then flavoring it with pepper so I couldn't taste anything else. My BF got some kind of steak, medium, but instead receive a variety of cookedness. In the middle it was rare and as you worked your way to the sides it was well well done. 

I don't know why I keep on buying living social deals. It seems like lately the only restaurants that are on there are ones that are awful... but I guess that kind of makes sense.
author: Rona Y.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night for dinner at 7pm to meet a friend to catch up. The place wasn't busy at all except for a couple couples scattered here and there. Uva Enoteca is definitely a cute little nook that is totally a date spot. The lighting is dim and seating is intimate.

Here's what was ordered to the table tonight:

* veggie charcuterie - roasted brussel sprouts, cauliflower and asparagus.
* wild boar ragu
* boscaiola

My friend and I started off with the veggie charcuterie and the brussel sprouts were definitely our favorite, hands down! The sprouts had a nice roast on the outside and were tender to the bite - good seasoning as well. The cauliflower was my next favorite and we both didn't like the asparagus. It had a weird tang to it and I just didn't enjoy that.

My friend ordered the Boar ragu and I got the boscaiola. Both came in rather small portions and were just ok. Nothing spectacular and the pasta didn't taste that fresh either. Friend and I each got a glass of wine to go with our meals which complimented them well. Just wish the pasta was better! I don't see myself coming baack here.
author: Julia K.

description:
The food and service are decent here, but nothing we had was exceptional the way you can get in SF restaurants of similar pice. 

Although our waitress was polite and friendly, I didn't like how freaking trendy the place is (unnecessary, focus on your product, not on your Toms and socializing with your coworkers while on shift) nor how casually dressed the entire staff was for, in my book, a more expensive place. You're not working a coffee shop job anymore. Jeans and Ts don't cut it in my book. Especially if you're gonna kinda be pretentious and/or pricey. 

Thanks, Yelp, for letting me voice my opinion.
author: Sarah X.

description:
Randomly stumbled across Uva Enoteca, thought it looked cute, had good reviews and was craving some good pasta.

The ambiance was really nice, I liked the feel of the open bar, light walls, and high ceilings. More conducive to a HH environment which is why this place is popular.

Started with the 3 meat platter, none were outstanding. It felt like we were eating luncheon meat out of a container. There was some mustard but it would have been nice to have some other sides like some toasted bread or something to accompany the meat slices.

I got the Boar Pasta and BF got the Bolognese. They looked almost identical but the boar ragu tasted way better. Nothing out of this world, just ok. The pasta didn't taste super fresh and wasn't served super hot like I prefer either. I am suspicious that the meal gave us stomachaches later too, hrm. Probably won't come back.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Ah.... The magically vanishing wait staff. Maybe I'm old fashioned, but I don't think the floor should *ever* be absent all staff. This happened more than once while we sat waiting for... anything.  I mean all staff - even the bar.

After sitting 1.5 hrs with only a visit to take our order (after a bit of a wait), a visit when our food arrived - (btw, the mains took an HOUR to arrive - and I'm not kidding),  I went up to the only staff person I could see in the place for the check and a box -- the guy behind the bar. He said "ok. Let me finish refreshing these waters."  (?!?)   Then he left half the food we asked to be boxed up on the table.  He was very pleasant - but overwhelmed and probably a better bar-dude than a waiter (at least I hope for his sake he is!).  

Maybe it was a one-off staffing issue on a Sunny Sunday & everyone called in sick to the brunch shift. But no apology/can I get you a glass of wine/etc was was offered other than "thanks for waiting" when we got someone to take our order. 

For the price point & level the restaurant seems to be striving for, the service was a minus 5.  As for the food, I think it also suffered due to the staff issues.  My food was good.  My partners food not so good (they forgot one of his pizza toppings & brought it on a separate plate).  The room is cool - but really loud.  I'm giving 2 stars because I really liked my food and I'm writing this -- not my very disappointed dining partner  :) But I'm definitely not going back.
author: nomi c.

description:
Great cozy atmosphere, attentive service and delish food.  The best tho is of course the $10 belinis during brunch.  

My fav thing on the menu is the salame and pecorino pizza - it sounds pretty basic, but it tasted so good b/c the ingredients were so fresh and of high quality.  I also went for it and added a freaking fried egg on top - best decision of my life.  YUUUMMMM.
author: Ursinha G.

description:
Dear Living Social:
Thank you for the Uva $25-for-$50 of food deal you offered thanks to which I have now finally tried this place out.

We went on a Wednesday evening, and based on Yelp warnings I made a 7:30pm reservation for 2.  Don't think it was really necessary on a Wed night and all, but still, never hurts to prepare in advance.
------------------------
+ Yummy bottle of reasonable priced, fruit-forward yet spicy on the palate red (don't remember the name but it was the last one in the Vinno Rossi bottle section)
+ Pizze w/potatoes, rosemary, goat cheese & tomato. Good heavens that should be illegal.  It was thin-crust scrumptious-ness.
+ Amatriciana (pasta) - mild heat, great pasta, great flavour.
+ Vanilla gelato w/bergamot oil & sea salt. (!) Sigh.....
= $73-ish tab(ouch) w/the living social discount (knock off $50 woot! woot!) ~ made it a steal of a meal!
------------------------

I would love nothing more than to go back, and it's actually a lot more affordable than I thought, and yes, next time I would love to try more of the Carne/Formaggi/Verdure options.  

If you wanna treat you and a girlfriend you need to catch up with, or go on a sweet date, or just enjoy a happy meal by your Fabu self then by all means, go ahead and indulge!
author: Anjali V.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place.  The food is good, and interesting... but not to-die-for.  

The menu is really confusing, and when we asked the server the first time I was there (for dinner) how much food we should order, she told us to get wayyyy too much food.  We were stuffed to capacity and had tons of leftovers.  With a bit of a high price tag, it seems uncool to recommend that your customers order way more food than they need.  But hey, at least the food was pretty good.

The second time I came it was for happy hour, after checking out yelp and seeing tons of great reviews.  My mom and my Aunt were in town, and I thought they'd like it because of the extensive wine list and good happy hour prices.  The happy hour menu just says "Vino - $4" for wine, so my mom asked the server if the house wine was just red, or if they had white too.  

He responded that it was NOT the house wine (rude!), but he would check and see "what he had open."  Now, I know happy hour is often the time to get customers to drink wines that aren't top shelf, or before they go bad, but you could at least act like it was not the dregs at the bottom of the bottle.  

When he returned, he said they had a dry muscat.  Being personally concerned that muscats often tend on the very sweet side, and having made the mistake of ordering a wine that was described as a "dry" muscat, only to find it very sweet, I asked if the wine was sweet.  Rudely, he responded. "It's DRY."  Okay, I know what dry means; I'm not an idiot.  But even if I did not know what dry meant, it's no reason to be rude to me, a paying customer.

The bottom line is this: a generally enjoyable place, but weird, semi-rude servers.  For this amount of money, I'd probably go somewhere else in the future.  Except, perhaps, for that $4 Vino.
author: Erin B.

description: Sat at the wine bar and had a great dinner. Got some glasses of wine that were well recommended and were able to try a couple different types before deciding on which one to get. Pasta was thick and not overly rich which is always a plus, kept it light and right. We got the pizza as well, can't remember what the name of it was but was spicy with some choice meats on it! Again really tasty and fresh. This place is a hot little number for a date or casual wine bar. I suggest sitting at the bar if at all possible, always more fun.
author: Ezra B.

description:
At 7:45PM. Hi, for 3 please. Do you have a reservation? Well, I tried to call earlier, but no one picked up the phone. Well, we're not open before 5....Me: Thinking in me head, "huh, I just called 2 hours ago?" 

Me talking: "Um, can we get a table?"
Friendly Hostess: We don't have a table until 8:30.
Me: Can we sit by the bar?(while eye balling the two empty tables right next to me)
Friendly Hostess: Let me ask the bar..(runs back and forth).. Um, no, they cannot allow kids to sit by the bar.
Me: Can I just order to go then?
Hostess: Yes.

So the hostess and the super pushy waitress kept asking me what I wanted to order and we put in our order and we wait and we wait. Finally at 8:20 the food comes out. The two pizzas, a pasta.... but wait.... where's the sliced meats. So we wait again...... by now I'm just watching my food get cold while wondering how Fxxkin long it takes to slice some friggin deli meat. After another 15 minutes, I go to the pushy waitress, "did you ask them to expediate the order, it's like cured meat ya know(in a hunger deranged anger mode)" Another 10 minutes go by.... so it's like 8:45PM now when I could of gotten a table by then, and while the entire time I was sitting at an empty table waiting for my food. Or they could of just let us sit at the table and we could of finished our food by now, but no, that would be too logical. 

So I had to walk to the car, drive another 15 minutes back home in  Friday night traffic , apologize to me super cute baby for starving his super adorable cheeks for that amount of time, and finally dig into their food. 

And the review on their pasta, it's not something I'd even wait 3 minutes for. It's not that I'm just angery, (that partly), but it's like chef-boy-yardi with big noodles. 

So to Uva Enoteca(however you friggin prounounce your stupid name), you are a no go. And I hope a homeless bum throws a rock through your window. Ha!
author: Alex C.

description: We frequently roll the dice and tell the wait staff to bring us whatever they recommend no questions asked.  Usually they stutter a bit but the server didn't even hesitate....first course was the squash soup. Honestly I wouldn't have ordered it but WOW.  I'm glad we got it.  It was followed by the brisket, duck sliders and finally the gnocchi.  All of which was amazing.  They have the huge single ice cube for my scotch on the rocks...which I really appreciate.  It was a fun atmosphere...great for a date night.  Only draw back was it was a bit loud.  No reservations walk in only.
author: Jason F.
