description: I'm very into brunching. I mean when you get to your 30's your days of balls to the wall fun is over , and all you have left to do is get some friends together and brunch it up. I had heard good things about this spot for brunch and took two friends there for their birthdays. I had the slow cooked egg dish which was highly recommended and I wasn't over the moon about it. I was very into the side of bacon I shared with my friend Heather . My friends seemed to enjoy their dishes , one got the breakfast sandwich and I will probably try that the next time I go. The bellini drink special is nice . Great service and nice atmosphere .
author: Lauren V.

description:
delicious lamb pizza... thin crispy crust, not so doughy and chewy.  seasoned very nicely... the selection of gourmet pizzas are sure to please everybody.  

this was my first lamb pizza experience and it was delightful.  very flavorful but on the brink of being too salty.. i guess pizzas should be more salty than bland.  

i love wine but am clueless about italian wines... therefore, the selection was a bit of a mystery to me.  i settled on one that was just "OK".  

we walked right in on a hustling weekday evening.  it was still jam packed so we had to settle for bar seats....which in my opinion are more fun anyways.

UVA Enoteca you are not so shabby.
author: Brittany H.

description: we were strolling through the neighborhood looking for a place to eat when Uva caught our eye.  The restaurant looked small and narrow at first but there is a larger back room.  We ordered the beet salad, the wild boar lasagna and the margherita pizza.  All were very tasty.  The wild board lasagna had a lot of flavor and was very filling.  I wanted to order a glass of wine and our server was very helpful.  He asked what kind of wines I typically like and brought me a taste of a wine he thought would be comparable.  When he could tell that it wasn't my favorite - I thought it was just okay - he came back with something else and asked if I liked this one better.  He wanted to make sure that I was happy with the glass of wine I had ordered.  So on top of the food being delicious, there wasn't a bite left on our plates, the service was great as well.  We would definitely return.
author: Nicki D.

description: We always try to get here for happy hour - delicious wine and unique dishes. We like the pizzas, cheeses, desserts. Don't miss the cold vegetable plates - seasonal and delectable (mixed kale; roasted cauliflower are great).
author: Eve F.

description:
I really struggle to find something wrong with this place, or the staff.

I lived in NYC my entire life.  I've eaten at the first place Mario Batali ever cooked (Stuff Yer Face), then at his first restaurant (Po), and pretty much love his new style of restaurant, and his cooking.

I find this place to be the closest thing to a Batali-esque type 'teca (I believe he owns 4 in NYC).  He doesn't have anything to do with this one, but it reminds me of his places on most levels.

From the food to the wine to the knowledge to the atmosphere, it is one of my favorite places in San Francisco right now.

I don't mind less pretension, and dressed down service.  In fact, I prefer it.

FOR WHAT IT'S SUPPOSED TO BE, I give it 5 stars.
author: David W.

description:
[Food Review]

Its current 4 star rating is more a result of an easy to satisfy neighborhood crowd and weak competition in the form of late night Pizza joints. The food here is extremely underwhelming:

Pasta: I got more pleasure out of warm Chef Boyardee
Waitress: Ours seemed like mommy forced her into this night job
Atmosphere: Average
Drinks: Average
author: Janett R.

description:
I am never coming back here. 

I've been twice. On the first trip, they were out of the broccoli rabe for the broccoli rabe pizza. They subbed asparagus, which was absolutely the wrong flavor and combined with the lemon on the pizza really just made the whole thing taste like a lemon pizza. That was gross. 
However, everyone else's food seemed fine, if not spectacular. At this point I'd have given them three stars. The wine and salumi were good.

On visit number two, we ordered the burrata special for our appetizer. The burrata was spoiled. It tasted like sour milk. I have had more than my fair share of burrata in life and this stuff was bad. When I brought this to the waiter's attention ("Excuse me, but I think our burrata is spoiled") he was totally flustered and got the owner. The owner proceeded to essentially tell me I didn't know what I was talking about. 

Among the worst customer service I have experienced at any restaurant, ever. I will not be back.
author: Kate W.

description:
Slightly out of place in the Lower Haight, Uva Enoteca brings Italian wine and food to the 'hood.

With high ceilings and little in the way of decorations, Uva has a vibe that is at once starkly modern and slightly retro.  Perhaps this is planned:  with nothing to distract you the stars of the show are obviously the wine and food selections.

Like so many places these days, the menu offers the ubiquitous "small plates" -- selections of formaggio (cheese), salumi (cured meats), and verdure (vegetables), as well as pizze and slightly larger pasta dishes.  

Bright and fresh, the heirloom tomato salad was topped with tiny cippolini onions and the thinnest slices of creamy pecornino cheese.  While tasty overall, the crust on the sweet corn, basil, and fresh mozzarella pizze did not offer the wood-fired crispiness that one would expect.  (For that, be sure to visit Tony's Pizza Napoletana in North Beach.) Although full of flavor from carmelized onions and artichoke hearts, the wild boar ragu with orecchiette (small ear-shaped pasta) was not served as hot as one would expect for such a hearty dish.  

While friendly, service was a bit confused:  the hostess was unsure how to seat our reservation and had to find someone else to show her how to use the Open Table application; all the dishes arrived en masse, rather than being served in courses as one would expect; and it was hard to get the waiter's attention to order additional wine.

As one might expect, the standout at Uva Enoteca is the well-priced, exclusively Italian wine list.  Prices range from under $30 to only slightly more than $100, with the vast majority concentrated in the $40-$50 range -- almost unheard of in pricey SF.  Also rare were the knowledgeable recommendations from the server:  he was able to suggest multiple wine selections to complement each dish and could describe wines and their production methods in detail.

All in all, Uva Enoteca provided a nice, casual dining experience and a chance to try some little known Italian wines.  With a little polishing of basic service, the establishment could turn in to a stella brillando (shining star) of wine bars in The City.
author: CJ G.

description: I had the meatballs and the lasagna here for a dinner date on a Tuesday night. I enjoyed the dimly lit ambiance as it made a great date spot, but it got a little loud, and seating is a little crowded as it's a cozy space. Service was prompt and the portions were small, but fulfilling.
author: Ryo C.

description:
I had the mostly magically delicious cocktail here last night; 
*In Bocca Al Lupo* 
which consisted of Lillet Blanc, muddled chilies and basil, a float of prosecco and a coconut salt rim. 
Perfection in a tall glass, served up by the wonderfully talented hottie behind the bar. I must try to recreate this at home. 
As always service was flawless and the staff is ALWAYS at the top of their game. Such a pleasure visiting with them and hearing their excitement over the new menu offerings. I still need to stop in for brunch. . . .
author: Kia B.

description: Was here with 6 girlfriends on a Saturday for brunch. $12 bottomless bellinis are a great deal and they're generous with the refills. The waitress wasn't very attentive but she was patient with our group being big and boisterous. Only giving it 3 stars because parking is a bear-- only meter/ street parking around and the neighborhood is ravaged compared to the nice atmosphere inside. Also a lower score because the brunch menu doesn't offer variety at all. The food is delicious if you find something you can eat but there are no options for paleo or low carb or low sugar diets.
author: Kiki C.

description: Great wine list, comfortable neighborhood ambiance, friendly staff and enough small plates and pizzas on the menu to satisfy any palate. Great place for a date, a night with girlfriends or a dinner with the parents. I cannot wait to go back for another bottle of exceptional Lambrusco.
author: Erin W.

description:
Had a nice dinner here on a Tuesday night.

Pros:
Charming ambiance, romantic but lively
Good knowledgable service
Burrata salad was super tasty

Cons:
Over salted food - 2/3 dishes we had excluding desert were way too salty, even for someone like myself who loves salt
Desert - special was key lime pie and it was comically bad, rock hard crust and zero tartness
Italian - I guess its quaint to have the wine list in the native tongue but when your brain has shut down for the day the last thing you want to do is decipher a menu

Happy hour and brunch look promising, I'd like to give this place another go down the road.
author: Rich L.

description:
I have not been THIS full in a verryyy long time. I was supposed to be on a diet before my trip to vegas, but come here and you can forget all about your diet. You cannot say no to anything on their menu. It is all delicious (or at least the ones that I tried). The prices are decent for this place and the appetizers are seriously the best, BEST! You must have at least a cheese or meat dish. The dips are out of this world delicious. The honey, the jam, the nuts - omg I'm craving them already as I write this review! 

We ordered: 
3 meat appetizer (speck, pancetta, Milano salame) - noo idea which ones we wanted - the best way is to ask the waiter for recommendations
3 cheese appetizer (
Burrata salad - not your normal salad it has no leaves but it has tons of protein. Omg love it
Ragu - everyone talks about the wild boar ragu. Its alright
Meatballs - 4 huge meatballs with bruschetta -  the bread was crispy and delish. 
Lagrein - red wine recommended by the waiter. Soooooo good. Paired very, very well with our order

PS- you can order dessert or walk across the street to three twins ice cream :)
author: Jen S.

description: Nothing great. The menu was kinda limited and the food was just about average for the price. The service was great though
author: Gaurav A.

description: I ate here with a friend during a weekend trip to San Francisco. The food here was very rich! I forgot what I ordered but I was way too full to finish. I think my friend ordered a margherita pizza and it was really good. I don't know if I would come back anytime soon because it's very fancy, but I liked it!
author: Sherri D.

description:
We went crazy with a groupon and ordered a lot- but each thing was really tasty (I am a pretty good orderer).  
The cheese was in really small portions, which left this chesemonger wanting more, but other than that portions were good.  Go for the salad with the seeds (wheat?) and heirloom tomatoes- it was really amazing. 
The waitress helped us pick a couple of things- her advice was adhered to with great pleasure.  Wine was delicious. 
We did not eat dessert because we had already eaten too much- but it looked good.
author: Candace B.

description:
Wow, Uva Enoteca was poppin' on a Monday night! If you doubted whether an upscale Italian establishment could survive in the lower Haight, have faith... it's thriving! 

I've heard amazing things about their happy hour with $4 wines and $4 pizzas, but alas, we got there at 6:30. We decided to go for a medium salumi and the 5 cheese plate from the regular menu, which was perfect for two people. The cheeses were served with truffled honey, fig and a pear & pepper compote.

Mmmm... serve up my cheese with something bubbly! I had the "Miele Frizzante" with carpano antique vermouth, orange, peach bitters & heidrun buckwheat blossom mead (a honeyed beer). It was super tasty, especially with the honey-infused goat.

Molto bene! I'll be back for that happy hour.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I'm absolutely in love with this place. The ambiance, simple decor, and amazing food.

Every time I go, my friends and I order the cheese platter and pair it with some fabulous red wines. It's always the best way to start the dinner. I've tried maybe 4 of their pastas and the grilled eggplant sandwich. So far, I haven't found a single thing here I didn't like.

I don't know if their pasta is fresh but it is AMAZING. Soft with a very subtle chew. The sauces aren't overpowering and taste fresh and properly seasoned.

I haven't had any of their pizzas yet because my mad love affair for their pastas has me distracted. Soon, pizza. Soon.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Bomb!  I don't know where to begin; Uva's food, people, and ambiance are all awesome!

I've been eating at Uva for a while and recently came to the conclusion that you really can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  Some of my favorites are the verdure.  I have no idea what "verdure" means and I refuse to Google it, but I imagine it means something like "delicious vegetables that make you happy."  In particular, the roasted carrots, marinated mushrooms, and Brussels sprouts are fantastic.  On the leafy greens front, they have a zucchini and arugula salad that is mind blowing.  Then there are the pizzas which are among the best in the city.  The pizzas have always been good, but recently they somehow improved upon them with a few tweaks to the recipe.  Finally their wine list is great, and the staff are knowledgeable enough to help a shlub like me get a tasty glass every time.

Speaking of the staff, I am consistently amazed by how friendly and helpful they are.  They're superhumanly attentive, and always ready to offer a useful suggestion.  Aside from being awesome people who are good at what they do, everyone who works at Uva is also beautiful.  Word!

The good food and good people are combined with a warm, inviting atmosphere.  It is a lively place without being too loud.  It's the type of place where I like to stay for another drink after I'm done with dinner.  All in all, a great place to meet up with a few friends or to take that special someone.

Q: What more could you ask for?
A: Nothing.
author: Peter K.

description: If you approach this spot as a wine bar that has a kitchen you're likely to do better than expecting a top-tier restaurant with good wine. Maybe it's because I can recall going there about ten years ago and seeing the same menu (wild boar ragout, anyone?) and the same decor, but the place feels dated and in need of a facelift. It has that tried and true somewhat tired feel that EOS in Cole Valley had in its last days before closing. Nothing wrong with tradition -- I love the House of Prime Rib. But a menu that was edgy last decade inherently does not age as well as standard fare. I realized I was over this place at the end of my last experience there when the server copped an attitude at check out time. First he ignored us and the end of the meal when we needed the check. Then he neglected to bring us our change. After ten minutes or more of waiting, I tracked him down. His unforgivable, unprofessional response? I didn't think you wanted your change. Seems he's caught the presumption bug that that's befallen the owners.
author: JayBee L.

description: This place is: stylish, quality and tasty. Great understated atmosphere, like what you'd find in northern Italy. They are enthusiastic about being top shelf, and prices are very reasonable. As a jaded New Yorker, I hearty approve! I sat at the wide marble bar, but tables are softly lit, good for dates and sophisticated groups. This is a place for smart people to get together or romantic dates.
author: Kurt R.

description:
3.5 stars, but I'll round up.

Had a nice night out with friends here.  They have a decent number of veggie items, although the descriptions of them aren't spot-on.  I ordered what I thought was a creamy mushroom pasta dish, but it came out with a sauce redder and spicier than I expected.  It was good, but why omit the mention of spiciness?

Wines come in these cool beaker/mini-carafe thingies that hold about 2 glasses.  The menu is coy on this as well -- you think your wine is $6 and it ends up being $13.  They were also out of 2 of the wines I wanted to try.

Our server was kinda quirky and aloof, but we got what we needed.  I'd go back, but I'm not in a big rush.
author: Andi T.

description:
Like other reviews, I had a similar experience with the food:

I ordered the Lamb pasta.  It looked like it was piping hot, but when I went to bite in, it was if the pasta had been sitting out for a while.  The capers were extremely overpowering and essentially ruined the dish.  On top of that, I felt very ill after finishing the dish and nearly vomited 10-15 minutes later, but I battled the urge.

I've been here a couple times before and neither time was really impressive, but at least it didn't make me sick.

I'll only come here for wine from now on.
author: Chrys B.

description: I love this spot.  I took my parents and we had a delicious meal, great service, and cute atmosphere.  Uvo Enoteca is perfectly casual and is a wonderful go-to restaurant in the lower haight!!
author: Kelly M.

description:
nice place.

I would normally give 3 stars for this place but for the price, I decided to give 4. went here for a friend's b-day dinner and overall we had a nice experience here. my friends enjoyed their food and the atmosphere was nice too.

lots of people on Yelp recommended the wild boar ragu, so I ordered this dish. It was okay; the flavor was their and portion was very good however there was too much vinegar in the dish, i found it quite acidic for me. my other friends liked the dish though so I am happy about it.

their dessert was yummy as well.
author: Sung C.

description:
Wow. I loved this place.

Our meal was great, the prices were great, the wine was great and waitress/hostess was awesome and knowledgeable.

There are some happy hour deals and the lentils were just ok but the pizza was great.

The eggplant dish was interesting. The brussel sprouts very good and the cheese plate - OMG the cheese plate!!! SO GOOD!

Similarly the pasta dishes we tired were amazing - I highly recommend the FREGULA and BOSCAIOLA.

I loved the suggestions and help we got picking wines - most I was unfamiliar with but thoroughly enjoyed! 

Can't. Wait. To. Go. BACK!
author: Jessica L.

description: Been here twice now.  Once for brunch and once for happy hour.  Both times I've been impressed with the place.  The staff has always been friendly and helpful.  The food has been delicious.  The most recent trip, we stopped in for happy hour. The offered beers for $3 and wine for $5. On the food side they had a pizza for $10, which was delicious.  My friend also ordered the ragu which was tasty. Overall, this is a great place on Haight.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Met some friends here for what was supposed to just be a drink but evolved into eating.  I had the Carne platter with sopresatta, venison pate, prosciutto, and lonza.  The cuts were thin and beautiful, the meats extremely flavorful, and the bread they give you with it is a great compliment.  Additionally had the brussel sprouts and cauliflower off of the Verdure menu.  Both were very good with tons of flavor.

I also had the Panzanella salad, which was not so good.  Seemed to be thrown together with heavy chunks of bread cut up and thrown into it.

We sat at the bar which wasn't conducive to conversation and the place was extremely loud.

Would I go back?  Probably, but I'd make a reservation and get a table.
author: Robert M.

description:
Understaffed. Service itself was great but there didn't seem to be enough people working here.

Woke up this morning at 6 am before work and thought I was going to die. My stomach hurt so bad, and my date felt the same way. Had the runs for 3 hours, even pepto bismo couldnt stop them. Still have a lingering stomach ache as I write this. I've never had this bad of a stomach ache in my life and I'm guessing it's due to the sliced meat appetizers we had because that was the only food we shared in common. I was scared that I had gotten samonella or something, still hope that's not the case.

2 stars because the waiters were very gracious.
author: Anna T.

description:
Uva Enoteca is super YUM. I was meeting some friends here during my last trip to San Francisco, and it is definitely a good choice for smaller groups. They were very accommodating, the plates are the perfect size for sharing, and there is pretty easy parking in the Haight, at least at the time we arrived.

This is a wine bar as well as a restaurant, so those who know me, know how much I love my wine fix. They had lots to choose from and our waitress was very knowledgeable on recommending wines. The prices were completely reasonable considering the pours were larger than normal, I think they were about 8 oz, and the price was around $8-$10 per glass. 

We started with a lentil appetizer which was just OK, and also some pepperoni pizza. It wasn't exactly pepperoni, because this restaurant is more sophisticated than that, but it had that kind of taste and was really good. We also ordered the pasta with a sort of pecorino cheese white sauce and pepper. This may have been my favorite dish. I absolutely loved it and the pepper was not overkill, it just added the perfect amount of pizzaz to the dish. Highly recommend.

We also ordered a side of brussel sprouts as well an eggplant dish. Both were great sides. The eggplant had an unusual flavor but was excellent all the same. 

The Boscaiola is a great pasta dish, and it has goat cheese in it. Anything with goat cheese, in my opinion, is a winner. We also ordered the Fregula, which I am blanking on a bit but I do remember it had an unusual taste to it as well. It has an interesting array of ingredients, including pomegranate, pecorino, and pistachios.

No matter what you order, I don't think you can miss at this restaurant. The service was absolutely superb and I will have to add this restaurant to my list of musts whenever I'm back in the SF area (the only other restaurant that has made this list is Solstice, because of their orgasmic mac n' cheese).
author: Kristin R.

description:
Disappointing . Let me start by saying I am a food snob. I have eaten in some incredible restaurants (its my hobby). 
I was excited to go to UVA because of all the great reviews. Well it fell short of them.
The restaurant itself is nice, causal. Service good host very friendly and accommodating. This is just a good neighborhood place, not a special destination restaurant you would make an effort to go to.
I would stick with the antipastos of meats, cheeses and olives, and pizzas. They all looked good. Where UVA fell short is with wine, entrées and espresso.
With a large wine selection we ask the waitress to pair a glass of wine with our entrees. She suggested the house red ...REALLY? Oh course it was not good. We had the meatballs and eggplant parm. Meatballs had about 2 tablespoons of sauce on them and cold in the middle. The egg parm was little Japanese eggplants with sauce and cheese over them baked in the oven, nothing special that a 12 year old couldn't match.
The Panna COTA was good I will say that. But here comes the award of the night....
The worst espresso I have ever had. It was like Folger's coffee grounds they poured hot water through ... Yuck.
author: Tropical T.

description:
Yelp's caption for a 2-star review is: "Meh. I've experienced better." and that's exactly how my bf and I felt about our dinner there. The wine selection was good, but there is much better food in SF. Not that it was bad, it was just meh. The pizza had a chewy sourdough crust which I didn't think really suited the style that they were going for. The wild boar pasta was ok, but tasted a little flat and bland. Not that restaurants really take recommendations from their patrons, but I think this dish could have been much better executed as a plated pasta with pappardelle rather than mixed together and baked with no defining flavor characteristics.

Oh, and service was meh as well. Our server came over as soon as we sat down asking for our drink order, I commented that we might need a bit more time. Then he disappeared for what was about 20 minutes, which is a little excessive amount of time at a place with a limited menu.

My date was a bit more disappointed overall with the meal, but I was less so. Especially if I tried to think of it more as a wine bar with food (which I suspect it does better at), rather than a dinner destination.
author: Amanda S.

description:
I came here with a friend for dinner.  I got there early so I decided to go in and enjoy a glass of wine for happy hour.  They had a sign outside advertising wine for happy hour for $5, which sounded great.  When I got in to the bar, I learned that they only have prosecco for happy hour.  Although I do like sparking wines on occasion, I felt the sign was a misleading.  And, who in the City offers a happy hour special on wine and does not even have a red, even if it is some generic house red?

I was really hard to get waited on at the bar.  The surely bartender, who seemed to the owner or manager, was doing other things in the back and did not seem interested in the bar patrons at all.  When my friend showed up and we were ready to go to the table, I asked the host if he could transfer my bar tab to the table since there was no one there to settle up with.  The host said no and so I had to stand at the bar for 5 minutes talking to my friend until the bartender/manager finally came back.

The table that we had was in the back.  Cozy is definitely the word for the layout.  The whole place is not huge. It does feel intimate and comfortable.   The really big problem is that the restroom is right in the middle of the back dining room.  We were seated in the middle of the room but the restroom door opened next to us.  It was a bit off putting.  Given the size of the place, where ever you sat in the back would be within a few feet of the restroom door so it is not like another table would have done much.  That is an unfortunate layout for a restaurant.

The waiter was friendly and knowledgeable.  We started out with a few of the veggie sides the roasted brussels sprouts and the cauliflower.  They were good. I appreciated the selection of veggies as starters.  My only criticism is that the flavors were very similar.  They both tasted like veggies curried in vinegar.  Tasty but you don't really need two of essentially the same dish.

For an entree, I had the primavera.  When the description says that it is going to be pasta with pesto and sweat cream, you think it will be a bit decadent.   However, it really wasn't,  The sauce was very light- just a light coating of the pasta and nothing extra.  The taste was fine and I do understand that pasta is not meant to be drowned in sauce like some Oliver Garden commercial, but the dish was just lacking.  It felt like something I could make easily (and I am not a good cook).

It was an enjoyable night, but I don't suspect that I will go out of my way to return.
author: J D.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, really! BUT..the service here was not very good and the food was so-so.

We came in and were seated by the door, asked to change the tables and after a long hesitation they put us in the back right next to the kitchen window (okay, should i ask to be moved again? judging by the host's face - no ). 

Ok, waitress comes by , we are not ready..she comes again (we are still talking having a good time).. she gives us attitude! WTH? and so forth like that with an attitude the whole evening, what happened to the good old customer service?

Food:

Cuts of meat - good stuff
Buratta - very little Buratta, rest is wheat berry salad - not bad
Wild bore ragu pasta - overcooked and mushy!
Mushroom+lamb pizza - okay
meatballs - nothing special
pork loin - good stuff.
chocolate torta - just okay

so, food is just okay, service sucks, nice ambiance.

Not very many healthy choices either. Wine was just okay.
author: Kate B.

description: Very nice. Menu could be a bit broader. Ordered a cheese app that was great and the entre was of high quality but did not do it for me. Asked the waitress to pick a wine for us, she picked the $14 a glass wine that was very good but caught us off guard at the bill being over $150.
author: D T.

description:
Let's start with the good. The cheese plates and apps are nice. 

But the service? Let me just say.. I went her twice in two weeks (for the cheese plate!) and had two different waitress. BOTH  forgot a dish we ordered! The first time Waitress A forgot our salad, which we decided to just cancel since we already started eating our pizza. The second time Waitress B forgot our pizza, and asked if we wanted our bill, which is when we asked about our pizza. Then she said sorry and said she would put in the order. We had to wait an hour to get it. It was pretty ridiculous and the waitress didn't even comp it, which is pretty standard for a mistake like that. 

Now, I know bad service can be a fluke, but this happened twice with two different servers!? And both times the restaurant was half empty so they either need additional servers or just better servers. Also, the waitresses didn't write down the orders, which could be the problem. It's not impressive to not write down an order and then get it wrong. I'd rather they just write it down and get it right. 

Uva is totally a cute spot in Lower Haight though. Just make sure your servers know what you ordered and if you think they may have forgotten something, speak up soon or be ready to wait awhile!
author: Lily K.

description:
This was stop 2 on Eugy's birthday night out. I read somewhere that this place was opened by the same folks that opened the ever so popular inoteca in NYC. As soon as I walked in to Uva, I felt like I was immediately transported back to the lower east side of Manhattan. Boy was I happy about this! 

We were promptly seated in a table in the back room. This place is a lot bigger than both of us expected. Brick walls. Wooden tables. Low hanging lights. Sexy. Very sexy indeed. We both went with a white wine and the salame pizza. 

THE PIZZA IS SOOOOOO DAMN GOOD. And very cheap for what you get. $13 for fresh cheese, fresh herbs and really good meat. And pretty large. I still can't believe that we were eating pizza after going to Michael Mina. haha... Yeah, we're just that crazy about food. 

I definitely want to come back here and try the cheeses and meats and other wines. This place has great potential to be on my heavy rotation list. :)
author: Jen D.

description: Pretty Awesome service, friendly attentive staff, must have filled our glasses at least 10 times. had the champage drink and it was delicisous but I hate the glasses. margarita pizza was nothing special. If you're going to make a margarita pizza it better wow me, especially at $15. The meats and cheeses were exceptional so that took some of the sting out of the pricey pizza. Great atmosphere and like I said the staff was top notch....just don't order pizza :)
author: Michele H.

description: I love this place and am so excited that it is now open for lunch (Wed-Fri). We went there last week for lunch and loved it. The spicy chickpeas in tomato sauce were delicious. The portion was generous enough to split.  We also tried a heirloom tomato panini and the smoked mozarella pizza with an egg . Delicious. We'll be back here again for lunch (and dinner of course).
author: Olga S.

description: I think the Yelp reviews set high expectations for me, and honestly this is probably a restaurant I won't care to come back to. My friend and I ordered the popular boar ragu pasta, the mushroom pizza and panna cotta. I enjoy my pasta al dente, but theirs was just a little hard. Could have been cooked for another minute. The mushroom pizza was fine, but in SF there are so many stellar pizza places that this one just didn't compare. And the panna cotta was probably one of the worst versions I had. The flavor was fine but the texture was all wrong. It tasted more like pudding. Sorry, won't be back.
author: Jen K.

description: I loved this place and cannot wait to return. It certainly is a little gem and I do not know why I didn't know about it sooner. There is a great selection of wines, and the food was unique staples. I had the kale lasagna - it seems like they baked the kale prior to making the lasagna. It had a perfect crunch.
author: Ashley B.

description:
This restaurant is adorable! So dim and cozy, with great service and waiters who know their stuff.

Reservations: this was a little confusing because their website says that they encourage walk-ins, so I didn't call to make a reservation. However, when we got there, the waitress told us they were all booked for the night. She was super sweet and did manage to make us a little table in a corner, so our wait was only about 10 minutes. Moral of the story: make a reservation.

Food: I got the wild boar ragu, which was so hearty and tasty. It comes in a ceramic dish with a caramelized top and was delicious. My vegetarian roommates got the eggplant sandwich, which they both thought was too bland, and the potato pizza, which they both loved.

We also got the cheese plate, which comes with honey, almonds, and currants. Really good and unique cheeses that I had never heard of before, so it was great to try something new.

Expect to spend around $30 for dinner if you get wine.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Recently came here with a new acquaintance I met through a group of friends and had a great time enjoying a decently priced bottle of red wine from Italy (unfortunately, the name was a bit to long to remember,  but was one of the few to fall into the $20 category) that tasted quite delicious. The selection of Italian wines was a bit exhilirating and our wine bartender/espresso barrista (they have an espresso machine here as well!) performed informed tastings to those nearby us. The place was a nice change from the busier bar/restaurant scene on Saturday night, great for hosting large groups and eating some delicious cheese and meat platters. 

The one thing that really sold this place for me was the music - one of the female waitresses was big into underground hip-hop and I was surprised to find myself vibin' to Drivin' Down the Block by Kidz in the Hall while halfway through my wine glass. 

I didn't have any of the food though, so I can't give it five stars yet. Will definitely try to come back soon though!!
author: Alita M.

description: Uva Enoteca is a gem in the lower haight. This restaurant is quite classy, amongst the dive bars and laundromats. I love coming here to enjoy a pasta dinner before a marathon with friends.
author: Emily Z.

description:
This is my favorite neighborhood restaurant. It's a diamond in the rough for the Lower Haight. I love the fact that it's not your basic Italian restaurant and their burrata salads are perfect. I could eat it every day. The atmosphere feels very NYC, which is great...exposed brick walls and big art on the walls and the wine list isn't your basic CA wines. I've actually learned more about Italian wines from going here. 

I actually find the service funny. It's usually pretty bad, but I feel like that's the vibe they are going for. Very euro actually. To be honest, the food is too good for me to care that the service is so-so. I've brought my parents and friends here as my boyfriend and I just love it!
author: Ramey M.

description:
Delicious wine, served in various portions to encourage trying everything. Which is necessary since I'm not an Italian wine expert. Thankfully the bar tender or your waitress will give you solid direction.

Everything I've eaten here is delicious. The cheese selection is divine and you have a lot of pairing options to create your own charcuterie creation. The only downside is that by the time I've crafted the perfect tasting plate it's become expensive :) Their pizza is also recommended. 

Atmosphere is really nice as well - they've found that classy/cozy mix that seems to be a San Francisco specialty. 

Visit if you're wanting a decadent wine and cheese night!
author: Amber C.

description:
After giving them a year to get their act together, I ventured back to Uva for happy hour.  The prices were great--$5 for an 8 oz pour, $4 for scrumptious pizza, and $4 for bruschetta seemed like a steal.

However, the service is still marginal at best.  I'll be generous and say our waitress was cordial.  Maybe next year...
author: Jamie B.

description:
Worst dinner experience in San Francisco yet...

We both vomited in the restaurant and left. The staff were at least apologetic.

Spicy salami pizza. The best item we had... and it was still quite bad; the crust was certainly puffy and chewy, but the top had cooled. The cheese was so solid it slid off in one bite from the entire slice. The pizza reminded us of a fast food chain pizza and the seasonings were rather dull - spice was not found anywhere near this.

Boar pasta. First plate was sent back because the pasta was crunchy and the plate was stone cold. Second plate was still a bit crunchy, so I gave up. It was clear they had simply tried to heat the first dish in a pan until the pasta was cooked. This resulted in this greasy fat pool at the bottom of my dish and a flavorless ensemble of overcooked meat and slippery pasta.

Meatballs. The first dish was also stone cold and the meatballs were still chilly in the center. The second dish seemed rancid... Overall, there was this strange mealy texture in the meatballs. Perhaps an old batch of meat had been mixed into this one. The manager reported that the meatballs had been made that morning... The use of parsley and basil would imply they were trying to cover something up.

It was at this point that my dining partner had to vomit in the bathroom. I followed shortly. The meal ended abruptly here. 

The only good point would be the service; after seeing we basically didn't eat, they didn't charge us for the meal. 

From what I can tell, the neighborhood has many great dining options; I'd stay away from this one. At least the bathroom was clean.
author: Charlie H.

description:
knock knock.

who's there?

trichinosis.

trichinosis who?

don't get trichinosis into eating here. 

I didn't know people could make meatballs this badly. They were oddly very tough, as though they were shellacked. I couldn't cut into them with my fork. Plus, they were completely raw inside. 

Same with the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin. The bacon was cold & barely cooked, and the pork was still squealing. 

Pasta with no salt. Hockey-puck pizza with both the texture and taste of a salt lick. 

The server was ok, but didn't know enough about food to know that you don't offer to take that food back into the kitchen & "cook it some more". 

I felt like I was living in a "before" scene from Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmares. Nothing short of a Gordon Intervention will lure me back into this place.

p.s. I emailed Living Social requesting a reimbursement for my voucher.
author: Blue R.

description:
What a marvelous neighborhood gem.  A bustling Italian restaurant with unique, fresh inspirations, and spins on the normal.  I'm surprised I am not the duchess of here because I come here whenever I can.  They have an awesome bar where cool people like to hang out.  My first night here I met two foodies and chatted with them.

They serve wine in a quartino, and have a wide selection of Italian reds and whites.  

Things to try.  The homemade bread, asparagus pizza with an egg on top, the pork loin, and the list of pastas.  I would write more, but this is making me hungry.
author: apple r.

description: I've had a lot of awesome meals here but last night was a miss - the bread was very stale, definitely not baked that day.  the chickpea salad was weird.  service and wine were great however and I'll come back.  to the mgmt: please don't serve stale bread! :(
author: Amy Nicole W.

description:
You had better not mention your displeasure with the bad service, or the head goon will lecture you on why they service is not bad (they have experience) and then call you rude for calling the out.

And the food in truely uninspired.
author: Joey D.

description:
The ambiance is warm and hip but unpretentious.

If you're the type who likes their "hearty american portions" probably best to order the Wild Boar Ragu...or go elsewhere. My boyfriend was still hungry when we left.

Decent Pasta and great service. Still, something is missing for me.
author: Kaylie P.

description: I thought this place was not very good for brunch. The eggs are salty. The salad was salty. Good portions, good prices, nice space.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Food was pricey, wine was good, meal was great, appetizers seemed overpriced and skimpy, decor was simple, bathrooms were clean.  Front is crowded, seems more room in back.  It is more relaxing to sit in back.  

We had a pizza to go with our meals that we shared.  That was very good.   Not the best, but a good place to go.
author: Tim M.

description:
I was not very impressed with this restaurant.

The concept for the restaurant is interesting. They have three categories of small-serving plates: meat, cheese, and vegetables. You can mix and match items from each category. We went with cheese and vegetables. The cheeses were excellent. We were not a fan of the veggies, which were generally cold vinegar based salads. They needed more flavor, variation, or creativity. 

The menu then follows with pizzas and entree dishes. We ordered a pasta dish. The flavor was good, but I found that the presentation was lacking. The pasta, a butternut squash sauce over orecchiette, looked like kraft macaroni and cheese, and the temperature was luke-warm. The flavor was very good, however.

The service was mediocre. I was a little surprised by how informal the server was. I don't expect a lot, but I get tired of servers who insist on cutting off your sentence with a "you got it" every time you speak. 

Finally, my big let down was that the "cocktails" on the menu were not liquor-based. I do not think this place has a full liquor license. 

Two caveats: First, parking in this neighborhood is nearly impossible. Plan for that. Second, we didn't order the pizza. This review does not consider either the parking or the pizza.
author: Nathan S.

description:
Top notch italian food, top notch brunch. My dearest mimosa, I have found a new love and her name is Bellini! Prosecco and Peach Puree, where have you been all my life?

Enjoyed everything from the carne e formaggi to the pizza & paninis. Only criticism was that they seemed a little understaffed...I think we found the bottom of our bottomless bellinis for a good 15-20 minutes before we got another round.

But the waiter was apologetic, and the service was good overall.

Can't wait to come back with a couple friends for another sophisticated Sunday afternoon in the Lower Haight.
author: Katie S.

description:
've only recently begun to dabble in Italian varietals, so I was excited to try out Uva Enoteca in the Lower Haight. It's a charming restaurant and wine bar that is both classy and cozy, with an extensive wine list, simple but flavorful food, and very friendly staff.

Our waiter really knew his stuff -- he asked me for my preferences in varietal, flavor, and body, and was able to make several recommendations based on my comments. And of course, you can have a small taste of any wine before committing to a glass. 

The food was also fantastic, with a menu that included Italian appetizers, pizzas, paninis, and a drool-worthy selection of cheeses and crafted meats. I had the heavenly pancetta, chicken, and gorgonzola panini, along with platters of assorted meats and cheeses. Delish! 

(Check out my accompanying photos!)
author: Lisa M.

description: This was okay. So okay I don't even remember the food other than it was a pasta with a lot of black pepper. I remember the black pepper. Ah well. It's been a while since we went there, but we're unlikely to return.
author: Heather R.

description:
The cheese plate was super awesome, but anyone can buy good cheese.  I had the recommended ragu and was disappointed: it wasn't that big (I told the waiter I was really hungry) and mostly consisted of whatever the bowl-shaped noodles are and not much sausage; it wasn't even super tasty to make up for being small.

I don't leave that many reviews - just wanted to here because Uva Enoteca didn't live up to the 4 star hype and I actually was disappointed with my entree.
author: John A.

description:
I've been looking forward to coming here for awhile and unfortunately left little disappointed... 

I ordered the wild boar ragu and when it arrived it looked as though it was piping hot, but as I took bites it seemed as thought parts of the meat were still frozen. I'm taking really cold, not even room temperature. I asked the bartender to reheat the dish and he did without hesitation. Although, I think that he may have thought that I was a bit crazy because there was still steam coming off the pot. When he brought it back, although it was literally boiling in some parts, the meat was still really cold. 

I had high hopes as I've heard great things, but was not pleased with my food experience. I hope that someone in the kitchen reads this post and thinks about preparing that dish a little better....
author: Lauren T.

description:
My partner and I were very impressed with this restaurant. First, I have to mention the service. We both love cheese and wine, but we are not connoisseur's by any stretch of the imagination. I asked everything from how to eat the cheese to what wines we should have, and the young friendly staff did not hesitate to explain it all to me in simple terms and without any pretense whatsoever. I really appreciate it when people let the commonfolk  like me enjoy fine cheeses and wines and help me to learn more about them. 

We chose to do wine flights, 3 wines per person. You get 2oz of each wine at about $2-3 per glass, so it's a great deal and you get to try several varieties. We let them choose the wines for us and tell us about each one. They complimented our antipasti plate wonderfully. The plate included two cheeses, one a sheep and cow mix, and the other an aged hard cheese of some kind. It comes with veggies, dips, and nuts to eat with your cheeses.

We also shared a gorgonzola pizza which was the best gorgonzola I've ever had on a pizza. Delicious!
author: Mark S.

description: Good food but service is just so-so.  Get the cheese ( with truffle) and the meat plate.  Their kale salad is delish!!
author: Connie W.

description:
When it sucks it sucks.

I have given this place several chances on different occasions in varying areas. 

1. Dinner
---- Server cranky 
---- food basically alright but expensive
---- wine tasty but expensive

2. Eleven o'clock wine taste 1 glass (at least 3 times)
---- cranky rude server
---- rude server
---- annoyed server

3. Wine and Happy Hours noshes
---- Server behaved as though we were a bother
---- Server with ass in my face for half the meal

The staff seems to think that the customers are there to annoy them on their social hour.

I spent the first half of my Happy hour with a waiter who seemed to be annoyed that I came in at all let alone to have a birthday appetizer; a guy sitting directly in my view with his ass/underpants hanging out (see photo) and another guy who I think was supposed to be the wine expert in an old t-shirt and jeans, who spent the second half of my experience with his ass literally 6" from my face while he chatted up the table next to mine for at least 10 minutes.

I may not be trendy to your liking. But I was planning on spending some money there.
Now that's never going to happen.

Basically adds up to:
Rude staff
Mediocre food
Expensive
------------------
* / one star
Rather stay home.
author: Marz W.

description: Good honest Italian in a nice setting with friendly service. Best mid range option in the Lower Haight. A winning combo.
author: Jan M.

description:
Went for dinner last week and was highly impressed.  The food was delicious and the service was wonderful.  

The only draw back I experienced was not having a reservation, I was told there would be a wait, even thought half the restaurant was empty.  Having worked in restaurants myself, I understand how reservations etc. work, however when I expressed that I might leave, suddenly a table came available. 
My party dinned for almost an hour and the place never filled up.  

My suggestion make a reservation since they clearly need to work on their estimated waiting times.

Definitely worth checking out!
author: Derwood A.

description: Love this place, neighborhood go to, solid service, atmosphere, food is great and varied - staff always friendly and attentive.  Would give it 4.5 if I could.  Bonus is  you can actually get into without having to make a ressie two years ahead or wait an hour in line...hope that doesn't change!
author: Matthew B.

description: SO GOOD!! I usually do not dine out for Italian but we had to try it at last since we live only blocks away.  The burrata was great, pastas were delicious, wine was good, atmosphere romantic, and service friendly.  The only downer was the brussel sprouts appetizer is served cold - not exciting.  I recommend.
author: Chad S.

description: Great happy hour food items and friendly service. They had numerous dinner items at $3-5 discounts. Food was delicious and portions sizes were decent.  Sangiovese wine was excellent.
author: Steve D.

description:
We ate dinner here on Saturday, February 26 at 8:30 PM.

OK, I have to start with the fact that I was mean to them, perhaps even a jackass.  

I made reservations on OpenTable and we showed up and the hostess looks at the computer and says "could it be under another name?"  What, we have the email confirmation and we open the OpenTable ap and look up the reservation, there it is.

They are busy, booked up until 9:30 in fact.  She offers us a place at the bar to eat (there were two spots), but I'm annoyed, I mean I made reservations for a reason, not so I could sit at the bar.  It is coming up on 8:15 PM and we are still waitng for a table, or a reservation to not show up, the hostess is doing that thing shere she tries not to make eye contact as I stand in front of the hostess stand, impatiently.

8:20 PM, there is still an open table that I can see, I guess it is being held for an 8:00 PM reservation (in the meantime, the two spots at the bar were filled).  Finally, I ask to talk to the manager, it is 8:20 PM and there is an open table and I am hungry and I had a reservation afterall.  He comes out, asks if he can see the email confirmation, it is for Saturday, MARCH 26, I made the reservation for the wrong damn month (I'm an idiot and a jack-ass, maybe I should join the Republican party too).

In any case, he actually seats us at the open table after all the hassle (and I apologize twice to the hostess, I probably owe her more than that).

After all that, I really wanted to love the food.

We ordered the charcuterie plate, which was great - all three selections of meat were superb, plenty of bread and grainy mustard (a few cornichons would be nice, or a pickled onion, but that's a quibble).  Off to a great start., Oh and the service was delightful, friendly and quick.

My partner ordered the Fregula (pasta with prawns and pomegranite) and I had the Wild Boar Ragu.

The Fredula was a bit bland and really underwhelming.  The Wild Boar Ragu was mushy (like an overcooked casserole from a church potluck).  Both incredibly disappointing, although they were rather substantial portions and the prices were pretty reasonable ($15 each).

We brought wine and the corkage was $18, so middle of the road for SF.

After my bad behavior, I really wanted to like it, but I just didn't.

It might be good to go back with a group and have some wine and order a chees plate, a meat plate and a vegetable plate, in fact I think that is what we will do.

Again, my apologies for the reservation mess up.  I am often wrong, but never in doubt.
author: Greg J.

description: Boar pasta and pizza with blue cheese and caramelized onions were good, but the real stars at Uva are the cheese and charcuterie. The wine list is approachable and affordable. I'll be back for brunch.
author: Crystal T.

description: Incredibly cozy restaurant and delicious food.  The small plates (verdure) are unfailingly delicious.  Standouts include the seasoned garbanzos, the beets, the kale, and the corn.  We always order a few of these for the table to share.  The thin-crust pizza is divine (I order a margherita with an egg on it).  The wine selection is very cool, and we've learned more about unusual Italian wines since we've been coming here.  We often take visiting friends here and they always enjoy it. Sitting in the front room is the best.  Eating at the bar is also very nice.
author: Jessica M.

description: Great place for happy hour and/or dinner. We got the cheese plate, kale salad, and the margarita pizza. The last two were HH menu items and just as good as the regular menu. While you shouldn't be picky when it comes to happy hour drink selections, the $5 glass of Sangiovese was nothing to be picky about. Great Italian on lower Haight.
author: Ashley D.

description: Loved this place.  We accidentally walked by it twice though. Its so little ;)  great date spot, great vibe, exposed brick, basic wine list.  and yummy fresh ingredients that contribute to extremely tasty simple lovely food.  i am such a fan.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
This place is as good as it gets in SF. 

I've been several times (only for dinner) and have never, ever had to wait, which is a shock considering how good this place is. I assume most people don't realize it's there, as it's sort of hidden and a bit out of place on that particular stretch of lower haight. 

The food is always delicious and a good value for the money. The menu may look a little intimidating (lots of Italian words) but the food isn't fussy. 

The wait staff is attentive but not all up in your shit all the time. 

Do yourself a favor and skip the two hour wait at Nopa and the overpriced food at Maven. Or don't, so I can have Uva to myself :-)
author: Erin Z.

description: Great food and service. Had a pork loin charcuterie and 3 diff cheeses for the antipasti and salad. Then wild boar bolognese and spicy salame pizza--everything was amazing. Prices are reasonable and if you can get a table you'll be stoked. Can't wait to go back next time I'm in the haight!
author: Ryan H.
Melissa A.

description: Very good Italian fare.  Not a huge variety of choices but the choices were delicious,  If you go early like we did, you can take advantage of the "happy hour" with $5 wine.  A great array of salad and pizzas, the desert was yummy!
author: Donna R.

description:
Pretty simple, elegant set-up. Nothing too gimmicky or over-stylized. 

Amazing, diverse menu. Small potted saladish concoctions. The kale = nutty fantastic. The endives = lovely cold sour. And the pasta is hearty, fresh. And the pizza is really just so good. So good. 

My first bill was a bit of a surprise bc of the multiple glasses of wine we had ordered. They run steep (about $15 a hit), but the pours come to 8 precise oz - which is a hefty helping, so worth it - especially if you like Italian wines. (Though on school nights, when I've worked late and can't be bothered to cook, I head over there to read, eat, and drink a more modest 2oz pour for $3... Weeknight pick-me-up...)

I see the mixed reviews re: service. I can't say I have any complaints. The scruffy-handsomeish dude I usually get can be a little absentee at times - but I figure he wants to leave me to my reading and will come feed me when he thinks it's time for me to eat... It's ok. I'll just keep nursing that 2nd ounce.
author: kt s.

description:
We went here with a large group and had a really fabulous time.  Our server made great recommendations, although I have a feeling I would have liked anything we ordered.  

A bottle of Prosecco and a sparkling Lambrusco started us off.  We ordered the sunchokes, lentils and eggplant from the veggie section and selection of 7 (or was it 10?) cheeses.  Three pizzas and a really fabulous piece of chocolate cake (for the birthday girl) finished the meal.  Our only issue was that it seemed as though our server really wanted us to order way more than we needed.  Maybe she's used to big eaters or they are having a hard time during the economy - either way, we ordered  just the right amount.  

Great meal and a lovely atmosphere.
author: Mac M.

description:
I was surprised that this oh so chic gem of a wine bar was sat admist the smattering of grungy, divey hole in the walls of the Lower Haight.
I walked in and thought " crap this place is tiny" but upon heading towards the back, realized it actually opened up to a large eating/sitting space. But of course, I like to sit at the bar where all of the action is and definitely recieved great service and chatted it up with a lovely stranger who had come out for a glass of wine as her fiance was out of town, and stayed to hang out with my friend and I until we old geezers decided to head home at the end of the night. 

I think their wine selection is very good, the wine manager seemed to know his stuff and was generous with his pours. Their prices are very reasonable for the volume and the quality ( I mean have you gone to Bin 38 or any other pretentious wine scene in this city??).  They also offered tasting pours for those of the indecisive sort.

I had dessert of a pine nut tarts which reminded me of a more exotic pecan pie, but I savored every bite of its buttery rich goodness...Mmmmmm.
I had a nibble of the goat cheesecake and was pleasantly surprised by the hint of florals and subtle flavors.

I eyeballed others' salumi and cheese plates and they seemed fantastic and will be heading back to try some of those offerings next time I'm down in the Lower Haight.
 It is clean, friendly staff and a really great crowd of locals and people who wanted to try something new.
author: Kathy K.

description:
Love it here. The food is spectacular. The atmosphere is just right. The wine is delicious. Ask specifically for Leah as your server and you will enjoy your dining experience that much more. She is smart as whip with an impeccable knack recommending exactly what you are looking for. 

love the service, love the truffle honey, love it all.
author: Cameron M.

description:
In an area that lacks a REALLY good happy hour, this place shines!  The happy hour is understandably short (5:00-6:30pm) since it's really an Italian restaurant, but it really stands out.

The Birra Peronis for a $1.50 each are a great starter.  They also have $4 margherita and salami pizzas that you should not skip out on.  Finally, they have carafes (1/3 bottle) of wine for $4 and will just give you the whole bottle for $12. 

The service is quick and this place is quite nice.  I'll be coming here for dinner soon after this happy hour experience.
author: Joey S.

description:
We live in the neighborhood, and have been anxiously waiting, as Uva is quite different from anything else in the neighborhood.  The food is really solid - we had a cheese plate, some out of sight culatello (a cured meat), a few of the pane.  All were very tasty, and very attractively presented. (I did think that some of the food was a bit under-salted,  including the cured olives they brought out right away.)  And...and this is big to me, the food is really very original for little-old San Francisco.  It's more Italian than American, in my opinion, and gives us dishes that are unfamiliar in American restaurants. Which makes it that much more fun to  sample the menu in a leisurely way.  

We tried three wines and those were very nice.  We're not so familiar with Italian wines.  Luckily Boris had some nice suggestions.  The wine list is exciting,  with an emphasis on wines from regions that are not so well represented in most SF restaurants.  

We finished our meal with some very lovely gelato and sorbetto.  The pistachio gelato with basil cream was our favorite, although the pear sorbetto was really just like eating a poached peach with cream.  Yum.

Beyond the food, the restaurant is very attractive (although a teeny bit dark - it can be hard to read the menu), the staff is very pleasant, helpful, and down-to-earth, and as mentioned before, Boris the owner was great at suggesting wines to try.  By the way, they sell wines by the bottle and glass, but also by the quartino, which is fun since you and a companion can then try a wine together.  That is definitely the most fun way to enjoy their wine.   

We arrived at 6 on a Wednesday and by 7 pm, it was getting pretty crowded.  And yet the staff remained calm and pleasant.  (RNM might want to take a few pointers on blending in with the neighborhood...) 

The restaurant is really brand new, and you can see that sometimes, for example, as the wait staff are learning about the menu and getting used to working with each other.  I'm looking forward to Uva becoming one of my favorite places,  and also seeing how the menu evolves with the seasons, and as the restaurant gets into full swing.  I plan to go back regularly.
author: Carol M.

description:
Fun little restaurant! It's one of those storefronts you wouldn't notice though. I know because I've walked past it many times (usually when they're closed) looking for it. Blame me for not remembering addresses well.

Admittedly when I walked in I thought the place was very tiny, but there is space around the other side of the bar that really makes the restaurant feel more open. I liked how the walls weren't overly decorated. There was just enough wall art of bistro scenes that they were lovely accents as to gaudy reiterations (see TGI Friday's for an example). I loved the display case for the cheeses and charcuterie, it felt like a more european practice and made me feel a little closer to the food.

Speaking of food: I don't think I'd be able to visit often enough to taste and appreciate everything. In part because I don't have money. The rest is because they have so many different offerings. We had the eggplant caponata, a fig and quinoa salad, and a third that I have just forgotten. The caponata was sweet and nutty while the fig salad was earthy. 

We ordered three pizzas for our table. The lamb with bell pepper and the corn with pancetta were good. But I was really in love with the roast garlic and kale. So much more robust and meaty (surprisingly) than the other two pizzas. Great bold and rustic flavor in that veggie pizza. For dessert we tried the peanut butter gelato sandwich. The chocolate cookies were the star of that dish. My only criticism was gelato was icy. Perhaps the gelato is being held too cold. You aren't supposed to keep gelato at the same temperature as you would ice cream, but who really has the space for a dedicated gelato freezer?

Our party of four received lovely service and some great recommendations on the wine. Their wine list looks lovely, though I'm ill-equipped to comment on wines. Thankfully the service was able to suggest wines from the profiles that we like. AND you don't just get a glass, you get a small carafe. It feels like a deal to me.

What I found most interesting about Uva was the apparent size of the kitchen. It looks like there's one cook. Granted, it's a small place, but really? When that place gets slammed, I'm excited at the thought to watch the one chef work.
author: Jay V.

description: Overpriced and not satisfying.  The poor waiter who was there that day seemed to be the only person on staff for a crowd of about 40-50 people.  May be worth giving another chance, but likely not.
author: Mel G.

description:
The perfect spot to take a new fancy--or reconnect with an old friend. My girl friend Stephanie Y., who I've known since I was 17 and who I lost touch with since I was 18, was in SF and we came here for good, honest wine and cheese. (As if I would eat and drink something bad and deceitful anyway.)

We had three bottles of wine, two reds and one white, that were recommended by our waiter. I'm no sommelier, so I'm not delving into the aroma, accents, and textures, but they were all SMOOTH and SEXY. 

We also had a 5-cheese plate with 4 soft cheeses and 1 hard cheese. The complimentary truffle honey, figs, and fruit on the side were JUST HEAVENLY. I almost died of lactose intolerance, but it was worth it to reach cheese nirvana and tell my story on Yelp later.

Somewhere between wine, cheese, and lamb sausage pizza (very good and very good at absorbing excess wine in my stomach), Stephanie and I found out we missed each other in D.C. AND in London by days (where we both lived for a few months)! We even resided in the same apartment building in D.C.! It was then and there--drunk and dairy-ed up--that I knew we'd be friends forever.

We spent way too much at Uva Enoteca for our poor, debt-soaked, law school butts, but I only remember how much fun it was. Coming back here soon.
author: Liz T.

description: I love this place, it's like having dinner at your best friend's house who happens to be a great cook. The service is exceptionally friendly, from the person taking reservations over the phone to the staff that describe the food with passion like they made it themselves. The food is great too! I haven't had a single mediocre thing here, everything is delicious. We've been here several times and looking forward to our next visit.
author: Elzabeth G.

description:
Uvalala.  Uva was great.  We came with a group of 10 girls (a Wednesday).  We had a reservation and even though there were just 2 of us that arrived first, they were cool about letting us sit at the table to wait (rare for SF).

When we made the reservation, they requested that we order 'family style,' which was perfect for us.  We shared pizzas, pastas, cheese plate and apps.  The food came out right on time and the veggie pizza was especially delicious.

I'm surprised to see the negative comments about the service here.  Our waitress was amazing - really attentive and had great recommendations on food and wine.  She was willing to let us taste some of the wines before picking - and we all loved her choices.

Overall, a great experience from the service, to the food to the service - and for a reasonable price.
author: Gretchen S.

description: Brunch on 2/15 was so tasty...arrived with reservation and were seated without a wait. Boar lasagne, stuffed shells, french toast, Bellinis among dishes enjoyed by party. Clean plates all around! Waiter was informative and attentive as needed. By 1 p.m. started to become more crowded (also proportionately noisy) so reservations a good idea.
author: a l.

description: Laid back...I love going here for a chill evening...I feel tucked away from the "scenes", the food is bomb, I love their cheese plate, pizzas and pastas. Everyone is helpful and welcoming.
author: kristina w.

description:
I love a wine bar that has some interesting, lesser known wines. I also love it when they are generous with letting you try them, since they are lesser known and you have no idea if you are going to like them or not. I especially love a place that, when you taste them, has shown you that they have good taste because you like them all. 

Add to that some tasty small plates of food, a weekend bottomless bellini brunch (yes, even I like an occasional change from the mimosas sometimes), a nice decor, a friendly staff and the fact that the place is close to home and you have a winning combination.
author: Drue C.

description: Great service, very knowledgeable.  Cozy, classy, European feeling atmosphere, which is unexpected in the Lower Haight.  Cheese and desert places were great
author: Charles C.

description:
Went to Uva a few weeks ago with some friends for some wine and great food. Can we say delicious?!?!!? Everything tasted amazing! the wine was wonderful, the proscuito was really good quality! We ended up eating too many appetizers and decided to share the wild boar pasta (or something like that)....so delicious! We also ended up ordering the vanilla ice cream with olive oil and sea salt for dessert...altough we've had better we all agreed that it wasn't bad at all.
It's a pretty small restaurant with the tables pretty close together, typical of SF. However, it was cozy and cool....I wasn't bothered by the set up at all. Loved this place...would definitely go again!
author: Niki F.

description:
It's happening. The first signs of holy shizam I'm actually an adult are starting to show their inevitable heads. One of my friends is getting married. We came here with a group of girls for a little casual bridal shower type deal. 

Let me first say, that overall, I really do like this place. The ambiance is very nice - pretty wooden tables, romantic lighting, etc.The noise level is kind of ridiculous, as other reviewers have noted. The menu items are very affordable and the wine list is ample with plenty of choices in the $30/bottle range. Unfortunately, everything kind of fell short of expectations (except for the bottle of wine).

We all started the evening with one of their aperitifs and I am sorry to say that none were very good. I don't usually like schmancy cocktails so I should have known better. I think we all ordered something different so we got to sample each drink - meh. The best one was definitely the chili/basil concoction. I got some sort of a lemon deal that frankly tasted like a throat lozenge. The honey mead based cocktail was compared to robitussin by more than one girl at our table. The ginger/beer one just tasted like lime/ginger soda, which is fine, but at $7 I could just buy a 6 pack of Reed's Ginger Beer. 

We also ordered all seven of the cheeses (very reasonable at $28) and five of the verdure ($25). The cheese was delicious, because let's face it, that's pretty damn hard to mess up. However, the baguette should have been freshly sliced because it was already a little hard/stale (which I know, happens very quickly with baguette, but still). The vegetables were just nothing special - they all were in dire need of s&p and extremely difficult to eat with the ginormous cutlery they provide. Additionally, they bring out the cheese and verdure on these long wooden planks, which while they are attractive, they are not very practical. There was really no way to fit them on the table. 

All in all, the prices are extremely reasonable, and I may be back just for wine and cheese or maybe to sample a pizza. I was pretty underwhelmed with what we got and our server seemed pretty annoyed by us.

I think with a little more thought this place could be greatly improved. For now, Heart is still my wine bar of choice. It's too bad it's so damn far away.
author: Rachael S.

description: Really enjoyed this place! It was a great little surprise finding it in the middle of lower haight. It's a hidden gem and a great place to go for a nice bottle of wine and some laughs with friends!
author: Sheryl P.

description:
A friend recommended Uva Enoteca to us over the weekend, so we decided to give it a try after work last night.  It did not disappoint.  UVA is probably the best looking resto on Lower Haight, sporting a long bar up front and exposed brick walls in the back.  It was fairly empty when we got there. We decided to sit at the bar.  They only have wine and beer here, no liquor, but our waiter still concocted some delicious and unique cocktails--especially the "In Bocca al Lupo", essentially a procecco-based Mojito.

The menu is laid out with small plates / starters on top, and some heavier dishes / entrees below.  All dishes it seems are intended to be shared, which is how we love to eat.  For starters we got the Procsciutto  Cotto w/ Truffle and the Arugula and Grape salad.  Both were very tasty, and even better when we combined them, putting the salad and prosciutto on top of a slice of bread.  The prosciutto was a bit too heavy, however, and we weren't as hungry when our main courses arrived - the Pork & Basil Meatballs, and the Wild Boar Ragu.  Both were great, hearty dishes, but tough to eat after the bread-filled appetizer.

We were disappointed to learn that the dessert we'd been eyeing the whole meal - Caramel Gelato sandwich with chocolate and strawberry sauce - had run out for the night, so we got a the trio of gelatos instead, which was a nice, light way to finish off the meal.  While this meal didn't blow us away with flavor or originality, it was still a very satisfying dinner experience and a go-to spot in Lower Haight.  4 stars.
author: AdamLowell C.

description:
I cannot rave about the place enough! I went for an early dinner on Saturday and to my surprise it was Happy Hour which is always a plus. The only downside to the experience were the people seated next to us, but it happens. The ambiance is cool and casual perfect for an easy meal.

We started off with the broccoli and raw asparagus it was absolutely fabulous I had to restrain myself from ordering another round.
For our entree we split  the spicy salami pizza and it was perfect for two. The crust was light and the toppings fresh.
That night we decided to "go big" and we split an Afogato, it was absolutely delightful. 

If I lived in The City I would eat there every night!
author: Taylor H.

description: Great dining spot in the lower Haight! My wife and I have been here twice now. The first time was just two of us, and I was impressed with the quality service, intimate ambiance, and variety of Italian cuisine, much of which was tapas styled, and easy to share. However, our second dining experience was with a group of 6, and even better. With the larger group, we qualified for a three course 'fixed plate' menu, which offered more variety than the traditional menu, and had a great wine pairing selection. It was much better bang for the buck. I recommend the cheese plate, cured meats, calimari, and pomodoro pasta.
author: Culinary C.

description: Exquisite food! Every item we ordered was fresh and delicious. I am going to dream about this food...
author: Lady P.

description: Great place. Kale salad was tasty, not bitter, eggplant, pasta, tasty and well-prepared. Menu limited.
author: Barry B.

description: What a great little hidden gem. I have lived by this place for so long and never really noticed it. Thanks to yelp, came here because our dinner plans for another restuarant in the neighborhood didn't work out. They were able to seat us immediately. Their bread is yummy. When you order wine by the glass, they serve it is mini carafes so you can still share and try multiple wines during your dinner. The beet and burrata salad was fantastic, although I would suggest that the chef leave out the leeks next time. Brussels sprouts were perfect. I got the eggplant rigatoni as my entrée which was pretty good, but probably not the best part of the meal. Dessert was yummdiliumcious! I just made up that word.. just for this dessert... Chocolate budino w/ caramel sauce, whipped cream & marcona almonds! Oh my!
author: Vrushali P.

description: We went to Uva Enoteca for a date night after buying a LivingSocial 50% deal. The food was pretty good. Very fresh veggies, tasted amazing, the wine was very nice. The decor was great. The real problem I had with Uva was the service. All of the waiters were rushing around and no one seemed to be really interested in helping us. Could've been that we were there on an off night, but I got the feeling that we were being ignored.
author: Jenny J.

description:
Went here last spring for dinner with a groupon deal.  It was a while ago but the burrata with greens was amazing.  Staff was nice and had good wine pairings.   Would recommend for happy hour or dinner for two.

Don't go for brunch!
Was in more recently for brunch and was disappointed.  Sunday at 11 and the place was empty.  Food was mediocre, nothing exciting or even really prepared well.  French toast was dryish, my eggs were under cooked and the homemade bread on my friend's open face sandwich was so hard that he couldn't eat it as unit and had to deconstruct it into parts. Since we were the only ones in there, we did get a lot of attention when it cam to topping off the mimosa's so I guess that's a plus.
author: Nik K.

description: Great ambiance, delicious pizza, pasta & good wine. The prix fixe menu is great for a large group and very reasonable to add to drinks option.
author: Barbara B.

description: Came here for happy hour last week. The wine special was good, light, and refreshing (and great for $5!). The place was quiet, and the service was quick and friendly. Will definitely come back if I am in the area.
author: Sneha P.

description:
A real popular spot, this place was packed to the gills on a Wednesday evening when we arrived around 8:30. Another reviewer said that a wine that was recommended by one of the bartenders didn't deliver - we had that experience too. The second recommendation was much better. It's not an "easy" wine list - not a lot of familiar names jump out to the amateur oenophile so you really need to be able to rely on your bartender to hook up the knowledge.

I was really unimpressed with the food, too - the smoked prosciutto appetizer smacked of Slim Jims (sorry!... my dinner companion is fresh in town from London and had no idea what I was talking about - how charming) and the pasta with goat cheese dish had perfectly chewy tasty noodles but the sauce was very salty.

I'll be back if I'm in the area for happy hour and maybe another app or two, but will save my serious dining bucks for NOPA down the street.
author: Lisa P.

description: Went back for dinner... great cheese selection and great service.  This is a really god place to go on a date.
author: Laura P.

description: Kale salad was tasty and boar pasta hit the spot.
author: Ryan G.

description:
My girlfriend and I were looking for a place to eat late this past Saturday and saw that Uva Enoteca was going to be open until 11:30. Prices were reasonable as all pasta dishes are $15 and all pizza dishes are $13.50 and we decided that with the solid yelp ratings we would go check it out. I'm really glad we did because the only negative thing I have to say about the place relates to parking in Lower Haight (which is near impossible at times).

We ordered Cacio e Pepe, the third pasta dish on their menu. It was basically just Orecchiette in a black pepper cream sauce. That was amazing and I'll be tempted to just order it again instead of looking at the other interested menu options available. We also split one of their pizza's topped with salami and it was also excellent. A nice homemade thin-crust, very simple, but extremely delicious.

The girl that waited on us was very nice and polite. The decor was actually noticeably excellent, and I really could not care less about decor. Overall a great dinner experience. Definitely would highly recommend as mid-range date-night spot, but semi-casual works too. Ours came out to $37 for both of us with no drinks and a nice tip.
