Highly recommended.
author: Adam G.

description:
Came here on a Friday night after happy hour with a group of 7. I had high hopes for the place - we had all heard good things and it seemed like a nice ambiance. We had a reservation but didn't get seated for at least 20-30 minutes past the time. Still, we understood that happens sometimes. Ordered a bottle of wine and hung out at the bar until our table was ready. 

Our waiter was not the friendliest guy in the world, to put it lightly, so by this point we were starting to get a little frustrated. We ordered a bunch of starters to share including 2 orders of burrata.. Food took forever to come out and something was off with the burrata. One was good, but something was just not right with the other. 

Finally our entrees came, and mine was actually half decent which I think rescued the meal overall for me. We took a group vote and decided on 2 stars for Yelp but I'll bump it up to 3 because I did enjoy my entree (Boscaiola) and the wine. Not sure I'll be back anytime soon though...
author: Priya N.

description:
What a gem! It's the perfect little getaway on Haight St, with a truly European vibe and amazing food. While the menu is a bit confusing, our waitress was extremely helpful and made great suggestions for dishes. The food was outstanding! Hands down our favorite (even for non vegetarians) was the amazing pancake with mushrooms. Complex flavor combinations served in a simple manner... mmmm, delicious.

The place: fun location; cool clean design with exposed brick wall, intimate bar and lighting; good vibe.
The staff: friendly and knowledgeable
The meal: unfortunately their online menu is not updated, so i don't remember exact names, but: quinoa Verdure with figs; some magical "pea pancake with olives & mushrooms (to die for!!!); and meatballs with delicious sauce. 
The bottom line: yummy, yummy, love in my tummy
author: IkkI K.

description: I don't know how this place has 4 stars. The food was not good. Bland and nothing unique about it. Way overpriced for what you get.
author: Mei C.

description: They have a pretty decent happy hour- we all had the red sangiovese wine for only $5/glass.. unfortunately it wasn't very good.  I order the chopped romaine salad and my friend ordered the tricolore - both were overdressed and somewhat disappointing...(how hard is it to make a decent salad?)  I had the pork tenderloin which was very good and my friend order the pasta with wild boar which was described as okay/bland.  The service and atmosphere is very good.  There are just a few minor adjustments that will make this a very good restaurant - also get some decent bread please.
author: Kevin G.

description: Great brunch spot!  $10 bottomless mimosas (they do not scimp or use the cheap kind that kind you a headache the rest of the day). The sweet black pepper biscuits are amazing and eggs/bacon fresh and cooked well. Service was slow but otherwise great find on a Sunday morning.
author: Danielle M.

description: Food was great... but the owner was an ass. We went for a bachelorette party & he basically told the bachelorette that she couldn't be loud due to other guests. Very rude!!!
author: Laure T.

description: We bought a Groupon here, having heard good things for a few years now.  We were totally disappointed with our food.  The service was fine, and the atmosphere fine - our wine was also well selected, hence I barley allowed a second star.  However, everything we ate was pretty much terrible.  The pasta was ok, but pretty bland, and did not seem fresh, which you'd expect ordering a $18+ dish.  We ordered a trio of veggies but they were cold, as if they just came out of the fridge - so cold it hurt to bite them.  They felt undercooked and under-seasoned and just basically confused us.  I see that others really enjoyed their meals, so maybe we ordered the menu duds, but it was a really disappointing experience.
author: Dana M.

description:
HUGE selection of italian wines (a bit on the pricey side though). When I think of a good italian restaurant, I think of simple food with the freshest ingredients. This place is is trying to complicate the beautiful simplicity of fine italian food, and it does not work. I had the asparagus, pecorino and egg pizza - it was bland, I did not finish it, pretty boring actually. 
The wait staff are incredibly easy going, polite, professional and helpful, they were the highlight of the place for me.  I was amazed at how personable they were even though the place was way over crowded and I am sure they were being over taxed. I probably wont go back here
author: Jo A.

description:
our experience on friday night at Uva was outstanding.  I thought each dish that we ate was intelligent and delicious.  The service was really good and all four of us walked away happy.  The only reason we ended up there was because Uva was featured on Broke Ass Stuarts Broke Bucks promotion.  I thought we had purchased it but it turned out we didn't.  I looked at the menu and thought it looked cool so we went.  I will definitely be back.

House cured olives were terrific
pizza with goat cheese and potato also great
meat and cheese plate was delish
pasta with cream and pepper was rich and tasty
pasta with guanciale was porktastic
author: ari b.

description:
Fairly standard wine bar with small eats and knowledgeable waiters. A bit pricey overall for the quality of wines that they offer. Seems like a potentially good first date place because of the galleries that are nearby.

We arrived here at about 6pm on a Friday afternoon for some wine and a light snack. When we first arrived, the bar was full but most of the tables were open.

The service started out great, but as the night progressed, they made it clear that other people had "reserved out table." Sure, being a former-waitress myself. I totally understand, so I guess the lesson is if you're walking in, go early, and LEAVE EARLY. The waiter knew his wines (which they SHOULD) and let us taste one or two to make sure that we enjoyed them before getting the full 10oz. Again, this is standard in any wine bar. The wines were good, but nothing that blew my mind. 

We weren't too hungry, but were curious about their meat platter which comes with a selection of various meats. We opted for the cooked prosciutto with truffle, pheasant, and pate. The pickles and mustard that came with it  on the side were delicious. I might try the getting the raw prosciutto next time because the taste and texture of the cooked one reminded me more of ham than cured goodness. The pheasant and pate looked like slices of meatloaf filled with random greens. That said, I actually quite liked the pheasant (a bit different) and the pate. 

The wines were good but nothing to write home about. There are better places to get wine in the city, but if I'm in the Haight and craving wine again, I'd probably go again.
author: Sue Y.

description:
Having just read and seen Eat Pray Love I was in some serious need of italian cuisine.  I walked in craving crunchy bread, olive oil and red wine.  Upon asking for some bread, I received just what I wished for, bread so crunchy that the olive oil filled the nooks.  The wild boar ragu was savory and hearty.  The prosciutto and corn pizza was salty and sweet.

My only complaints would be the not outstanding service.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description:
a disappointment. 
ordered the eggplant. they came back 20minutes later proclaiming they didnt have it, but started to cook something else in its place (without confirming with me). because im nice, i agreed to it but when it came out it was as sad plate of completely undercooked noodles. and so they offered to bring something else out for me. i ordered the pork. by this time, my dinner companions had already completed their meals. by the time my meal came out, the kitchen staff had rushed it and it wasn't even seared and/or cooked. 

the wait staff was extremely nice and the ambiance was chill. but i probably will not come back to give the food a second chance.
author: Jeanne F.

description: Came here with a Livingsocial deal and am glad I bought it. I never venture to this area of the city cuz it feels nasty here, and while that is still the case, I would venture to Uva again. My friend and I liked the hip rustic ambiance and we got a seat away from the crowd. Even though the place was packed, we could talk effortlessly, so the acoustics were pretty decent. While all the food we got wasn't awesome, we would go back again as they all had many fun small plates to try and some unique dessert items that were too cool looking to not go back for. Service was great too! Prices were normal.
author: Unicorn U.

description:
Such a disappointment! I went here once for lunch and had a good salad, so I was pumped to check it out for dinner last night.  
The place itself is great- very casual and simple- and the staff was pretty attentive, though the waiter did get my drink order wrong.  But the food! Boo.
I ordered a cheese plate and took the servers recommendations on my 3 kinds.  The first just tasted like a tangy cream cheese, the second was fine but nothing special, but the third- the pecorino-style with truffles- it was awful.  I love cheese. I love truffles. Somehow putting the two together like this was just an disgusting mess.  It was served sweaty, so it was obviously sitting out, so maybe cold it's better? But really, just so awful. I forced my dining companion to try it just to experience the awfulness. It didn't help that the bread served with the cheese plate was clearly not fresh.  I also had the Venetian cauliflower with shallots, raisins and capers.  It was fine, but the menu didn't say it was pickled cauliflower, and that was what came out.  It was really vinegary and there were no capers.
My dining companion had a pasta dish with mushrooms that was perfectly fine, but the pasta was undercooked and there was nothing notable about the dish.  
Overall, I was pretty bummed about the food, because it's such a cool little place.
author: Mallori M.

description: Great food, awesome wine selection (and help for those of us less knowledgable about grape juice), cool little space, good service, and fun people. All comes together for a great experience. I will definitely be using it as my go-to date spot in Lower Haight.
author: Tirso P.

description:
Not my first spot to go for a full on dinner out, but definitely the first place I go for a glass of wine, a nice cheese and/or salumi plate, and maybe a salad to split.

The first time we tried it, the boyfriend and I went here before a movie at the Kabuki. We had an assortment of cured meats, a selection of salads, and a pasta. All delicious. Our wine was much lighter and more acidic than the server had said, so we were a little disappointed there, but overall it was a good meal. Very cute date spot.

The next time I went was with a girlfriend from out of town. We each had a salad (still excellent), and split a pizza. The crust was a little toasty at parts, but I'm a sucker for thin crust, and it was very tasty. Well balanced toppings, and not too saucy to get soggy. We ordered our wines by the glass and had a much more successful wine experience.

This is a great little neighborhood spot for a light meal or happy hour. Adorable decor, solid menu, and friendly staff.
author: T T.

description: No me gusta.  Before going, you need to know that, aside from pizza and pasta, the restaurant offers two dinner dishes.  Two.  The boar bolognese pasta was ok (I'm trying to be  positive here) but featured exactly no vegetables or additions of any kind, and my partner's clam pasta was simply bad-tasting.  There are just so many better places to eat in SF!
author: Tom W.

description: Made a reservation for a Friday night. Place was busy but we were seated immediately. Food was fantastic! Three carne plate and a pizza was more than enough to split for two people plus wine, free bread and dessert. The roasted mushroom pizza with fried egg and sage was my favorite thing I've had in a long time. Our server was fun and friendly and gave good suggestions.  Easy to miss from the outside! Glad we discovered this place.
author: Kate P.

description:
Salivating as I'm thinking of this place! We had:

3 veggie dishes as appetizers for $15 
-Red lentils, herbs, croutons 
-Root veggies with herbs
-Brussel sprouts with balsamic vinegar

Split an arugla pesto pasta dish and a goat cheese & pepper pizza.

Had a dark, full red wine & a lighter pinot-esque red in our own mini carafes. 

Simple Italian food done well. Friendly staff, well lit setting, beautiful people. Winning combo!
author: Amber K.

description: $10 for bottomless bellinis! The brunch menu is great too!
author: Tessa K.

description: Didn't have a chance to order from the dinner menu.  Review is only for the charcuterie, cheese, and dessert.  All were quite good.  Our server was attentive and enthusiastic.  I'd like to go back and try the cooked food.
author: Eric C.

description: Hella expensive, but damn. One of the best meals I have ever had. Thank you living social for the great deal so we could just go wrong and order of amazing boar pasta, a simple farro salad with burrata that I am still thinking about 2 months, the great wine list, the great pig part meats. What an incredible meal and service was knowledgable, fun and attentive.
author: Olivia M.

description: Great food and service.  It gets loud in there though, so small groups (2-4) are better. You can also try dining at "off" hours.
author: alexandria n.

description:
I guess this place is supposed to be for wine, cheese and small plates, so my review for the dinner might not be helpful to many. 

Anyhow, my sister and I ordered the sweet coppa, oyster mushroom pasta, lamb sausage pizza, food was blah. actually the pasta was almost worst than can sauce

I think my experience would've been better if the customer service was better. But my waiter din't bother to give me his name, failed on recommendations, and never checked in at our table. When he brought us our food, he just placed it at the end and said "here's your past and pizza". I know this isn't some fancy place, but the service was worst than McDonalds. I sure hope this guy was a temp, and not a reflection of the restaurant! 

Prices are really cheap, so I guess it would be great if you just want a nice cozy spot to sip on wine and munch on cheese and meats. But for dinner? avoid this place at all cost
author: Katherine C.

description: Hands down this is officially my favorite Italian restaurant in the city. It's the closest to a real Italian bistro that I've experienced in the states. Their cured meats, cheeses and wine list are extraordinary. The Lasagne Bolognese was delicious, and the salad with Bresaola was a perfect compliment to our meal. The service and ambiance were excellent. If I could give it 10 stars I would!
author: Michelle L.

description:
I live three blocks away from here and have been wanting to check out this place so I went here with my boyfriend. Needless to say, I don't think we will be going here again. 

First off, we had the brussel sprouts, eggplant and mushroom. I was really disappointed to find out that the all the vegetables were cold. It's like they cooked it hours before and just took it out of the fridge. It might have been better if there bread was crispy to pair with it, but unfortunately it was not. 

Second, we had the salad with beets and goat cheese. It not like you can really mess that up, but after my second bite a bug jumped off my plate and started walking around the table! I was horrified, I couldn't eat it anymore. 

Finally, we shared the meatballs and Ragu with pasta. If you want meatballs, you might as well go to Ikea since the ones here are tiny. The Ragu was good, but not good enough to make up for everything else that night. 

The one good thing about this place is that they have wine tastings. So if you are interested in trying various french wines, then come here for the tastings!
author: Vanessa C.

description:
I went here for the first time the other night with my girlfriend to check out the place out. I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. When I think of places on Haight St, I always expect some dirty hippie place, raw/vegan food or a burrito joint , but Uva Enoteca is actually a pretty nice place and makes me think twice when I hear Haight now.

Their menu is pretty solid, lots of meats while at the same time a lot of veggie dishes as well. Their pizza is good, their lentil's and olives were awesome (really, try their olives and I don't even like lentil's). The service was above average for the places I've been lately. I can't remember her name, but our waitress was very helpful and helped us pick out several glasses of wine. She told us about the types they had, let us sample several kinds and let us take our time to pick several we wanted to try. Let me tell you, quality service here in SF will make your place stand out, and after a string of horrible places lately, I'll say I was impressed.

Overall this place is pretty solid, I'll be back for sure. If you're in area and want some good Italian food paired with some Italian wines, come check this place out. It's a bit pricey, but not too bad as I think the food and good services is worth it.
author: Erik B.

description:
Excellent food and a great happy hour. From someone who has lived in Rome, the pasta is excellent, and though the sauces aren't traditional, they are still delicious. Yummy cheese course though not the best cheese plate I have had. Not a huge selection but everything sounds interesting and delicious.

Attentive and polite wait staff. Good Italian  find in the Haight!
author: Dave N.

description:
I'm a little torn on Uva Enoteca. I think the one factor that sticks with me after dining there last night is that I was confused. Starting with the name, to the menu itself, I kept thinking, what do I do with this? We eventually figured out the deal with the menu, but the problem was I just wasn't sure what to do with it, and it took a long time for the wait staff to show up to explain things. 

Once we ordered our food, we waited a while and never got anything to munch on. Being Italian fare, I expected bread or something to chew on while awaiting my meal, but when food finally did arrive, they brought everything at once: Appetizer, salads and entree. We were all just looking at this pile of food thinking, REALLY?? What started out as a confusing dining experience just got more confusing. Why would you do that?

The food itself was delicious! I had a lovely pasta and brussels sprouts dish and the pate was delightful. But even with that, there was a little bit of bread served with the pate, and we wanted some bread to sop up the sauce of the pasta, so when we got the waiter's attention, we asked for bread, and he indicated that we already had some. We thought that was for the pate, and there was just enough to eat with the pate, so it took cajoling to get a few more slices to use for our pasta, which they metered out a piece at a time. 

Noise level: This place is LOUD. We did note that our noise experience was primarily due to the two loud girls at the adjacent table, but in general, hard wood floors and no sound-dampening elements around made this place very loud. 

Overall, I enjoyed my food, but I left not really wanting to go back, which is a shame, as the place COULD be great if they'd work on their pacing and setup a bit. One thing I think of with Italian food is COMFORT, and I never felt that warm, yummy COMFORT feel here. I really don't want to slam the place, as I did have a nice meal, but the reasons above are why I can only give it 3 stars. I'll likely go back and try it again sometime, as the food is quite good.
author: Ken W.

description:
The happy hour here (5-6:30 Sun-thurs I believe), is just fabulous.  $4 glasses of wine and $1.50 beers.  Sign me up!  Also, the food during happy hour the 2 times I have been have also just been delicious.  Both pizzas I had were very very good (one was salami and the other had corn on it).  The most recent time we had a creamy pasta and another pasta that was tiny balls with olive oil (don't remember this name).  Everything was delicious!  

Eating and drinking at happy hour here really is a treat.  You get an awesome meal with delicious food and drinks for a totally reasonable price.  We ordered all 3 things on the menu and 2 glasses of wine and the bill with tax and tip was somewhere around $31.  

Only con is the hostess is the only waitress really during happy hour so service may not be amazing.  BUT still totally worth it!
author: Rachel S.

description: Great atmosphere and service. The pizza was excellent. The marinated vegetables were so vinegary that I couldn't eat them and I love vinegar. A good restaurant is all about knowing what to order. I'll be back again for pizza.
author: Patricia B.

description: Probably the best affordable Italian wine list in town! You don't find such delicious, lesser-known Italian whites just anywhere. I love the decor and atmosphere. Even sitting at the bar! Food is simple, clean, flavorful. Can't got wrong. Perfect for a date even though I've only come with girlfriends so far ;)
author: Marina S.

description:
Went to Uva Evoteca wine bar on Haight Feb 16 to do some wine and food tasting. I have to say I was impressed with the wine selection and the value of both the wine and the food. 3 plates with veggies, meat and cheese were just $14 each and were enough for two people for dinner and 5 for a taste. As additions to the cheese, they added mustard ...and apricots, a beautiful honey and yellow
raisins. The raisin paired wonderfully with a truffled cheese and the the tallegio and goat cheese were just plain tasty on their own. We tried 5 wines in quartinos (glass and a half at about $12/each) including a Tocai Fuilli (white), Pignoletto (white - must try), Nero d'avola (red - OK), a Dolcetto (red - fantastic) and a Garganega (red - strange, but interesting, worth another try).
author: Eric W.

description: Pretty delicious stuff. Only knock is parking sucks around there.
author: Evan T.

description:
What a nice surprise!

Being the yelper that I am... I wanted to find a low key Italian place with yummy food.  I not only found this gem, but was happier than I expected.

Our waiter was very relaxed, informative and friendly!  My girlie friend and I ordered some meats and cheese to start - this is a must.  Then we had pasta dishes which were scrumptious.  The prices were very decent and the decor is adorable.  I can't wait to try brunch here soon.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Uva is my fave place to get dinner in Lower Haight. Somehow you can walk out of here after eating/drinking yourself into a near stupor, and hardly have spent any money at all. It's magic. I recommend getting a selection of both the meats and cheeses, go heavy on these and light on the main courses, which are fairly average. There is one type of truffle-infused ham in particular that is ridiculously good. 

Bonus points because you can ALWAYS get a reservation on Open Table, even on weekends at prime dinner times.
author: Julia G.

description:
**UPDATED**

+
physical restaurant
menu
presentation
PIZZA
sampler apps
wait staff

-
don't sit near the kitchen, 
when they mad something
spicy, we all aspirated and 
coughed.  
waiter a little slow when you
want the check.
author: pete c.

description:
After my first experience here I was dying to go back, I'm just sad I waited 4 months to do that.  Two visits later Uva still doesn't disappoint.  The location is somewhat an outlier next to its hipster Lower Haight neighbors.  It is deceivingly spacious inside (there's a back room behind the bar), not obnoxiously crowded or sceney, but  maintains a comfortable ambiance.  

A great place to gather with a group of your best friends, enjoy a good meal, and drink enough red wine to make it seem like you're the only people around.  Always a big plus when you can just breeze into the restaurant without reservations and get seated in 2 seconds.  I love instant gratification.

Our orders were taken pretty promptly and came out perfectly timed.  
We started with the cheese plate and ordered 3 cheeses - a perfect size for 3 people.  The honey, figs, and peaches they had on the side were a perfect complement to the cheeses we picked.  They serve a nice hefty dose of vino - enough to get 3 glasses out of a regular order.    They also serve half orders for those of you who might have to be designated driver for the night.  

We ordered pastas which were a decent size portion - not too big or too small.  I had the lamb sausage pasta.  The pasta itself could have used a little more seasoning but the highlight of the dish was really the lamb sausage meatballs.  I took a bite of my friend's Bucatini pasta and that was a lot more flavorful - simple but still packed some punch.  Good for those who like to keep it spicy.  At $14, it was pretty on par with other similarly tasty pasta places in the city.  For dessert, we finished up the meal with their gelato.  The cardamom whipped cream was delicious though I could have done without the strawberry syrup.  

Overall, a good meal with great friends is always a good time.  We stayed long enough that we ended up closing the place down.  Big bonus for turning the lights on versus the usual waitress nag.
author: Jean A.

description:
A quaint smallish italian restaurant tucked into the heart of the lower Haight?! Come on..... is this really going to good.  HELL YESSS!!

Had the wild boar ragu and had a taste of the lamb pizza... SEX ON A PLATE!  With a flight of good wine to boot this place is a must-eat.
author: Win R.

description:
Visiting from out of town we met some local friends here for dinner on a Wednesday night.  We arrived about 40 minutes early intending to have a drink at the bar but it was already packed.  The hostess promptly seated the 4 of us at our table for 6. 

Boris, our waiter for the evening, was extremely helpful and pleasant.  He helped my wife and mother pick out a couple of wines and very attentive without being hovering.  

When the other 2 members of our party arrived he quickly served their drinks and kept all our glasses full throughout the evening.  

He suggested the a chef's choice for the meat and cheese course and we were not disappointed.  I wish I could tell you which among their selections were the best, but they were all fantastic, both meat and cheese.  

For our main course everyone got a pizza except my dad who got the wild boar ragu.  I had read mixed reviews about that dish but that night at least it was awesome.  The sauce was rich and meaty and the pasta, although not quite al dente, was not mushy as previously described by other reviewers. 

The remaining in our party got the lamb pizza or the meatball pizza, all of which were amazing.  The pizzas were actually larger than I had thought they would be and we even had some leftover, which is rare in my family!

They did add 15% to the bill but I gave Boris another 15% for the well deserved attention he lavished on us for the entire evening.  I would not hesistate to come here again.
author: Joe M.

description: The entire experience was great - food, wine, atmosphere & service. Will definitely visit again.
author: Nancy V.

description:
I really want to like this restaurant, but having experienced so many of the wonderful places around the city, this is one that I will not try again.  All I have to say, is that I am glad we had a bloomspot coupon and didn't have to pay full price.

Pros
Though I did not like this restaurant (nor did my boyfriend), there were some highlights.  The burrata salad was delicious.  I also liked the meatballs on the pizza we ordered.  Finally, the bartender who took our drink order and appetizer order (because our waitress, after 10 minutes, still hadn't stopped at our table) was very knowledgable and friendly.  

Cons
The reason for the two stars.  The noise level was outrageous.  I could clearly hear both of the other tables' dinner conversations- could have just been the patrons or it could have been the poor acoustics in the restaurant.  The pizza (meatball, mozzarella) was not fully cooked.  I could taste the potential (which could have been great), but poorly executed.  The amount of asparagus in the burrata salad was pathetic.  We asked for break- no oil, nothing.  Ick!  Finally, our Pasta Pomodoro, absolutely undercooked.  Not tasty at all.  

Severely underwhelmed- will not return and will caution all friends to be hesitant to try it.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Is it wrong to be in love with a meat platter? If it's real love can it ever be wrong? Say no or I'll beat you. Haha..I kid I kid..but not really. 

So I had the assortito of carne here and I can't get my mind off it. The meat was perfectly flavored. Can't wait to go back for Round 2. As for the rest of the stuff..

Service: Perfect. Waiter was attentive but not overly intrusive. 
Ambiance: Cool vibe. Very SF.  
Food: I've already given you my meat assessment. Other than that I had the Bucatini alla amatriciana (baked pasta) which was good but, as always, could use more baked cheese. In fact, they should create a dish of just baked cheese. Why hasn't someone done that as yet? I'm gonna be the first. Someone open me up a restaurant so I can put it on my idea to good use..Genius..

This place is solid. Definitely check it out for a good meal and good times.
author: Shreya C.

description:
Oh, Uva...I love you, but not 5 stars love...yet. My buddy lives just a few blocks from here and we came here for dinner the other week. That day we just drove back up from SLO and we're a bit beat. Also, on the way up we stopped at In N Out and so we weren't starving but needed some food that night. So, we headed to Uva. 

Right when we walked in, I could tell my buddy and his girlfriend were regulars. Everyone knew their name and after greeting them, introduced themselves to me. The decor was simple but perfect. We just sat at the bar and ordered some food and a glass of wine each. We started off with a meat and cheese platter. It came with some prosciutto, fennel flavored salami, and then some other meat that I wasn't too familiar with (looked similar to the prosciutto but a darker red color). The cheeses were a blue cheese, a brie cheese, and an aged sharp cheddar (don't remember their exact names). Served with this platter were 3 dishes consisting of almonds, honey, and dried apricots. This was the perfect start to the meal. 

For our main meal, my buddy ordered Pancetta, chicken, and gorgonzola panini. His girlfriend ordered the prosciutto, raisins, and fresh mozzarella panini. I ordered the mixed lettuces, gorgonzola, pears and almond salad. I was still a little full from the burger, but this hit the spot wonderfully. After our meal, Chris the bartender, gave us some vanilla gelato. It was prepared in a way that I had never had nor had heard of. It was served with sea salt and olive oil mixed in. It was very strange, but very good. Although, there were bites that had too much salt in it, but that was a rarity. 

The price for this place is way cheaper than what I was expecting it to be. I would recommend Uva for friends (not a large group) wanting to catch up or for a date place. The setting is intimate with the space size and lighting and the prices are very reasonable for the quality of service and food you get. Well done Uva Enoteca...well done indeed.
author: CLINTON W.

description:
I have been here 2 times and am really not impressed. The wine was not exceptional at all, in fact, I was rather disappointed at the taste of the 4 I tried here. I do like the fact that you can get a 2oz. pour and try a few different varieties for the price of a glass. 

I have had their pizza 2 times and I think this is the best bet on the menu. It is a thin crust and large enough to share as a small meal.

I found their pasta dull and the tomato sauce lacking in creativity. The sashimi small plate came on a salt block which is really different, but the fish did not melt in my mouth as I find sashimi usually does.

The ambiance is really nice and rustic though - I just really wish I could love this place because I really want to :(

I have been telling my friends to skip this place but I am going to give it one more go just for wine and a cheese plate before I write it off completely - it is just SO CUTE I want to love it. . . . . . .
author: Katherine B.

description:
This place gets a big ol' Meh.  Prices are fairly reasonable, but the food is so totally unremarkable for a city with fantastic Italian that the only reason I would come here is because it's crawling distance from my place.

Service is generally friendly and helpful, but again, the food.  Boring.  Salumi lacked complexity.  The lardo edges were dry and scaly.  Pasta was past al-dente.  I had a lovely winter salad, but it didn't save the rest of the meal.

I brought a family member who is a freshman in college here, and she was unmoved.  Which is telling, because if you can't impress an 18 year old, you're not doing that well.
author: Lorin Y.

description:
The carne plate was a good deal (5 different meat for $22), a perfect appetizer to share if you have a group of people.  We had pancetta, prosciutto, pate, terrine plus another mystery (yet tasty) meat.

Unfortunately the entree was blah - I went for the wild boar ragu because that seems to be what everyone else is ordering.  Served in a stoneware pot, it's a pasta cooked with chunks of meat (i suppose as the name suggests, wild boar) and tomato, then oven baked so as to give the tasty burnt edges.  It was okay, but not something that I can envision myself craving.  The pork loin was a bit tough and (again, unfortunately - because I want to like this place) unappetizing.

The space though, was cute, and our server was lovely.  

PS - parking can be tough.  Just sayin'.
author: Ange L.

description: Amazing food and service.  Cozy, small ambiance.
author: Maryam M.

description:
I had a horrible experience at Uva Enoteca about a week ago and i was so mad I couldn't even bring myself to write this review until right now. 

I walked in with 3 friends and there was one 4-top available. The host said "sure, I'll seat you right now ..." then looked over my shoulder at a woman who walked in with 2 friends about 2 min after us. The host then looked at me and said "one moment," walked up to the woman, and gave her our table. Then told us it would be a 20 minute wait. 

My memory was that Uva didn't take reservations, so I was confused. I asked him: "do you take reservations?" he said, "no." so i said, "why did you give her our table?" he paused and seemed to think through a politically savvy response ... in other words, he knew he was in trouble. He said, "well, she called me 10 minutes ago and asked me to hold a table." So I said, "you do take reservations then, just only for certain people." 

He never apologized ... he just told us we'd have to wait. 

the situation could have been resolved to my satisfaction ... Uva missed the opportunity. I expect better.
author: Scott H.

description:
Assorted meats, cheeses and veggies mixed with good pizza and wine?

AND A HAPPY HOUR!!?!?!

The last time I said "hell yes" faster was when I was offered a two for one coupon at Round Table.

I really do like this place.  

It's unassuming from the outside but once you walk in, has a very cool atmosphere.

I've nicknamed Uva Enoteca "654" as in reason #654 why I love the lower haight.

Carrafe.
author: Archie R.

description: The food was awesome, love the olives and cauliflower dish. totally going to come back again. The cheese and meat were the best I've ever had
author: Jessica Z.

description: Very trendy, nice atmosphere but as an Italian I was disapointed by the food!
author: caroline s.

description:
There are two types of food that make me ill when I even think about it. 1) Zingers. It's sick by default, but then I once ate it as a child, while I was extremely sea sick on a sailboat. 2) 'Anchovy butter.' 

I'm sorry to say that I had the latter at Uva. 

I still really like Uva, but as a whole I'd stick to the beverages cheese and charcuterie plates. Food's not so much their strong suit.
author: D'arcy N.

description:
Went there for happy hour last Sunday and, although the food (well, to be precice, the pizza) did not live up to the expectations, I did like it and will be going back. Why did I like it?

The atmosphere was relaxing and smart with indie tunes in the background and our server was sweet and attentive. The $1.5 peronis at happy hour were definitely a plus and we also tried their $4 beer cocktail - it was GOOD (it had ginger beer and lemongrass). The rose wine that we tried was not bad either - and big pours! Now, although the salame and mozzarella pizza was disappointing with rather bland tomato sauce and very small size, the two paninis we tried were excellent (chicken-gorgonzola and, the star of the evening, speck-fennel-apples!). We also had their heirloom tomato salad which was delicious and fresh, but... $12?? 

So, we will be back to try their other wines as well as meat and cheese platters (they looked great at the table next to us)
author: Chris D.

description:
I agree. I felt like this was so NYC style, but on Haight. A bit too upscale for Haight, more so than Alembic.

Anyway, so the 3 wines were great. Lightest to fullest. I kinda forgot what each one tasted when you have 3 in a row. But the flavor was good and that matters.

I remember the bartender with the long hair and tattoos speaking about wine. You could tell he knew his stuff. Also, he knows how to serve coffee like a pro.
author: Alexia R.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite go-to weeknight spots. I'm not really confident enough in people to pick things out for me in general, let alone something as important as my food and drink of choice but there's something about this place and it's employee's that makes me trust them. It probably has a lot to do with the fact that my favorite music is always playing in the background. Or because the beautiful cheese and bread they slice and serve is sitting out in big hunks like delicious, culinary art.

Every time I go here, I belly up to the bar, tell the same guy who's always behind it to pick me out some cheese and a glass of red and I leave 2.5 hours later with black teeth, a full stomach, and a song I love but haven't heard in forever happily stuck in my head. 

They serve fantastic cheese plates. I love the ever-changing accompaniments to the selection, always a perfectly palatable combo of nuts, some type of sweet paste like quince or fig and honey, and something savory. I've also sampled a few of the salads - all on target - and a few meat dishes, the real standout being a wild boar ragu which inspired me to make my own meaty concoction a few days later. Gotta love that. 

For me, a perfect week food/drink wise would include a stop in here, which reminds me I haven't been in a little. I think I see a Sunday brunch in my future.
author: Sarah M.

description:
the service sucked.
food was good, but not amazing, and the service was overwhelmingly bad.
after taking 20 mins to get our bottle of wine, i politely asked for it and was given a snotty "its coming" response, like i had asked 2 seconds after it was ordered.
there are so many restaurants in the city- probably wont be back soon.
author: Erica D.

description: Wanted to like this place. They have the potential to be a really good restaurant. The cooking is so heavy handed. Someone needs to pay attention to the food coming out. Cold, flavorless cabbage. Cauliflower dish had so much vinegar we all winced at the first bite. We asked for another one. Another arrived with way too much hot spice. We had the tiniest kale dish I have ever seen.  It was so bland and soulless. These cooks need to have a meal at Delphina or Locanda and see how this type of food is prepared.  It was all kind of sloppy.
author: Sandra W.

description:
My wife and I had a LivingSocial coupon to go to Uva, and we went last night.  We had gone once before, so we were excited to go back again at a discount!  We started with three veggie antipasti -- brussels sprouts, parsnips, and asparagus.  The brussels sprouts were our favorites, followed by the parsnips. There was not must asparagus in the third dish, and it was mostly Israeli couscous.  I'm a fan of Israeli couscous, but this one was just ok -- a little low on seasoning, and a lot of them were clumped together. We followed that up with the boar ragu bucatini -- recommended by the waiter -- and the asparagus and potato pizza.  The bucatini was cooked perfectly, and I really enjoyed the hearty ragu. The pizza was good, but not great.  The crust was average, but the toppings, especially the burrata, were very good.  Overall, I would give it a solid 3 1/2 stars, but they get an extra half star for the service and the freshly crushed red pepper they brought us for the pizza and pasta, which had a really nice kick to it.  You usually don't get stuff with that sort of kick at most restaurants, and we really enjoyed it.  

We'll be back again sometime, even without a coupon.
author: Pilan C.

description:
- food: hit or miss
- atmosphere: interesting and warm
- staff: pleasant
- price: more than it should be

additional info:
- there's better Italian restaurants in the neighborhood
author: J. B.

description: Cool place.  Delicious meats, good pasta.  Three cheese pasta is great, wild boar pasta also great.
author: Michael E.

description:
she asked, "if you were a bottle of wine, how would you describe your finish?"

"well,"
I said,
"my grapes would grow
on a one thousand year old vineyard
located on the side of an active volcano.

on those vines would be thorns
and the thorns of my vines
would pierce the delicate skin
of those brave enough to pick me.

when crushed, the broken flesh of my
grapes would spill crimson into the vat.

when sampled, winemakers would
later say that my grapes,
'taste like a pack of lucky strikes,
like thunderstorms,
rising tides,
the morning breath of Zeus,
acid rain
with a hint of vermin.'

they will say that my wine,
'tastes like a punch to the face.'
or,
'tar covered gravel boiling under
a hot August sun.'

when my wine has aged
and is uncorked,
the sound of screaming souls
will escape and
dampen in the misty night,
fading into a distant cry."

"I see," she replied.

she turned from the table,
her apron lifting weightlessly,
inertia in play.

she returned with a bottle,
a grin.
she poured.
glug glug glug.
"try this," she suggested.

I swirled my glass,
held it up to an amber bulb,
bowed slightly,
poured it in
and inhaled.

I let the wine bang its way
to my belly like violent
waves crashing against
ancient stone.

I looked to her,
my Uva waitress,
and said the only thing
left to say:

I said, "Lacrima, you know me too well."
author: Benjamin G.

description:
One of the best food comas of my life. Delicious food, affordable price and welcoming atmosphere.
The beautiful marble bar and dark wood furniture make for a casual, yet sophisticated decor. Its perfect for a casual friday night date or dinner with the girls. I made a reservation for 7pm on Friday, but it wasn't really necessary. The dinning room really got going around 8-8:30pm.
The food here was absolutely delightful. We had a Chef selection of 3 cheeses and 3 meats, the wild boar ragu, amatriciana pasta, meat ball pizza and lam/muchroom pizza. Highly recommend the pork shoulder and the soprasetta. There was also a coat cheese, which looked like whipped cream cheese, that went perfectly with the delicious honey. BTW, the honey that comes as part of a cheese condiment trio is so heavenly, you'll want to bathe in it. The pastas were fresh and perfectly aldente. The pizza was on the thinner side with a chewy braided crust, a perfect platter for the fresh, tasty toppings.
Overall, this place was fantastic! Enjoy!
author: Kiri I.

description: We ordered the pizza and were very disappointed.  Pizza is so hard to rate though because everyone has different expectations.  The crust was VERY chewy and tasted like a sourdough base.  If you like the sound of that, then go!
author: candice T.

description: Was introduced to the location after purchasing a living social deal and was impressed from the moment we walked in. Quaint and well lit, the brick lined wall provided a warmth that the staff reiterated. We got there 15 minutes before closing and were not rushed at all. In fact they were generous enough to make sure we ordered appetizers and decide our meal before making wine and beer suggestions. Impeccable service and super friendly staff. We ordered a meat platter for our appetizer, the boar pasta and meatball pizza as our entree and pear snickerdoodle for dessert. The food was delicious and couldn't recommend this place more highly. A great find and must try.
author: Keerat D.

description:
Yes I like to whine and wine, and I like a little cheese to go along with it. In fact, few things, aside from the knowledge that Obama will be our president for the next 4 years, make me happier than the pairing of mold and the fermented grape. Which they do quite well here. 

The staff are always highly knowledgeable about both, and happy to recommend or suggest something. They have a sizable offering of cheeses, including sheep, goat, and cow's, as well as a full menu of shared plates such as pizza, pasta, salads, cured meats, and desserts. The wine "tastings" are actually very generous pours, yielding about one glass and a half each, and they feature some interesting varietals including lambrusco, my new favorite. As far as wine bars go, Uva feels very unpretentious, like a neighborhood enoteca, and their prices are fairly reasonable. 

Full disclosure: I'm here about twice a week. And no I'm not going to say which night, you stalkers.
author: Suzanne R.

description: Amazing little spot.  Great vibe...amazing cheeses, meats and Italian wine.  Go at happy hour.  Largest glass of red wine for $4.  How can u beat that.  Bar manager is super nice.  One night I was stranded in the rain waiting for a cab - took an hour.  They took care of me and were so sweet.  A few months later - came back and they remembered.  Such nice people.
author: Kate H.

description:
Came here for dinner on a date last Friday night. Great wine selection, but limited options if you are on a budget. The place intimate, but it gets a bit loud. Our waiter gave awesome recommendations, very knowledgeable. 

Here is what we ordered:

Wild Boar pasta: Not up to my expectations, the meat was game-y and the pasta wasn't impressive. Not a ton of flavor either.

Pizza with heirloom tomatoes, mascarpone, & almonds was unlike any pizza I've had before...the mascarpone cheese was creamy and delicious. 

Affogato with spiced almond gelato and ritual espresso for dessert.

Don't know if I would come back for dinner...possibly for brunch?
author: Ayesha B.

description: This place is one of my favorites--mostly for the wine list and the ambiance.  I have been there three or four times--once on a date, and the other times with a gaggle of girlfriends. Each time, the waitstaff was super chill. It can get loud and busy but it never seems to be obnoxious and always retains a neighborhood feel. I love sitting both at the bar and the tables. Their tapas plates are tasty, but I have not had a full meal here so I am not sure how it compares to other joints like it. Their parsnips and pea dish should be warm though. It was a a little icky. That was the only downer the last time I was here. Amazingly we got there at 7:30 on Thursday and there were plenty of tables and bar space. It filled up soon though. Can't wait to go back!
author: Uda W.

description:
Background: I went to Italy in 2006, and I left my heart there...with a dish in Siena. That I haven't found here in the states.  A spicy wild boar ragu with pasta. 

I've been in the neighbourhood for a while now and still had not been to this place until last night, and all I can say is wow. It's a little hole in the wall, doesn't seem that big from the front but there is more room in the back. Great lighting, simple decor. I loved it. 

I've been wanting to try this place for some time, despite not really knowing the menu.

Night of: Walk up to the door, sort of drunk/stumbling/starving. Look at the menu- and there it was. The dish. 

We ordered the prosciutto appetizer, which is just a tray of prosciutto and there is absolutely nothing wrong with that. 

Got the three cheese appetizer as well, paired with two different kinds of delicious wines. These were recommended by our great waiter. 

And then there was the dish. Although still not quite like the dish back in Siena, it was pretty delicious and the best thing I could have in replacement of it. Absolutely divine. 

At this point, I was completely stuffed. But we shared the chocolate gelato with blood oranges and chocolate sauce.

All in all, this was an absolutely unforgettable meal. And Uva Enoteca instantly went on to my list for top five restaurants.

I will be back. After all, it's only two blocks away.
author: Lauren S.

description: The bread and pizza dough were too salty. The cauliflower was drowned in vinegar and was served cold (not necessarily bad, just surprising) . The pork was too pink and tasted more gamey than I expected. Oh, and even the wine was sour. The bacon wrapped dates were tasty and the atmosphere was nice (great artwork on the walls too).  Overall, this was quite a disappointment considering my 4 star expectations. Thankfully I had good company as the one redeeming factor!
author: Josh F.

description:
Here's the breakdown:

Pros:
- impress your date if you know Italian
- good wine
- waiters are knowledgeable and helpful
- food is very tasty

Cons:
- very expensive for small amounts of food
- takes a long time
- incomprehensible menu if you don't know Italian
- loud dining
author: Jennifer M.

description:
A telltale sign of gentrification in the Lower Haight - the addition of this trendy Italian wine bar that has seemingly found a comfortable niche in this somewhat grungy neighborhood.  

And yes, while I prefer the diveyness of nearby Toronado or the trivia nights at Mad Dog in the Fog, I think it's not bad to have a little diversity in bar selections.

And what better way to fit into the neighborhood than by offering a great happy hour deal.  From 5pm to 6:30pm (Sun to Thurs), Uva offers $1.50 Peroni (bottled) and $4 glasses of wine.  For $4 you can also nibble on personal-sized pizzas (nothing spectacular but they hit the spot) or side bowl of lentils, herbs and croutons (ok, served cold).

And while the refined atmosphere of this place may seem a bit stuffy to some, it clearly attracts others as I noticed a relatively crowded scene by 6:30pm.
author: F. P.

description:
My best bud and I dropped in this place for a couple of proseccos a few months back and went back last night to partake of the tasty foods.

It was still Happy Hour, so we had some cheap eats and drinks until it was time to have real food. It was yet another incredible Cheap Thrill - an 8 oz. carafe of a good Montepulciano for $4!

We got a platter of meats (the waiter steered us right in saying the "single' platter was enough for two) - some incredible smoked speck from Iowa, and two other meats we inhaled with excellent bread. This was not an HH offering, but for $17 in comparison to other salumi platters (like Adesso in Oakland - gasp at the portion v. prices) it was a total deal.

Next was a mac and cheese sort of dish with orchiette pasta with pecorino and some mighty tasty fresh ground pepper. We each  cooked for a living for years and were dying to know what the peppercorns were. Such a simple dish, but really incredible, and HH price for $4 - yow. It was a huge portion.

We refilled our carafes and ordered a pizza before HH was up. The pizza was tasty, with salami and mozzarella. Just okay but for $4, who's complaining?

All the wild boar recommendations on this site made me cravin' it (a favorite dish anytime) so after a short break we stuffed that in, too. This was a casserole dish of more orchiette with a nicely ground chunky wild boar ragu. I think all the pastas are $14 - hey, this place was a total deal. 

I'd like to go back and do just starters on HH and then have more of the regular menu choices. 

The service was great, although sparse during HH, of course, as the place filled up with those looking for the cheap eats and drinks. Definitely worth a try.
author: Renee R.

description:
Really delightful neighborhood spot.  Residents of Lower Haight, rejoice!  There's good food and more importantly, really good wine in your 'hood!  And it all comes in the most adorable neighborhood resto.  If you're looking for a place to hang as a local, or a really sweet date spot, or just awesome food - go here!

Lamb skewers, awesome pizza dough (Delfina fans, you're missing out), farro and burrata salad.  Really delicious.  Thanks in part to the new kitchen folks, and to an amazing wine selection.  Italian wine lovers, visit and drink as much as you can.
author: Swati M.

description:
I remember fantastic pizza and an incredible off-dry moscato.  I also managed to contribute to a $350 bill between me and six other friends.  I have no idea how that happened -- I was already three sheets to the wind when I entered the Uva, and added several more topsails while there.  All I know is this -- if I end up dropping $50 of my own money on what amounted to a little food and a lot of wine, and remember few specifics except that it DID TASTE GOOD, something great MUST have happened!

Don't ever walk into a nice enoteca while drunk.  You'll drop ducats.
author: Nick B.

description:
the food is ok, service is not bad.  atmosphere pretty cool, but outside not so cool.

overall had a few tastings (2oz pours) of red wine and was just ok.  wild boar seashell baked pasta was pretty bland, i had a great wild boar ragu at bottega in healdsburg and another nice restaurant in forestville, i think zazu had a very delicious wild boar.  quattro formaggi pizza had a great thin crust but cheese was overload on the heavy side.  proscuitto was normal and the mustard greens were cold with orange and almonds which was refreshing
author: Kevin L.

description: Uva invited me back for a second go at their service. I arrived without announcing myself, and everything went incredibly smoothly. No food on my lap this time, I am pleased to note. The food is delicious. We had the burrata salad which was a little on the dry side without the usual tomatoes, and the kamut rice was hearty, I have a soft spot for their goat cheese tomato-based pasta.They must make their own pasta. It is melts in the mouth. My husband liked the ragu. Dessert (pear pecan tart) was more on the savoury side - but that's probably a better thing for my waistline anyway. We had a waitress who was very attentive and sweet - despite how busy they were. If I owned a restaurant, this place would be my manuscript. Feels local, cozy, upbeat, inventive, interesting, busy...definitely worth a visit.
author: Killing Me Softly ..

description: Went here for a drink with my roommate. It was relaxed and casual, and our waitress was super friendly.  The wine list was really nice- deff the best you'll find in haight.  I got a glass of sparkling red wine- didn't even know such a thing existed- it was delish.  We just ordered apps which were average. The olives, however, we're out of this world!  This place is worth a try.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Big disappointment.  Slow and inattentive service, mediocre pizzas, uninspired small plates (the descriptions sounded great but the flavor just wasn't there).  Didn't try the wine because no one took our drinks order - list looked good though.

Too bad, the space is great.
author: Ethan R.

description:
Thumbs up: Intimate ambiance, affordable wine pours by the taste (_loved_ this), pork ragu pasta, salad with burrata, honey, and pears (my _favorite_ part of the entire meal)., the mid-level prices for the ambiance

Moderate thumbs: Service - the waitress was responsive but also very abrupt.  She left the table immediately multiple times if we hesitated for a second on our orders or responses to her questions.

I enjoyed the experience - ambiance was great, service was okay, and food was pretty decent.
author: Melinda C.

description: Everything has been very, very good. i'll come back here. loved my pasta, and my rosso canosa.The bar service can often leave much to be desired though.
author: Penguin P.

description:
A nice little place. A huge menu of Italian wines by the bottle. A shorter list of wines by the glass. The pea shoot salad with prawns is great. Nice atmosphere. 

The front is echo-y, but the back is a little quieter if that's what you're looking for. A great little date spot.
author: N B.

description:
Came here for dinner last night.  This is a cute little place on Haight Street.  The front of the restaurant is not very noticeable.  Definitely could use some more curb appeal.  The inside is simple and intimate.

We had 3 meats (salami, spicy coppa, and prosciutto) and 3 cheese (gorgonzola, Cremoso al Tartufo, and another one that taste like blue cheese), Bresaola and arugula salad, and the lamb and wild mushroom pizza.  All were delicious!  They must have cut the meats and cheese with the same knife because the salami and all the cheese had a hint of truffle due to the cremoso al tartufo.  The cheese come with 3 small condiments (roasted almonds, dried apricot with mustard seed and honey).  The salad was very good.  Well dressed and the flavors worked really well with each other.  The pizza had thin crust and really stringy cheese.  Full of flavor!  Great little dinner place :-)
author: Eegnam A.

description:
So, this place not only has great wines, inventive cocktails, and terrific beers, but they also do some pretty fine food.
Went in last night with a friend who lives in the neighborhood. He has been raving about this place, so I needed to check it out.
The service was great. Prompt, comfortable, knowledgeable, just perfect. 
The environment is clean and warm. A good mix of larger and smaller tables that would meet about any size party's needs.
The wine selections were terrific, and I own a wine shop. I was impressed.
The food quality was fresh, well-prepared, and the presentation was terrific. 
All of the staff is really friendly and clearly know their food and wine. They're also not bad on the eyes.
Will totally go back next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: We went to UVA ,SF last Vacation with couple of my friends,after we were spent time driving from LA to SF for 5 hours we were so starving and one of my friends was looking Italian restaurants on Iphone so we picked this restaurant...we couldn't find parking for 30 minutes ummm!! finally i got some space....foods was great we were really like it,drinks....don't even ask again it was super good........serverr was friendly with us......we had a good time :)
author: Patch S.

description:
I give this place 5 stars for the following:

1.) Charcuterie selection- Try their housemade pate (I'm not a fan of pate normally, but they put some herbs that take away that livery taste).
2.) Delicious Cheeses - Can't get enough of them
3.) Small Vegetable dishes- Brussel sprouts (Again, I'm not a fan, but they made me one)

I also enjoy the friendly tatted up servers who have great recommendations on food. Reminds me of a bit of Italy mix with some Lower Haight.
author: Elaine L.

description:
Lovely brick and steel decor with great happy hour prices. You get a good sampling of wines and appetizers. Their full wine list is pretty awesome (though rarely in English) and the bartenders have never steered me wrong.

I've only stayed for dinner twice and didn't think it was worth the money spent. Come early to start the night off but head elsewhere for a full meal.
author: Kimmie N.

description:
Do you hate interesting and offbeat Italian wines?

Does the thought of creamy burrata cheeze with fresh basil make you want to barf?

Are you totally bored with really obscure and interesting salumi plates?

Do you hate a busy yet unobnoxious vibe with cool yet unobtrusive music in the background?

Do you find it irritating when you're sitting at the bar talking to your best friend and the bartender steadily keeps an eye on you to make sure you don't need anything but never ever interrupts your super important stories?

Definitely do not come to Uva. It will be a complete fucking nightmare for you.
author: Andrea S.

description: Amazing brunch, a nice cute place to chat with friends, I love that this place is never noisy or crowded. The soft scrambled eggs with brown sugar biscuits is divine. Basically, you had be at bottomless bellinis for only $10! Affordable, nice atmosphere, quality food and good service.
author: Sonya S.

description: A generous serving of their Italian meats for apps, entrees are solid - I recommend their roasted pork loin, asparagus for a piatto, for a pasta their armatricana is spectacular.  To end, finish off with their bergamot sorbetto, green tea oil, almonds is, OH, SO GOOD!  A very notable of formaggi offering, as well.  Next time!
author: Tiberius A.

description: So freaking loud in here. Nice wines - try the sangiovese/montepulciano blend. Great meat appetizers - try the Speck and the Prosciutto Cotto. Skip the ridiculously small cheese plate. Actually the laughably small cheese plate tainted my whole opinion of the experience. And how obvious they made it that they wanted us to finish up.
author: David W.

description: I have been looking for a good, chill, wine bar that I could walk to from my house and I think this might be it. From right when we walked in the atmosphere was chill and the service was friendly. My friend and I split the pesto pasta and the caramelized onion pizza and both were amazingly flavorful. We put it down with a nice bottle of white wine before going out on a  Saturday night... it proved to be a great start! (They also have a range of smaller plates on their menu so its pretty easy to find whatever you are looking for.)
author: Shanna T.

description: The food is great and reasonably priced. An extensive wine list doesn't hurt, either. The only downside is that the restaurant is small and can be noisy, so get a reservation on busy nights and be prepared to speak loudly.
author: Kyle C.

description:
context: sunday night, party of 2, around 7 pm
pros: service was friendly, pretty prompt, helpful and suggestive
food was delicious (boar pasta, primavera, great wine), reasonable prices, relatively fast
decor and ambience was pretty good too, not too casual, pretty quaint (it's sectioned off into roughly 3 sections)
would definitely recommend to others to try!
author: Sandy K.

description: Cute place, nice atmosphere, great artwork, very friendly staff.  Burrata salad is a must, lamb pizza was good but a bit overpowering.
author: Monica C.

description:
Second time at this place, so I've given it two chances.  Unfortunately, one word aptly describes the food here.  Bland.  Tasteless would also work well.  Great selection of wine, cheese and meat, but when it comes to the entrees, they totally miss the mark.  Went there recently and shared a pasta and pizza with my GF.  The boar ragu was way past being saved by some salt and pepper and the pasta was over cooked.  Pizza crust might have been cardboard, I'm still not sure.  Someone below mentioned pizza's being almost as good as NYC.  That couldn't be further from the truth (and somewhat offensive, being a NYC native), unless you were sitting in your apartment in NYC and the oven timer goes off and you pull out your DiGiorno frozen pizza.

Nice enough staff and good wine, but don't go here expecting excellent food.  It just won't happen.
author: Chris V.

description: Great wine, and good selection of cheese, salad, pizza, pasta. Perfect place for a date or dinner with a few friends. Nice waiters and bartenders give good recommendations.
author: Natalie J.

description: I think its noteworthy that I never rate anyplace after not having visited at least 3 times to make a fair judgment. That said, this is ONE of the best Italian food restaurants in the City. And I am a huge connoisseur of Italian food having eaten the best ever in Italy. Obviously this is not made by a Mama at a small home in a village, but its on the better side of the spectrum. I have eaten almost all of the pastas and they are all sooo yummy! I usually go by myself and eat at the bar and talk to the owner (or one of the owners) for a bit and its really nice. My only recommendation for this restaurant is they should have panna cotta on the desert menu. The desserts seem delicious but they are just too much for one person (me) maybe if you are really hungry you could do it all. All in all, cute spot, super cozy, super friendly, super yummy and pretty affordable!
author: Janel M.

description: Have I really never reviewed Uva?  Ok, well, I love Uva.  They have great pasta and great wine.  And you can usually get a table; bonus.  Oh, and great service that puts up with people like me.  Thumbs up!
author: Amjad S.

description:
Uva is the single best place in central San Francisco to bring a date. The wine list is amazing, and reasonable, the antipasti and light dishes are wonderful and full of flavor, and the entres are unique and interesting. The decor is great-- simple California wine-bar atmosphere-- but chic nonetheless. And, the guys who run this place are the coolest San Franciscans around. They're also there every night so you know they put a lot of love into this place.
I'd love to see what these young resteranteurs can do with their next place. Go to Uva a bunch and support thee upstarts-- they really have something great here.
Oh, fellas... chicks will really dig you and your knowledge of SF if you bring them here for a late night romantic snack/drink.
Uva is the best reason to visit the lower Haight.
author: Ross S.

description:
I'm giving this place 5 stars because I think it's the perfect combination of many factors that make this a great spot for a date (romantic or friend), or just to hang at the bar by yourself.  I wouldn't say all factors are five star, but Uva has the right mix of everything to me to receive the 5-star.

I've been here around 4 times.  Every time, I've walked in without a reservation (never past 10pm) and found a comfortable spot - whether I'm with someone or on my own.  I'm a SF foodie type and I love going to all the popular places, but sometimes you just have to have a reliable place where you can walk in, have some good food and wine, chill with your friends or have a nice date, and enjoy the atmosphere and friendly service.  Seriously, just as an example, I am tired of trying to walk into NOPA (at 11pm no less) and being told it's an hour wait for a table or being jostled at the 3-person-deep bar.  Uva is a great antidote to that experience.

I don't know terribly much about Italian wines, but every time the servers have been very knowledgeable and helpful.  The food is also very good (not excellent) and makes for an enjoyable meal.  Highlights are the bresaola/arugula salad and the pizzas.

Service is super chill and friendly.  I'll definitely be back again, and often.
author: CC L.

description:
Drool...OK, been back here a few times and tried a lot of things. The only thing I'm not crazy about is the radishes with anchovy butter, but then I hate anchovies, so Uva can't really be blamed for that. Here's the breakdown:

*Lardo: definitely an acquired taste. For me, best enjoyed in moderation...I loved it for the first few bites, but there is such a thing as too much.
*Cheese: all fantastic, as mentioned in the earlier review.
*Brussels sprouts, pancetta, onions: yums, I love brussel sprouts when done right. Uva does them right.
*Persimmons, burrata, chervil, saba: words cannot begin to describe the fantasticness of this dish, so just go in and try it. Now.
*Tuna crudo, olive oil, vanilla salt: fresh and tasty. The vanilla adds an interesting kick.
*Pizzas: very tasty. Not quite as authentic as La Pazzia's, IMO, but still damn good.
*Shrimp, avocado, pancetta tramezzini: wow...incredibly good, but also extremely rich, so consider yourself warned. 

I highly recommend going with a group of like-minded eaters and sampling a bunch of dishes from the menu--there are still many I'd like to try (and will!). Oh, and did I mention great wine? Prices, I think, are totally reasonable for what you get in quality and atmosphere.
author: Jasmine F.

description: The best neighborhood Italian Restaurant in the City.   Cuisine was absolutely superb and memorable.  My faith in good Italian food has been restored. Thumbs up to the culinary expert behind the scenes.  Highly recommend the Cianfotta: eggplant, olive& pepper stew and the Wild Boar Pasta. Loved it!
author: Coni B.

description: This place is cute and quaint and one of the nicer spots to dine on a date in the Lower Haight.  The pizzas are pretty good and the salads are great.  Only major complaint with this place is that all the food is overly salted.  I mean, really, dehydratingly salty.  The staff is really on-point and nice.  The wine selection rocks.
author: Brittany T.

description: Intimate, romantic setting. Great for dinner or a great glass of wine and a bit of their fantastic selection of cheeses and home-cure meats. Highly recommend it. The owner/ staff are very chill and knowledgeable.
author: Courtney J.

description:
I can really appreciate a place like Uva in San Francisco. My friends and I came here the other day for happy hour and there was so much to be impressed by.

First of all, the service was super friendly. My friend ended up loosing her wallet later that night, and Uva was one of the places we thought the wallet might be. When we returned the host was more than friendly and understanding. 

The happy hour is AMAZING as well. $1.50 beers. Sold. The food is also very reasonable, I feel no entree was over $15. All the food looked exceptional as well. 

The decor of the restaurant is also impressive. It's a beautiful space, on top of being reasonably priced and pleasant. For young 20-somethings on a budget in San Francisco that is a great find. It's a place where you can go out to a nice dinner with friends with out breaking the bank.

Love this place, will be back soon.
author: Bobby P.

description: I absolutely love Uva. It's in our neighborhood which is a bonus, but I would travel to go here. The service is fantastic and the food delicious. I would definitely recommend a meat and cheese plate to start.  So many great flavours. I usually just ask the server to choose which kinds they like best.  I would also definitely recommend coming to Brunch too! bottomless bellinis !!
author: Katie M.

description:
I rarely venture into this hood, but a friend raved about Uva and I have to say, it is really impressive!

My friend and I sat at the bar and enjoyed a couple flights of wine. The bartender was incredibly friendly. We told him what types of wines we like and he put together a few choices for us. They were all very tasty. The menu is all tapas style and super inexpensive, especially the happy hour menu. My favorite item was the pear and fontina bruschetta. It actually tasted like dessert. The wine prices are great and they give a hefty size pour. I can't wait to go back and try more items very soon!

The location is fairly small and intimate. I would suggest going with no more than 3 friends, or for a date. The size just doesn't look good for groups. Parking is tricky, so give yourself some extra time to find a space.
author: Kandace K.

description: Great food. Simple, elegant, casual design. The Ragu was my favorite dish by far. The Panna Cotta was also divine. I especially liked that they offer wine by the 2oz taste so we were able to sample several wines. So fun.
author: Kelly S.

description: Hmmm. I had a wonderful 1st dining experience here when I came w/ one of the owner's friends. Great wine, attentive waitress, and good food (yes, including the brussel spouts -- divine!). I loved it. When i came again, with a different friend & sat at the bar approximately 1 hour to closing, the service was icy. I know we've all have lost our concept of $ for food here in the city, but if we are going to pay such dinner prices, & have to sit at a bar to eat, the least the waiter/bartenders can do is be a bit more polished & courteous. The food was also literally lukewarm compared to the first experience. Seems like a great place at times, but give it a pass if it's later in the evening.
author: Lynn m.

description:
One of the advantages of exposing myself to deviant sexual acts starting in the sticky awkwardness of pre-cum and ending in panicked flight, physical and mental abuse, insults, acrimony, and a bunch of sick motherfuckers otherwise known as my friends is that nothing surprises me these days. You just robbed a Walgreens? That's nice. You got double-fisted by two burly bears? Did that yesterday. You just set your lover's bed on fire -- with him in it? YAWN. I cast an unblinking eye at the ugliness of the world. I wear my post-foundational "liberal ironist" mantle (60% Rorty/30% Williams/10% Nietzsche [for stretch]) with pride and reside in the house of disillusionment, at least that's the public impression I convey.

But I'm not unflappable. 

When The Ex told me -- after a wonderful and surprisingly affordable (around $30/person) visit to Uva Enoteca with two mutual friends consisting of 

- Expertly house-cured carne assortito on a serving block. The Sopressata and Culatello were especially excellent.
- Another serving block of seven artisanal cheeses with candied fruits and truffle honey on the side. I highly recommend the Cremosina and Fontina val d'aosta.
- Roasted Asparagus with meyer lemon and moliterno, which were taut and crisp.
- Semolina gnocchi. If memory serves, there were six lovely pan-fried puffs filled with potato and paired with a salty speck that made my lips curl with delight.
- Piadine containing prosciutto, asparagus, and a creamy layer of moo cow Moliterno cheese.
- Panini with thin slices of a Bresaola hinting of cinnamon and a zestily tart lemon aioli dressing.
- A carafe of a dry Piemonte dolcetto with an exquisite mandorla finish.

-- that he had been dating a woman he met at a gay bar for around three weeks now, I almost lost it. The voices in my head were saying WHAT?!? ARE YOU TELLING ME YOU'VE TURNED INTO A MOTHERFUCKING PATROLMAN WITH THE PUSSY GOBBLING PLATOON?!? SERIOUSLY?!? YOUR CLOSET DOOR SWINGS BOTH WAYS AND YOU RE-ENTERED *AFTER* DATING ME?!? WHY DON'T YOU JUST BLOW MY BRAINS OUT WITH A DOUBLE-BARRELLED SHOTGUN, IT'LL BE QUICKER! SONO STANCA DI QUESTA MERDA! SEI UNA PUTTANA MERDOSA, VAFFANCULO!!! and I wanted to die or puke or plant one of Uva's well-weighted stainless steel knives in his skull. But because I was more than satisfied with the food, ambiance, and professional service (In all fairness, things did take rather long to reach our table), I simply nodded and wished him well.

Funny how noshing and drinking at a classy establishment gives me a sense of decorum.

Behold the power of the Ova -- I mean, Uva.
author: d s.

description:
Oh Uva, I think I love you. I can go on and on about the pizza or the creamy burrata or the semolina gnocchi but I would like to highlight the following: Uva serves meat on a plank. Yes, order the assorted meat plate and it comes to the table on a wood plank. And what amazing meats we were served! Prosciutto, Speck, Bresaola, Mortadella, Sopressata...my mouth is watering just thinking about it.

I glossed over the pizza a bit but shouldn't have - we ordered the two pies on the menu and both were fantastic. Come to think of it everything we ordered was great. See, here's what I loved about eating at Uva - you order a little bit of this, a little bit of that and wait to be amazed at the constant stream of food brought to your table.

Make sure and save room for dessert - the pistachio gelato lasted about five seconds between the four of us (we should have ordered one each!) and my afogato was serious stuff. 

Uva exceeded my expectations on every level. Awesome food, great wine and reasonable prices. What's not to love?
author: phil h.

description:
When you grow up thinking Italian food is Chef Boyardee spaghetti and Dominoes pizza then you find out Mario Batali is from Seattle and then you're shocked that Fresh Choice and Pasta Pomodoro are not really haute Italian Cuisine, and then bucca di Beppo is not really like an Italian's family restaurant, you revel in your experience at places like Zuppa and Uva. 

The service was great, not just because the birthday girl is like a sister to the owner. They really took care of us. Service is not something you can turn off or on. It's something that takes repetition. And the good service didn't seem like it was strained or something new to them. 

The pizza was delicious! We had the asparagus, salami, cheese, and pepperoni pizzas. 

You can bet I'll be back to try the other menu items. 

Happy Birthday Rachel!   http://rachelf.yelp.com
author: Kevo M.

description: Great wine and service. Their broccoli pizza reminds me why broccoli is wonderful. Great Italian food at a good price.
author: Vani A.

description:
What a terrific -- and much needed -- addition to the Lower Haight. As the name states, it's an enoteca experience, which as far as I can garner, is the Italian version of a French bistro, that is a casual eating and drinking place.

The first thing you see when you enter is the main bar; there are about 10 seats total but definitely a great spot to start your evening. Actually, I take that back, you probably will find Boris (one of the owners) greeting and chatting away. He's a good guy, and treats you like an instant regular the moment you step in.

Anyhow, order a glass of wine (their list is refreshingly all Italian), or a wine-based cocktail from Camber Lay (she of Epic and Range fame). Talk it up with the other patrons: the first time I was there the guy next to me let me try his glass and then when my party sat down we ended up ordering a bottle of the stuff. 

There's a back room, which is a quieter but we wanted to be near the action so asked for a table up front. Now ordering at Uva is process of discovery. The menu is broken up into carne, formaggi, verdure, pizza, bruschette... I'd say order a couple of dishes from each section, mix and match, or ask your server for suggestions based against what you're drinking. 

Just ordering some salume and cheese, sitting at the bar, might even be enough for some, and I can see a more industrious diner stopping in for a pre-snack before venturing off to another restaurant. That said, the  prosciutto di parma and asparagus pizza is sizable enough for a small meal (but share, please), and immensely satisfying. If you hunger for more, no one's stopping you from ordering a panini or piadine!

End your meal with some house-made gelato, and for a brief moment you'll realize that everything is alright in the world.
author: Nish N.
