description: Great time last night at Uva!!! Had the hanger steak & my friend Amy had the Pork... So delicious. The stuffed pork loin came chopped prosciutto & peaches with a butter sauce.. It was cooked perfectly. I had the hanger steak & I must say it may have been the best hanger I have ever had!! The steak was cooked a perfect mid-rare to medium.. It was served with buckwheat polenta (huh)? I know strange but amazing... We drank the wine & dined like Romans.... This is becoming one of my favorite places in the bay area...  Oh & the wait staff so un-pretentious...  & that is a good thing when trying to decide on the many great choices of wines they have to offer...
author: Riley H.

description: Uva has the nicest bathroom in the Haight - upper *or* lower.  Just sayin' . . .
author: Joe C.

description:
Disclaimer: The owner is like a brother to me, but I always write my reviews without bias. Promise. 

Thursday evening, around 9:00 pm. We'd decided to try out Uva Enoteca on a regular open night (I came to their soft opening, but was determined not to review it until I'd tried it out thoroughly). The place was packed (but not as packed as the next night, I hear...Boris told me that there was an HOUR wait!). 

We stood at the comfortable bar and Chris, the bar manager, hooked us up with wine that was "chewy" and "full-bodied" as I'd requested. I'm not sure what it was, but it was exactly what I'd asked for, and I like that it came in a large pour.

We sat down five minutes later at a gorgeous 2-top table in the back. We had been perusing the menu for about ten minutes but were still a bit confused (it's all in Italian!). The meats sounded good, as did the cheeses, so we told our sweet waitress that we wanted to have an assortment of delicious and random meats and cheeses. I wish that they'd come with tags on them so that I could remember which ones we ate, but I tell you, they're all pretty darn good, and they satisfy anybody's taste. 

Upon ordering our bottle of wine, we had a lot of assistance from the sommelier. He was very knowledgeable and listened to our requests. He told us that the Dolcetto would be right up our alley, so off he went to get a bottle. Upon returning, he opened the bottle, took a whiff of it himself, told us that the wine wasn't quite at its peak, and rushed off to get us another bottle. Now that's customer service. 

The plates may be small, but they're deceptively filling. We didn't try the pizza, but it looked delicious, and the asparagus was cold and freak-out good. We saved no room for the gelato, but the couple at the next table seemed to have liked it. And they carry Ritual Coffee Roasters coffee. Yum! 

Their water closet rivals the bathroom at the Mark Hopkins Hotel. Seriously. They really did a bang-up job with it. 

I can't wait for them to be open during the afternoons so that I can sit at the bar and enjoy a glass of wine with some meat and cheese on a Sunday afternoon.
author: Rachel F.

description:
I promised myself I was only going to write movie reviews.  Dammit!  I have too much time on my hands.  But this place and it's damned delicious pannini's and "Italian quesadillas" and it's little plate of raw fish laid out next to a vinegar soaked salt lick.  It's forcing my hand.

The experience was much like going to see a movie.  Lets say, for argument's sake, say, an ITALIAN movie.  There was progression and movement throughout the meal.  

I arrived and was freezing.  Sat in the back, hot guy walked by and we locked eyes and I warmed right up.  I'm a sucker for a man with short dreads - Well, he looked straight from the front, but totally gay from the back (skinny jeans, what can I say.)  My pardner arrived.  We ordered the little morselly foods first - gnocchi with speck, perfectly dressed salads, Kampache with a salt lick.  We told clever and hilarious stories, complained about work.  We tried carafe after carafe of medium bold Italian reds.  Then came mediocre fig dish.  Mid meal, we had to send back the eggplant capanata  because it tasted like raisins and sugar, and things went south for the second act.  

The gorgeous skinny jeans guy was reading Vanity Fair which means there was no way to tell whether he was gay or straight.  (I must put people into boxes!  But hate it when they try to box me...)  Then the pardner and I had a huge silly fight over which of our previous devious lovers who were never really ours was more full of shit.  ("Well, yours was married."  "Well yours had a kid and lived with someone."  "But yours took vows."  "But yours had cooties."  Like that...)  Then we moved on to the really heavy wild ass sweet Italian wines (just ask the damn server the  names cuz those people know EVERYTHING about the wine they serve.)  

And for the third act, out came the big crunchy melty savory panninis, and Lambrusco:  It's red, but it's also cold and effervescent (that's bubbly to you old friend)...  and my pardner and I were smooching like bonobos in no time.

I think we totaled 9 dishes and 8 carafes.  And that only ran us around $60 each.  Speaking of running, I ran into the owner on the street the next day (OK I was lurking and wanted another pannini cuz now the taste is in my brain and torturing me).  I told him how great I thought his place was, and he was like... "yeah, I remember you, you were at the back eating us out of stock."  

One star off cuz the amazingly knowledgeable server spoke on a decibel level that only dogs can hear so I had no idea what she was saying.  But I nodded, smiled, said, "You decide for me!"  And she totally scored.  Shit, I'm an old deaf bitch so I guess I shouldn't mock the low-frequency impaired.  Forget it, the one star off is for the figs and the eggplant.  

I have to go get a Pannini now.
author: jill n.

description: What an amazing place! The best lasagna I've had in SF! And my companion (who is Italian- from Rome, Italy!) was blown away as much as I was!!! We'll definitely come back!  Highly recommended!
author: Einat L.

description: This was my third visit, and I've returned each time because I really wanted this place to be worthwhile - it would be great to have a nice little Italian place in the neighborhood. It seems this isn't to be. Each time, I've ordered hopefully and then been faced with bland, overcooked food; perused a mediocre wine list; and have been made to feel that the customers were nothing more than a burden to the waitstaff. In all honesty, I wouldn't even have afforded Uva a third try if it hadn't been for a Living Social deal that they offered. With the discount, I thought, surely one more attempt would be justified. Nope. Even with a much cheaper bill I still walked away disappointed. I won't be back.
author: Jay M.

description:
This place has the look, feel and taste of a NYC restaurant.  The perfect marriage of food, wine in a sexy down to earth atmosphere.

Ben, the owner, loves food.  His recommendations are laser beams on point.  Ask about the meats and cheeses, you'll be guided down a path of delicious.  And probably gorge yourself like I did... practically left in a coma.  

My favorite place to go when I come to SF.
author: Lily A.

description: My husband and I went on a date night. I don't even know where to being. I really like the small neighborhood feel. The bar was littered with seemed to be locals or regulars and the other tables were full of conversation and people having a good time. The noise level was pretty even, not too load but loud enough to know that you were in a popular spot. My husband and I got a bottle of wine... $45 that was recommended by the server and it was AWESOME! We also ordered a pizza as well as some meat and cheese combination. I wish I would have eaten the food before my two giant glasses of wine! ! We will definitely go back... with friends and make a night of it. This time I'll eat first!
author: Kathie R.

description:
I absolutely love love LOVE this place. It's gotta be one of my favorite new places in SF. The food is delicious and great for sharing. The wine guy is awesome and when my fiance and I sat there wondering what wine to get, he suggested a few and let us try each of them! Very generous indeed. Plus the wines we did get were really great.

I recommend getting one of their platters that lets you try a few meats, cheeses and veggie entrees. That way you get to try a bit of everything. I didn't try the bruschetta but it looked amazing! I'll have to get that next time.
author: Galeet L.

description:
While the SF dining scene doesn't have quite the turnover of New York  so far as restaurants are concerned, there are just enough openings in a given month to keep the avid gastronomes busy while also allowing for familiarization and (in rare cases) regularity.  There have been a slew of "wine bar","tratoria" and "bistro" openings over the past year.  I haven't felt compelled to write about one until hitting on UVA.

First, the location is GREAT.  Not that I frequent or particularly love the Lower Haight, but the neighborhood needed something like UVA that was just high enough on the "gentrification" meter as to be a draw without detracting too much from the grungy, gruff 'hood that gives the LH it's (deserved) reputation.  If RNM was the beachhead, then UVA is the reinforcement.

The ambiance is perfect for the type of place that UVA strives to be (a neighborhood wine bar). The decor clean and simple - not ostentatious.  Air conditioning was sorely lacking, which in 90+ degree heat was somewhat of a bummer.

The food?  Infused honey that goes well with everything; portions that are suitable, but not skimpy; cheese and charcuterie selections that have varieties of good options (we went five for five with the cheese tasting); even the pizza was cooked perfectly.  Hat's off to the chef.

The wines are complementary to the cheese/meat selections and not your standard fare.  Great Italian varietals and glasses of wine are first poured into small carafes - a very nice touch, enabling two or more people to share a single "pouring" with ease.

The wait staff are, appreciatively, not afraid to express their opinions - none of the "they're all good" b.s. that is as offensive a response as you can come by when you ask for an honest recommendation.  Add to this the fact that our waitress (Sarah), the owner (Boris), and the host (nice guy name unknown) were all refilling our water/wine glasses and constantly asking us if we needed anything else.

This place deserves to stick around.
author: Nils E.

description: We were happy we could get in for a last-minute Saturday night reservation here. It's a solid choice for a last-minute dinner in the neighborhood, but we wouldn't make plans in advance around it. It was a little overpriced and pretty standard Italian.
author: Kristen C.

description: Uva Enoteca is a little hidden gem in the lower Haight. I'd always seen this place but never ventured in. Thanks to Living Social, I got to experience this place TWICE in one weekend. Uva Enoteca is a great little place when you want to escape and enjoy a lovely Italian meal in a cozy, relaxed atmosphere. My friend ordered the boar pasta ("memories of Florence" he said) while I had the roasted pork loin with bacon-wrapped dates. Incredible! On our second visit we decided to try the pizzas. For myself, the lamb, tomato, and mascarpone pizza. My friend got the spicy salame, herb, pecorino, and tomato pizza for his entree. Both were insanely good. We split the snickerdoodle pie and chocolate budino, with smoked salt, granola, and berries (mind-blowing!) for dessert. Overall, a fantastic experience. Affordable, nice atmosphere, quality food, and good service. Our server Beth was very sweet and the food was delicious. We couldn't recommend this place more highly. A great find in the lower Haight. We are definitely looking forward to returning.
author: Denny G.

description:
Update. I have been to Uva approx. 20 times in the seven weeks they have existed. That's 2-3 times per week. I've spent somewhere in the four figures. I have never done this with a restaurant before much less anything I've mentioned on Yelp. I hope that is saying something. 

Just some highlights:

1. They do amazing things with greens I've never heard of. It's all about the pea tendrils. Zucchini blossoms (not deep fried) -- crazy. Barley-corn-fava-squid! Some other shit I've never heard of nor could remember if you asked me apart from it being delicioso. And this is "supposed" to be a meat/cheese kind of place first and foremost.. Even the veggies are interesting.

2. The staff is universally adorable. And professional. I have to imagine that any dings in service are completely attributable to their being slammed at times.

3. The carne, cheese and most of all *wine* are all geared towards sampling and experimentation. It has kept me interested all this time and they keep it fresh.

4. Do not be afraid to go girly with the rosato, pignoletto, in bocca al lupo prosecco cocktail, salads, crudos.. Not every meal has to be heavy with tannins and fat.

5. You probably know about the crudos and the cheeses but their *condiments* are standouts in and of themselves.. vanilla salt, son!

6. I mentioned this before but it's worth mentioning again. The wine list is broad, interesting and pretty reasonably priced.

7. Do not miss the sorbet. It's really creamy and fruity. Not at all sugary/icy.

Something to keep in mind is that this is a perfect place to meet with friends and have a casual meal with wine. Each dish is around $4-8 and the wines are all $10-14 or so for 8 oz. carafes. 2 oz. pours are exactly a quarter of that price. Within that framework it is a fantastic experience. The atmosphere is airy and conducive to conversation. Their pricing structure and menu is very much geared towards sampling and experimentation, so I suggest you take advantage of that and explore stuff. And drinking. It's very good for drinking.
author: Tom L.

description:
Came here for the first time about a year ago with my friend, T, who highly recommended it. Not used to too many wine/cheese places, but must admit that the stuff she ordered was top notch. I love my wine but awfully ignorant when it comes to selections. Still, loved all that they threw my way. 

The decor is really cute. I think it's because I'm a big fan of high ceilings and such. The place itself isn't too huge but it has a hip, bar feel.
author: Emily C.

description:
What a wonderful little place. Actually, it's not that little as there is more seating in the back.
The waitress was very knowledgeable about wine and food and not shy to give great recommendations. 
We were 3 ladies, had 3 veggies and 3 cheeses and a pasta and a pizza. It was a little too much but all really delicious. The truffle honey goes with everything. The prosciutto pizza was really good, with molten mozzarella and a nice thin crust. The pasta was shells with boar ragout, it was so good, it was hard not to over eat. We had no space for dessert as we had too much savory.
Accidentally we ordered 3x 8oz of red wine which was a little too much for us and which made the thing a little more pricey. And still it was affordable. Keeping this in mind for next time, a little less food, a little less wine and we'll be fine.
author: Alexandra D.

description: Excellent atmosphere and service. The roasted eggplant with Japanese eggplants was very good and an exception valpolicella was recommended.
author: Marcus N.

description:
During my visit to San Francisco, I was delighted to find this cute italian wine bar.  Still being on EST, I went for an early dinner and was seated immediately, and the waiter was very attentive.  The menu is a little confusing and in italian, so I had to ask a lot of questions.  He brought out bread with olive oil which was delicious- very fresh tasting and the olive oil was outstanding.  I ordered the Wild Boar Ragu which was a baked pasta dish with shell-like noodles, ground boar meat (tastes like a cross between beef and venison) with tomatoes, onions, parmesan cheese, garlic and other delicious herbs. It was fantastic! A great combination of crispy, cheesy and meaty with a delicious tomato sauce.

Dessert was ginger snap ice cream in a cookie sandwich with chocolate. SO GOOD!!!! I would easily order the exact same thing next time. Four stars instead of five because of the limited menu.
author: Julie R.

description:
A great independent restaurant in the Haight. It looks small from the outside, but the space goes deep into the block, so it's a good choice for semi-large parties.

The gnocchi with aioli sauce was easily the best appetizer and dish. It's family style, so we shared a plate of assorted meats (AWESOME) and piadine (eggplant). 

For dessert, we had the goat cheesecake... it was a bit soft, but that's what you'd expect from the mushy delights of goat cheese. 

Parking can be a bit tough, but it's worth the visit.
author: Kel S.

description:
Mrs Cheesemonger and I went to the Big City last night for a rock show and tried out this relatively new Italian small plates/winebar.  

We loved the extensive Italian wine list, peppered with not well known varietals and lesser known producers.  The Cheesemongers tried three new wines and two new varietals, and loved them all.   

The wines were well-priced and laid out on the menu in a logical geographic array.  Wine service was thoughtful and not overbearing, and new glasses were brought for every taste we had. 

The food was very good - with the best part being the salume plate - well curated and presented.  We also had two vegetable apps (an amazing sliced Pluot with lardo and a very good bean and pancetta dish).   The mains were good (a small casserole of Orrichette that was slightly overcooked but had some very nice melded flavors of Parm, wild boar, tomato and pasta, and a corn basil Pizza on a slightly soggy crust).

Service was understated and friendly,and we felt very well taken care of by our waitress and one of the owners.  

The ambiance is muted, dark and not overdesigned, although the constantly opened and closed curtain 'masking' the kitchen was a wee bit of a distraction, as was the Pink Floyd being played slightly too loud (the Cheesemonger loves the Floyd, but would rather hear softer music, or Italian pop, or non-vocal stuff when he's dining in a nice restaurant).

Pricing was a wee high for the location - the lower Haight across from the Noc Noc -- we spent over $50 per person on wine, apps, mains and dessert.

We wish the owners well, and will return if we're nearby.
author: Cheesemonger Jeff D.

description:
An unlike gem in the middle of Lower Haight amongst organic co-op groceries and plenty of the grimiest dive bars in the city (in a good way), Uva Enoteca brings modern, innovative, and classic touches to accessible high-end dining. With a warm, soft, cozy atmosphere, friendly service, and moderate prices, this restaurant aims to please its patrons with its slightly rustic and inspired fare.

I came here with a girl friend and she said that this was one of the best meals she's ever had in her life. In terms of experience, I have to agree. We arrived, were seated quickly, were calmly waited upon (although the service was on the slow side), had the entire menu explained to us, and were given drink suggestions. We got some delicious libations (I had this particular cocktail made with lillet blanc, garnished with red pepper - tasted like a pizza, in a good way), and some appetizers and some entrees to share had a great conversation, relished in the simple, understated elegance of our surroundings enjoyed every morsel of our food. The most memorable item were the polenta cakes - I have never had such buttery, creamy, sweet polenta cakes seared in sweet butter in my life and have attempted to find something similar and to replicate it in my kitchen to multiple failures. The house pinot noir was lovely, and went well with my wild boar ragu served with fresh orrechiette pasta. Yum! 

This is a great after-work spot, as well as a fantastic upscale neighborhood establishment that I will be visiting over and over again in the years to come.
author: Y K.

description:
Went to Uva again recently and the experience was pretty good except for one slip up. We had 3 platters - cured meats, cheeses and veggies/verdure. Unfortunately, the verdure plate was totally and completely GROSS. Out of our party of five, we ordered 3 of the veggies and barely made a dent into any of them (and we were a hungry bunch - the meats and cheeses disappeared quickly). They were all cold (not even room temperature but cold, as in, they tasted like they were out of the fridge) and bland as all hell. 

Our server suggested a great bottle of wine - I think it was only $30 something bucks. I was really pleased with that, so pleased that we ordered two more bottles after we downed the first. 

I really like the nice extras you get with bread - the apricots being my favorite. I wish more restaurants thought about the little things that make people come back!
author: Alli J.

description:
Fun restaurant for lil nibbles of a tasty adventure.  Great service and ambiance.  Pricey, but delicious food.  The server was very helpful in recommendations.  We ordered the assortito (carne); 5 cheeses our server picked (all cows cheese); and a pizza.  

This is a good restaurant for those that aren't starving and don't mind paying the cost for excellent, unique cheeses and meats.  Fun to go with friends and share.
author: Gina B.

description:
I have to admit, I almost considered upping to 4 stars after dessert.  I strongly suggest coming here for a glass of wine and dessert and skipping dinner altogether.
We had the chocolate pot de creme (really fantastic, light, came with a dash of salt), and the gelato sandwiches (with a generous spill of caramel - yuuum).  I recommend both!
Dinner?  Well...the appetizers are ok, but not really special and the pasta are fine but you could make better at home.  So...again, come here for dessert!
As a final note, I loved the ambience though our table was a bit cramped.  However, there's really no "good" table - you're either next to the bathroom or next to the front door and susceptible to cold gusts.
author: Cathy L.

description:
Here's why I like Uva Enoteca:

My friend and I stopped in for a snack and a drink around 5:30pm on a Saturday.  We sat at the bar, ordered a bottle of Montepulciano d'Abruzzo for $20 and a cheese platter for $10.  

The cheese platter turned out to be a cheese meal-- It was amazing!  
We were shocked and awed by the 3 gorgeous dipping sauces that accompanied it (pear/black peppercorn compote, dried cherry sauce & honey).  
The  bartender refilled our bread supply a few times and served up extra olives (which are flavored with lemon zest...mmmm).

Major value, ambiance & flavor = I will be back.
author: Heather P.

description:
Why, why do I do this? As if culture isn't accelerated enough these days. The minute you find a hidden gem, a good deal, it's gone. The second you find that hot new color, or shirt, or whatever, it's over. H&M has it the next day. 

And so will go the Happy Hour at Uva. I'll keep this simple: you can get a prosciutto cotto and fresh mozarella pizza and a glass of lambrusco for $8 until 6:30 PM Sunday-Thursday. What!? A great pizza and glass of wine in a great space for less than 10 bucks?!

Wait, where are you going? I'm not finished with my review yet...

Shit, there goes my seat at the bar.
author: ashton c.

description: this place just gets better and better.  so glad to be right around the corner.  came in yesterday looking for pizza.  as we were on the way, i was wondering if it might be happy hour still.  surprise...  it was!  not only did they have $5 house wine, but my favorite pasta there (bucatini pomodoro) was on special, along with the pizza margherita, which we also got with an egg on it.  as always, the food and wine totally delivered, and service was great.  totally love this place for a casual yet exciting meal.
author: Ash T.

description: Great Italian food and a really good selection of wine.  Had a simple late dinner - arugula, dried cherries, and roasted salsify (which is some kind of sweet potato-like small, thin carrot-looking veggie) salad followed by a thin crust spicy salame pizza and accompanied with a very yummy bottle of Sangiovese and merlot mix red wine.  It was the perfect amount and our waitress/hostess was super attentive and lovely to chat with.  Wonderful ambience...light music, pretty chill, dimly lit...romantic, great for conversation and/or catching up.  Highly recommend it for dates or a small group of friends for dinner or apps and wine!  And per suggestion of the exceptional company, I am definitely coming back to try their desserts.
author: Maria D.

description:
They don't have an actual kitchen so don't go there for food.  Go there to have some wine with friends after dinner or meet up for a drink in the afternoon.  

Good date spot.  But if you order the cheese, she's gonna have stinky cheese breath afterwards!

The wine is exclusively Italian and I don't know nothing about no Italian wine.  But the waiter was helpful enough and the four of us got 4 different wines in a total of 16 glasses so we each had a taste of each wine.  That was nice.
author: Ashkan J.

description:
My below average rating of Uva Enoteca has nothing to do with the food, which we all thought was pretty good. Perhaps not five stars, but at least four. The menu is expansive, with quite a few meat, cheese and vegetable/fruit small plates (in a variety of sizes) to choose from. One really nice touch are the "complements" that come with the cheese and bread - honey, a mustard concoction and almonds. Each were terrific, especially the honey.

We also got two larger plates - the veggie panini featuring speck, fennel and apples (really, really good) and the asparagus pizza (oily, but good, and rather sizeable at six pieces).  Everything was accented by some nice wine selections, all chosen by the table's resident wine guru (fellow yelper and all around good guy Louis M.) and a very friendly and knowledgable sommelier.

So far so good. Unfortunately everything else detracted from the experience.

Service was the big miss. I wanted to like our waitress more than I did, cute, friendly, trying hard....but trying too hard. Everything felt scripted, lacked authenticity, and I think we were being upsold from the minute we sat down. The vibe was off. It didn't help matters that they were out of my original panini choice - chicken. It would have been totally fine had she let me know then it was not an option. But I learned an hour later, right before they were due to bring our next round of food (which I though took way too long). Unacceptable. If I place my order, set aside my chicken. If it's not available, tell me right away. Instead I was forced to make an alternative selection on the spot if I planned on eating anything of more substance than a breadstick.

It didn't get any better when the bill came. Things would be have been greatly remedied had the panini been comped, but it wasn't, and was listed on the bill as the chicken panini. We pointed out that we actually didn't get that, we got the veggie one, and her reply was "well it's the same price". Um, yeah, not the point. We then asked for it to be taken off the bill, and she left, assumingly to get permission, and when she came back, agreed to do so, even though "we ate it". OK, whatever. Also didn't help that we were charged for both a large and a small meat platter. We ordered the small, a large was brought to our table, which they swapped for a small, and then charged us for both. At this point, their gesture of comping two coffees was too little too late.

Beside service, the music was atrocious. Such a nice wine bar setting ruined by a way too loud mix of Pat Benetar and rap. Everything has its place, these two music genres do not go with a wine bar scene.

Before leaving we gave all this feedback to the hostess, so things might improve. They've got a good thing going with location and food, fixing everything else would likely turn these two stars into four.
author: Jason B.

description:
The food was savory and tasty, ordered some pasta and two pizzas, both delicious - the meat ball pizza I think it was called was one of them and the boar gnocci was not bad. I am giving the place 3 stars because the place was just not very intimate (at least not where we were seated), the back looked a lot better, heads up. 

Wouldn't go back. I am glad I went and I enjoyed my experience there but it was not as comfortable as my friends and I expected it to be. We were having a small reunion of four of us and we were sitting at a table across the bar... just wasn't our cup of tea... we asked if there was another location to sit at but they said there was no server in the back, it was 7pm on a Thursday night...  if we're paying 100+ for food and drinks we would like to be comfy. 

Also the waiters were dressed like the average person in there... so it was hard to get their attention because we didn't know who was who... :/
author: Angie S.

description:
Strong work from Uva Enoteca last night.

Good setting....place had a good buzz to it but wasn't packed to the point of being uncomfortable.  The one negative was that they were understaffed so the service was fairly weak.  It was a little annoying.  Took a while for anyone to acknowledge our presence, which is always offputting.  

Other than that though I was really blown away.  We got the prosciutto lightly cooked in truffle oil to start and it was phenomenal.  First time i've had it prepared that way and I was very impressed.  Great way to start.  

Wine list is obviously very unique as this is a wine bar.  Its mostly italian wines that I hadn't heard of other than a couple of sicilian reds.  Ask the waiter.  We had Dragone which was very good and reasonably priced.  

For entrees my girlfriend had boscoiala which she said was very good but not memorable.  I had the Ragu which was a five star dish.  Boar meat, a little cheese, shell pasta, in a red sauce that was done with a bit of class (not too thick, not too salty, not too garlicy).  They put this all in a ceramic bowl and bake it, as some (but not all) ragu dishes are prepared.  Absolutely nailed it.  couldn't recommend this entree any higher.  I get the impression its the star on the menu.

Very good option in the NOPA area.  They take open table reservations but not many.  Much of the restaurant is reserved for walk-ins so if you just show up you'll probably get in with a little bit of a wait.  Consider going, putting in your name, and then put in some work at the wine bar.
author: David R.

description: Lovely place with great, if somewhat inconsistent, service.  Portions are on the smallish size but priced on the gourmet side!  But the food is extraordinary!
author: Jill B.

description:
What this place does well, it does incredibly, unfortunately it's missing consistency.  There were long delays between courses - dinner was nearly 3 hours long, all of the food is lukewarm at best  our table was ignored repeatedly, wine was poured without much explanation and the bill was wrong.  Some of the dishes (particularly the Farro and the onions were boring and bland.  The gorgonzola pizza was fine, but nothing memorable).

That said, the eggplant, the lentils and the lamb pasta were phenomenal.  Loved them beyond belief and they are enough to convince me that this place deserves a second chance.  I loved the extensive list of 2 ounce wine tastings that were available and the fact that each one was unique and delicious.  The apple crisp was accompanied by a lovely gelato.

I hope they work out the kinks with the service and  the temperature of the food because if they do, this will be one of my top spots in the city.  If they don't work out the kings, I don't think i'll be returning too often.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
Can you say awesome blossom?

Food: good
Ambiance: good
Price: decent
Service: good

I'm guessing this place is pretty authentic Italian, but I will be the first to admit, I'm no expert.  Only prob, is it's a pretty small place, but it does add some coziness to the ambiance.
author: Nancy V.

description:
Ohhh Uva How i Love thee, Let me Count the Ways....

   I managed to stumble across this little gem of a restaurant while searching for the next top happy hour spot in town. I had grown tired of our usual spots and was aching to try something new. Uva not only impressed me with its classic minimalist decor but the simple classic flavors of there dishes sent a chill thru my spine. I still dream of there constantly changing cheese plate! 
   If you have the chance to stop in for there bottomless belini brunch then Run dont Wok. Theres a simple magic about belini's and cheese that just cant be beat! 
   I recommend sitting at the bar if an attractive female named Anica appears to be working. Not only is she adorable she's extremely knowledgable and have you entertained for hours. If i was gay id think id have fallen in love.
author: J J.

description:
I came here for the wine near closing time on Saturday and didn't have a chance to try the food, though I did drool over huge chunks of ash rind and blue creamy cheeses over on the cutting board.  In fact, full though I was, everything on the plates of nearby diners looked good.

The service was a bit cranky but ultimately helpful - I got one of the most delicious pours I've ever had, really (a barbera, which only recently hit my radar).  8oz was the perfect size for someone like me who tends to order but has a bit of trouble finishing that second glass as we hit the am hour.  Great prices considering the pour size (and none of that lame pour-line business).  

The atmosphere is upscale deli and was very quiet and subdued - very lounge like without the couches.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Went back to UVA while my mother was in town after trying it once the opening week. Boy did I enjoy it A LOT more this time around. Unlike the crowded bar that I pushed myself into several months ago, this visit was extremely pleasant. We cabbed over to Uva after dinner at Beretta - needing one more glass of wine before bed. We probably missed the crowds - but it was a Wednesday night...perfect for a leisurely, friendly, comfortable experience. LOVED the wine selections by our waitress (I couldn't tell what was what on the menu...all in italian) and same with her cheese choices. We got the 3 cheese platter for $10 and it sure was worth it. The cheese was out of this world and it comes with sauces on the side which make the experience all that more enjoyable. 

Live in the 'hood or looking for a new wine bar to try? More oova Zuni and Amelie!
author: Deann M.

description:
Every hood needs an amazing wine bar and this is the Lower Haight's. It will seem a little out of place but it's MUY nice.

I LOVE the 2oz pours that makes it easy to create your own wine flights. Hard to have more than a table of 4 here but I can live with that. Servers seem to make great recommendations.

Had everything from a pizza to meat plate to appetizers and there seems to be a good mix. I wouldn't come here solo for dinner but with the wine experience I think it's top notch.
author: Mike T.

description:
I am in love with sitting at the bar and cheaply taking advantage of the incredibly affordable happy hour or ordering one of their expertly executed salumi plates.

Gnocco Fritto: crispy balls of love and cheese, dusted and fried to be eaten with a lovely aioli.

Any salumi plate: best salumi in town by far (and I have had many).. every paper thin slice of meat sets off a unique symphony of aromas, tastes and textures in your mouth.

Wine: expertly chosen Italian wines. You can trust the people here to give you what you need - no more, no less.

Wine & beer cocktails: like nothing I have had anywhere else. I was blown away by the 
IN BOCCA AL LUPO Lillet blanc, chilies, basil, prosecco &
coconut salt 

Salad: (went home and tried to replicate it. didn't need the prawns) Prawns, peas, pea leaves, lemon aioli $10 

I think the time is a little wonky for happy hour... a little early perhaps, but I hope more people catch on and not just for happy hour.. just a great place to chill with some great wine and food with friends.

The heavier pasta dishes were not my favorite, but I think I prefer soft fresh made pastas and that is not what UVA is about. The dishes are hearty and filling.
author: Claudia O.

description:
I went here on a Monday night right before their closing time, but the bartender was nice enough to let us order some food and a couple of glasses.

I live in Union Square/Financial District area, so I don't generally hang out in Lower Haight, but I was surprised to find such a nice place with reasonably priced wines and mouth watering food.  They even had a pizza that my VEGAN friend could eat!

I would definitely have to go back there and try out their meats and cheeses as well as digging deeper into their Italian wines....
author: Sophia F.

description:
Uva Enoteca opened right before we had to move out of the Alamo Square/ Lower Haight neighborhood.  I was glad to return to my old stomping grounds, if only to sample some of the wines and fare here.

For the most part I enjoyed the food - there were some hits as well as misses.

The apperitivi I ordered -- an Ultras: Birra bionda, ginger beer, lime, lemongrass & tarragon -- was very sour -- even though I hadn't conveyed to the server that t I enjoyed my drinks on the sour side.  It was a bit *too* sour even for me -- such that the rest of the subtle favours of lemongrass, gingerbeer and tarragon were obscured.

We shared a couple of salads: heirloom tomatoes with ricotta salata and simple balsamic/ oil dressing - flavourful enough, hard to screw up. I definitely enjoyed the raw pea leaf-salad with peas, prawns and lemon aioli. Pea leaves are one of my favourite vegetables, and I usually have them stir-fried rather than raw.  The salad, very lightly dressed, was innovative and refreshing.

I opted for the Paccheri with goat cheese, arugula and lamb sausage -- the pasta was tasty enough, and toothsomely well-cooked (al dente).  The flavours of the sauce were coherent and complimentary to the lamb sausage meatballs which had a nice funky gaminess to them (the way I like lamb).  However, presentation left much to be desired.  It was served gloppily on a too-small plate and threatened to ooze over the side.  The wine that was recommended - a Montepulciano - was also unfortunately too earthy for the rich dish.  I could have used a bit more acid or brightness to cut through the fatty lamb and creamy sauce.

All in all, I'd definitely return, though.  The space is absolutely charming and larger than it looks from the outside.  I hope it was an unusually slow Saturday night.
author: Claudine C.

description:
At first I had no idea where this place was. I just couldn't picture it. Then we got here and I realized it was in the old Horseshoe Cafe space.
The interior is really calm and relaxing and the restaurant is bigger than it looks. 
We ordered the cheese plate, a meat side order and a vegetable side and worked on it for about an hour. We had great wine, and when we were done with the cheese plate we ordered a pizza (to complete the cheese overload).
It was delicious and well worth it. The staff was very attentive and accommodating. I would go back.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Ended up here last night  with some of my culinary  friends. We were huge fans of the rosato. I think we ended up with 5 bottles. It was a Rose sipping sorta night.  The service was friendly. The space is comfortable and cool. The pizza's, duck salad and cheese plates were fabulous. We asked for salt, cause that is how we roll. 
It is a wonderful new addition to the neighborhood.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
came in last night, excited to try a new place in the neighborhood.

were seated and given menus.  we waited for 10 minutes with nothing. no one to take our order, no one giving us water (it was hot) and no acknowledgement at all. we stared at the staff, we tried waving... nothing. so we left.

i will give it another go sometime, but it's not off to a good start.
author: Ge O.

description:
The much anticipated wait is over, and Uva was brimming with people. So much so that they were moving people around from the front to the back room to accommodate smaller parties. The space is very simple; off white walls, crown moulding, with a central bar that spans the rooms. The otherside has exposed brick, the semi open kitchen and the restrooms smack dab in the middle. 

After perusing the small but focused food and beverage menu we opted with the following:

- Chef's choice charcuterie: prosciutto, bresaola, sopresseta, umbrian salumi 
- Panini: Pancetta, chicken, blu del moncenisio
-Pizza: Funghi misti, robiola cheese
-Tramezzini: Shrimp, avocado, pancetta

Everything was pretty tasty with the chef's choice meat plate being the winner. Too bad we didn't get the Culatello with it because it comes from Salumeria Biellese in Manhattan, a great family owned deli, where stuff is done the old fashioned way. So now I know how to get a Biellese fix without actually having to go across the country. The pizza was good a bit on the bland side because the mushrooms overpowered the robiola cheese which has a quick melt factor, giving a different mouth feel than pizza with a higher gooey index (yes that is the scientific term). The panini was also on the blander side as the chicken and blu overpowered the pancetta a bit. A little more pancetta and this panini is perfect. Finally the Tramezzini, which is a cold rolled sandwich was the most intriguing as the shrimp, avocado and pancetta was quite harmonious. I think if the roll were grilled it would be over the top and I make motion for them to offer this as a panini also!

The service was the real winner. As I said the place was wall to wall and our server Sara, who seemed to be the only one in the front, hammered away at all the tables getting things the best she could even  though we could see it was overwhelming. 5 stars to her for making it through the night. 

The craziest thing about Uva (at least the opening night) was the people watching. The lower Haight is always full of characters and they were out in droves. Some of the more entertaining watches:

- Eye patched man and his friend, who tried to mack on two women sitting adjacent to the bar
- Swinger couple at the bar openly switching partners every few minutes
- Getting checked out by both girls and guys while waiting for my table. 

There was definitely also a large neighborhood vibe as many people seemed to know each other.  Kudos to their team for adding another late night destination to the dining scene (open till 12am) and I wish them the best on their success.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
New Wine Bar opening in the lower Haight scheduled for 3/31. Will feature antipasti, pannini, and cheeses to compliment the extensive Italian wines.
author: Kim N.

description: Service is still great and the pastas are so good!  Plus the veal terrine was to die for.  Walking away with zero complaints and no suggestions for improvement (a rarity).  Besides Beretta and Poesia, this is THE place to go for "young" Italian.
author: Luke M.

description:
I could go here for dinner every night and not get tired of the varied selection of meats and cheeses with excellent wine to go with.

Some standouts from the varied menu over the past few trips...

1.  The Speck and Lardo are musts!
2.  Brussel Sprouts!  How can you have any pudding if you don't eat your greens?
3.  Kingfish crudo rocks...
4.  Oricchietti with WIld Boar was awesome! Enough meaty deliciousness, just enough crunch...perfect.

Save room for desert.  My first time there I had a salted caremel gelate(or something like that) and it was a perfect topper to the night.
author: Sean W.

description:
There was a half hour wait at 9:15 on Wednesday so the host took my number and we bar-hopped till 10.  

So it might have been the beer buzz that impelled me to order the Tramezinni, which our waitress described as "a crustless english tea sandwich rolled up like a burrito" -- waay gross, but everything else was amazing.

$17 for 5 choices of cheese, served with dates, some sort of candied pears and decadent truffle honey... hands down the best cheese plate I've had in the city.  The fava bean bruschetta was small but flavorful.  The prosciutto piadina was cheesy and salty in a good way.  And his duck salad was delicious (He said, "I DARE anyone in the city to make a better duck salad for even double the price!").

We shared all of that and a bottle of red for only $65!  Big ups to Uva for staying true to the neighborhood by not being pricey and pretentious.  I look forward to clocking some serious wine and cheese hours there in the future.
author: Abby M.

description:
Let's see, if I could put together a meal consisting of my three favorite things, what would they be?

Meat. Cheese. Wine.

If I could put together a meal consisting of my three favorite things and make each of those dishes incredibly amazing and mouth-watering, then I'm at Uva Enoteca. 

I can't read Italian so we basically had our sweet waitress do all the selecting - an assortment platter of 3 meats, 3 cheeses. I almost died when they came on huge wooden slabs. "Can it get any better than this?" I thought to myself. Oh, it can. 

The wine was amazing. It comes in a carafe - very chic and trendy, I know, but also means you get more than just a glass, which pleased me very much. The cheese came with honey, cranberries and something with almonds - until that night, I didn't even know that honey and cheese complimented each other so well.

I enjoyed seeing the bikers at Molotov's hanging out next to a group of Italian foreigners outside the restaurant as well. Always amusing.
author: Hannah L.

description:
This place is a ham and pork bar disguised as an Italian tapas bar.  It is really really really good, though not the place to take your kosher friends.  They have an amazing selection of cheeses and smoked pork, as well as a tremendous wine selection and bizarre mixed drinks.  My mixed drink of choice was the Bucco di Luppo.  It is essentially a mojito with peppers in it.  It was strong and tasty and left my mouth all tingly.  They don't call it the Mouth of the Wolf for nothing!

The service was also really great.  Super friendly tattooed waiters come by often, but not enough to be annoying.  I went there with a group, but it would also be a great place for a date.  If you (or your date) are big eaters, this is probably not the place for you as the portions are quite small, but the quality of the food and atmosphere is superb.  I highly recommend it.
author: Adam E.

description:
I was walking around the Lower Haight Art Walk. Yelped local spots on the phone. Saw this place and strolled in. Although it was packed we got a table in the back. 

Next thing you know...badow! Best meal I've had in a long time. EVERYTHING I ate was solid. The pizza, the gnocchi, the panini, the salad, and the dessert were all incredible. Yeah, I forget exactly what they were called or what was in them. But I'm not a details guy. Big picture is this...go here. I know parking the Lower Haight blows, but take some public tranny out here and prepare to get stoked.
author: Justin And Courtney L.

description: Came here last October before Hardly, Strictly Bluegrass for their brunch - all you can drink bellinis for a good price.  Delicious brunch food and excellent service.  What more can you ask for?
author: Emma S.

description:
eh, uninspiring. Not great for vegetarians. I'm not one but it was uncomfortable how much blatant MEAT there is. Albeit good. it' expensive for what little you get, small portions. the wine is pricey. really, it's a wine bar with small servings to share. not great for hungry folks. parking ain't great. location a bit spotty. the service was excellent. i was impressed with how much she knew about every cheese, meat, wine, bread option. 

pass on this if you're hungry. 

make a go of it if you have cash to burn.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Came on a date with my hunny a few weeks ago and had a wonderful evening.  We came in open minded and upon realizing we couldn't understand the menu (it's in Italian), we asked the sommelier to take care of us.  I described what kind of wine we liked and he brought us a couple to choose from.  

The wait staff is extremely attentive and helpful - our glasses were always full and never waited more than 2 minutes without more bread,etc being served.

We had wine and the meat/cheese plate - it comes with spreads and other goodies - we were pleasantly surprised.

I have already recommended Uva to friends and would definitely come again!
author: Alice H.

description:
BLAH!!!!

Came here for my birthday, a group of 6. They seated us very quickly, no problem. Restaurant was nice, service was pretty good. 

2 people in the party don't eat pork, on the website the UVA menu had a number of items that would be good options for the non-pork eaters. When we got there, the menu didn't have those options, they said they had not updated the website with the new menu. Anyways, we worked around it, there were still some non-pork options.

The food was truly mediocre. The pizza dough was not very good, the meats and small cold appetizers we got left something to be desired. The bresaola was pretty good, but we ordered two portions of some turkey gallantine, since we had non-pork eaters, our waiter said it was very good, I CAN'T BELIEVE I PAID $9 DOLLARS FOR TWO HALF SLICES OF SOMETHING I CAN GET IN SAFEWAY!!

We were going to order a few entrees after the appetizers depending on how hungry we were, needless to say we unanimously decided to go elsewhere.
author: Josie T.

description:
I went to Uva Enoteca on a Tuesday night with 5 friends and a reservation, and I doubt I will go back any time soon. 

The noise level is too high, in part due to LOUD cheesy & inconsistent music played in the restaurant, as well as the phone constantly ringing in our ears. 

Our waitress was rude to us, not answering our questions (she left in the middle of us talking to her for the first time!) and being overall blasé and rushing. Paradoxically she asked us numerous (= too many) times if everything was ok, to which I only responded yes to make her go away and stop interrupting us. I wouldn't have wanted to engage in an honest feedback with her anyway. 
And the included 18% tip in the end definitely felt like an ultimate insult!!!

The food? WAY too much garlic or goat cheese in the pasta dishes, good cianfotta, ok pizza.
DON"T GO THERE FOR WINE COCKTAILS!!! They simply don't make them despite being advertized on their website.
author: Laure b.

description:
Although I have to agree with everybody that this place is a great addition to the 'hood, the food just  wasn't all that.  Truly, this 'hood sure needs a place like Uva.    

We had a few servings of cheese (microscopic - and tastewise, just so-so), a few thin crust pizzas (not nasty, but definitely not good), a dish that looked like an Italian version of a quesidilla and a few glasses of wine.  The experience was all just one big "EH".

The server was also hurried - we never saw her between the time she took our orders and the time we complained about extra items on our bill that we never got.
author: Clarice V.

description:
I've been sizing up Uva Enoteca for some time. Situated next to Laundry Locker, I walk by Uva on a regular basis. This past Thursday, two friends and I hit up Happy Hour before a concert and were pleasantly surprised. 

I knew it was a wine bar but I had no idea that it would be an affordable, interactive and educational experience. We made it for Happy Hour and benefitted from $8 large pours of delicious red wines and $4 appetizers. We tried the fried gnocchi, salumi pizza and a chicken panini on foccacia. The cheese plate was a great introductory course and it was served with Uva's signature honey, fried almonds and pepper-pear compote. Keilani was a gracious host and deftly guided us through the menu options.

We shared a salad and pizza for the main course and popped a lovely bottle of Prosecco to wrap things up. Both the thin crust pizza and green salad were excellent. The conversation was great, the ambiance cozy and our bellies were satiated.

I kept thinking, I can't believe I haven't been here yet. Uva Enoteca is wonderful. The facade is mini, unassuming and understated. If you blink while driving down Haight, you might miss it. So keep your eyes open and try to get there before 6:30pm for Happy Hour.
author: Corey F.

description:
Went here last night for date night with the girlfriend.

Had the Eggplant Tapenade to start, which was not what we were expecting. It was served cold with cinnamon and spices and wasn't very good.

But for the main course, we shared the lamb sausage pizza with oyster mushrooms, which was amazing! It was served on flatbread and the sausage was soooo good!

She had the lambrusco sparkling red, which was really good (and I normally don't like sparkling reds) and served in a small, single pour decanter. I had the martzen amber beer, which was from a Mendecino brewery, and was quite good.

We sat right next to the door because the place was full (seems like business is still strong, especially on weekends), but the host was very nice about it and shut the door for us when it was too chilly.

Nice ambiance, friendly service, and good food, when you know what to order. The table next to us ordered a GIGANTIC meat platter with what looked like 12 different kinds of cold cuts!

Three stars, would come back, especially since it's right around the corner, just stay away from the Eggplant Tapenade!
author: Ali C.

description: We liked the authenticity and ambiance of Eva Enoteca.  The food was remarkably solid and very good well thought out.
author: Brian H.

description: I cannot decide if I am more in love with their wine list or their food!  Everything was amazing.  Great wine recommendation from our server (including a few tastings until we got the one that fit everyone's palate).  Arugula salad was so fresh and peppery, but the wild boar ragu was the show!  Rapini pizza was also amazing.  Great, fresh ingredients and beautiful space.  Perfect for a date or a night out with the gals.
author: Denice M.

description:
So excited Uva finally opened for business! 

Tried them out for dinner last night and left full and happy.  The food, the wine, the service, the atmosphere - everything was perfect!  

I can't wait to go back!
author: erica g.

description: Delicious food and friendly attentive staff. A hidden gem in a fun neighborhood. We went in for Valentine's and they had a great special menu
author: Chey B.

description:
We came here early on a Friday night, not particularly hungry, expecting to grab a glass of vino then move on. Two delicious bottles later, a pizza, some olives, and an asparagus plate, we were quite satisfied. (To our alcohol-consumption defense, our party went from 2 to 3 pretty quickly.)

I wish I could remember the wine we ordered, especially the 2nd bottle, because both were nice. Perfect temperature for a warm eve. Here's a sorry attempt to describe: both white varieties, Sauvignon-Blanc style...crisp..."like biting into an apple" according to our server (and he was actually right.)

The pizza, however, I can detail: fresh moz, sweet baby corn, basil, tomato sauce, crispy thin crust, a touch of olive oil. Extremely basic, although it didn't taste like it was missing anything. The asparagus plate was small but delicious with fresh shaved parmesan. Service was great, and the olives at the table was a nice touch.

I'd definitely come back here again, maybe sit at the bar and try some different plates. The nice thing about all the food is everything is a la carte, so mixing and matching and sharing (despite being a bit pricey) is feasible.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Just about 3.5 stars....

If I lived in the 'hood, I would make this my regular Friday post-work stop.  If you like wine (and who doesn't), cured meats (again, who doesn't), and cheese (this is getting redundant), this is a great little spot for a bigger-than-a-snack-but-not-quite-dinner thing.  The optimal seats would be at the bar, then you can avail yourself to all the wines available by the "taste" - 2oz pours.

The place is lively, but not too loud.  It's still easy to carry on a conversation.

Pizza needs a little work.  The crust was a little underdone. Also, the pea tendril salad was more like pea vines - a little woody in the stems, must have been from plants that were more mature, and it didn't work.  Tasted a bit like eating a house plant.   But the speck made up for any of those inconsistencies.  I'd certainly go back.

Did I mention they have burrata?
author: darla s.

description:
O, the food is really really good. Well the only thing I've had is the wild boar ragu. BUT it was really flavorful. It was different than I expected and have a feeling the other dishes are as well.
The staff is super nice as well.  
The devil however is in the details. Asked for bread, got some bread. Just bread. They have no iced tea. They have no diet soda. It seems like the place is fairly new so Im sure these things will work themselves out. 
I'd go back...if I could find parking int he Lower haight...
author: Greg H.

description: I recently went for my birthday with a large group and they were surprisingly accommodating and low key considering the size of our party and the size of their restaurant.  In total I have been four times, and the wine and food is always excellent, and the service is fast and friendly.
author: Maggie K.

description:
Cool place. We got here about half hour before closing so we didn't really get to try their dinner items as much as I'd like. However, we did order some meats and cheese with our wines. Our 5 assortments of meat was excellent. The waitress gave great recommendations for red wines. Unfortunately, she also gave a very bad recommendation for the dessert wine which was way too syrupy for our tastes. (Sorry, I can't remember the name off the top of my head.) 

I'll definitely come back again at a more reasonable hour to try their food and enjoy the full ambiance of this place!
author: Jonathan L.

description: Can I say YUMMY?!?! My husband and I tried this place (we had a Living Social coupon) last week and it was a perfect little place for wine and dinner. Service was quick and efficient, the dishes were very unique and absolutely delicious! We had a hearty grain salad, followed by an amazing pizza. I would definitely check this place out if nearby.
author: Ms. B.

description:
My hairdresser, his boyfriend, and I stopped by Uva Enoteca after a haircut one Monday evening. This is of note as my hairdresser is in Lower Haight and there are only a few restaurants open on Mondays in that neighborhood (we usually go to RNM). The atmosphere in Uva is dark and subtle, warm and inviting. There is a bit of an oddity with the Zeppelin music in the background, but I kinda liked it. As it was my hairdresser's birthday, I brought a homemade cake and the waitstaff were more than gracious in holding the cake for us as well as cutting and serving it after our meal. When we sat, we were given a small bowl of green olives. They were gone so quickly and thankfully, the waitstaff offered more. What *are* those giant, bright green olives?

The three of us started with three cocktails;
~ [i]Prosecco Cocktail[/i] with peach bitters and a bit of sugar.
~ [i]Miele Frizzante[/i] - Carpano antique, orange, peach bitters, and Heidrun buckwheat blossom mead. VERY odd cocktail; the mead made it seem like a light, fruity hefeweizen. Interesting, but not something I think I'd order again.
~ [i]In Bocca Al Lupo[/i] - Lillet blanc, chilies, basil, prosecco and coconut salt. Too much chilies for me; spicy.

They have a very extensive wine list and we let the owner(?) offer a suggestion. He came up with a Barbera d'Alba, "Gisep," Massolino from Piemont. 

Loving the nosh, we again put ourselves in the hands of the capable staff; bring on a bunch of meat, a bunch of cheese, and some appropriate side dishes. 

We started with the crudo of the day; on that day, Tuna with olive oil and salt. As my hairdresser's BF is a professional fish-monger, he confirmed my compliment that it was a great quality fish. 

Next the meats and cheeses arrived. They offer various assorted sized plates and offerings and so five of each seemed a good compromise; Prosciutto di Parma, Bresaola from Bernina Montevideo, Coppa di Testa from Boccalone, orange and fennel from Boccalone, and a hot Soppressata from the Bronx. Sorry I can't remember the five cheeses, but I can remember the accompaniments with the cheeses; truffled honey, a lemon/pepper condiment, and Marcona almonds. 

Also served was chunks of fresh bread, eggplant caponata (a bit on the spicy side for me but still enjoyable), roasted asparagus with lemon aioli and Parmigiano (very fresh and nicely crunchy with person aioli), and fresh beans with pancetta and onions (I ate most of these, but I am obviously the veggie eater in the group). We should have stopped, but we were intrigued with the Semolina gnocchi with speck. Of all the dishes we ordered, the gnocchi was the least successful. Perhaps I'm spoiled with Sean O'Brien's gnocchi but these were on the gummy side and with the speck and no sauce, way too dry. It needs SOMETHING moist on the plate and there was nothing.

I have to admit that there were a number of desserts which looked intriguing and I wished I could have tried the pumpkin cake with vanilla gelato, apples, saba, and pinenut brittle, but we had this cake I made instead. Again, the waitstaff was amazing and I would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Carolyn T.

description:
First time here having pre-gig drinks with friends and lo, there was a wine-maker from Italy showcasing Piemonte (sp?)...had some with frogs' legs (yum), veal sausage, and cheese plate - all excellent pairings. 

One friend from a Napa winery swapped some nice vino with him, which Uva happily held for me until I returned from a trip - nice of them. 

Service was great, crowd seemed cool, food was excellent, wine - too much to choose from! Will definitely go again.
author: Mi M.

description:
Totally excited for this place. Too bad it fiiiinnaaally opens when I'm gettin ready to move. Oh well. I know I'll still be frequenting this place on visits. I came here Mon night for their opening, which was happening! The hip and fabulous came out for this one. My boyfriend and I got their early thinking we were too early, but no, the narrow space was pretty packed! 

They kept pouring the wine and slicing the salumis, prociutto and mortadelo on the super cool shiny red vintage meat slicer. Everyone mixed and mingled... well, as much as they could. The space is kind of awkward as it is very long and narrow. But could make for a cool intimate setting once things are settled. The decor lacks, but perhaps they were not done yet.

But the best... ohhh the best... was the cheeses and TRUFFLE HONEY. I was in heaven. Don't know why I'd never thought of it before, but it's pure genius. I was so content, despite being shoved into, like every five minutes, sipping my red wine and eating my creamy cheeses drizzled with Truffle Honey.

I can't wait to check this place out once it's officially open, and then I'll update the review...
author: Nina H.

description:
We missed happy hour, but had dinner for a group of 7 here. Our table was ready, which I appreciated.

Hits:
- I liked the space
- cheese plate (love that you can choose a S, M, L size plate)
- 8oz wine pours for reasonable prices. and we all enjoyed what we got
- a few fun drink, including a couple made with beer
- possibly one of the best affogatos I've had, and I'm not usually a Ritual fan. If you're in for a long night like I was, get it!

Misses:
- snarky waitress (really annoyed me, though the waiter in the front seemed nice)
- food presentation. serving a pasta main course on a salad plate makes it look like a side dish. very odd.
- it was between moderate & spendy, which was funny since the wine was so well priced
author: Shal J.

description:
Much more reasonably priced then I anticipated
Bartender poured up 2 4 glass flights w/out a hassle
He was informative & non pretentious
Did 5 appetizers that were tasty & pretty
No problem seating us at the bar around 9pm on a Saturday night

I'll take a stroll across the street to return for a little more nosh & sipping.
author: Anne Marie M.

description: Such an interesting menu and all delicious! I've been several times. Makes me feel like I'm back in Florence... I love that you can order everything from small bites to full plates. Great Italian wines, yummy gelato! Fun place, I will go back again & again!
author: Valentine S.

description:
Love this place...and the wine!  The bartenders make incredible wine recommendations and the food is delicious as well.  My favorite is the lavender honey that comes with the cheese plate.  Just delicious.  

The back of the restaurant gets a bit noisy when it's full, but the bar or front are just perfect.
author: I S.

description:
Went there last night. Mixed feelings. 

Pros: 
Prosecca(?) sparkling wine is great ($7/glass)
Nice atmosphere--cool without being too cool.
Nice servers. 
Wine by the bottle a good value. 

Cons: 
Food is not a good value, especially considering nearby Cafe du Soleil has cheese and wine plates that are at about 80 percent of the quality for 50 percent of the price. In other words, if you're an appreciator but not hard-core connoisseur, I think the meat and cheese plates are over-priced, especially considering the portions. 

I don't like it that you can't just order a cheese plate or meat plate sampler. One has to pick, but if you're going there to be enlightened, it's almost too much. It's like, you tell me, Uva, I'm the newbie, you're the expert, so show me the best Italy has to offer. 

Probably my most fundamental criticism is the whole enlightenment (or lack of) thing. I don't what's going on with Italian wine/cheese, and the menu is all in Italian and there are no tasting notes on the wines. Our server was very nice, and she seemed to know her stuff, but I felt like I had to go out of my way to get educated, not just order. 

Bottom line: 
I might go back, especially if I knew someone who was really into Italian gastronomy. Otherwise, for wine I'd go to Hidden Vine or London Wine Bar, for cheese/meats probably Market Bar or just the nearby Cheese Store and stock up myself. I hope they do well though, as it is a welcome addition to the 'hood--nice without being totally snobby.
author: Josh K.

description: Boar Bolognese really hits the spot on a chilly night. It's a simple dish, though! Just that.
author: Ben G.

description:
For me to go to a place with a difficult parking situation and lack of a train, I think twice or I hear two fabulous views. I heard two amazing reviews from very critical people and they did not let me down in any way.

The space is people. It is sleep, uncluttered, and with wooden features that give it both a warm and trendy environment. Finding both of these qualities is not always easy. Either I am hip and cool or relaxed and sipping hot chocolate. 

Now, the important part, the food! They specialize in small plates: pizzas, sandwiches, cheeses, meats.... Don't get me wrong, it is a dinner place by all means. The food is different, dishes you will not find in North Beach, though all delicious.

My favorite was a crustless sandwich that had fresh avocado and shrimp on the inside. The pizza was also delicious, as well as my vegetarian, tomato pasta (don't get any ideas, I am not a vegetarian). 

The one downside was that even though it was not packed, it was still really loud. My advice, go with people you see a lot and don't need to chat with. As to a romantic date, I wouldn't suggest it, unless you are close and both working professionals! 

I really enjoyed my time here!
author: Christopher W.

description: Went to Uva today for the first time.  The ambiance was great, the service was fast and friendly, and the food was delicious.  We had three cheeses that came with honey, jam, and nuts on the side that were great.  We also had 3 different meats that were also delicious. I can't think of any of the names right now, but the portions were very generous.  We also ordered the wild boar pasta, which we ended up taking with us because we were full (we did have a taste and it was very flavorful).  Overall, great experience and reasonable prices.  I HIGHLY recommend :)
author: Ash A.

description: Great food, from pork starter to pecan pie.
author: sean m.

description:
Uva Enoteca is a delight.  I've gone a few times for wine and cheese in the evening, and also for brunch.  Ask your server about the cheese selections and get a brief lesson.  The staff is accommodating and delightful, they warm the greens to go with my panino at brunch and stash my razor scooter for me.  On my last visit they made a mistake with my special order, so they brought me a whole new meal and didn't charge.  

This is one of the rare spots where you feel so at ease and comfy that even after your meal has been over for a half hour, you are trying to make that last half glass of wine last just so that you won't have to leave.
author: Caroline K.

description:
Didn't know what to expect from this place. Found it on my AA Dining Rewards list. It is just like tapas. You have a cold selection and hot selection. There are a lot of meats, vegetables and cheeses to choose from. You can choose meats individually ($8 a piece) or as an assortment. ($16, $21, etc in multiple amounts). Almost same type of setup for cheese. The vegetables does not have an assortment option. Anyway, if you are like us, you did not know what to choose, the house can choose the assortment for you. Anyway, we had a lot of prosciutto and pork belly and pepperoni. It was all good. For cheeses, there was a wide range of flavours presented from hard to soft. I don't recall all the names, but They were all good. My favourites were the blue cheese and the stinky cheese. The blue cheese paired with the honey was amazing and the stinky cheese on bread was awesome. 

For the hot dishes, we had the pizza (toppings: salami). It was really good, thin crust. The other item we had was the Tramezzini. It was a sandwich made up of bread (crust cut off)  and shrimp. It was pretty good. 

The wine we had was really good and went well with all the food items we had. They have a large selection of wines. Don't get intimidated. 

Anyway, the price gets a little high ($137 for 3 with tax and tip), but still is worth trying out.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
This place is classy.  And at happy hour, it's cheap too!

The wine list, cheese and meat list, and small plates menus are thorough and tantalizing.  

We had the prosciutto pizze, the gnocci fritte and a panini with chicken and cheese, as well as a cubed eggplant dish whose name escapes me.  The former three were only $4 apiece, hapy hour price.  Everything had wonderful fresh texture, the flavors melted together nicely.  

And the beer?  Peroni, $1.50.

The service was prompt, friendly, unobtrusive and helpful.

Yes, I'm a cheap-ass, BUT I'd come back and pay full price here anyday!
author: Eric S.

description:
What f&^k is going on in the Lower Haight?


A food destination?  Well, with places like Uva opening up the neighborhood is fast becoming a dining destination.  Where else can you get great food and drink and yet be among punk rockers and public housing residents -- you got to love the City!

Back to Uva: what can I say but great wine list, even if I have no clue about any of the bottles -- I've not been steered wrong, pair that great carafe of vino with some cheese and meat and you have a gastronomic party.

The place rocks too, the staff are friendly (a bit crazy running around but they never stop making sure all is well) and I do feel like I am in an Enoteca in Rome.
author: G R.

description:
The food was pretty subpar. As was the wine. To be fair, it was the happy hour special and the cheapest, but that's not an excuse for terrible food. Your cheapest wine should still be a good wine.

However, the gelato I had for dessert was on par with the gelato I had in Italy, which is its saving grace. Great atmosphere/ambiance too. I might go back here and order from the non-happy hour menu.
author: Mark A.

description:
Where else can a table for eight feel like such a genuine mixture of nostalgia, newness, and comfort? Those feelings were of course in part due to the excellent company in our entourage, but also the warm, hospitable, and totally knowledgeable staff at Uva. The food was fantastic and the wine pairings were not to be forgotten. the food was well-prepared and delicately spiced, and the desserts were amazing. 

Uva is great whether you're with two snuggled up in a corner or a group of friends catching up. Highly recommended.
author: louise z.

description:
The Lower Haight just got bumped up a notch! I discovered Uva Enoteca by accident the other night when I was looking for an open laundromat. If you blink, you just might pass it's teensy store front, but inside it's packed with such goodness, it could possibly blow your mind!

If you understand Italian, you'll love reading the menu. If you don't, then you'll get to have your lovely server translate it for you like we did. Such an awesome staff...very informed and patient. Everything we ordered was exquisite and so artfully prepared.

Since I live across the street, I'll never have to deal with the lack of parking, so I'll definitely be back!
author: Laura A.

description: Best cocktails in the city!  And an awesome ambiance.  The black pepper pasta was great too.
author: Diane L.

description:
What a fun little spot - grab some vino, some cheese, and a sausage - you're good to go. 

Seriously, this charismatic wine lounge/tapas/restaurant was a bit of a surprise. In an incredible neighborhood with some great gritty finds, this place is super chic. It's a little loud, but everything going in the belly was go-od. The great staff knows their stuff too, so don't be shy to ask for reccos. The wine list is fun and a little eclectic in flavors, which makes it an adventure of the nose. The cheese plate (hello buratta seekers! It's here, it's here!) was wonderful with a nice selection of goat, sheep and cow. The veggies were awesome - sunchokes and brussle sprouts rocked it. The saprossata was plentiful. 

I would like to come back to try the panini...it was calling.
author: Erin M.

description:
I'll admit that I might be a little bit spoiled by the fact that my room mate works here. But, aside from this, I must say that this place is pretty damn great. 

The wine selection is delicious. The staff knows all about each wine and can discuss the subtleties of each. The snacks are yummy. The decor is fresh and modern, Chic but still hip. 

AND the happy hour special rocks.
author: Mister G.

description:
The ambiance is great.  The service is great. The cheese and meat platters were great.  Everything else was just OK.

The service staff here is very friendly and knowledgeable.  The recommendations they made were usually spot on.  

The cheese sampling was awesome.  I love the honey truffle with one of the nuttier cheeses (I forget the name of it).  And pairing it with some of the smokier cuts of meat was delish.  Unfortunately that was the highlight of the night.

I hate to only give Uva Enoteca 3 stars, but the entrees weren't that great.  The pastas weren't as flavorful as I'd like.  Perhaps the dishes were prepared a certain style and I'm not just a fan of that style, but the sauces seemed a little bland to me.  No one at our table particularly like it either, so perhaps we're all uncultured in the ways of classic italian.  The pizzas weren't too tasty either.  They were very simple, which can be good when properly executed, and didn't stand out like the cheese and meats.

Overall, Uva Enoteca is a nice place with a great ambiance and I would definitely go there for happy hour for snacks, but I wouldn't eat dinner there.
author: Johnny C.

description: Wow! I was thoroughly impressed by this cozy neighborhood Italian restaurant. Being a Sunset kid, I rarely venture into the lower haight but the positive yelp reviews and my love for italian food brought me to Uva Enoteca. We went for happy hour which is GREAT DEAL! $4 for almost half a bottle of red wine, $1.5 beers, and AMAZING pizza for $4. We also tried the plate of meats with Prosciutto Cotto w/truffles (such a unique flavor and texture of prosciutto), wild boar, and hot coppa (not as spicy as I thought).  This place loses one star because it forgot to place one of our entrees, but it ended being ok because we ordered more than enough food.  Overall, wonderful dining experience at Uva Enoteca and I would definitely return for happy hour.
author: Sara A.

description: Very slow and mostly inattentive service, on a very slow sunday. My pizza crust was very tough, but not crispy, and the other dishes, meatballs were also mediocre and over salted.
author: luke k.

description:
My friends and I were planning on trying Memphis Minnie's but they were closed so went next door to Uva.

We got a table quickly and were handed menus.

The service was okay.  Quick but not much emotion or energy from the server.

The atmosphere was nice, a good place for a chat with an old friend.

We ordered a meat platter to share.  It was pretty good but nothing special.

Each of us ordered a different pasta or pizza.  
The pizzas were good.  The pastas were sub-par.  

Prices were decent for a place like this, but I didn't feel satisfied with my food quality.  

Overall, I wouldn't go back, but I don't regret going either.
author: Emily C.

description: Amazing vegan selection. I ordered their 3 plate verdure that came with a kale salad, eggplant capanota, green bean dill dish. Their salad and olives to start are the perfect accompaniment to a great $30 bottle of wine. Wait staff was friendly and on top of it. Going back next time to try one of their desserts!
author: Laura L.

description:
To start with, take my 5-star rating with a grain of salt as I have yet to eat there. However, I did go there for drinks and was astounded by the exceptional service and the quality of the wine they served, all for an unbeatable price. 

My friend and I opted for a couple of 2 oz. tastes since we weren't familiar with most of the wines on the list. We asked the sommelier to choose for us and he came back with four bottles that were truly delicious, distinctively different (including one red that had the nose of a Riesling) and all very affordable. Most were $4 a taste and one, of a significantly higher quality, was a whopping $4.50.
