As for the service, not only did our sommelier bring the bottles out to allow us to examine them, but we got an extremely thorough explanation of the wines and left having learned something: the region they came from, the grapes, what these obscure Italian varietals were similar, etc. Adding to the experience was his slight Italian accent and his passion for the wines that shone through. This is a guy who knows his wines and loves his job.

Overall, this was my best wine bar experience ever (truly) and I would go back again in a second.
author: Kara A.

description:
so I decided to give this place another shot and returned with a few friends.
Although my experience was much better, nothing really blew me away. Everything was good and the service was fine: 3 stars.
author: Justine K.

description: I love it here, I've sat at the bar everytime, the bartender is friendly and plays a lot of 80's/new wave off his iphone. It's fun to run through a few trials until you find your favorite wine. I'd recommend trying the sliced meats, prosciutto etc., and a few cheeses. The pizza is pretty good, the salads are hit and miss.
author: Ryan M.

description: Fabulous and the great service even made it better. We were headed to UCSF for some scary tests..but needed a quick bite before. Found this gem of a place and the food and service made all our cares go away.. Loved the brussels sprouts to start followed with the wild mushroom pasta and pizza made exactly as I ordered. Our Esspresso and my Cafe Americano was nice and hot , just the way we like it. Love that they serve raw sugar and the cream in the carafe was a nice presentation. Only wish we didn't have to head off so fast, as we did spy some yummy deserts. But next time, because we will be back!
author: Patrice B.

description: This place is just smooth, like butter. Very yummy butter. Honestly, there are many great things to say about UVA and I'm to lazy to write. But I had a great meal filled with lovely cheeses and a very simple pizza that was divine. And their bathroom is probably the coolest one I've even been in. =)
author: Theresa D.

description:
Seeing how Yelp! took it upon themselves to delete my account without warning, upon re-registering I figured it best to review the best first.

I reserve 5 stars for the best of the best. Uva Enoteca defines what I consider to be an exceptional dining experience. My girlfriend lives in San Francisco and I visit her once every two months or so and my only rule for visiting the city was that I require at least one panini whilst visiting. My rule has changed--I require at least one visit to Uva Enoteca within a two visit period because I love this restaurant!

First off, I have never had an entree here that was not a panini (I will change that upon my next visit); however, when I think San Francisco I think four things: hippies, Sundays in the park, hills and paninis! And Uva Enoteca has the best of the latter category. I have had the prosciutto, caponata, bitter greens; the tre fromaggi; and the salame, arugula pesto, pecorino paninis and each one has been as delectable as the one preceding it. The prosciutto was my favorite (considering my inclination toward prosciutto above all other meats, this is not surprising).

The beer list is one of the exceptional qualities of this place, which is incredible considering that there're only two on the menu. Uva Bionda and Uva Scura. I'm not sure where either are brewed and I've never seen either one at any other location anywhere, so I'm assuming they may be brewed by Uva themselves; but both are exceptional in taste and I'd say I do like the Bionda for its richer flavor better. Crucify me for saying, I've not had any of the wine at this ultra-hip Italian Wine Bar on Lower Haight (again, something I'll rectify upon my next visit).

I do very much enjoy the infused-olives that come as an appetizer and the uniquely awesome breadsticks that come as well. I have had an assortment of their appetizer menu, having loved the orange and fennel carne, as well as every cheese assortment we've ever gotten (again, all of this is memory-based thanks to Yelp's awesome deletion of my account)

In all... this is a diamond in the rough on Lower Haight and each time we've gone the service has been top-notch and an easy 5 stars. Combined with a mellow clientele (it has been busy each time we've gone, though never enough to where we've ever had to wait for a table) and a menu, which might as well be in Chinese to me, yet still hasn't failed me once: this is indeed Haight's gem and a place to be experienced for anybody who spends even five hours in the city and wants a true taste of the Emerald Bay's gluttonous glory!
author: Michael Patrick R.

description:
No thanks.  It's classy, but the bar area is way too narrow, and  I'm not on the Atkins diet.

I felt bad for our waitress because my 4 years of latin wasn't enough for me to decipher the specifics of the Italian menu.  She spent almost all her time translating and describing things for us.  

My first question was: "I can't find any pastas, where are the pastas?"  I'm old school, I guess.
author: Tim G.

description:
The wine hear is very good. I love Italian varietals but don't have a ton of experience with the regions.  Fortunately the servers are very knowledgeable and always make great recommendations. (Four stars for wine selection and staff's knowledge).   
The decor is nice but  I can't seem to reconcile the atmosphere with the image I have of a relaxed wine bar. It definitely feels like a place you should order food, but sometimes i just want a nice glass of wine and  be left alone to catch up with my friends without being asked if I want to order. I think Uva Enoteca definitely needs to determine what type of character they want to be defined by wine or food. Once they have determined that I will likely love it.
author: Courtney R.

description: The bread they use for their carne and formaggio appetizer plates was delicious and the entrees themselves were well prepared (my friend and I each had a pasta: she had the wild boar ragu and I went with the cacio e pepe). As usual, though, I was slightly disappointed with the wine selection - from what I could see the bottles sit in an ice bucket (much like your coronas would at the beach) and their flavors were unusually weak. Definitely go for the food, but do drinks elsewhere.
author: Justin B.

description: Nothing to write home about. The food was descent and reasonably priced, but I won't be coming back here. It took about 15-20 minutes after being seated by the hostess for any of the servers to notice us and get our drink orders as well.
author: Emily W.

description:
NUTRITIONIST APPROVED! 
OMG. OMG OMG OMG. i love it here. i want to move in and live here, for realz. dropped in last night and had (too much of) that unfiltered chardonnay blend along with those fucking AWESOME olives they have there. after raving about them, they sold me a container of them for $4. HOLLA. we split a tomato-basil-balsamic salad with the. most. amazing. cheese. EVER. on it. i mean this salad was to die for. the tomatoes tasted like they had just been plucked from the vine, the cheese was like creamy ambrosia, and the balsamic and basil were the perfect compliments. my dining companion had pizza, which i avoided in favor of more wine, but i tried the pancetta and cheese on top, both awesome. we chatted up boris the owner, who was super friendly. i was slightly wobbly upon exit but FUCK. this place is AWESOME.
author: Mary V.

description: I went here last night using a living social deal and had a great experience. I have to admit though that my rating is probably based off the living social price. The food was good, but at full price I might have expected a little more. But alas, I had $60 ready and waiting for me to spend there, so it seemed great to me. My boyfriend and I tried several wines but I liked a Rosso the waiter suggested the best.... forget the names. I like that they serve the 8 oz in little carafes so you can share and try different wines. It was a little loud, but the vibe was nice. The food was decent and I had a nice experience, thus the 4 stars, but I don't know how I would feel about going back without a deal..
author: Christine C.

description: Really disappointed.  Had been there a year ago, and thought that everything was really good.  But this time, nothing was good.  There is something wrong with their pizza dough.  Texture is not that crispy outside with a nice chewy interior.  Kind of bland and chewy throughout.  The flavors of the meatball pizza just seemed like a mistake.  The pasta dish we had was all herbs, and no other flavors.  Very one note.  Feels like a new "chef" came in.  So many better options for this type of food:  Berretta, Flour & Water, etc.  Even with a Groupon it was still pricey.  Would not go back.
author: Tom Z.

description: Open relatively late on weeknights and serving some tasty vittles,  nothing to complain about.  Desserts a little weak, better off finishing your meal with a sweet drink.
author: Poppy C.

description: great pizza! the crust is amazing and the wine selection is varied.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Tried this place with a group of 4 a short while ago.  The appetizers of various beans and vegetables were very good.  The mains were underwhelming.  The grilled pancetta just didn't taste like a whole lot.  The wines we had didn't really live up to their billing.  But when our mains were taking a while the staff brought out a cheese and cold meat plate on the house, which was very nice of them.  It was also so loud we were yelling across a small table.  Prices were quite reasonable.
author: danny b.

description: Uva Enoteca is a great little place in a great little neighborhood.
author: Krishan G.

description: I like the honesty of all the favors this resturant presents. I love the cheese and meat sampler and that was amazing, the wine was great.  however when we came around to the wild boar ragu, it was rather flavorless and fell flat.  The desert was really a let down, it was basically a soup of ice cream in soda water.  For the cost, i had hoped for more.  Having lived in italy i'm still searching for that Italian experience in SF.
author: Linda T.

description: Underwhelmed by the brunch service. The meat and cheese plate was alright, although I found the jalapeno prosciutto over cured and tough. The salami was good and spicy but the bread was insufficient and didn't taste really fresh.  I ordered the fried eggs which was disappointing as I couldn't find much egg amongst the dry overcooked potato. It was served like a slice of quiche and obviously reheated. My espresso was good, and the bottomless bellini made my date happy It was not the most memorable part of the day. I would however go back for a dinner service because I know there's a different chef in the kitchen during dinner.
author: Justin T.

description:
First of all, before you go here, you need to be clear about what you're getting. 

Uva is a place to go if you want to have wine with  fancy Italian meats and cheeses and find the Italian-language menu charming. Me, I wanted to have dinner and my options in English. 

I had a selection of vegetables from their Verde menu - broccoli rabe, mushrooms, and sunchokes. All of the veggies were raw or barely cooked. This worked well for the broccoli, but not for the others which I probably should have sent back, but didn't. The mushrooms in particular were of an exotic variety that I can't name, but recognized and have made at home. This type of mushroom really needs to be cooked, otherwise there is a bitter taste and I think it's not edible. I was quite sick this morning, which I'm hoping its a reaction to the mushrooms and not the flu.

We also had pizza - the thin-crusted, artisan kind - and the ricotta pound cake, both of which were lovely. The small, round cake was dwarfed by enormous curls of pistachio gelato and served with slices of candied lemon, which IMO were the best part. 

Mostly though, the food here is so ridiculously fancy you can barely eat it. If you're looking for a culinary adventure come here. I mean, it is nice if that's what you're looking for. But I wasn't in an adventurous mood, I just wanted dinner.

The service was great. The wine was great, the place is pretty. If I came back just for wine and cheese, I would be happy here.

It was pretty busy - about 3/4 full when we left - which surprised me since it was Wednesday and we're in a recession.
author: Amy T.

description:
Came here with 3 friends.  Not very impressed.

Pros:
Nice scene.  Trendy crowd.
Small plates offer people lots of choices. (could be a con)
Good wine list by glass.

Cons:
Terrible value. $5 for a cup of 3 brussle sprouts?  Are you kidding me?
Portions are tiny.  Yes I know it is a small plates place but when you charge $14 for a cup of pasta, you'd have to spend $40-50 to get full.  If we're going to talk about that price range, there are SO MANY better options.
Service was terribly slow.  We sat down at 7 and did not get our food until 8:30.  

All in all, I will not be going back there.
author: Hui C.

description: Great decor. Nice wait staff.  The food was hit and miss. It all sounded good but I was underwhelmed.  It was bland.  The bill I received just didn't match the experience I had.  I did love that you could get small pours of wines. We tried a variety, but as other reviewers noted the wines are just okay.
author: Cary R.

description:
After months of anticipation I can truly say it was worth the wait.

Service: was spot on and very informative.  The have an extensive wine menu and they encourage you to ask questions.  Also, they offer a variety of wines by the 8oz carafe so you don't have to commit too much to something if you are not too sure.  

Space: open and private at the same time.  Well done interior knows not to try to overwhelm the customer.  The idea is a simple place for good quality relatively simple dishes the decor should reflect that.  Well done.

Grub: top notch.  Seriously, you have to try the tuna on the raw menu.  The vanilla salt is ____________(fill in any out of this world expression here).  The plates are simple and don't try to fool you.  Its honest food at decent amounts, i.e. not trying to stuff me to fool me.  Lastly, the menu is diverse and offers one many opportunities for different experiences for different visits.  Even though the ingredients and preparation are exceedingly simple you'll be wowed by what can be done with the minimalist approach.

This place is perfect for after work/whatever for the early dinner with 2-8 people.  In addition its good for light tasty meals and then of course later night noshin'.

I'll be back again and again...with friends.  If you like my reviews and trust my judgment you'll love this place.


Lastly,
I've been in the lower haight for some time and welcome this establishment with open arms.  If we need a rehashing of the pros and cons of new business here please see my Danny Coyle's review.
author: Chris D.

description: A sure choice in the Lower Haight. Their cheese and prosciutto plate are a great share and the prices are reasonable.
author: Paul C.

description: I wasn't impressed.  The restaurant was balmy and hot, my $14 lasagna looked like a child's plate, and the waitress couldn't be bothered for any attention.  It was my second visit, the first time I had the boar bolognese and it was pretty tasty, but this 2nd dine was enough to pass for a while.
author: Jeremy F.

description:
Pretty good, I got a flight and some cheese with the love of my life on his birthday.  It certainly is cute in there but it is a little hard to decipher the menu and some of the cheeses we got were incredibly strong.  Granted, the bartender gave us a replacement cheese for the stinkiest one.

I like it!  But then again I don't go to wine bars too often so I;m not a great judge.  It is a great addition to the neighborhood though.  It's nice to have a place that isn't an Irish bar or hair salon sneak it's way into the Low Haight.
author: Reggie G.

description:
Beautiful design, simple and sophisticated, esp for Lower Haight...  Nice brick, dark wood, warm lighting.   Decent amount of bar seating.

Great service, cool staff.

Delicious: Salumi, cured meats, burrata, and asparagus.

Bland: Some crostini which was 3" tall bread with bland pureed green something.  Not very good.

Didn't try any bigger plates.

Cool: $10 mini-carafes of wine.

Good date place or for a group of friends...
author: Melanie C.

description:
Meant to write about Uva after the first time I went here a few months ago but after taking a bottle of delicious wine to the head with a friend here last night I felt especially inclined to write this time on this hungover work day.

Uva is a small Italian Wine bar with a delicious selection of small plates, carne (meat...as in carpaccio not steak), fromaggio (cheese.. keep up people) and other things like Panini's and Pizza's.  

They have this eggplant copponata that is incredible (chopped small with tomato, pinenuts, onions and some other delicious veggies with a hint of cinnamon) and gnocchi like I've never had it before served on a thin slice of speck (see carne above).

Last night my friend and I ordered their cheapest bottle of red wine due to being on a budget ($20) and I was extremely impressed.  For growing up with a father who installed his own wine cellar into our home, I like quality wines.  So it's a very good thing when a restaurants' cheapest bottle of wine is actually affordable AND delicious.

The service at Uva is also incredible, the staff (including at the bar) can explain anything about the wine and food selection and are very pleasant.

Oh!  And they give you these AH-mazing green olives when you get there that are seriously the best olives I've ever had...and I eat a LOT of olives.
author: Ariana K.

description:
Gotta love Uva!  This place is pretty unique for the Lower Haight - a clean, modern, inviting restaurant with delicious food and a great atmosphere.  The italian-influenced menu tastes authentic without being heavy -- try the wild boar ragu or some of the more inventive desserts.  And the space is warm and intimate -- perfect for a date or a nice dinner with friends.  I'm reluctant to mention the happy hour for fear of causing a stampede, but suffice it to say it's the best value in the neighborhood.  

In case you couldn't tell, I love this place.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I had never been here before and arrived just in time for the happy hour drink special-a sparkling red wine (which was delicious).  The cheeses were amazing and paired well with honey, almonds and a quince.  the veggies were great, my favorite being the brussel sprouts.  

I went with some girlfriends and had a great time.  Might be a nice date spot, but i honestly couldnt imagine many dudes i know wanting to eat here.  Very lovely atmosphere though and great service.
author: Katie Sue A.

description:
Beautiful decor (especially at the bar).  Nice wines, reasonably priced, and you can get just a "taste" instead of a full glass.
However, please note they don't really have a kitchen here. The "cooked" food is not good enough to justify the prices. The cured meats and cheeses are pretty good, especially with the wines.
author: Meredith G.

description:
I have been here 3 times so far and I absolutely love it and will keep coming back. The first time I went it was just for the wine, which was great. Even if you're not familiar with Italian wines, the waiters/waitresses are really helpful. Their by-the-glass wine list changes every night. The second time I went I tried a couple of pasta dishes and didn't enjoy them much. However, last night I went with some meats, cheeses, veggies and a salad and YUM! all very interesting and delicious. I highly recommend the sunchokes. 

I wouldn't go here if I was starving for a big meal, but it's great for Friday night small things to taste and sip some great wine!
author: Sandra E.

description:
It was a wonderful experience -- and we're so glad that we got there when we did because at 7pm the place was packed! The service was very friendly and our server had great recommendations for cheeses. 

I'm not sure if it's because it's the type of place where you're supposed to linger or whether it's because it's new, but everything moved a little slow. Nothing outrageously slow, but there were a couple times when we were wondering what the hold up was. And the people we were sitting next to were just too much. I could go into it, but it's just too tacky to believe.

That aside, everything was great. The gorgonzola cheese is fantastic with the truffle honey! We also had the arugula salad with some tasty pecorino, and the bean, asparagus and gorgonzola panini. All was very good.

As for wine, the bartender suggested two very dry white wines, which was exactly what we were looking for on that warm evening. We also tried the evviva (I think that's what it was called), which was a great wine cocktail. Needless to say, we left very happy campers.
author: Tamara M.

description:
Lovely neighborhood gem, saw families, first dates, friends and just plain folks enjoying themselves.  Three of us ate, and although we'd all had a lamb slider each at Alembic before coming here, 100 bucks bought us each a good glass of wine or champagne and full tummies.  Tried the assortito, three cheeses recommended by our lovely server, a finger sandwich of shrimp and avocado, and two of the salads.  Each of us had one of the desserts - the holiday bread special was dry, but flavorful; the basil cream, cookies and (YUM) pistachio gelato were seriously good, and the g-something gelato (chocolately flavored) with berries was easily finished.

Likely will return, great place to take it easy, munch and chat.  Not too noisy, intimate without being stuffy, and the inside is very warm.

Although I'm starting to feel sorry for missing out on this water closet...
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Where did this little gem come from? 

Surely it's a sign of my transformation into a souless yuppie, but I find the incongruence of this place--amidst NocNoc, Toronado, and all my old familiar dive haunts, strangely charming. 

I heart the wines--although I still can't justify $16 for a glass (sorry--no more sugar daddies), and I found the olives simply divine. What a treasure.
author: Kathleen G.

description:
Yum! Their gorgonzola cheese is unreal (so creamy)--make sure to try it with the truffled honey.

Thin crust pizza was cooked perfectly. Try to order a balance of meats and cheese.

Their olives were unbelievable. I've never had olives like that before. Rich, yet not salty.
author: John M.

description: Uva Enoteca is right nearby and is one of the places I intend to make my go tos when I'm in the mood for Italian.  I'm a huge fan of their pizza-- most recently, I had their meatball, san marzano tomatoes, mozzarella, pecorino pizza.  While I would have liked some greens on the pizza, I am a huge fan of their crust-- it's chewy and delicious.  Great atmosphere for a date or for a small group of friends.
author: Alice Y.

description: This place is awesome! We live right down the street so we tend to frequent it for dinner. They have a nice casual atmosphere with superior dishes and really good knowledge of the italian wine they serve. I go here whenever I can , I love it!
author: Carol B.

description: we love this place. GREAT happy hour, always good wine. Excellent Burrata appetizers and great pasta / pizza entrees
author: Chris R.

description:
Nice little spot in lower Haight area. If you don't pay attention you might miss it since there were no huge signs in the front. Once you step into the restaurant, you initially will think "wow this place is small" but there were more table towards the back. The bar area is located in the front. The decor has a very chic Manhattan feel with exposed brick walls, high ceiling, and low lit environment. We came on a Wednesday night so got a table immediately and parking, although is usually difficult around that area, we didn't have a problem.

The food menu was very short and mostly in Italian which we had to ask the waitress for clarification. Appetizers, you can choose an assortment of salami, hams, cheese, and veggies. Since this place was labeled as a wine bar, I think it made sense to have those small bites. For the so-called entree, the selection of pasta, pizza, and panini, were quite short. We ordered a trio of salami, a panini, and a pizza. The portions were small and the food tasted average. Once you flip the menu, there was a huge list of import wines (mainly Italian wines). You can order by the bottle, 2 oz, or 8 oz. I just had a 2oz from the waitress' recommendation (don't remember the name of the wine) but it was excellent. Service was good but the food took a bit of time to get to us.

Overall, if you're a wine enthusiast and a small eater then maybe you'll love this place. However, I thought the portions and selections of the food were quite small for the prices they are charging. Although I do love the one wine that I tried. I think I might give it extra stars if I tried more wines but it was a WEDNESDAY NIGHT!
author: Peter L.

description:
I really enjoyed our first trip, we got there on the early side so we didn't have to wait for a table which was great because by 7:30 on a Wednesday it was starting a wait list.

The wine list is a great mix both of styles and price points with several lovely selections below 30. The assorted meat platter is a good value fro the quantity and quality of the meats. We also really enjoyed are pizza and the lovely gnocchi with speck, the only problem is that there were too few, not for their price but for their awesomeness!

The service was lovely and the only real oddity that struck out was the packaged breadsticks they give you when you are seated!

As someone who can't drink enough water, I love the carafe at the table!

A great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Tara A.

description:
I took my gf to Uva Enoteca last night and it was fabulous! As it was our first time, we decided to take in as much of the menu as possible. We started with the antipasti platter, which included delicious high-quality italian cheeses and cured meats, an eggplant caponata that was to die for and roasted asparagus with a delicious creme accompaniment. 

We customized our own wine flights with a few 2 oz. pours and not a single wine I tried was a dissapointment; to the contrary, I was pleased to find some new experiences, including an Italian chardonnay fermented in clay barrels, as wine had been for much of its history. My favorite tasting of the night was a barolo, but I greatly enjoyed the sangiovese and abruzzo as well. I was especially impressed by our server, who was able to converse intelligently about each and every wine we chose and made great pairing suggestions.

For our entrees, we tried the corn, mozzarella and tomato pizza, prepared in an authentic Italian style. I'd never had corn on pizza before, but it was quite good- the corn stayed nice and crisp and added a great little sweetness to each bite. We also tried the orecchiette with wild boar ragu, which I loved. I couldn't quite finish it all, but had to take the rest home and had it for breakfast today. :)

For dessert, we shared an order of the tre gelati- hazelnut, pistachio and vanilla- and it was a fittingly delicious end to a great meal. The gelati were extremely flavorful and creamy; my mouth is watering just thinking about them!

We will definitely return. I can't wait until next time!
author: Daniel M.

description: So hard to find a "real" enoteca in San Francisco... ever been to Italy... then you will know that they have got it going on.  Want American style food... not the place for you, want as close as you can get to enoteca plates then this is the place for you.  Great wine list also.
author: Christie L.

description: I made a reservation for a Monday night at 7pm for 3 of us.  The host was pleasant enough, and we were seated pretty promptly.  The waitress, however, was the end of good service.  She first appeared to be annoyed that we were there.  Being an American who does not speak Italian, the menu is difficult to decipher without her assistance.  When I inquired, she was clearly displeased that I should even ask her any question.  During dinner, she never stopped by, not even once, to check on us.  She basically just ignored us the whole meal.  When it was time for dessert, she didn't even offer the menu to us.  We had to ask to see the menu again.  The food was not bad, but I've had much better Italian food in San Francisco.  My pasta with peas and mushrooms were seriously lacking in peas and mushrooms!  For the price we paid for three people (over $100 total), the service and the food should have been much, much better.  We will never return.
author: William L.

description:
Have been there a few times since they opened. Excellent food, wine and atmosphere, knowledgeable staff. 

A welcomed addition to the Lower Haight.
author: eric m.

description:
This restaurant if fantastic, The Italian wines by the glass are solid. the charcuterie and cheese are fantastic here. 
Wood oven pizza, salads great.
This is perfect for a date. I would not suggest this place for a large group. 4 at the most. The idea is you share and it becomes too difficult to do that with the cheeses and the charcuterie. I would also say the portion sizes are a bit small, but the quality is great.
I will definitely come back here for a little salad, some charcutie and cheese, pizza and good wine. 
Again I highly suggest you don't come here with more than 4 people.
author: Fernand P.

description: I'm frankly worried about writing this review because Uva is one of those rare places that is consistently delicious and yet strangely never too busy to seat me. They have a policy of keeping 3/4 of their tables open for walk-ins, which normally I hate because it just means waiting forever for a table. But in this case, it means that our weekly pilgrimage for delicious Italian wine and scrumptious pizza, pasta, salumi and salads can be impromptu. Hallelujah. A neighborhood restaurant where I don't need to make a reservation 3 months in advance or wait over an hour for a table- with amazing food? Yes please and thank you very much.
author: oona m.

description: I had been to UVA for nibbles and vino a couple of times in the past, but this weekend was the first time I had tried their brunch.  Besides being in a great location (Lower Haight) they've got a very "unhaight street" feel to them and they are the prefect size for any group whether intimate or large. The food and service was AMAZING.  Wine list is extensive and the breakfast flatbread with egg and prosciutto was delish.  I would definitely recommend for a low key brunch or as a spot to take out of town guests with a stroll down Haight either before or after.
author: Serena M.

description: This place is amazing! The food is delicious, the atmosphere is exquisite, the service is spot on & the owner is the shit! I would recommending going there for a great meal, date or just for some drinks.
author: Adam S.

description: With all the choices in the Lower Haight, I usually always go back to one of three places. This is one of them. The food is always great, the service consistent, and the staff friendly. The price is reasonable and the bartenders know their wine. Good stuff.
author: Onika C.

description: Finally tried this place after walking by it time and again and hearing rave reviews. It was pretty good. The wine menu is great and offers a lot of different options many of which were new to me, so I liked that a lot.  The food was good- simple- nothing too fancy.  I went with my boyfriend and we opted to order 3 cheeses and 3 meats and split a pasta. The cheese and meats were great, but the wild boar pasta was pretty boring.  The place is cute and the waitress was helpful but really only after we asked for advice/opinions. I would have appreciated a more proactive staff especially since their menu is not easy to figure out and has a lot to consider.  Overall, pretty good, and I'll give it another go.
author: Laura H.

description: I absolutely love this place! Everything here is tasty - the wine, the pizza, the pasta, the cheeses, the small plates, the salads, the desserts!
author: Dianne R.

description: A group of us went here for a dinner celebrating a birthday and recent engagement of friends. We ordered the cured meats as an appetizer and marinated mushrooms. Both were probably the best part of the meal. The meats were nice and salty, served with bread and mustard. The mushrooms had a nice acidic yet earth flavor. I was really looking forward to the next part of the meal, the wild boar ragu, but was sorely disappointed. It had to be the most flavorless ragu I have ever tasted. Totally unexpected. It was like they mixed plain, unseasoned  minced meat and a tasteless, watered down, tomato sauce together and tossed it with some rigatoni. Not impressed. We also tried the margarita pizza and the lamb and sausage skewers. Both were OK, but nothing I would go back for. The highlight of this restaurant was the service. The servers were on it as far as replacing plates, silverware, bringing out dishes, and answering questions. The wine the waiter suggested for our table was an excellent choice for all. I might give this place another try, but will definitely try different dishes to see if there is anything that is tastier than what we ordered this visit. I really wanted to like this place a lot, not just a little.
author: Sara H.

description: Inexpensive and always good.  Very casual and comfortable atmosphere and really knowledgeable service.  If you don't know Italian wines, let them choose for you.
author: Josephina L.

description:
Just had dinner at Uva last night and was a bit disappointed. We had three veggie starters, the wild boar ragu, the meatballs, and two desserts.  Plus wine.  The veggies were quite good - really nice seasoning with the beets (though I'm not sure cauliflower is the best pairing).  The eggplant was spiced with cinnamon which was a surprise at an italian place.  The Brussel sprouts had awesome potential, but were very un-roasted.  Raw really. 
The ragu was very good, though it would have benefitted from a fresh pasta instead of a boxed 'small shell'.  The meatballs were very good, though I was glad I had a big app because there were only 3 on the plate.  That should be an app, and there should be an entree with pasta or bread or a side salad...  
Dessert was a major bummer.  The caramel ice cream sandwich was just too sweet - it was dipped in chocolate, which was overkill (this coming from someone who eats marshmallows by the bag).  The pound cake was a bit dry, though the ice cream on top was delicious. The wine we had was a 2000 montepulciano red - suggested by our waitress and very good - easy to drink with everything we ate. 

Overall, not a terrible meal, but nothing was outstanding.  It was also VERY loud, and we left STINKING of kitchen grease.  I would go back to try the meats and more of the wines...
author: leah w.

description:
The husband and I came here last night and were blown away. Both being fans of italian cuisine, we fell in love with:

Small plates:
-Speck (smoked proscuitto)
-cheese tasting 
-oyster mushrooms with basil
-crudo: tuna with olive oil and vanilla salt

Entrees:
-gorgonzola pizza with bitter greens (served with a red sauce, mmmmm)
-burrata and pomegranate tramezzini

Dessert:
-nocciola gelato
-affugato (the best we've ever, ever had)

There are a lot more adventerous items on the menu, but we went with what we knew. The presentation of the food is great, and the atmosphere is very clean and comfortable. Perfect place for small or large groups. Definitely going to become one of my favorites.
author: megan k.

description:
One of my favorites in my neighborhood.  The staff is warm and welcoming.  The Happy Hour is awesome and it's a great place to start the evening or end the night (kitchen closes relatively late for SF).  Early evening background music is great 80s/90s alternative and the vibe is chill.

Their meat and cheeses are tops along with their pizzas.  Everyone I've taken here always wants to go back.

Can't thank them enough for introducing me to Lambrusco!!
author: Dee Dee N.

description:
Very much liked this place. Would definitely go there again. I love the small portions, especially the salami/meats (ok, i'm not super knowledgeable about Italian food names...), cheeses. The menu has only a few categories, but lots of variety in each.

I went there with one other person, but would definitely recommend it for a group of friends looking for a relaxed time. 

Easygoing but professional service and terrific food.
author: Adam P.

description: You really can't go wrong with bottomless bellinis. The food is good though the options are minimal. The arugula pizza is really good except I've come to find I'm not a fan of fried eggs on pizza. Other than that the crust is really good and you can ask for no egg or just take it off.
author: A S.

description:
Initially I was a bit wary of a high-end Italian (or any other cuisine, for that matter) restaurant opening up on a block of Haight that is more known for its no-fuss bars and casual eateries.

Upon entering, I found the decor to be simple, yet elegant, and I was pleased to see a larger dining room that opened up behind the crowded bar area.  

The food, though it had a few shortcomings, it was right on par, if not better in some respects, than meals I've had at more established Italian eateries like A16.  I really enjoyed the meat and cheese plates (all served on handsome wooden cutting boards), but the pizza, while good, wasn't anything to rave about.  Great wine list with a sommelier that really knows his stuff.  

I think when I go back (and I will), it'll be at the bar, ordering a few different glasses of wine and sticking to the meat and cheese selections.
author: John S.

description:
I know everybody so far has given great reviews of the place and said all the same things - great food, decent portions, stellar service, etc.  And they're right.  This place is amazingly great especially since they've only been open a week or so.  

The food menu is extensive and while everything looked great we settled on a pizza with asparagus and prosciutto, trezzameni sandwich with shrimp, avocado and pancetta, 3 cheese plate (comes with kick-ass black truffle honey, white pear with black pepper and cherries), tuna crudo (best sushi-quality tuna with unusual vanilla salt) and assorted salumi plate (came with prosciutto, coppa, bresaola and some other ones I can't remember but we're all good).  All of that plus two desserts (best pear sorbet ever!), two bottles of wine (dolcetto) and two dessert wine glasses (moscato) plus a generous tip and it was only $57/person(there were 3 of us).  Great deal for a satisfying amount of food and plenty to drink.

Service was impeccable.  Every question was answered knowledgeably.  No one rushed us along.  We got there early (6:15) so we had no problem getting a table but by 7 every seat was filled and by 8 there was a wait.  As the word gets out this place will be packed.

Highly recommend this place!!
author: Jennifer A.

description: Loved this place. It's intimate, charming, romantic and the wine and cheese and food is delicious. Loved the brick walls around it. This is a great date place or just a nice setting to catch up with some wine and food with your friends. Authentic italian menu written in italian as well.
author: Yvonne C.

description: We sat at the bar on a busy Friday (thanks to the lovely hostess for snagging us two seats). The bartender recommended a great bottle of reasonably priced red to complement the cheese plate, the beets and asparagus and mushroom pasta. Everything was tasty and fresh. We'll definitely be back.
author: Gretchen S.

description: Place was appealing when we walked in but went down hill from there. The waitress we had was quite pretentious. Treated us like we didn't have the skills to order and kept suggesting to order for us. I guess she was humbled a bit when she knocked over a glass of wine on me and the glass shattering everywhere. The food is very rich not a great menu but enjoyed the salad and cheese and meat appitizer. But With so many restaurants to choose from in the city, would not recommend and will probably not go again. over all not the best of experience. Got the living social coupon.
author: Judy R.

description: Everything was delicious but I would make a special trip for the mortadella.  (it was similarly spiced to the head cheese at Boccalone).  They create their charcuterie in-house.
author: Steen X.

description: I've only come here a few times for wine tasting and the staff have been phenomenal. The wines have been interesting and yummy but the service has been great both times, even when they are ridiculously busy. On my to do - come back and try one of their cheese and meat plates - they look amazing!
author: shadi m.

description: As a regular for over a year I must say I have not been disappointed. Uva is a great place to sit at the bar and have wine and a small snack. I come here for the Lambrusco which I find hard to get in SF and the chicken paninni. I would recommend checking out this place to catch up with old friends or as a date spot. The service is always friendly and the food fabulous! Oh, and they are going to start serving brunch in a week or so with BOTTOMLESS Bellini's! xo
author: Michele G.

description:
Very nice decor, looks like a bar in NY which seems to be the trend in dining out.  You can order 2oz of wine for an average of 4$ a glass.  Or the glass that I had 8oz for 12.  Nice option.  Do not come here if you are extremely hungry.  The dishes are really small!  I ordered the raw tuna......with vanilla salt...........not going to order this again.  Something about the cut was very mushy.  Not much flavor at all for an 8$ slice of tuna.  Lots of bread!!  I recommend the cheese plate!!!  Served with almonds, honey, and some sweet dip.  Really loud, good for getting a drink of wine expect to pay about 20 a person for a drink and one app.  

Good service very informed staff.  Great clean bathroom!  Presentation was beautiful.  I will be back and sit at the bar again.  A nice addition to the area.......  

This space reminds me of the places I worked in NYC!  SF please don't loose your edge:)
author: Velvet V.

description: I would give this place 5 stars, but it's like that saying "life is like a box of chocolates, you never know what you're going to get"...well it's the same for this place.   The first time my friends, Bernard and I went here we had an excellent time.  Our waitress was very helpful in explaining the entrees and different types  of cheeses on the menu, etc.  She was very pleasant and eager to serve, but last night we had a waiter who treated us like we had leprosy.  This time we had a prix fix menu coupon to cash in on and even though the appetizer was amazing, the entree and dessert were just okay.  I did enjoy the wine pairing.  I think next time around, we'll skp the special prix fix coupons and just go with the regular menu and choose a bottle of the wine we had that accent the menu.
author: Terry S.

description: Great space, good wine, and tasty meats, but go down the street to Three Twins for ice cream.
author: Mary P.

description: The service is surly, especially the male waiter. I have eaten here several times. The food was disappointing this last time.
author: David L.

description:
Did not try the food; the menu did not have anything which peaked our interest. 

The Bar is worth visiting.

Good for small groups, 2 - 3 people.
author: Adil A.

description:
A welcome addition to the Lower Haight. 
Although the entire menu is in Italian, the staff was very patient and helpful, and made great food and wine recommendations. This isnt the kind of carb-loaded gut busting Italian food you find at corporate places, its just an assortment of fine meats and cheeses with a few light pasta dishes, sandwiches and pizzas. The food is all very refreshing, just enough to fill you up but not stuff you. 
The staff was super helpful and the music was great, not too loud to cover conversation but loud enough for me to catch they were playing everything from Jesse Malin to At the Drive In. 
I'll be back.
author: Brad O.

description:
I live in the Lower Haight, and this is by far my favorite restaurant in the neighborhood for upscale dining. The staff is super friendly and knowledgable about the diverse array of wines and cheeses that they have on the menu, and they're constantly adding and changing it around so I have to come back every week to see what's new! The atmosphere is basic - clean and classy without too many frills - and it's a great place to come with a group of people. I'm going to liken it to having Italian tapas. 

Really, you gotta check it out.
author: Casey C.

description: Went there for a glass of wine after dinning somewhere else.We were accommodated with a table right away,which was very nice.They have wines by the bottle, 2oz and 8oz. glass size.Brilliant option for thjose who don`t know much about wines since you could sample the 2oz ( in the $3 range) until you get to the one that you really like and next time you may go with larger glasses or a bottle.Our server (Boris) was very attentive and even though we were last to leave we didn`t feel like we had to.Will definitely go back and try their food as well.
author: Tony M.

description: As incredible as it may sound the waiter ( the bearded guy ) fallowed me out side (half a block )because I told him on writing on the check that his service failed ( he forgot an item I had order), and he did not do anything else, he said to me that bad karma will do 4 me. I told him that I was not happy and that I was willing to call his boss, he told me that he would be happy to give me his  boss phone #. ..................................So all I can tell You is be careful , expect bad service and be harassed
author: Juan S.

description: I thought the atmosphere was great but I'd probably eat at Memphis Minnies next time and come for drinks.  Food was just ok.
author: Eamonn T.

description: Went here with my husband and another couple.  The server was awesome.  She opened three bottles of wine so we could try them all before picking one.  We had a cheese plate and all the cheeses were awesome.  We all had pasta dishes and everyone was very happy with their choices.  Big fan for the price!
author: Deidre D.

description: Best food you can find in the lower haight.  Delicious food, reasonable prices.  The vegetables are incredible, and the wait staff is very friendly.
author: Trevor W.

description:
We came here to celebrate a birthday party and what a good call! From the outside, you'd think it's a small place with a good sized bar, only to find that it extends further in the back...and there you have it: A nice, lofty restaurant that looks like it belongs in the Napa Valley, minus the snooty service. The wine selection is nothing short of amazing! The bartender's so good, he could recommend a bottle that proves to be spot on to your liking. We had several bottles of Campo di Mezzo, a Sangiovese. At $35 per bottle, it not only knocked our socks off, but our pants off too! It paired so well with the prix fixe menu...Bravo, Bartender...Bravo.
Once seated, we were immediately greeted with a variety antipasti:
-Assortito Carne: I don't necessarily know what was offered...I just know that there were some that were not to the Birthday Girl's liking. One of them being Pate...I think I was better off not knowing what everything was. I do know that the salami and prosciutto good: freshly sliced and perfectly cured.
-Verdure: An assortment of various veggies: Brussels Sprouts (What is it about kids not loving them, but as we get older, it's a favorite...well, for me anyway!), Eggplant Caponata (I liked it until I found out it was eggplant), Lentils, and some others. Overall, they were good starters. For some people, they were probably better off not knowing what the dishes were, because everything was quite tasty...
-Insalate: I believe we had two kinds. An arugula salad with potatoes, gorgonzola and almonds. I don't know about you, but a salad with gorgonzola is always a winner to me. We also had a mixed salad with sweet potatoes, raisons and parmesan cheese...With all the other flavors going on, I wasn't paying much attention.
After we were done with the antipasti, we were bombarded with a slew of main dishes to share. I won't bore you with the specifics, but I'll share my favorites:
-Pizza: Potato, Goat Cheese, Tarragon and Tomato--Another ingredient you can't go wrong with: Goat Cheese...It was such a great combination of a solid potato and soft cheese. A yin and yang of pizza, if I may...
-Pasta: Lamb sausage and goat cheese--I believe this was the one that came out baked, with burnt cheese on top. Oh man...there's something about burnt cheese on top of pasta...like a match made in heaven.
-Dessert: They served several and I had a difficult time deciding which was my favorite.
Vanilla gelato with olive oil and sea salt...such an interesting blend of tastes...but so good. Scoop a dollop into your Ritual Americano (Yes, Ritual Coffee!) and you are GOLDEN!!!!
Lemon Sorbetto...The kind that gives you a scrunchy face once dissolved in your mouth...Loved it!
Finally, pomegranate ice cream...sweet, different, but still good. Again, one dish that takes a back seat to its counterparts.
Overall, a wonderful dinner. Be prepared to come close to losing your voice, because it's loud in there...A sign of a great Italian dinner!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Lovely little place. Lots of wines that you can buy in either 2 oz or 8 oz portions ( I could get in real trouble here by ordering 18 2 oz glasses!). We had the small meat platter which looks intimidating when it first comes out, but it isn't as much meat as your eyes first think. Every now and then they come by and bring you more slices of bread. Highly recommend it for a light meal.
author: Donna W.

description:
I went with a friend for brunch on Saturday with a "Coupon" for a great deal. We were the 2nd table with only 3 other people in the place. We did get our drink order right away, but our egg and pizza order took  "FOREVER " or so it seemed. Some people who came in after us by 15 minutes or more got their order before we did, maybe because they  just ordered pasta. 
Anyway as far as the food- The bottomless Bellini was originally served with orange juice (a mimosa) but later we were offered a Bellini with which seemed like peach juice (it was clear like apple juice.) The mimosa-Bellini was the best part of the meal and a good deal for $10.
My egg with biscuit was just OK-the eggs were sort of hard scrambled with some sauce topped with homemade biscuits that were shaped by hand. The pancetta was actually just 2 strips of bacon (maybe they ran out, but they did not explain it or thought we were too inexperienced as diners or cooks to notice?) My friend ordered a pizza with caramelized onions and as another reviewer said there is something "wrong" with their dough. It was very thin but had a weird consistency like maybe it is a frozen pizza dough and not a good one. The caramelized onions on top looked like it was put under the broiler to brown the onions which might have contributed to the strange texture. Also I took a couple pieces home and cold or reheated-it was no better. How can you ruin pizza? 
I would not go back  unless I was in the area for a glass of wine. It does have nice ambiance and the server was friendly enough, but did not explain the long wait with so few people in the place. He was the only wait staff and maybe the cook just came in late-our reservation was for 12 noon and it opens at 11 am. He did review my coupon very closely to let me know I could not use more than one and I could not use it for alcohol (which I already knew.)
author: Elizabeth M.

description: Great place for tasting wine with a small/med apps.  The service was great/poor based on who your server was.  We didn't have an assigned server, it seems that everyone there is your server; thus we had some that were really knowledgeable and some that seemed very new.  They have a good selection of wine except anything full-bodied and the wine experts that are knowledgeable really know their wine.
author: LIVE to E.

description: This little gem is hidden among the dodgy dives and artsy shops of lower Haight Street, and when my friend and I stumbled upon it on the evening of my last birthday I was most pleasantly surprised!  The wine selection is great, perfect for enjoying a glass or sharing a bottle (latter highly recommended) and the munchies are the perfect compliment to a glass of wine.  We settled on the prosciutto pizza and couldn't have been happier!  I am a sucker for cured meats, and this rendition did not disappoint.  It was truly delectable; thin, fresh & crispy crust with a sweet tomato sauce that was obviously made from scratch...my only regret is that I didn't take more advantage of this spot while living around the corner.  I am sadly across the country now, with no seconds in sight.
author: Jessica T.

description: This is typically one of my favorite neighborhood spots (I live down the street), but I had a really disappointing experience at happy hour last night. We walked in a few minutes before 6:30 and sat down at the bar. Spent a couple of minutes trying to get the bartender's attention so we could get our order in before HH ended. He (the guy with the red beard) stood at the other end of the bar wiping off glasses (not even helping anyone; it wasn't crowded). Finally he came over and and when I asked, he informed us happy hour was over. I checked my phone - it was 6:30 on the dot. It honestly felt like he was trying to set us up to be late, although I can't imagine what incentive he would have had to do that. His overall attitude came off like a cop who had caught us breaking the law rather than like a neighborhood bartender. If he'd been even a bit nicer about the situation, we would have stayed and ordered at the regular price, but he was such a jerk about it that we just left. As I said, I've had good experiences at this place - and even, if memory serves, with this particular employee - in the past, so I'm not sure what was going on, but it definitely left a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Taryn F.

description:
we came here for my wife's b-day for a low key dinner.  the ambiance and decor lent itself well to that but i was expecting a bit more out of the food.

we got there around 7pm and the place was empty.  good for us since we'll get our food quickly!  we looked over the menu and after a bit we came down to getting a few apps and a few entrees.  for apps we got the pearl onion, pomegranate and grape vinaigrette cold salad and the persimmon, fennel and prawn salad.  the pearl onion salad was nice but nothing special.  the prawn salad was nice but there was way too much fennel and it over took the lovely persimmon.  the prawn was cooked very well.

for mains we got a pasta w/ brussel sprouts and onions and a pizza w/ arugula and potato.  both were decent but not great.  the pizza was unique due to the small cubes of potato.

overall it was a decent restaurant but i don't see ourselves jumping to go back.
author: Swarup B.

description: Went here for dinner mid-week and had a lovely, filling yet inexpensive gourmet Italian meal. I like that they have good affordable wine by the bottle. I love that they have cheese, meat and veggies plates and they don't skimp on any of them. And I appreciate their simple yet cozy decor and great service. Definitely going back for more!
author: Sara W.

description: Great food, knowledgeable and friendly service, extensive wine selection.  I loved it!
author: Erika B.

description: Amo questo luogo! They really know how to do it here. The food is amazing, the wine phenomenal, and the staff are all friendly and know their stuff. I recently came for the happy hour and could not believe the deal. Funny, that never happens...Happy hour, and then the bill comes and you leave ecstatic!
author: Brian B.

description:
nice italian wines.  i enjoy the 8oz carafes. 

they serve meats and cheeses on wooden slabs. i had proscuitto today and it was perfect.
author: Yevi A.

description:
Now that's my kind of wine bar. ITALIAN WINES! Went here a while back and tried the Lambrusco upon recommendation. Wasn't really in the mood for bubbly, but boy was I won over. Could have had 30 glasses then taken a bath in it like Marylin Monroe. Thanks to adorable Muffintop Red head bartender. 

2nd time I hit up the Natural Wine Event they had. fantastich. 

Last time ordered San Fereolo's Dolcetto. 

Lord help me.
author: Ginger H.

description: I came here to raise a couple glasses of barbera to Nominee Barack Obama. Celebrations aside, Uva Enoteca is a simple, nice wine bar/restaurant. Large selection of wine, knowledgeable employees and less uptight than you might think, based on a quick look around. I usually don't come to these places to eat-eat, limiting my choices to wine, cheese or meat slices, so perhaps I'll come back for a full-on dinner.
author: Tara R.

description:
The atmosphere was nice. The decor was tasteful. The service was attentive and knowledgeable. The meats, cheeses and all the ingredients used were first rate. Speck and taleggio = crazy delicious. 

Happy hour is from 5:00-6:30, Monday-Thursday. The happy hour menu includes 3 food items for $4 each, a full third of a bottle of delicious Lambrusco for $4, and $1.50 Peroni. Try the Lambrusco. Trust me. Just try it.

If it's not from the happy hour menu, the portions are generally somewhat small for the price you pay.  The pizzas are only about 6" in diameter, but are excellent. The gnocchi was decent, but nothing special. The menu is full of interesting choices (such as celery root & pomegranate which was excellent), but the menu's font was so small and the lighting was so dim that I could barely make out some of them.

My suggestion is to arrive before happy hour ends, get a Lambrusco and whatever pizza is on special, then stretch out with some regular menu options and some wine tastings or specialty cocktails. Just don't go too often. I don't like crowds.
author: Kelly D.

description:
This is the kinda place I've been seeking for quite some time.  Streamlined--just a focus on meat, cheese, and wine.  Of course, there are other selections, but this is what makes Uva special.
We checked this place out the other night.  Upon arrival, it was pretty packed.  We were told only a few minutes for a table, but it ended up being quite a while.  However, they have a little spot where you can order drinks, so we congregated there and, aside from my growling belly, it wasn't too bad.  
When we finally sat down, we weren't messing around.  We ordered the Molto platter of meats, which has 10 options and was incredible.  The lardo, soppresata, and prosciutto were my favorites.  We also ordered 5 cheeses.  Now, if you know me or have read my reviews, you know my world revolves around cheese--literally.  They have some great options here, but I was soooooooo disappointed when the cheese plate arrived only because the pieces were so small and thinly cut that they were just about enough for one person to get a good, full bite.  Too bad there were 4 of us.  I was really sad that, after sharing each piece among us, I felt like I barely got a fair sense of the cheese's flavor.  And, for $19, I expected more.  If the portions were adequate, they would have earned 5 stars from me.  Actually, if I could have given 3.5 stars, that would be more accurate...that's right, this cheese offense earned a 1.5 star loss--but I can't do that, so I'll round up.
But, that was the only complaint.  The bathroom was clean and smelled good, the service was friendly and attentive, and the atmosphere is warm and welcoming.  I will be back, but I'd better get more cheese.
author: Jessica L.

description:
If you want to run with the big boys, you better deliver on all levels.

So this place comes with a fine pedigree- the co-owner worked at Mario Batali's Otto in NYC, a fact that our server was oh-so-happy to drop on me and my girlfriend Mary.  She also said that the chef had worked with Mr. Iron Chef, though I'm not sure she had her facts straight.  Either way, she set our expectations very high- we expected a culinary mind-melter.

The sommelier came around table by table, which was a nice touch.  We were pleased with the Italian wines and he helped us pick a truly lovely Marzemino.  We felt that it was a good value and that it really did compliment the cutting-board fare with which we stared our meal.  We ordered two salumis- a wild boar salami and a very fatty coppa- as well as a trifecta of cheeses (parmigiano, moliterino, and robiola tre latte).  We also ordered the tuna crudo for good measure because Mary loves raw tuna- and she was not disappointed with the extremely fresh fish swimming in very high quality olive oil.  However, I have to say, right off the bat, it took an excruciatingly long time for them to bring these simple items.  As I eventually asked, "How long does it take to slice meat a cut cheese."  We waited for a good 20 minutes- perhaps a ploy to encourage faster wine consumption?  Regardless, the food DID arrive eventually, and was for the most part underwhelming.  The wild boar was excellent, rich with red wine flavors and very fatty, but the coppa was disappointing, missing the salty/fatty explosion that I love so much.  The cheeses were nice, and the 3 'dressings' that are lovingly brought to each table do bring a nice complexity- particularly the pear and black pepper compote, yum.  However, the parmigiano was merely pedestrian and the ribiola tre latte was foul.  It tasted like goat (good) and shellfish (bad), and did not pair well with our wine at all, emphasizing a metallic bitterness that had not been present before.  I would take the blame for this poor pairing, but for the fact that our server specifically recommended this cheese after the one we ordered was unavailable for the evening.

Obviously, I started the meal extremely underwhelmed.  Luckily, we pressed on and ordered some more substantive fare- with greater success.  We got a Tramezzini, made with semolina, playfully rolled into a mock sushi-roll and filled with shrimp, avocado, pancetta.  The dish, while disappointingly small, was very tasty and well-balanced- although they were a little heavy-handed with the mayo (which was not house-made).  We also ordered an extremely delicious green garlic pizza with a perfectly crispy crust and a nice balance between cheese and delicious tomato flavor.  Although we're not big pizza eaters, Mary and I agreed that this simple, well-balanced pizza was the best plate of food in the entire evening.

Dessert is wisely out-sourced to Berkeley's artisan Almare Gelato.  We got a hazelnut gelato dish spotted with crumbled biscotti and peeled, pan-fried almonds.  Dessert was very, very satisfying and we regretted that we chose to share one because it was so delicious.

Overall I was extremely disappointed.  I think there is great potential here, but that they fail to deliver on many, many levels.  If they want to be just a "Wine Bar," as they imply, they should scale back on the food and focus on quality.  The wine was excellent, and I would go back but only to sit at the bar and drink wine.  I think it can succeed as a wine bar, but has already failed as an Italian restaurant.  I think they're sitting back on their Batali pedigree and failing to deliver what I think is reasonable to expect- consistent quality in every dish.
author: Jeff M.

description: So much fun!  We like to go here with a big group because it's fun to order lots of dishes and share.  They have a variety of meats and cheeses, some even made in house that are great to pass around the table.  As the restaurant name suggests, they offer a great selection of wines.  The biggest surprise was how delicious the vanilla gelato with olive oil and sea salt was!  So yummy!
author: Ben R.

description: A delight. What a wonderful atmosphere complimented with a fine collection of wine. The lambrusco reggiano  is wonderful and I am so happy that my friend brought me to this place. It's my current favorite place. The food was delicious.
author: Matthew S.

description:
In our quest to find the best charcuterie/salumi in town we decided to try Uva Enoteca.

Made reservations for 7, table was ready when we got there. Service was very good. Our waiter suggested a great Lambrusco to go with our salumi. The portions were lager than we expected, nice surprise. The prosciutto cotto with truffles was the high point. The pate was disappointing. We had 3 very good cheeses, can't remember what we had. We also ordered a pizza. The crust was a little on the soggy side, but still good. 

Not sure if I would go back. Bar Bambino was a better over all experience and closer to home.  Uva is definitely worth a try!
author: Anthony N.

description: I am changing this review for Uva because after having a bad experience here, the manager contacted me, apologized for what had happened and graciously offered my boyfriend and I a complimentary dinner.  The food, as always, was delicious.  The waiter was very friendly and apologetic about the slow service as there was an impromptu wedding party that came and filled up the place (he made sure to fill up my Prosecco so I wouldn't have to wait to get another drink!) and the ambiance was charming and warm (they play good music in there!).  I was a little dissapointed to see the dude behind the bar that had been so rude to us before but, I assume he got a talking to and hopefully got his shit together and will start treating the customers with a little more courtesy.  I definitely think we will come back as it's right in the neighborhood we like to hang out in and the food is really good. Thanks, Boris, for your devotion to your business and the lovely meal.  We enjoyed it immensely!
author: Chloe B.

description: Oh god, at some point tiny portions become just ridiculously expensive! Guys you sell food, not art...
author: Mimil H.

description: Service was amazing. Very relaxing. Great for foodies. A nice break from the standard Italian fare. Highly recommended.
author: John B.

description:
Nice design, lovely place to meet up with friends for a glass of wine. As far as the food for dinner, it was far less than stellar. As an enoteca, they have a ton of pork & beef on the menu. Great for meat eaters, not great for me ( I don't eat red meat or pork :).  Our waitress showed me a few vegetarian sandwiches and salads on the menu, but I was really hoping for the summer squash pizza. Unfortch she told me they were out of the squash, so I got an asparagus +  prosciutto pizza minus the prosciutto. I probably shouldn't be admitting to that...but thems the brakes when you're a picky eater!
Still even without meat, this pizza could be vibrant and delicious. Instead the sauce fell flat and the only spice I tasted was huge chunks of black pepper.  No basil, no oregano, nothing. just pepper.
A real bummer was when the host (who I believe may be the owner) filled up our glasses (of purchased Italian still water) with tap water. awww man.
author: Nicole L.

description: Best wine bar in the hood! And by hood I mean all of SF. Thanks Boris for makin almost everyday just a little bit better. Tip, order the ragu!
author: David M.

description: Wow, this little Italian restaurant is amazing. All of the ingredients were fresh and they had interesting food combinations. A lot of the pasta and pizza dishes had wild game or choice Italian cold cuts. My friend and I started off with a bottle of Terre Di Orazio 2007 and it was a mild red, with good acidic notes. It paired with our entrees and since it was raining cats and dogs outside, we decided to go with comfort food. I got the lamb, mozzarella, peppers pizza. The lamb was in little chunks and the cheese was creamy. The crust was crisp and thin. I also tried the ragu pasta with wild boar, tomato, parmigiano, and onions. The pasta was by far one of the best pasta dishes I have ever had. The pasta was little gonococci and was fresh and cooked perfectly. If I go back, the ragu is the only way to go. We both finished out meal with Affogato, which is fresh espresso poured over vanilla gelato. Its a small dish, so not good for sharing, but a perfect way to end an amazing meal.
author: Brigid T.

description:
3.5 Stars

was in the neighborhood and was looking for a night cap. the atmosphere was amazing... from the well decorated walls to the romantic lighting. noise volume was manageable. this would be a perfect date spot.

We sat at the bar I order the miele frizzante which was carefully crafted cocktail that I really enjoyed. Also ordered the apple cake w/ gelato which was not so memorable.
author: Phong D.

description:
I JOINED YELP TO TELL YOU THAT UVA HAS BRUNCH.

Of the several good restaurants that have opened near me this year (i.e. L'Ardoise, Poesia) Uva is the most exciting. It combines great food & wine with a casual elegance that is a welcome addition to the Lower Haight.

I have enjoyed dinner there several times, and today was the premier of Uva's brunch. It was fantastic. We had a fruit plate with burrata, French toast with cherries & star fruit, and fridos. A frido is like an omelette, but made with cheese instead of eggs. After trying the frido with speck, we had to try the one with potatoes too. Both were good, but the speck was my favorite. 

I highly recommend trying brunch, it will inevitably get crowded.
author: Kevin H.

description: Good local spot. the food is ok to good. The space is nice. these guys come from Otto in NYC, which is a much better joint. Nothing is bad at all, but nothing stands out. I never really itch to go back. The pizzas are small and thin. Glad to have them around the block, but would not travel here.
author: Sir M.

description: Great place, great wine and the owners are super knowledgeable and chill. I love their wine selection and recommendations. They also have a good coffee program but their execution fell short, or their coffee fell short (unsure who the culprit was). It has a clean, realxd atmosphere which is why I love that it is on Lower Haight street. It's like a little treasure in that dirty but awesome hood.
author: Gabe B.

description:
so-so.  Arrived and it was slow and the waitress tried to seat us right smack in front of the bathroom door which opens right into the small dining area.  We asked to move to one of the dozen open tables further away and all was fine.  What was funny was that she tried to sit three other couples there and they wouldnt have it either!

I had the summer special prix fix meal.  it started with an asparagus strawberry and cheese salad that had precious little asparagus in it and soggy strawberries.  The next entree was much better -- a creamy fregola.  The wine paring with the salad was nice, but the wine with the dessert and fregola were both weak -- they didnt go.

The service was okay, the ambiance was fair, but this place could be a lot better.  It was a $70 Bloomspot coupon that I wish I never bought because $70 was way too much for what we got.
author: ellen r.

description:
I went to Uva Enoteca for dinner with a friend recently and was really looking forward to it and expecting good things from all the good reviews on here.  The place was nice and warm and inviting.  A cozy little place.  The wine list is a little difficult to understand, so the waiter was needed and made a good recommendation.  The food was good and I would like to give this place 4 stars but half way through our dinner it was as if the waiter was ready for us to leave and get another table.  He came and took our nuts and appetizers that weren't gone yet.  Then we saw him giving all the tables around us bread from a bread basket, but ignored us each time.  I thought well maybe they asked for bread, but no, they were just getting bread.  So we paid our tab, still tipped him the 20%, while gritting our teeth, but I've been a waitress and understand you work on tips.  Still, it wasn't deserved.  So I'd say, for sure try this place and if you want bread, ASK FOR IT.

Oh and the goat cheese pizza is deliciious!
author: Meg G.

description:
Started with the charcuterie- boar salami, heart of prosciutto and a spicy salami- the boar was too dry for me and the prosciutto was cut thick like jerky- no good.  The cheese selections we had were Parmesan, goat cheese and goat, cow, sheep blend (the best of the three)- we had an arugula,potato, quince and Gorgonzola salad- it was OK.  By this time we were ready to bail on dinner but decided to stick it out and see if things would improve.  We ordered a pizza based on fact the waiter told us how good they were- thin and crispy. I do not know what happened, but we were delivered something that was NOT thin or crispy.  It had the texture of a store bought frozen $5.99 special- and they an extreme amount of black pepper on a cheese pizza. The kitchen was right behind our table so I decided to peek in- no wonder the pizza was bad- it looked like they were using an ez bake oven to cook the damn things! 

Genuine disappointment to the point of no second chance- I just called Italy- they are pissed!
author: Scott W.

description: Cute inside decor. Went with 3 friends and split some of the small plates. The waitress recommended what to get (mainly because we could barely read the menu) and her choices were good. The meal would have been a bit better if we had more bread, but at the end of the night the panninis and pizza left us all full and happy. If you go with a group I definitely recommend ordering a LOT as the meat and cheeses were minimal.
author: Kristin M.

description: I've heard about Uva Enoteca for awhile but rarely make it to Haight for dinner since the parking is usually a nightmare. This place makes the trip well worth it and I'm so glad I finally experienced this little gem. It's a great place to share plates with friends and I loved everything from our wonderfully gracious and attentive server, Leah, to plate after plate of starters, sides and entrees. The pizzas were a huge hit as were the salads and the side of lentils.  They are accepting the CozmoDeck $15 discount cards through the end of the year, so if you still have your deck, make sure to take advantage of the savings and this awesome little restaurant soon.
author: Cher E.

description: This place is a new find for me since I never venture down the Haight area.  I came here with 2 other friends for drinks and to catch up on life.  I didn't get to try much of their plates but we did have a cheese flight and some brussel sprouts.  Yes I said it brussel sprouts....one of my better experiences here.  I never really liked those little green things but it was pretty good here.  We each ordered a glass of wine too...which was not bad.  Overall this seems like a great date place or just an evening out with some friends....I definitely will be back to try the other things here.
author: Allison T.

description: Didn't really blow me away. Charcuterie plate was just alright. There are other places for you to savour your cured meats fix. Do start ur dinner with the refreshing UVA spritz. I did enjoy the bucatini and they have an extensive wine selection. Staff was knowledgeable and great service on the whole but. Why are they so stingy with the bread?
author: Topazskye L.

description:
came here for early evening wine and snacks and wished I was staying for dinner.  great space.  the sandwich I had was great.  service was good, but typically san francisco in that they were a tad casual in appearance.  seemed like a popular date place.

why do restaurants in SF insist on having their lights on so bright?  

i will definitely return.
author: Christian H.

description:
The service was great, the owner was our server.  Seat in the back of the restaurant, it's much nicer with the exposed bricks.

Visit the restroom, the water facet is like an aqueduct.

The food was OK, nothing special.  We had the orecchiette with boar with was good and the orecchiette with olives which was not that great.

The atmosphere is very nice, soft lighting, you can hear what your dining partner says but the food was not great.
author: Sailing A.

description: Loved the crudos (Fatted Calf and Boccalone) and the cheeses. The honey truffle condiment paired with the blue cheese was heart stopping good. Can't get better than ending it with salt sprinkled vanilla bean and hazelnut gelato.
author: Katie K.

description:
Uva has raised the bar for afficianados of Italian salumi, viniculture, and yeah, formaggio. Oh and panini and pane. The creative vision of founder Boris N permates every detail of this establishment -- I have not seen a more handsome establishment in quite some time. Right down to the cutlery and the quartino bottles (yes, the Italian quartino, cousin of the French pichet, is the civilized way to drink wine).  
When I first visited Mario B and Joe B's Lupa back in the Vilage, I swooned when they brought out their proscuitto on a wood cutting board.  So imagine my delight when our really excellent server brought out three different salumi on a wooden cutting board, oh and also three insanely great cheeses on their cutting board, along with the pots of confiture to take with the cheese. Get the idea?  This is the real deal, Boris worked for Mario Batali and short of spending the $$ and time to go to NYC, just go here.  I agree with the comments that this is a great way to spend a few hours drinking great wine, nibbling on wonderful food, and watching the parade of dreams (some operative and some shattered) that is Haight Street on its way. Welcome Uva, we are blessed.
author: Mark P.

description: Intimidating menu. Wonderful service. Great wine. Panini and assorted meats = penis movement (that's a good thing).
author: Boyd W.

description:
Absolutely amazing!  I actually have been here now 2 nights in a row.  The first was with my boyfriend when we decided to have a nice late night nibble and some good wine.  We started with the Rosato...delicious! And munched on an assortment of meats and side dish of cheese and salad. A perfect evening.  The next night I was with a group of friends and we were trying to decide on a wine bar to go to.  
I immediately reccomended Uva as I had sucha good time the night before.  We got to the place around 9:15pm and had to wait about 20 min. since we were a party of 5, but the staff was great in making us feel comftorable and attended to.  We orderded the Rosato again! and a Pinot Bianco...both reccommended to us and they were fantastic.  When we finally sat down we had the 5 choice cheese assortment, and it was very good!  The truffle honey was out of this world!  At the end of the night every one of my friends was raving about the place saying they would be back......and I most certainly will be as well!
author: Yael G.
