description: I'm extremely impressed with this place.  The wine list is huge and their servings are a decent size given the price - 9 ounces/serving I believe?  Whatever it is, it works.  The design of the place is well done - brick walls, warm, inviting.  Food choices were awesome and I could have ordered everything off their menu.  Mmmm, burrata.  Service was perfect - such a sweet and patient waitress.  Nice touch with the owner swinging by our table to check in.  Can't wait to go back and enjoy it again.
author: Piper B.

description:
so i realize for openings i am supposed to really really like a place. you know.. free wine, free food, cool people "in the know" etc etc. and i have some peer pressure knowing that tasha r. and tom l. really liked it. 

 but i didn't.

i mean sure it was alright. but just a little bland. bland walls, bland food,.. but here i go talking about a place before it really has gotten its start. sh*t, I don't even know where the tables are going to go. but taster food should be fine representatives of what is to come. right??!


so how about if i place 3 stars for a positive start and some optimism. i am definitely stoked about what camber has planned. and taking in the uva experience. new haight bar with some old world feel? absolutely. 
here's to hoping.
author: Jeremi M.

description: The service and food was great!  I would recommend the cheese plates with the truffle honey dip.The bottle of LaCrima wine was amazing and I would make the trip over for the gelato alone.
author: marnie m.

description: Have been trice in the past months. Thats saying alot for a serious low budget nosher. Service is consistently informed and attentive. Ahh, the joys of wine sipping (2oz pours) and a committment to a full glass or a bottle.  Will continue to return till something fails misserably.
author: One P.

description: This is a fabulous new find in the Haight.   I love wine, but don't know a lot about the various varieties, so I love that they let you have tastes of all the wines.  The tastes are almost as big as a regular glass, for half the price, so you definitely get your money's worth!  The menu doesn't have many vegetarian options, which puts it a little lower on my list, but I still managed to eat and enjoy my dinner!
author: Amanda L.

description: Great place.  Excellent bread and salumi.  Good pastas.  I am also always a fan of being able to buy a short glass of wine.  Best part about this place is their value.  It is a good, reasonably priced meal.  The only reason I knocked off a star is because i would have liked to see a bit more in terms of larger entree-ish menu items.  Go there - it's good.
author: Ellen R.

description: My initial response to the opening of a frou frou wine bar on lower Haight was less than enthusiastic. However, stopping in with my best girl on a wine neccessity afternoon my entire opinion is forever changed. The place is nice, SOMA style with exposed brick and a cozy bar...with additional tables for groups of 2-4. Best of all they have Happy Hour from 5-7pm where you get a REALLY generous glass of the daily special for $4 plus a lovely menu of delights for $4 each. Easy on the wallet and a great early evening spot.
author: Colleen B.

description: Great food, wine selection, and service.  I had a LivingSocial offer and we shared the salame pizza and wild boar ragu and both were delicious and at a fair price.  Beware of limited parking in the area!
author: Debra A.

description:
god, i love being able to walk to places in this city.  used to live in LA where my options were to walk to the scary electric plant (.6 miles away) or my grody "neighborhood" 7-11 (.8 miles away).  now i get all the joys of the lower haight right at my finger tips. and uva is the one of the best of them all.

double-dated at uva this weekend, to break in the new 'hood.  we had a super lovely bottle of sangiovese for only $30 bucks.  score!  shared several plates - the wild boar ragu, fatted calf salami, and heirloom tomato salad really stood out.  the desserts were the bomb - the hazelnut gelato was my fave.

our server, allison, was classy yet spunky - very knowledgeable but not pretentious.  service was PRIMO.

 i love my new neighborhood and i love my new neighborhood wine bar!!!
author: Julia J.

description:
Love this place... Great selection of truly Italian meats and cheeses.  Excellent pizzas and sides with a fantastic wine selection.
Can't wait to go back and chat with the ever so charming and handsome owner Boris.  He took such good care of us!
:-)
author: wow j.

description:
Potential. 
Is it a negative or positive thing? 
Similar to, Hey you almost made it...but eh you kind of fell short there buddy....
Uva Enoteca is an Italian restaurant, thereby I entered. 
I love Italy, I love their food, I love their warm, welcoming, in your face culture, I even love their cars. 
However. this place only has potential to be the Italian I want and need. Yes, they give this Italian menu with all these great Italian wines, and these little antipastes, and apertivos. and then the service shoves it all in your face with, 
"Don't you want that $100 bottle of wine, not the $30?"  
"Aren't you getting sparkling mineral water or are you goin to order shhh, oh no, don't you say it... tap water?!!!" 
"Those plates are NOT big enough to share you better (BETTER) order two and bump up my tip mister!"
Does any of that sound like a relaxing and welcoming atmosphere to sip on some good Italian wine and cheeses while thinking of the mediterrean, and enjoying that slow, European lifestyle full of pisolino il pomeriggios? 
Not to me. 
Potentially Italian, that's all I'm saying
author: Daniella B.

description: I think the word OKAY sums up my description of UVA. The cheeses we sampled were okay. The honey that accompanies the cheeses is to die for, so I give them props for that. The pizza was okay; I've definitely had much better at numerous restaurants in the Bay Area. We ordered a good helping of the veggie antipasti and the Brussel Sprouts were bomb. Mushrooms okay, as well as the other stuff. Prosciutto was okay as well. Maybe it's my taste buds, but it wasn't much better than the stuff I bought from Costco. service was above average as well. All said, the place was OKAY...
author: Arick R.

description:
This one, I'd probably have to go there again sometime to maybe review my review.  As of now, I'm not convinced, at all.  And we're talking two blocks distance from my house, which would make it ideal if not, well, if not the first time there hadn't been such a let-down. 

I'd rather write positive reviews but what's got to be done has got to be done.  Let's see.  It was a weekday nite, me and one of my girlfriends went there to grab a bite and drinks.  It has a nice atmosphere but at the same time, it (as in the "background" music) was fairly noisy and we had a hard time carrying on a decent conversation without yelling at each other.  And even though we only ordered a few appetizers and wine, it was challenging to fit everything on the tiny table that was probably designed for having drinks ONLY.  One of the appetizers, the cheese plate, actually cracked me up as there was this huge wooden plate that came with three teeny-tiny pieces of cheese.  Hahaha!  Needless to say, I was not impressed.  And the overly "attentive" service annoyed me to no end as they were trying to clear our table way too early and way too often. Last but not least, the bill made me (!) speechless, as those few little appetizers and a couple of glasses of wine amounted to 75 bucks, for two people, ookeeeh...  So, I'm not sure if this place is the right fit for the Lower Haight.  It has potential but, like I said, I'd have to go there again to possibly convince myself.  But given all the other great choices in the hood, this is not likely to happen anytime in the near future...
author: Sabine W.

description: the grilled polenta is bomb.com! as are the lentils with croutons (an interesting yet delectable pairing), the beet salad, and the spicy pasta. this is the perfect place to come for a casual/reasonable/delish dinner. the crowd is unpretentious and the decor is welcoming. the happy hour drink specials are very worthwhile as well. def worth checking out in the lower haight.
author: Kelly N.

description:
I've spent a lot of time in Italy so I was looking forward to trying this trattoria last night. What a disappointment. The portions are laughably miniscule and would send my Italian brother in law into an apoplectic rage if he knew this place was passing for  an Italian enoteca. 
While the wine list is impressive, they don't know how to make a Bellini and the waitress had no idea about the wine nor could she answer our questions about the menu. To top it off the noise level made it impossible to chat. Molto falso!
author: Cathy N.

description:
the menu is in puro italiano and i couldn't read a damn thing. but hey, keeps things interesting!  i thought the list of cheeses was a list of meat entrees.

the best thing about Uva is that it's a spot where you would take a friend or a date and because of the atmostphere (and the wine) just end up staying for hours having great conversation.  i have high cholesterol so the beautiful meat and cheese platters i had were basically a big serving of heart attack, but that's my own damn fault.  they were very exciting looking, though.

and the staff are top notch! they went above and beyond to explain the menu, seat us quickly, make us comfortable...service was excellent. overall feel...i had a really nice night.
author: Hella M.

description: Went here for dinner with a friend.  Wine list was really fun.  The Lambrusco is really good and it was refreshing to be able to have something different.  We started with a Carne plate with 3 different meats, which was a meal in itself.  Really delicious.  I had the wild boar ragu.  Not so good.  Top of the ragu was burnt, which i understand is how they make it, but it just tasted, well, burnt.  Not like the burnt topping of mac and cheese, but like burnt pasta noodles.  And the boar was ground boar, I thought it would be like pulled pork like other boar ragu i've had.  The dish just never really came together.  If I came again, I'd try a pizza.  My friend's pasta didn't look that great either.
author: Ashley R.

description: yepp, one of my top 10's. great wine selection served in a wine glass and extras in carafe! bomb dinner menu too. my fav has always been the salume and cheese selection. might i add excellent service from a professional staff.
author: Melanie S.

description:
Maybe my partner and I were there on an off night, but this place sucked. Way too expensive for what we got.  Antipasti plate was terrible.  Pizza was like dumbed-down volare (across fillmore).  

And the staff were utterly unable to come up with a reasonable wine suggestion.  I asked for a red that had a peppery or spicy flavor, and was inexpensive. The server suggested a moderate to highly priced red that was not at all in keeping with my request -- very sweet.  

$90 for two people| app, two entrees, and a bottle.  We shoulda skipped out. 

A last note: the music was terribly inappropriate for an uppity joint like this.  Some shitty pounding supertramp or something.

I don't think it's terribly helpful to masquerade as a restaurant and expect people to recognize the etymological relationship between enoteca and "oenophile."
author: Srikanth S.

description:
Before you read on: I want everyone to know that I am not a fan of .. yelp.. but chose to open an account just so I could voice how dissapointed I was in this place. 

On the surface, this place looked perfect.  

I went the other night just looking for good appetizers and a nice bottle of wine.  The wine was great, thanks to the boyfriend who knows what he's doing - but the food was awful.  There was no taste/flavor and I spent most of the meal in search of salt.  Not to mention it took about 40 minutes to get our pizza and pasta.  This could have been the bartenders fault because she quickly approved any doubt I had in her....

I'm not big on servers that hover over you; so when wanting to have a casual meal, I opt for the bar.  Being mid week, it wasn't busy either.  So naturally we thought the bar would be perfect.  We sat down, ordered a bottle of wine, and the rest of our food.  The bartender littlerally poured us a taste of our wine without asking us how we liked it, put the bottle down, and walked away.  Then she proceeded to ignore us for the rest of the night while we poured our own wine and she talked to her friends at the other end.  My sympathy goes out to the rest of the staff that ran the whole show while the bartender flirted with every guy that sat down and didn't lift a finger.  

No good.
author: John S.

description: We had dinner here tonight with mom.  We were the first ones in but were soon joined by 2 other groups.  The place is quite cozy and inviting, it encourages relaxation, at least during the earlier evening hours.  We had 3 each of the meats (such generous portions!), cheeses (but why are the cheese portions so tiny??!) and vegetables.  The highlights of each for me are the specks (smooth texture, just the right amount of fattiness, not too salty) with the chicken pate a close second, the blue cheese (full of flavor, again not too salty) and the brussels sprouts.  We also ordered the potato pizza but by the time it arrived, we were already happily satiated, so we only tried it, with mixed opinions.  We also had 3 glasses of wine, one of which was for 2 oz. only, all were consumed without complaints :-)  But for a wine bar, they might be more convincing if they have more than the 7 or 8 wines by the glass for white or red to choose from.  In any case, the place definitely warrants another visit!
author: Yvette F.

description:
Because of the econ crisis I decided to do the Uva happy hour ($4 pizzas, panins, and wine) for my birthday.  
The server mentioned their special wine so boyfriend and I decided to have a glass.  The wine was decent enough that I would have paid full price for it but I was very excited to get it half off.
We ordered a pizza, panini and a salad.  When the bill came the pizza and panini were both listed as full price.  When I asked our server he informed me that the happy hour only pertained to the items on the special list.  I said that I had not seen the special list (I think they gave it to boyfriend who never passed it over.)  and that it was my birthday and the happy hour pricing was why I had come + it did not say anything about a specials list on the yelp announcement.  The server was extremely gracious and apologized for my confusion and changed the bill without me having to ask.  
Honestly I was not very impressed by the food (the salad and panini were a little bland and the pancetta on the asparagus & pancetta pizza was a little fatty and the chunks were too large) but I was very impressed with the fact that they were so nice and actually changed my bill that I am giving it 4 stars and would give this place another shot.   
I would like to mention that although I did not try the cheese or charcuterie I was very impressed with the offered selection.  And even if you don't go for happy hour the prices are fair.
author: Kaylee T.

description:
So, it's really great that there is a nice and somewhat innovative Italian wine bar and cafe in the lower Haight.  Really.  If you are looking for a spot to try out some Italian varietals and have a light, informal meal, this is a place you should definitely try.  If you are looking for a more traditional, 'stick to your ribs' kind of Italian dinner, you may be disappointed.  The menu is heavy on cured meat and cheese appetizers, panini, salads and small pizzas.  But everything I had was excellent, including the Pino Blanc.  The several glasses of Pinot Blanc, I might add.

So why only three stars?  Well, I was there on the Sunday of Labor Day weekend with my husband and 5-year old son.  The place was full, but no wait -- no wait to sit, that is.  First, we eat out a lot, often with the kid but not always.  The boy is definitely 5, but give him something to color and a plate of pasta and he is good to go almost anywhere.  We don't take him to Postrio type special-occasion places, but often to places every bit as nice as Uva.  He has been to numerous restaurants in the Castro and downtown, and we felt perfectly welcome and accomodated.  Uva is the first place I have taken him anywhere where I felt like the host looked at us like we were trying to bring a big wet dog into the restaurant.  And instead of sitting us at the available table for four near the door, he sat the THREE of us at a table for TWO in the back near the kitchen.  Remember the coloring comment above?  Try that at a tiny, crowded table with servers bustling by every 30 seconds.  Not that they were serving us, mind you.  We waited 15 minutes and then I asked the bartender to have a waiter take our order.  And then the food came slowly, we never got the bread that was supposed to come with our appetizer and the entres took forever.  My impression was that there was no owner or manager on site, just a number of hipsters waiting tables who needed to spend a week in a Denny's learning the trade.  One high point was the tall Latino guy busing the tables.  The ONLY person busing tables and he did it with alacrity and professionalism.  I would give him a raise and put him in charge of Uva's staff training program.

In short, nice place, good food, definitely mediocre service.  And save yourself a headache and don't bring children here.  Take them ANYWHERE else in the city.
author: Valerie W.

description: Eddie and I got a little hopped up at Molotov's and hit Uva for snacks. It was super mobbed on a Friday evening, but Patrick took care of us. Excellent charcuterie- esp. mortadella. Mmmmmmmmm.......fancy bologna.  Delicious wine, chatted w/ Boris about Otto in NYC, and when drunken Eddie left his phone on the table the nice busser guy chased us down to return it.  We'll be back, but maybe we won't drink Jack and Cokes out of pint glasses first next time.  MAYBE.
author: David M.

description: Welcome to the lower Haight.  now we have a nice Italian place too.  Just be for-warned that an enoteca wont have big portions.  Its also small so i gues just don't go there if you are really fat and hungry. hahahaha
author: California B.

description: Nice little place, though slightly bland on the decor (or like any other crib).  The plates were insanely small, but good.  Wine pours on the small end as well.  A bit disappointing overall, but might try it again.  It was that cheesy NYC Battali vibe to it, not what I had expected in the hood.
author: rerun w.

description: OE is in my hood so I thought to check it out.  Went with some friends and we hung out at the bar for maybe 3 hrs.  Lots of fun.  I didn't have any of the food but the wine was great and the staff very helpful in answering all of my questions.  Nonetheless, there's something about the vibe here that I didn't like and I can't put my finger on it, maybe it had to do with the lighting?  I wish I liked this wine bar more since it's w/in walking distance from my place but I can't say that I do.  Give this place a shot, I'll probably need to go again to see if my opinion changes.
author: Nene K.

description: Uva Enoteca was not crowded at all when I went for an early dinner on a Sunday evening.  I was trying to decide which kind of cured meat I wanted, but my lovely dining companion suggested we get the selection-of-delicious-meats plate.  Which is really the only sensible thing to do.  Two kinds of prosciutto, mortadella, bresaola, and salami, served on a long wooden slab for that rustic/elegant enoteca feeling.  The wine was great too.  A good addition to the neighborhood.
author: Rachel D.

description:
big points for the very nice wait staff, $26 bottle of rose, finger-lickin good truffle honey, and nice ambiance. places like uva are bringing the upscale vibe to the gritty lower haight, which i hopewill only enhance it's diversity. eiher that or its the beginning of gentrification. 

the food, which seems to be the theme in a lot of reviews, is not so impressive. we ordered 3 cheeses, which came with some pretty dry unimpressive bread. the cheeses were great tho and so were teh condiments that came with them, esp the black truffle honey. that was the best part of the visit. we also ordered a side of asparagus, which was $5 and came with exactly five asparagus spears. i felt that was kind of a rip-off. asparagus is not a delicacy kids. then we had the pizza with roasted green garlic. i think there were about 3 pieces of said garlic ont he thing and the crust tasted a bit like a tortilla. we couldn't figure that one out. 

the rose was really nice, and such a bargain. i would def come back to try more wines, but foodwise, they have some serious improving to do.
author: rachel p.

description: I really wish this had been open when I lived nearby. It's a great place to go with a small group of fellow foodies. (It's tapas style, so everyone must be into sharing.) We sampled a ton of stuff on the menu (cheese, meat, salad, asparagus, crudo, panini--you name it, we probably tried it) and everything was delicious. Add friendly service, great wine, and pretty reasonable prices, and you have a winner. I'll definitely be back next time I'm in town.
author: Leigh M.

description:
What a delightful evening!  Uva is my new happy place.  Sitting at the lovely marble bar, looking out toward the door, I felt like I could be in any one of my favorite cities: New York, Paris, my own SF, or maybe a magazine spread.  The simple white room with small tables, a little exposed brick, and a long inviting bar, is cozy and welcoming without being precious or contrived.  

I was there for happy hour, so didn't sample the regular menu, but what we tried was great, especially for the money!  $4, that's crazy!  I can't wait to return for the regular menu!  And then I'll add the 5th star, I'm sure.

Attentive service, good wine, nice food, great value.  Definitely going back!
author: Bonita H.

description:
This place was adorable.  Randomly walked in with friends on a Sunday afternoon when we spotted the Happy Hour sign out front.  Definitely a notch-up from the pub we had left in terms of presentation, but nothing so fancy you become self-conscious about the bag of Sunchips you've been carrying around after a picnic.  Anyway, the servers were sooo nice and didn't mind at all that we only ordered 2 rounds of 1.50 draft beers and no food or wine, and that really matters when you stop into a place like this.  The rest of the clientele (about 1/3 full on a Sunday at 6pm) was chicly dressed-- out for an early Sunday dinner or wine and apps. Hip but certainly not hipster: kind of a Hayes Valley vibe but less pretentious I guess.  It was, to use a juxtaposition of words, a modern quaint.

For the 1.50 HH draft selection they were only serving Peroni.  They had $4 glasses of wine and a few $4 appetizers (a thin sliced pizza slice was one of the options I remember).  Besides our small group, there were a few others there for drinks only , and the bar- which only seats about 10 people- was filed to capacity.
author: Reena R.

description: Finally got down here the other night to try it out.  I thought it was pretty solid.  I love meat and cheese plates served in that manner, so I was delighted.  We also tried the tuna crudo, a pizza, and one of the paninis.  There are a lot of wines for under $40 and even under $30 too which is great.  I thought the staff was welcoming, friendly, and knowledgeable as well.  And since I live a couple blocks away, I will definitely be back.
author: Katie M.

description: Good Place for Appetizers and Wine. You got to like cheese and meat, that's their specialty. Great wine list. Small, hard to find place on Haight Street. Worth going for apps.
author: Meredith A.

description: A wonderful Italian wine bar. The cheese selection (along with charcuterie) are of a SUPERIOR quality. The wine selection probably needs some attention. There are many unfamiliar Italian wines on the list that the wait service do not necessarily know or describe well. But the food, including pasta, are of a superior quality. Wonderful place to have a date or easy-going evening with friends.
author: Scott S.

description: I feel compelled to review this restaurant because I was so incredibly disappointed.  My husband and I have been here twice before over the last year and a half and each experience was fantastic.  Last night, however was terrible and I will never eat here again seeing as our food experience was just so poor.  We ordered the wild boar pasta; it was way over cooked with absolutely no flavor and dried, burnt pasta shells on top.  We also ordered the meatballs which tasted like rubber and were also terribly dry.  We were excited to share this place with friends who were here visiting and I was embarrassed that this was their last meal here in such a fabulous town, highlighted by other exceptional dining experiences throughout the week.  My friend ordered the pork loin and it also came dry and over cooked.  Terrible-blech!  Never ever again.
author: Lynette S.

description: not worth the money. very hipster vibe, i loved the exposed brick wall and light fixtures but the room was a bit noisy. thanks to a giant cutout, i could also see into the kitchen where a man with a bun and a huge beard was preparing my food - yikes. though luckily i didn't find any hairs, i was seriously disappointed with the pizza. the crust was alright (thin, as i like it) but there was just not much flavor - no herbs to be seen, the meatballs were way overcooked, and the cheese was clumpy. we had also ordered the boar bolognese, and while i was happy with the al dente fusili, i was a bit disappointed with the sauce. fyi, apparently authentic bolognese does not contain tomato sauce! i was unaware so the butter based sauce threw me at first. it was tasty, but just not what i was picturing when i ordered it. i'd say our favorite part of the meal was the cheese course we started with. a prettily arranged cheese board served with bread, fig jam, honey, and salted roasted almonds. luckily it was pretty filling, since afterwards we had to wait quite a while for the rest of the meal to come out (of course no apology but our server did eventually come say it would be out in just a minute...). two glasses of wine, three pieces of cheese, one dish of pasta, and one sm/med pizza = $80ish... i guess that's not that bad for eating out in the city and paying for the trendy atmosphere, but for the quality of the pizza and the long wait, i was glad i had a bloomspot deal or i would be peeved.
author: Holly M.

description: I really can't get enough of this restaurant. Any place where the menu is dominated by cheese and salami has me as a lifelong customer. Plus I love that you can get tastes of the wines - so nice to just get enough to see if you like the wine before buying a full glass. I'm also always impressed with the service - very attentive without being pushy.
author: Amber I.

description: I went to dinner with an authentic Italian workfriend who was in town from Manhattan. She did all the ordering. We ate meat, we ate cheese, we drank wine. Great times were had by all.
author: N S.

description:
i was surprised to find this place tucked into the sketchy part of haight.  the interior was comfy and cozy.  i didn't really know what to expect since they don't have any links to menus or photos on their web site...

as my hubby and i waiting for our friends at the bar, the bartender suggested a great wine for me (all i had to guide him was "i usually drink cabernet" - i conveniently left out that i am partial to Two Buck Chuck).  he chose a moderately priced glass. nice, not trying to up the bill.  also got breadsticks and olives as bar snacks.  we had no prob getting a table.

the "dinner menu" is pretty much small plates consisting of meats, cheeses, sandwiches and pizzas. don't get me wrong - i love all of those things - but i wished there was the option of ordering bigger plates. the cheeses were great and we loved the dipping sauces and sides they serve with them (honey with truffle infusion, bing cherries).

the menu was waaaaaay too confusing. it took our waitress 5 minutes just to explain it. and she seemed annoyed with us. she kept taking away our menus even though we told her several times we wanted to order more.  when we ordered our starters she grimaced and said "i have to admit. this is light."  we felt insulted!!  

the food was fantastic.  i would give the food 4 stars and the service 2, so i settled on 3.  pizza was good (asparagus and onion) although we added pepper flakes because the taste was a little bland.  the gnocchi with speck was absolutely amazing, so good.

all in all, a great place to sit at the bar and drink good wine with tasty small plates but i think they need to decide if they want a bar with really tasty wine and small plate snacks, or a full fledged restaurant.  if they want a restaurant, they should add some bigger plates to the menu.  if a bar, they should modify their tables to appear more loungy.
author: Christina K.

description: I'm a bit at loss for words; earlier today I submitted a review with a lower rating because of a mix-up that the management has quickly cleared up, so my complaint is no longerand that only leaves me with the good stuff: the knowledgable and attentive crew, the good wine list and short but spot-on (and yummy) food menu. Will be going again.
author: Jesse G.

description: Couldn't decided between 3 or 4 stars. The size of meats- good, cheese- too small, Wine is a good amount as well. The place is nice! BUT our waitress kept pushing us to order more food, she asked at least 5 times if we wanted to place another order. One of those times was right after we ordered some food and were still waiting for it...What do you think changed in 2 min? Nothing, we still don't know if it will be enough or not, so let us get the food first and then we'll decide!
author: Anna B.

description:
Hit. Hit. Miss. Hit. Miss. Miss. Miss. 1/2 Hit. Miss. Miss.

Walked in to this clean, quaint little spot - nice feel, better size than most wine bars. Seated in less than 5 minutes. Approachable menu, with lots of great sounding things - prices seemed great until the food started to come. Small...read this: S--M--A--L-- L portions, and prices not matched to scale. Okay tasting, but nothing crafted from passionate cooks (sufferable knife skills, and worse presentation).
Wine is nice enough, but we were directed to order glasses, as the tastes were purportedly "super small." Glass serving is decent - wine served in individual carafes, but we found overall the wine was very high in alcohol (so the minimal food could not keep up).
Dessert so-so. Crowd was initially calm and reserved, but mid-meal became loud and super reminiscent of dot-com bridge and tunnel crowd. No price or quality can overcome that, so we departed soon and wrote this one off for a future visit.
Too bad - the size and staff was friendly, but the rest got in the way of our evening.
author: Margaret K.

description: 2.5 Stars - This place really underwhelmed my senses. The pizza crust was very hard and I would definitely not recommend coming here on a hot day. My friends & I met up here on a hot summer day and yes, it's true - sitting by the kitchen on a hot summer day will probably cause you to go into a hot sweat until the cool glass of white wine tempers your fever. The cured meat board was good, but honestly I don't feel the necessity go to a restaurant to eat this stuff at a premium price, but I also didn't choose the dish. The pasta with the guanciale was probably our favorite dish. Very flavorful and good texture to the pasta. Service was OK. Generally speaking, with so many other competitors out there doing the same stuff, Uva Enoteca needs to step up their game a bit.
author: Jeannette L.

description: Excellent wine, food, and staff. Always a great experience when I drop in. A gem in the lower haight. Great for dates since they serve small portions and don't try to kick you off the table in hurry. I normally like eggplant but that is the only item in the menu I would not recommend. Be sure to try the olives even if you hate olives. I do, but these are really good.
author: Esso E.

description:
tried to book a birthday dinner reservation here once and they wouldn't do it. said they don't take reservations. 

"but last time i came you had no room"

"We still don't do reservations."

Fine.

Anyway finally made it there last night. Nice enough staff but when the staff first has to explain " how we do things here" you know you are in for a bit of bullshit.

you will like this place if you are a mouse. The menu is nearly illegible with so much stuff crammed on a flimsy sheet in 8pt font, way overwhelming and with the seminar from the waitress....

uninterested in a semester of UVA classes, we had her bring out her recommendation for starters. again she was NICE, but it was nothing but a bunch of hard cheeses and dry meats that you'd find in the fridge of your local europhile. half way through the over-labored table presentation. i was thinking:

"Maybe you could do all that back next to the fridge where you got all this, i like the concept of benihana and all but honey drips really slooooowly."

The condiments that took all day to present were quickfire challenge third placers at best.

oh yeah and their silly cocktail glasses have got to be the most  un-ergonomic design of all time. picture a wine glass with an opening just slightly bigger than a coke bottle. cute, it's a little tear drop, but who wants to have to tip their head back all the way to the sky to even get a sip. seriously you need to fall over backwards to get the last drop. DUMB. you can literally rest the glass on its side and not lose a drop. try it.

i suggest you take a trip to your local fancy deli and make your own cheese/meat/eensie weensie asparagus with mayo tray. nothing special here. 

it's all trying way too hard. it's silly.

and they don't accept american express.
author: merkley m.

description:
i will be a regular here for sure. the staff was really friendly and attentive and even humored our crazy friend by inquiring into what the umbrian salami was made of.  the wine list is interesting and they give you an 8 oz carafe at reasonable prices.  my favorite was the bellini though, which was made with fresh apple puree. 

the food was all delicious, especially the cheese platter (ahem TRUFFLE HONEY), and the panini.  the pizza smelled great but they unfortunately ran out before we were seated (it was like 9pm so I'm sure they'll work that out).  six of us ate and drank to our heart's content and the bill was shockingly low.

only gripes: the whole no-pizza thing, and the lack of ventilation - it got rather smoky in there.  

i'll be the redhead at the bar on a weekly basis.  come say hi.
author: Laura M.

description: Love this place.  The food rocks - simply delicious.  We had an excellent server and the ambience - lighting, music, decor was comfy and perfect.   Can't wait to go back so I can try some more dishes and have another one of my new favorite cocktails -  a miele frizzante.
author: Carolyn S.

description: What a great addition to the Lower Haight.  I met my guy there last night for a late dinner and I was very pleased to see that they serve food until 11pm and closes at midnight.  We sat at the bar and received great service and felt very comfortable. We enjoyed a very tasty pizza, a fresh and well seasoned arugula salad and a delicious prociutto and arugula paninni. We also enjoyed two glasses of crisp white wine, an 8oz pour served in a little carafe. I like the decor and the feel of the place, I felt the portions were just right and the prices very reasonable for the quality of the food. The menu is all in Italian (so brush up before you go) and full of meat and cheese dishes, yummy, so I would go somewhere else if I were dinning with vegetarians.
author: Sabrina L.

description: Nice element to our neighborhood. Feels a bit like Union Street. Will the Lower Haight someday compete with Union Street for fine dining and fancy shopping?
author: Katy D.

description: The place was lovely...I think the server plays an important role in one's experience here, though. I eat a lot of different foods, but it was very helpful when she explained what coppa was, and the difference between prosciutto and smoked prosciutto! The wines she suggested were wonderful too. The only negative were the veggies...as the other person who recently reviewed said, they were practically raw, and they were the type of veggies that do need a bit of cooking
author: annie s.

description:
i LOVE this place. i came here with 8 others and we were seated promptly in the back. the service was excellent and gave us spot-on recommendations in size, flavor, and without being too exorbitant. we ended up getting just the right amount of food, with the perfect and complimentary flavors and it was all extremely reasonably priced.
if you're unsure what to get (and there is a lot too choose from, most of which is in Italian) then just ask the server to choose. she won't steer you wrong. we got an assload of cheeses and meats and then the verdures came and we were even further blown away. seriously, *really* interesting flavors, but without being wacky.
and then the wines, oh man! they have really interesting choices, some grapes i had never even heard of, and they were all very sanely priced. 
and yes, of course, the desserts were phenomenal and they had my favorite, the affogato, with the gelato of the day which very fortuitously was my favorite, chocolate hazelnut. 
i left uva hours later super drunk, not just from the copious wine and bubbly, but also from the general zeal of having discovered a perfect wine bar with perfect execution.
author: Whitney A.

description: I came here on Saturday night and it wasn't too busy. My friend and I were promptly sat, and our server was very helpful with the wine list. She served me a great pour of exactly what I wanted. Afterwards, she made some suggestions on food, but once our food appeared she disappeared. I thought the prosciutto and caramelized onion pizza had no flavor, but I couldn't find our server, (or any other server), just to ask for some salt. I won't be back. Next time I'm going to Nopa.
author: Alexander J.

description: Kyla and I had a bottle of Cortese from Piemonte on a beautiful warm summer evening,  gnocchi wrapped in prosciutto, baby asparagus with pancetta, 3 kinds of cheese, love their truffle honey and marcona almonds.  Small plates are the best way to go, that way you can enjoy many different flavors and textures -- such a tactile experience.  Staff was extremely knowledgeable, helpful, and pleasant.  Felt like I was in Italy again, really enjoy being able to dine late in the city.
author: D L.

description: I stopped in on a rainy Saturday for a late lunch. Uva only does brunch on Saturdays and Sundays, and I've never been a big brunch guy. But the bar tender was very, genuinely personable without being a tip whore, and the food was good. I love the wine list and they have great selections by the glass. The prices were great, and I enjoyed a nice, casual lunch with some wine without leaving my right arm to pay for it. I'll go back, I want to try the pizza.
author: Frank P.

description: Amazing service, there is a wine director who can answer any questions. The location is perfect, it only has a few pretentious people littering the seats, which is refreshing since the food is very straight forward and delicious. I had a cheese and meat plate, some apps, wine, dessert, and more wine at the bar. There seem to be regulars who come in, its hip an young, I have been back a few times and always enjoy the experience.
author: allen s.

description:
Came here opening day, and the place was packed.  There was a long line for seating, or even bar seating.  Luckily I made reservations.  They only serve Italian wine (a bit more dry... but delicious).  I can't remember what type I ordered, but the head wine guy gave great recommendations, and samples till we found one that suited our palates.  You can order a larger pour for the wines you really like for a very reasonable price.

Food was great!  I highly suggest you order a cheese dish when you get there, it really compliments the drink.  I ordered a prosciutto panini, which was good, but the Pancetta, chicken, blu del moncenisio which my friend ordered was much better.  Serving sizes for the paninis were larger than expected from a wine bar.
author: Kevin K.

description: This is a fantastic addition to Lower Haight.  A classy little place, interesting people, cozy, great selection of wines and the sommelier knows his stuff.  I was here for my birthday with a few good friends and loved it.  Nickie's is nearby and a good place for an after dinner Belgian ale.
author: Hashem B.

description: Great pizza, tomato and heirloom salad and speck tasting.  Absolutely great.  Everything else was subpar,  and a bit pricey.  This place is worth a visit, though, for the 3 things I mentioned.  Can't say enough about the pizza and salad.
author: greg f.

description:
Mostly good, some not so good.

The good: varied selection of wine, and generous portions for single glasses. Service is attentive and helpful, and they can help you try new wines you may not have any knowledge about. Oddly, the best thing I had here was their Viognier. Their cheese selection is also quite good and as others have noted, the truffle honey is great.

The bleah: they say they have a plate of serrano ham which tastes and looks likes something they bought up the street at corner store. Prepackaged deli cuts are just as good. Which is unfortunate, as false anticipation for serrano ham can be devastating.
author: EZ R.

description: Can't say enough about Uva -- from start to finish, everything was superlative.  The owner himself took care of our table, and chose two wonderful wines for us, and made sure everything was perfect, without hovering.  If you go, do yourself a favor, make sure you order one of the pizzas, and save room for dessert.  Have something from each section of the menu, but be sure to hit those, without fail.  We ordered the radish and pear and romaine salad, which was perfect to share, and impeccably done; the carmelized onion pizza with prociutto -- oh my god, so good; the meatballs, which were heavy but delicious; and the chocolate budino, which was so delectable and sinful that we almost licked the cup clean; and the lavender and thyme panna cotta, which I thought might be too perfumey and herby, but it was subtle and light and utter perfection.  Decor is hip and understated, the energy is relaxed but efficient.  Really...loved every last aspect of it.  Will put it on my list of places to return to often.
author: Bumble B.

description: My husband and I really enjoyed eating here. We especially enjoyed the wine. The prices seem high for a glass of wine, but really, there was enough there for two glasses, so all was good. We got a cheese plate and then a pizza, which was a perfect amount of food for the two of us. We went home quite happy, although I could see how people might not have been excited as some of the other dinners were rather pricey.
author: Alison T.

description: I had a huge stomach ache after drinking a few glasses of wine with salami and cheese.  There was no bread or pasta on the menu to balance it out. This place is for San Franciscans who are willing to tolerate a stomach ache to prove they have personality!!
author: Nancy Y.

description:
Just simply the absolute best!  great for a glass....a bite....a date.... 
wonderful gracious service....lovely environment......
Gigantic Thumbs up!!!
author: SF C.

description: The food was fine and the wine list was reasonable.  Does necessarily not fit into the neighborhood but the area is changing.  It is nice to have an Italian restaurant near my home.
author: Michele W.

description: DELICIOUS! Can't wait to go back. I had the prosciutto and five cheeses as an appetizer; a bottle of wine (Montepulciano red - it was great); and one of their pizzas for an entree. The cheese and prosciutto were my favorite - by the time my pizza came along, I was already stuffed and daydreaming of the day I'd return for more appetizers! :) The pizza was good too; it's pretty big, so you could split it between two people if you're not terribly hungry, or if you have an appetizer beforehand. The wine list was huge and had things organized by the regions in Italy they came from - very cool. I highly recommend it.
author: Laura P.

description:
I got a deal on BloomSpot for Uva Enoteca. It was for a 3-course Prix Fixe Dinner and Wine Pairings for Two for $70. 
So I went there with my husband. The ambiance was nice, dimmed lighting works well for a romantic feel. But the music got way too loud towards 9.30-10PM. I couldn't hear my husband from across the table. 
The menue for the Prix Fixe dinner on that BloomSpot deal was very limited, just 2 choices for each course and the portions were kinda small too. Which actually wasn't a bad thing, we were full by the end of the dinner, and not stuffed. 
A couple dishes definitely stood out. The burrata and strawberries salad is delicious! I strongly recommend it!The meat and cheese plate was good, although I didn't care for the apple, it was a bit strange, mixed with some kind of herb... but my husband liked it. The carbonara I had was WAY too salty. And I like salty. But this is the kind of salty that sends your veins into shock... I tried to pick out the pasta and wipe off all the excess of the sauce. Which wasn't exactly my idea of how you eat your pasta. 
I really liked the wine pairings, the wines were spot on. I even asked for the names of 2 of them, and our waitress brought me a piece of paper with types of the wines written on it. I wanted to know the names of the wineries and the year as well, but couldn't get this info out of her... No clue why. She kept saying that I can just get any Moscato at Bevmo, and it'll be the same. And that's a strange answer coming from a person working at a wine bar.
Overall, we were pleased with the experience and might come back.
author: Svetlana D.

description:
This place is obviously still working out the kinks with the early crowds, but it's a great addition to the neighborhood and with a little patience you'll have a wonderful meal here. 

The food was excellent, particularly the meat and cheese plates and other antipasto. The wine selection was also solid, and we were well advised by both the bartender and the waitress. The staff in general seemed a tad overwhelmed on a Friday at 9 pm, but they were handling it fairly well and it didn't interfere with a great meal. (Also of note: the hostess actually skipped us in front of five or more parties after 45 minutes, saying that "you're the only ones who haven't yelled at me.")

As a gluten-intolerant person myself, I find it bizarre that one of the first reviewers here gave this place one star because "everything had bread on it, and as a person who is gluten intolerant, this was a major bummer." One, that's not remotely true: I could eat every antipasto, especially the meat and cheese which is their specialty and what we came for. Two, why would a gluten intolerant person go out for Italian meat and cheese place and expect to find extensive entrees to eat? Pasta: no. Pizza: no. Panini: no. (It's also funny that the review right after that one gives one star and complains that "there was no bread or pasta on the menu." Also completely untrue).
author: Evan R.

description:
fabulous.  the decor is calming, the servers are pleasant, the food is fantastic and the wine is superb.  we ended up with an $18 bottle of red that was awesome; wish someone would have recommended that from the get go.  

the food portions are small and delicate, which i appreciate.  if you're looking to grub, you should probably look elsewhere.  if you're looking for delicate deliciousness, you have found the right spot!  i will definitely be back.  oh, and ritual coffee is the name of the game for all you coffee lovers out there.
author: Luisa A.

description: this place is nice and shizznizzley. super neat concept (cool-beans italian tapas?) with friendly staff, wine picks from the owner, and just really tight food and wine. atmosphere is a little stark but whatev's. nice and classy, right up the street from me, yummy and different food, a chance to learn a little about italian wine, and a good place to bring out-of-towners as well as a place for me and my honey to canoodle over wine and cheese (as well as other innovative, really interesting food). thumbs up!
author: Cristabel L.

description: Went on a Friday night and there was a small line when we arrived. The waitress allowed us to hang out by the bar while the area cleared and although she told us there were 3 couples in front of us, after 10 minutes she came over and whispered she'd given up on the other couples so we'd be up next. After quickly seating us our server was very knowledgeable and recommended a couple wines-the joint carries only Italian wines so the common SF wino might have a little trouble. She recommended a $15 glass of white which seems a little high especially for a place with no actual kitchen but the waitress came over and filled a small carafe for us. Same deal with the red plus they have 2 beers on tap. We ordered a spicy cotto from petaluma and 3 cheeses all locally made. Cheese portions were smaller than I would have preferred but the richness of the food made up for the portions. The cotto was piled high when the platter arrived and combined really well with the cheeses that were rec commended. Although we didn't order dinner, the pastas and pizzas looked great despite they're all cooked in small ovens. Overall a great experience and good value when the tab arrived.
author: ben R.

description:
Remember that sesame street sketch that goes "One of these things is not like the other... ?" Well that's how I'd describe this little gem of a restaurant hidden in Lower Haight. 
Had an amazing meal here on Friday night. Started off by ordering a bottle of wine. I was there with a friend who lived in Italy for a few years, and she selected a wine from the northern region where she used to live. Unfortunately, they were sold out of that bottle, but our server asked a few questions to determine why we'd picked that one, and then recommended that we try a wine that they'd just gotten into stock that wasn't even on the menu yet, but that he felt was really solid. He said there was another selection on their menu from the same winery as this new wine but that it was about twice the price point, so we should try the new one. I appreciated that he wasn't trying to "up-sell" us, and the wine he suggested was nothing short of PHENOMENAL. Extra points for him. 
For dinner, we started with the brussel sprouts. They were prepared perfectly (not too bitter, perfect amount of oil, just fabulous). Then we decided to share a pasta dish and a pizza for the main course. We tried the Wild Boar Ragu and it was excellent. The four cheese pizza was also very good, a good size for two to split when one other main dish was ordered. Prices were all reasonable. 
The vibe is very young and hip and it seemed totally random in lower haight but that actually made me like it more. It was a little loud, but in a way that just made it feel like a fun Friday night out on the town (it's probably not an ideal spot for a quiet dinner date on a Friday night, though). 
Honestly, we both left vowing to add this place to our "rotation" of favorite dinner spots in the city. Would highly recommend it!
author: Leah K.

description: i finally made it to uva after months of wanting to go - well worth the wait!  i love their menu, with lots of delicious meat, cheese, veggies, pizza, pasta, etc.  we shared a meat plate, a salad, and 3 different veggies.  all were delicious!  i have heard great things about the pizza, but we weren't in a pizza mood that night... will just have to go back!  great wine list too!
author: Carolyn B.

description: As Yelp says of 2 stars: Meh. I've experienced better. If you know your Italians wine- save yourself the trouble and buy a well priced one and enjoy it. If this were in some small town it would get higher marks b/c there would be no competition. But in SF, just head a short jaunt over to CAV on Market and see what a wine bar should be. Last night two of us dined at UVA. The place was 1/2-3/4 full but the service was like it was over capacity. When we did get our waitress, she didn't know the first thing about wine (this is a wine bar, right?). She went to get "Bruno". That took another 20 mins. When he did show up- it was like he couldn't care. i know a bit about wine but when i go to a place like UVA, it's to have people who really know and care about wine share their excitement and finds. In that aspect- it felt like we showed up just after the bong had been tapped. As to the food- stick with the prepared items (cheeses, olives, etc), they were well selected. The 'kitchen' item were just ok to so-so.
author: Dan k.

description: I love Uva. Period.  I've been here several times and each time I remember why I liked it so much the last time.  The service is great, knowledgable waiters and bartenders fill you in on the wine and food, but not in a pretentious way like some other places can be.  They offer tasting pours of all of their wines by the glass, so it's fun to get to try 2 or 3 different wines for what you'd spend on a full glass of just one.  I love the lambrusco - cold, red and sparkling (trust me!!) and they also happen to have fantastic cocktails if you aren't in the mood for wine.  But my favorite part is the little nibbles that you get for free!  The olives are AMAZING, they literally melt in your mouth.  If you order food you also get a little sampling of marcona almonds, a housemade jam (i've had the quince paste - yum!) and truffled honey (which is pretty much heaven in a tiny dish). They've got a great selection of cheeses and meats too.
author: Erin L.

description: Cold plates are good.  Wine is good.   Pasta might as well come from a can.   Service was polite but neglectful.
author: al. L.

description: Love everything about this place except the noise level when it is full. Trendy Roma cuisine with mostly small plates, good wine list, and excellent, friendly service. The bartender even gave us an umbrella when it unexpectedly started pouring right when we were ready to leave. $4 small carafes of lovely Italian wines for happy hour. For some reason 80% of the clientele is female.
author: tess s.

description: uva, i am so happy you are in my neighborhood. i love my rosamunde and memphis minnie's too, but it's nice to have options. the service is very good and many SF restaurants could stand to take notes. the miele cocktail is amazing, just smelling the thing is wonderful. the only sadness is that it is a loud place, nothing soft on the walls to soak up the noise. maybe that's the way it's supposed to be but just a tad quieter please! other than that it's lovely, and it was kinda funny watching all the ladies in fancy heels and handbags strolling in. um, where did y'all come from?
author: rena t.

description: A great addition to the lower haight (the upper haight could use a decent italian place too).  This was put in the location of the old horshoe lounge and it's a nice hidden little spot.  Good layout for a quiet dinner.  I am a sucker for the red brick and wood feel, and the food is beretta-esque (simple italian but good).
author: Will C.

description: Potentially a fine addition to the wide range of eateries in the Lower Haight.  Once a few kinks are ironed out, this place MAY live up to the hype (all those Mario Batali graduates - as if this were a GOOD thing!).  At present, the service is spotty - very nervous and edgy servers who seem to have NO idea how to pour a glass of wine (in most wine-bars, they allow at least a brief GLANCE at the label).  Cheeses are excellent, in miniscule (perhaps 1/2 oz.) portions - no bread was offered, only pre-packaged airline-style breadsticks; but lovely condiments - honey (!), dried cherries and pear conserve - a nice complement to the salty cheeses. Small tables make it hard to have a selection of wines (the menu offers 2 oz "tastes") - three glasses plus the cheese board basically fills the table, making it hard to think about ordering more food.  Of course the bus-people are trained to whisk away half-empty glasses of wine and plates left unattended for more than a few seconds - this place is about rapid turnover, not fine dining.  A real disappointment.  Noise level rates a double-bomb (using the Chron's rating system).  Better food, better wine and actual service are readily available in the neighborhood (try Cafe du Soleil, just a block away).  But for pretentious atmospherics and that Pacific Heights attitude, it's hard to beat UVA (a friend tells me the name sounds like something gynecological).
author: Steve S.

description: good speck. pancetta and prosciutto cotto? ewww! mediocre pasta and over priced cheeses. nice show. crap service: taking my plate away before my date had finished: seating me before my date arrived and he had a reservation (Oh shure, i will look the lonely girl part, no problem); wasnt asked if I would like a drink for 15 minutes and then assumed I wanted the bill when I said notihing of the kind. meh.
author: Monica W.

description: Uva is great at what it does well, meats and wine. I've been a few times and I've once tried to eat an actual meal there. That time was not so good - food was OK but just not that interesting. On the other occasions I've simply sat at the bar with friends, nibbled from a big board of cured meats and cheeses, and sampled a lot of very good win. On those times it's been great. I've never encountered any problems with the staff and have always found the bar tenders to be very knowledgeable about the wines.
author: Dale C.

description: What a great find! Great ambiance, cuisine, wine list, and service.
author: Shannon R.

description: Heirloom Tomatos and Burrata Salad, Wine and bread = EXCELLENT MEAL. Oh and the Labrusca Prosecco is my favorite wine ever.
author: LJ S.

description: I was impressed.  First of all, make sure to make it to happy hour... you miss the dinner rush later in the evening and they have several $4 food items.  The food was very good... the pizza was amazing, the other finger foods good, the bruchetta amazing, the meats excellent.  The wild boar pasta was good, but when I return I will probably stick to other items as it just was outclassed by them.  More importantly, this is a great place for wine tasting.  There are roughly 16-18 wines that you can get 2oz pours of [almost all for under $4] so it is possible to try a wide range of wines.  One could also try one of  the many bottles they have but that seems to miss the point of a wine bar... trying lots of wines.  I liked all of the 7 wines I tried... so either I got really lucky or they have done an excellent job of selecting wines so that most/all of the tasting/glass options are quite good.  Best of all, two people can get full here while trying 7 wines for roughly $35/person with tax and tip.    I will be returning here often.
author: Alured P.

description: 4 stars for the happy hour!  There is a special happy hour menu that lists the items available for happy hour. When I went today they had beer for $1.50, one cortino (8 ounces, or 1/3 of a bottle) of red wine for $4 (regular price $8), a chicken gorgonzola panini for $4 (regular price $8), fried gnocchi for $4 (not on regular menu, as far as I could see) and a salame mozarrella pizza for $4. The pizza is the best deal because the regular price is around $13-$14; unfortunately, the pizza oven wasn't working tonight so pizza in general was unavailable. I definitely wouldn't hesitate to come back to the happy hour, and hopefully the pizza will be available next time. Service was just okay - a little surly and slow - but that's not really a big deal with food and liquor this cheap. I would not come here full price, however.
author: Rogue R.

description: loved it.  apparently, they only opened about 6 nights ago, which is why I hadn't really heard of it yet.  the food quality was really good - delicious.  there was a slight hiccup where we didn't get the drinks we ordered, but after we asked about our drinks, they were comped on the house.  great service for opening week, and better service than many other restaurants i've been to lately.  i will definitely go back, tell people to go there, and eat my way through the entire menu.
author: Julie B.

description: This is my new favorite restaurant. It has everything I need in life: wine and cheese. The service is fabulous. The restaurant is lovely and comfortable. A perfect place for an intimate dinner (and vegetarian friendly too!). And even though it is certainly a yuppified addition to the lower haight, the clientele is more lower haight-like than some of the other gentrifiers (which doesn't say THAT much).  Anyhoo, LOVED IT!
author: Mia M.

description: I wish I could give it 3 1/2 stars. The positives: the wine we had which, while on the pricey side, was excellent; the atmosphere - such a cute place for the Lower Haight; the cheese plate - decent portion sizes compared to some places and a good selection, priced reasonably; the art on the walls, which is very interesting & done by a local artist; friendly service (and owner, who stopped by to welcome us - what a nice touch!); now for the less than positive: $4 for a plate of 4 asparagus - really?? $1 per spear?!? I'd rather pay $8 and get a decent portion size!; the salads, which were relatively uninteresting; the small bowl of funghi misti, which didn't taste good (and also very small). All in all, a nice addition to the Lower Haight, but it seems some of the plates are hit or miss. I'd recommend sticking to things like the pizzas, paninis, and cheese. I'll definitely give it another try.
author: SL N.

description: Menu is confusing.  Pizza toppings are good but crust tastes like frozen pizza crust heated up.  Salad is basic.  Wine is great, but somehow my husband and I ended up paying almost $40 for what we thought was $4/per glass of wine.
author: Rebekah R.

description:
i was so excited to check out this place for lunch......i love a new lunch option.

their weekend hours listed on yelp and their websight say they are open during the day on sat and sunday.  i tried to call first to double check, but got the machine, which said all info is on their website.

headed to the lower haight (on a sunday), got to uva enoteca......and they were closed.  a man who worked there was outside and said they open at 5.  no sign or anything...

hmmm... am a little confused...
author: n. h.

description: What a great addition to the neighborhood!  Yahooo!  or Grazie mille!!  The staff was friendly and knowledgeable, the wine list interesting.  I would highly recommend it to anyone who would like to enjoy a delcious and different glass of wine and some very good cured meats and cheeses.
author: stephanie z.

description:
The service here is super friendly and the wine list is cool, lots of variety in price and varietal... and the 2 oz pour option is great for commitment phobes or those who want to grab a glass before work. 
We had a great rose lambrusco, perfect for hot afternoons, and tried some cheeses and meats. The meats are from boccalone, fatted calf, and fra' mani. Mmmm, especially the lardo and cured beef loin. The cheeses come with candied cherries and truffled honey, but the portions seemed small. 
The rest of the menu was a little meh. The tea sandwiches seemed out of character and the panini tasted like toasted tea sandwiches and both were just combos of the meat, cheese, and veg sections at the top, wrapped in squishy bread. They also make strange quesadilla looking things with more combos from the veg section on tortillas.
So come for the wine and snack on prosciutto and lardo. Oh, and the green olives they set out are great! Really lemony!
author: Sarah P.

description: Uva seems misplaced in the lower haight but, it works. Really tasty food and wine. The service is great.
author: Jeff B.

description: a bit noisy and a little too "self-congratulatory" on some of their offerings, but it is a place where foodies will gather. It's one of the few places that offers serious wine, cheese, and cured meats. All the options sparked enthusiastic responses not only from our table, but from others around us. That's always a good sign. The wine steward is though first-rate; he knows his wine far beyond the usual sommelier who memorizes tasting notes. He has a great grasp of the weight or heft of wine and how it pairs with all of the dining options. Surprising to see someone that confident, especially when questioned about lots of the nuances of the wines. I thought the pours were especially generous since you're drinking from the taster-sized goblet of Schott Zwiesel, i.e. they're big glasses. We were there for hours. At 6:30, it was pretty quiet; by 9pm, it was animated and crowded. By 11, it was absolutely cacophonous.
author: k J.
